description: The Lean Six Sigma Greenbelt Certification offers many options when it comes to getting certified. This series covers everything you need to know from beginning to end. Cherokee Boose introduces Dr. Terra Vanzant Stern to explain the process and project ideology in detail.
name: Lean Six Sigma - Green Belt
subtitle: Green Belt

episodes.description: The Lean Six Sigma Greenbelt Certification offers many options when it comes to getting certified. This series covers everything you need to know from beginning to end. Cherokee Boose introduces Dr. Terra Vanzant Stern to explain the process and project ideology in detail.
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.046 --> 00:00:05.279
[SOUND]
>> Welcome to your Lean Six Sigma,

2
00:00:05.279 --> 00:00:08.994
Green Belt Certification Preparation
series overview.

3
00:00:08.994 --> 00:00:10.467
I'm your show host.

4
00:00:10.467 --> 00:00:14.525
And we're briefly going to be describing
what this series is all about and

5
00:00:14.525 --> 00:00:17.440
what we'll be covering
throughout the series.

6
00:00:17.440 --> 00:00:20.806
With us to help me explain that,
is Dr Terra Vanzant-Stern.

7
00:00:20.806 --> 00:00:24.410
Thank you for joining us today doctor
>> Thank you for having me Cherokee.

8
00:00:24.410 --> 00:00:25.090
>> You're welcome.

9
00:00:25.090 --> 00:00:29.035
So, when I decide I wanna sit for
the Green Belt Certification,

10
00:00:29.035 --> 00:00:30.139
where do I begin?

11
00:00:30.139 --> 00:00:32.910
What are we gonna be
covering within this series?

12
00:00:32.910 --> 00:00:36.330
>> Okay, I think I would like to
begin by saying that my company,

13
00:00:36.330 --> 00:00:41.370
SSD Global Solutions, takes a leaner
approach to teaching Lean Six Sigma.

14
00:00:41.370 --> 00:00:43.910
In fact, we call it Leaner Six Sigma.

15
00:00:43.910 --> 00:00:49.900
So when you get done, you can still sit
for the Lean Six Sigma Green Belt exam.

16
00:00:49.900 --> 00:00:53.243
But we just teach the concepts in
a little bit easier way to understand.

17
00:00:53.243 --> 00:00:55.891
To prepare you for the test, and-
>> Well, I'm all for that.

18
00:00:55.891 --> 00:00:58.289
>> [LAUGH] And
the first thing we're gonna do,

19
00:00:58.289 --> 00:01:01.291
is we're just gonna talk
about what you need to know.

20
00:01:01.291 --> 00:01:05.406
And there's a little bit of confusion
because you can be Six Sigma certified or

21
00:01:05.406 --> 00:01:08.350
just Lean certified or
Lean Six Sigma certified.

22
00:01:08.350 --> 00:01:09.800
So we're gonna talk
a little bit about that.

23
00:01:09.800 --> 00:01:10.884
>> And you'll break it down for us.

24
00:01:10.884 --> 00:01:11.507
>> Exactly.

25
00:01:11.507 --> 00:01:13.750
>> Okay, great.
>> The different paths that you can go on.

26
00:01:13.750 --> 00:01:16.990
I shouldn't say little, cuz they all
require some studying, obviously.

27
00:01:16.990 --> 00:01:18.435
And then what we're gonna do,

28
00:01:18.435 --> 00:01:21.337
is we're going to use a method
called accelerated learning.

29
00:01:21.337 --> 00:01:24.470
And what that means is we're gonna
kind of take a top-down approach.

30
00:01:24.470 --> 00:01:28.377
So we're gonna give you sort of the idea
of what are the process improvement

31
00:01:28.377 --> 00:01:28.879
basics?

32
00:01:28.879 --> 00:01:32.695
What are the math and statistics basis?

33
00:01:32.695 --> 00:01:35.810
What are the actual models and
methodologies?

34
00:01:35.810 --> 00:01:40.050
Because we believe at SSD Global
Solutions, that a lot of times if we

35
00:01:40.050 --> 00:01:43.630
provide a framework,
you can fill in some of the blanks.

36
00:01:43.630 --> 00:01:46.810
Many of the things that you'll be learning
in this program, you've done before.

37
00:01:46.810 --> 00:01:48.730
You just call them different things.

38
00:01:48.730 --> 00:01:52.160
So some of the other topics is we're
gonna talk about critical to quality.

39
00:01:52.160 --> 00:01:55.120
We're gonna really concentrate
on the DMAIC model,

40
00:01:55.120 --> 00:01:58.700
the different phases of
this problem solving model.

41
00:01:58.700 --> 00:02:01.310
We're also gonna address
other problem solving models,

42
00:02:01.310 --> 00:02:04.670
such as typical problem solving and
scientific problem solving.

43
00:02:04.670 --> 00:02:08.650
And plan, do, check, act, which is
something you may have already studied

44
00:02:08.650 --> 00:02:10.790
in your project management program.

45
00:02:10.790 --> 00:02:11.830
>> Well that sounds amazing.

46
00:02:11.830 --> 00:02:16.220
I can't wait to get started, and I hope
you guys are excited just as much as I am.

47
00:02:16.220 --> 00:02:19.210
And I just wanna really say thank
you Dr Stern for being with us.

48
00:02:19.210 --> 00:02:21.720
And well, let's go ahead and get started.

49
00:02:21.720 --> 00:02:25.930
So we'll wrap up this particular intro and
sign off as your show host.

50
00:02:25.930 --> 00:02:27.240
I'm Cherokee Boose.

51
00:02:27.240 --> 00:02:29.887
I'm Dr Terra Vanzant-Stern
with SSD Global,

52
00:02:29.887 --> 00:02:32.011
hoping that you're going to go lean.

53
00:02:32.011 --> 00:02:34.851
>> We'll see you next
time here at ITProTV.

54
00:02:34.851 --> 00:02:38.449
[SOUND]

episodes.description: This episode introduces you to Dr. Terra Vanzant Stern from SSD Global Solutions and host Cherokee Boose. You will also learn of the different certifications available as well as sources for study resources.
episodes.title: Introduction
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.230 --> 00:00:01.170
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.170 --> 00:00:08.570
I'm your host, Don Pezet [CROSSTALK]
>> You're watching ITProTV.

3
00:00:08.570 --> 00:00:17.701
>> Welcome to your Lean Six Sigma Green
Belt Certification Preparation series.

4
00:00:17.701 --> 00:00:20.290
I'm show your host, Cherokee Boose.

5
00:00:20.290 --> 00:00:24.161
And, well, if you're looking for
study for Greenbelt certification,

6
00:00:24.161 --> 00:00:28.657
regardless where you take the exam, you're
definitely in the right place because we

7
00:00:28.657 --> 00:00:32.410
have a really great expert in house for
this specific series.

8
00:00:32.410 --> 00:00:33.430
Here name in Dr.

9
00:00:33.430 --> 00:00:37.110
Tera Vanzant Stern, and she came all
the way from Colorado to be with us.

10
00:00:37.110 --> 00:00:39.820
So we`re really excited about starting
this theory and thank you for

11
00:00:39.820 --> 00:00:41.010
joining us today doctor.

12
00:00:41.010 --> 00:00:42.770
>> Well, thank you, Cherokee.

13
00:00:42.770 --> 00:00:46.540
>> So, what we gonna be looking at for
the overview,

14
00:00:46.540 --> 00:00:50.038
or what do thy need to know before
getting started this wonderful journey?

15
00:00:50.038 --> 00:00:52.830
>> Well,
what I'd like to do is go to my slide deck

16
00:00:52.830 --> 00:00:56.390
because cuz I think the best thing is
just to say is what you need and why?

17
00:00:56.390 --> 00:00:56.890
>> Okay.

18
00:00:59.847 --> 00:01:02.398
And I'm gonna take a second
to introduce myself and

19
00:01:02.398 --> 00:01:04.771
tell you why you should
even wanna certify, and

20
00:01:04.771 --> 00:01:08.710
what types of certifications are
available, and then how the process works.

21
00:01:08.710 --> 00:01:09.890
That's how we'll finish up.

22
00:01:09.890 --> 00:01:11.150
>> Great.

23
00:01:11.150 --> 00:01:13.500
>> And this is just a brief bio.

24
00:01:13.500 --> 00:01:19.560
I'm Dr. Terra Vanzant Stern, I did
the IT Pro TV series for Yellow Belt.

25
00:01:19.560 --> 00:01:22.000
And the reason why that
might be important is that

26
00:01:23.060 --> 00:01:28.010
if there's a section that you want more
in-depth on, there'll be several times

27
00:01:28.010 --> 00:01:31.190
that we'll say that's covered
more in-depth on the Yellow Belt.

28
00:01:31.190 --> 00:01:35.250
>> So if they haven't already been working
in this field, then it would probably be

29
00:01:35.250 --> 00:01:39.040
a good idea to jump to that first so
they have that background knowledge?

30
00:01:39.040 --> 00:01:44.260
>> I think it's just individual
decision about if you see a topic and

31
00:01:44.260 --> 00:01:46.050
your familiar with it,
you can just keep going.

32
00:01:46.050 --> 00:01:47.700
>> Okay.
>> But if it's a topic that you're not

33
00:01:47.700 --> 00:01:53.180
familiar with, I'll try to remember to say
this is covered more fully on Yellow Belt.

34
00:01:53.180 --> 00:01:54.500
>> Sounds good
>> Does that sound fair?

35
00:01:54.500 --> 00:01:56.080
>> Yes.
>> Okay, great.

36
00:01:56.080 --> 00:02:01.367
Okay, so I did the ITProTV Lean
6 Sigma Yellow Belt, and

37
00:02:01.367 --> 00:02:08.000
that exam is available on
the SSDglobal.net page, SSDglobal.net.

38
00:02:08.000 --> 00:02:14.350
I also was
the ASQ Lean Enterprise Division Chair.

39
00:02:14.350 --> 00:02:17.310
And I'm currently
the ASQ Denver Education Chair.

40
00:02:17.310 --> 00:02:21.170
And you'll see why all this ASQ stuff
means something here in a second.

41
00:02:21.170 --> 00:02:23.960
I'm also the chair of
the Rocky Mountain Quality Conference,

42
00:02:23.960 --> 00:02:27.160
which is a virtual conference
that we do every year in March.

43
00:02:27.160 --> 00:02:29.090
And it's a completely virtual conference.

44
00:02:29.090 --> 00:02:32.700
The students sign in and
so do all the instructors.

45
00:02:32.700 --> 00:02:34.610
It's pretty exciting.

46
00:02:34.610 --> 00:02:40.790
And then, my credentials is that I'm a
certified quality engineer, a PMP, a GPHR.

47
00:02:40.790 --> 00:02:42.460
>> There's lots of acronyms there, yeah.

48
00:02:42.460 --> 00:02:44.240
>> HR, Six Sigma master black belt.

49
00:02:44.240 --> 00:02:48.590
The reason I'm telling you all that
is just so that you'll trust me.

50
00:02:48.590 --> 00:02:49.172
>> I do.
[LAUGH]

51
00:02:49.172 --> 00:02:49.697
>> Good.

52
00:02:49.697 --> 00:02:50.877
My latest books

53
00:02:50.877 --> 00:02:54.087
are the Lean Six Sigma
International Standards and

54
00:02:54.087 --> 00:02:58.760
Global Guidelines, which we draw a lot
of information from from this class.

55
00:02:58.760 --> 00:03:04.770
Another book, another newer book,
is Lean and Agile Project Management.

56
00:03:04.770 --> 00:03:07.620
>> And we will also be covering
that on a separate series,

57
00:03:07.620 --> 00:03:09.740
if you're interested as well.

58
00:03:09.740 --> 00:03:12.750
>> And I've got lots of white papers and
articles out there, but

59
00:03:12.750 --> 00:03:14.070
this is just my latest work.

60
00:03:15.850 --> 00:03:19.870
Now, if you're a student
taking the ITProTV class, and

61
00:03:19.870 --> 00:03:24.150
you decide to take the certification
through our organization, SSD Global,

62
00:03:24.150 --> 00:03:28.470
then there's also going to be an e-book
available called Leaner Six Sigma,

63
00:03:28.470 --> 00:03:30.310
because that's the product
that we promote.

64
00:03:30.310 --> 00:03:33.960
Now, your certification will
still say Lean Six Sigma,

65
00:03:33.960 --> 00:03:38.700
it's just that we have a leaner,
more concise easier approach to studying.

66
00:03:39.810 --> 00:03:43.060
So, Cherokee, what's the deal
with certification, anyway?

67
00:03:43.060 --> 00:03:45.310
Why certify in anything?

68
00:03:45.310 --> 00:03:49.780
And I think the answer to that question is
that it shows you have current knowledge.

69
00:03:49.780 --> 00:03:52.350
And especially if you're trying
to maybe cover up a little bit of

70
00:03:52.350 --> 00:03:56.220
an educational gap, or it's been a while
since you've been to school, showing that

71
00:03:56.220 --> 00:04:01.090
you're certified in anything tells the
employer that you have the basics down for

72
00:04:01.090 --> 00:04:03.040
whatever they're hiring you for.

73
00:04:03.040 --> 00:04:07.070
Many, many times, I have a large
background in executive HR, and

74
00:04:07.070 --> 00:04:09.810
many times it's the certification piece

75
00:04:09.810 --> 00:04:13.520
that's the differentiator between two
employees, one certified one's not.

76
00:04:13.520 --> 00:04:15.970
It's like well, I'm gonna go
with the one that's certified,

77
00:04:15.970 --> 00:04:17.830
because that's a safer bet.

78
00:04:17.830 --> 00:04:21.150
In the Lean Six Sigma
family of certifications,

79
00:04:21.150 --> 00:04:26.200
there's a number of certifications you can
get, and they are hierarchical in nature,

80
00:04:26.200 --> 00:04:29.440
and they follow a martial
art nomenclature.

81
00:04:29.440 --> 00:04:34.170
So you can be a Yellow belt, a Green belt,
a Black belt or a Master Black belt.

82
00:04:34.170 --> 00:04:36.280
Those are the certifications available.

83
00:04:36.280 --> 00:04:39.380
Some of you may have heard of
the term called White Belt.

84
00:04:39.380 --> 00:04:42.350
And that's really sort of just
an information orientation.

85
00:04:42.350 --> 00:04:45.980
And there's usually not a test or
anything that you have to take.

86
00:04:45.980 --> 00:04:47.945
It's just some basics.

87
00:04:47.945 --> 00:04:49.900
Sometimes White Belt's just a lunch and
learn.

88
00:04:50.920 --> 00:04:55.380
So, in the Yellow Belt program,
which we do offer through ITProTV,

89
00:04:55.380 --> 00:05:00.380
there is an exam on
the SSD Global Solutions site,

90
00:05:00.380 --> 00:05:03.580
and that's www.ssdglobal.net.

91
00:05:03.580 --> 00:05:06.270
It's at a discounted rate
from our other students.

92
00:05:06.270 --> 00:05:10.851
You have to have seen all
the Yellow Belt programs, and then there

93
00:05:10.851 --> 00:05:14.410
are a couple of other little requirements
that we give you a study book, and

94
00:05:14.410 --> 00:05:17.060
that type of thing, and
you can take that exam.

95
00:05:17.060 --> 00:05:21.860
The difference between Green and
Black belt is that the Green belt

96
00:05:21.860 --> 00:05:25.630
typically is focusing their
efforts on process improvement,

97
00:05:25.630 --> 00:05:29.090
which means making things better,
faster, more cost effective

98
00:05:29.090 --> 00:05:33.480
in their particular vocation or
the job that they want some day.

99
00:05:33.480 --> 00:05:36.936
So I'm gonna take everything that
I learn in Lean Six Sigma, and

100
00:05:36.936 --> 00:05:40.560
I'm gonna apply it specifically
to what I do during the day.

101
00:05:40.560 --> 00:05:44.080
Now, the cool thing about this is that, in
the Green Belt Program, many of the things

102
00:05:44.080 --> 00:05:47.370
that you apply to your job you can
also apply to your personal life.

103
00:05:47.370 --> 00:05:49.260
So, I think that's pretty cool.

104
00:05:49.260 --> 00:05:51.520
Now, the Black Belt, on the other hand,

105
00:05:51.520 --> 00:05:55.140
is saying I have a good enough
basic business knowledge.

106
00:05:55.140 --> 00:05:58.450
And that's typically a Masters
in Business Administration,

107
00:05:58.450 --> 00:06:01.970
MBA student, someone whose already
owned their own business and

108
00:06:01.970 --> 00:06:07.390
had to wear the customer service hat, and
the marketing hat, and the financial hat.

109
00:06:07.390 --> 00:06:11.120
Or, sometimes people in IT
who have had the opportunity

110
00:06:11.120 --> 00:06:14.848
to interface with enough
departments at a company.

111
00:06:14.848 --> 00:06:19.240
What I'm saying in this case as
a Black Belt, is that I could go into

112
00:06:19.240 --> 00:06:22.970
any department and help you be better,
faster, more cost effective.

113
00:06:22.970 --> 00:06:25.890
Now that's not to say that I have
the subject matter expertise in

114
00:06:25.890 --> 00:06:29.210
every department, but
that I could kind of get you started.

115
00:06:29.210 --> 00:06:34.530
And so a lot of times, IT professionals
will end up staying in IT, but

116
00:06:34.530 --> 00:06:39.190
the certification says you know what, I'm
comfortable with all aspects of business.

117
00:06:39.190 --> 00:06:42.820
And then there's the Master Black Belt
certification, and

118
00:06:42.820 --> 00:06:46.758
this is a very misunderstood,
I think, certification.

119
00:06:46.758 --> 00:06:49.490
Typically, Master Black Belts
go into companies and

120
00:06:49.490 --> 00:06:52.940
design internal Lean Six Sigma programs.

121
00:06:52.940 --> 00:06:57.490
They're teachers,
they're facilitators, they're coaches.

122
00:06:57.490 --> 00:07:00.790
What I think's kind of interesting
is a lot of people struggle with,

123
00:07:01.970 --> 00:07:05.830
a lot of teachers, for example,
struggle with the Black Belt curriculum.

124
00:07:05.830 --> 00:07:07.340
But then they get to Master Black Belt,

125
00:07:07.340 --> 00:07:10.620
and they're like, wow, this is just
all about teaching and facilitating.

126
00:07:10.620 --> 00:07:14.780
And then there's some people who are
quality engineers, and sometimes IT people

127
00:07:14.780 --> 00:07:18.200
that take the Black Belt program, and
then they go to the Master Black Belt

128
00:07:18.200 --> 00:07:20.920
program and they've never taught a class,
or put a class together, or

129
00:07:20.920 --> 00:07:23.610
put a program together and
that's what they find difficult.

130
00:07:23.610 --> 00:07:26.920
So it just depends on what it
is that you're wanting to do.

131
00:07:26.920 --> 00:07:30.720
Now, the certification world gets a little
confusing when you're talking about

132
00:07:30.720 --> 00:07:33.270
Lean Six Sigma, and
I'd like to explain that next.

133
00:07:33.270 --> 00:07:34.568
>> Good, I'm glad you're here to do so.

134
00:07:34.568 --> 00:07:35.880
[LAUGH]
>> Thank you.

135
00:07:35.880 --> 00:07:39.480
You can actually, these days,
certify separately.

136
00:07:39.480 --> 00:07:41.720
You can certify in Six Sigma.

137
00:07:41.720 --> 00:07:45.149
And back to that thing,
all the connections I have with ASQ,

138
00:07:45.149 --> 00:07:48.926
it is a volunteer job, however, so
I would like to point that out.

139
00:07:48.926 --> 00:07:53.228
But ASQ is probably the most
known group of people that

140
00:07:53.228 --> 00:07:56.201
administer the Six Sigma only test.

141
00:07:56.201 --> 00:08:00.860
You could also just take
the Lean only test, right?

142
00:08:00.860 --> 00:08:04.670
And the most known person, although in
both of these cases there are other

143
00:08:04.670 --> 00:08:07.760
vendors and other universities
that will offer this test but

144
00:08:07.760 --> 00:08:12.340
the most known person in Lean is
the society of mechanical engineers.

145
00:08:12.340 --> 00:08:17.120
So just so you know that you could
get certified in one or the other.

146
00:08:17.120 --> 00:08:21.040
Now, on the six sigma, and this is all six
sigma, whether you take it through ASQ or

147
00:08:21.040 --> 00:08:24.290
not, on the six sigma, certification,

148
00:08:24.290 --> 00:08:27.410
it still follows the same
marshal art nomenclature.

149
00:08:27.410 --> 00:08:31.270
You can be a yellow,
green,black or master black bell.

150
00:08:31.270 --> 00:08:34.535
You can sit for exams in those topics.

151
00:08:34.535 --> 00:08:40.200
On the lean side,
they do bronze, silver, gold.

152
00:08:40.200 --> 00:08:45.360
And right now with the lean exams, keeping
in mind that SME is the most popular place

153
00:08:45.360 --> 00:08:50.240
to take it, but there are other vendors
and other associations that offer it.

154
00:08:50.240 --> 00:08:54.985
However right now it is still fairly
hierarchical, where in ASQ and

155
00:08:54.985 --> 00:08:59.070
with our organization is
it possible to skip a step.

156
00:08:59.070 --> 00:09:01.910
The Lean organizations
pretty much to say you know

157
00:09:01.910 --> 00:09:04.494
you need to have that
>> [CROSSTALK] You must join this

158
00:09:04.494 --> 00:09:06.053
organization and have these prerequisites.

159
00:09:06.053 --> 00:09:08.537
>> Exactly thank you thank you.

160
00:09:08.537 --> 00:09:11.291
Now there are people that allow
you to certified together and

161
00:09:11.291 --> 00:09:13.130
frankly that's the trend.

162
00:09:13.130 --> 00:09:15.380
Certifying in Lean Six Sigma together.

163
00:09:15.380 --> 00:09:17.414
Certainly SSD Global Solutions.

164
00:09:17.414 --> 00:09:20.970
That's my company,
has a test that you can take.

165
00:09:20.970 --> 00:09:24.540
We do have some requirements
that I will explain at the end.

166
00:09:24.540 --> 00:09:28.230
But different vendors have different
requirements for sitting for that exam.

167

00:21:53.200 --> 00:21:56.220
But we also offer public
classes throughout the U.S.

393
00:21:56.220 --> 00:21:59.160
So if you're wanting to just
come to an actual class,

394
00:21:59.160 --> 00:22:01.870
just look at our website and
see if you're in that area.

395
00:22:01.870 --> 00:22:02.370
>> Pretty cool.

396
00:22:03.410 --> 00:22:07.660
>> And I think that's about all I have to
say about why you want tp be certified,

397
00:22:07.660 --> 00:22:09.790
and how to get certified and-
>> Well, thank you for

398
00:22:09.790 --> 00:22:11.670
taking the time to explain all of that.

399
00:22:11.670 --> 00:22:14.280
And I'm really excited to get
started with this series.

400
00:22:14.280 --> 00:22:15.990
I hope you guys are too.

401
00:22:15.990 --> 00:22:17.480
So we're out of time for this show.

402
00:22:17.480 --> 00:22:20.390
But we're going to go ahead and
begin with some really great content.

403
00:22:20.390 --> 00:22:21.700
So stay tuned.

404
00:22:21.700 --> 00:22:22.800
>> Get comfortable.

405
00:22:22.800 --> 00:22:24.260
We'll see you in the next episode.

406
00:22:24.260 --> 00:22:28.350
I am going to go ahead and
sign off as your show host Cherokee Boost.

407
00:22:28.350 --> 00:22:31.940
>> And I am Dr. Cherry Van Sanstern
with SSD Global Solutions.

408
00:22:31.940 --> 00:22:35.615
>> See you here, next time at IT PRO TV.

409
00:22:35.615 --> 00:22:41.525
[MUSIC]

410
00:22:41.525 --> 00:22:43.560
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode you will learn the core concepts of process improvement as well as identifying other process improvement programs.  In addition to distinguishing between real vs projected return on investment, you will also discover Lean Six Sigma ROI and why ROI is so important to the Process Improvement Effort.
episodes.title: Process Improvement Basics
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.250 --> 00:00:06.551
Welcome back to ITPro.TV [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:06.551 --> 00:00:08.264
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.264 --> 00:00:12.083
You are watching ITPro.TV.

4
00:00:12.083 --> 00:00:13.800
>> Welcome to section one of

5
00:00:13.800 --> 00:00:18.231
Lean Six Sigma Green Belt
Certification Preparations Series.

6
00:00:18.231 --> 00:00:20.628
I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:20.628 --> 00:00:25.200
In this segment, we'll be taking a look
at our process improvement basics.

8
00:00:25.200 --> 00:00:26.690
To help us with that today.

9
00:00:26.690 --> 00:00:29.570
In house, we have Dr. Terra Vanzant Stern.

10
00:00:29.570 --> 00:00:30.880
Thank you for joining us today.

11
00:00:30.880 --> 00:00:33.150
>> Thank you.
>> So where do we get started?

12
00:00:33.150 --> 00:00:36.190
What are the first topics that we
should go ahead and investigate?

13
00:00:36.190 --> 00:00:38.770
>> Well, I think I'd like to
go over to my slides, and

14
00:00:38.770 --> 00:00:41.960
talk about the process improvement basics,
just like you said.

15
00:00:41.960 --> 00:00:43.040
>> Perfect.

16
00:00:43.040 --> 00:00:46.740
>> The reason why I think this is
important is because if you get the basic

17
00:00:46.740 --> 00:00:52.340
understanding of process improvement, you
will be able to answer the test questions.

18
00:00:52.340 --> 00:00:58.230
You'll remember from before, we said that
you might be sitting for a Lean exam.

19
00:00:58.230 --> 00:01:00.440
You might be sitting for a Six Sigma Exam.

20
00:01:00.440 --> 00:01:04.520
Hopefully, you'll take our suggestion and
sit for the Lean Six Sigma Exam.

21
00:01:04.520 --> 00:01:06.790
Because that's the trend these days.

22
00:01:06.790 --> 00:01:09.680
However, sometimes just
understanding the concepts,

23
00:01:09.680 --> 00:01:14.030
you can reason through the question,
no matter what exam you're taking.

24
00:01:14.030 --> 00:01:19.550
So what we're gonna try to cover in this,
may morph over into our next program,

25
00:01:19.550 --> 00:01:23.040
but we're gonna talk about the core
concept of process improvement.

26
00:01:23.040 --> 00:01:24.530
What does that actually mean?

27
00:01:24.530 --> 00:01:27.910
Some other process improvement programs.

28
00:01:27.910 --> 00:01:30.890
And you need kind of a high
level of knowledge just to know

29
00:01:30.890 --> 00:01:33.190
that there are other process
improvement programs.

30
00:01:33.190 --> 00:01:37.829
And what's so cool about Lean Six Sigma
is it's sort of a hybrid of all of those.

31
00:01:39.320 --> 00:01:44.940
We're gonna talk about ROI projected and
real ROI because for some

32
00:01:44.940 --> 00:01:49.765
reason this seems to be one of the biggest
topics that people miss on their exams.

33
00:01:49.765 --> 00:01:51.620
>> Okay.
>> It's also one of the topics that's

34
00:01:51.620 --> 00:01:55.105
the hardest when they're
doing Lean Six Sigma report.

35
00:01:55.105 --> 00:01:55.670
>> Okay.

36
00:01:55.670 --> 00:01:58.300
>> So I think we're gonna go over that.

37
00:01:58.300 --> 00:02:00.343
>> Start with the difficult topics,
I love it.

38
00:02:00.343 --> 00:02:02.186
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, I think so.

39
00:02:02.186 --> 00:02:03.240
>> [LAUGH]
>> And

40
00:02:03.240 --> 00:02:06.930
then we're gonna talk a little bit about
the difference between charters and

41
00:02:06.930 --> 00:02:09.860
reports, cuz that's just
another basic thing.

42
00:02:09.860 --> 00:02:13.740
And then we'll continue to learn about
how to put our projects together.

43
00:02:13.740 --> 00:02:14.470
>> Okay.
>> Okay?

44
00:02:16.670 --> 00:02:22.240
So simply stated, process improvement
is gonna take an existing process and

45
00:02:22.240 --> 00:02:26.550
make that existing process better,
faster, more cost effective.

46
00:02:26.550 --> 00:02:31.550
So when we talk about process, and some of
you may have watched the lean Six Sigma,

47
00:02:31.550 --> 00:02:37.500
Yellow Belt Program given by ITProTV,
we gave some examples of process.

48
00:02:37.500 --> 00:02:43.630
But just as a reminder of that,
any activity is going to be a process.

49
00:02:43.630 --> 00:02:45.730
So a task is one thing.

50
00:02:45.730 --> 00:02:47.950
But a process is a series of things.

51
00:02:47.950 --> 00:02:51.660
For example,
there is a washing your clothes process.

52
00:02:51.660 --> 00:02:53.810
And there's a cleaning your house process.

53
00:02:53.810 --> 00:02:57.095
And there's a driving to work process,
right?

54
00:02:57.095 --> 00:03:02.570
Business processes, typically
are things like the payroll process.

55
00:03:02.570 --> 00:03:04.890
Within the payroll process,
would you agree Cherokee,

56
00:03:04.890 --> 00:03:07.240
there's probably a lot of mini processes.

57
00:03:07.240 --> 00:03:08.760
>> Yeah, a lot of those sub-processes.

58
00:03:08.760 --> 00:03:09.540
>> Yeah, exactly.

59
00:03:09.540 --> 00:03:15.670
So if you look at it, we have a marketing
process, we have an operations process.

60
00:03:15.670 --> 00:03:18.530
We have, if you're working in
a manufacturing environment,

61
00:03:18.530 --> 00:03:21.420
there's obviously different
manufacturing processes.

62
00:03:21.420 --> 00:03:25.120
So just kind of think any
kind of activity, and

63
00:03:25.120 --> 00:03:28.850
within that activity there may be
sub-processes that you're looking at.

64
00:03:28.850 --> 00:03:31.720
But I'm taking something
that's already happening, and

65
00:03:31.720 --> 00:03:35.810
I'm trying to make that something better,
faster, or more cost effective.

66
00:03:35.810 --> 00:03:39.990
Now when we say more cost effective,
what we're trying to do is we're trying to

67
00:03:39.990 --> 00:03:44.660
make money, save money, or
avoid spending money, okay?

68
00:03:44.660 --> 00:03:50.640
Now, the part where it gets a little
tricky is that when you say save money

69
00:03:50.640 --> 00:03:55.240
in a process improvement program, Lean Six
Sigma, remember is an example of a process

70
00:03:55.240 --> 00:03:59.820
improvement program, but in any of them,
when you say your gonna save money,

71
00:03:59.820 --> 00:04:03.860
it's not quite the same as when
you just save money on your own.

72
00:04:03.860 --> 00:04:04.470
>> Okay.

73
00:04:04.470 --> 00:04:10.390
>> So for example, if I went to the store
and I saw a designer dress that I really

74
00:04:10.390 --> 00:04:14.690
wanted, and then I went to another store,
and I saw that same dress for cheaper.

75
00:04:14.690 --> 00:04:17.820
Sort of like some of those
commercials you see on television.

76
00:04:17.820 --> 00:04:21.170
In my mind, I've saved money.

77
00:04:21.170 --> 00:04:26.010
But the way saving money works in process
improvement is I had to have already been

78
00:04:26.010 --> 00:04:30.190
given the money, and I gave you some back,
or the money was already budgeted.

79
00:04:30.190 --> 00:04:31.310
So just cuz I go out, and

80
00:04:31.310 --> 00:04:34.720
I get a good deal doesn't mean I've
saved money in process improvement.

81
00:04:34.720 --> 00:04:38.250
I have to actually have the money
in my hand or it's budgeted.

82
00:04:38.250 --> 00:04:39.470
>> Okay.
>> Does that make sense?

83
00:04:39.470 --> 00:04:42.110
>> It does.
>> Okay, and then cost avoidance is just

84
00:04:42.110 --> 00:04:45.764
what it says, but sometimes that
gets a little hard to process.

85
00:04:45.764 --> 00:04:50.540
Because I'm going to have to give you
a stronger argument for cost avoidance.

86
00:04:50.540 --> 00:04:55.850
So, you may have wanted to spend a certain
amount of money on a process improvement.

87
00:04:55.850 --> 00:04:59.660
I think if we spend a little bit
more money up front, down the line,

88
00:04:59.660 --> 00:05:01.930
we may avoid spending more money.

89
00:05:01.930 --> 00:05:04.140
>> Sure.
>> So if I go in to my boss and

90
00:05:04.140 --> 00:05:07.300
I say, I have a process improvement
that's gonna make us money,

91
00:05:07.300 --> 00:05:10.650
because making money profit is still king.

92
00:05:10.650 --> 00:05:11.578
>> Of course.
[LAUGH]

93
00:05:11.578 --> 00:05:12.956
>> At least they're gonna listen.

94
00:05:12.956 --> 00:05:13.457
Right?
>> Yes.

95
00:05:13.457 --> 00:05:14.252
>> Someone's gonna

96
00:05:14.252 --> 00:05:15.470
listen to me.
Right?

97
00:05:15.470 --> 00:05:19.010
And if I go in and I say guess what
I've made a process improvement and

98
00:05:19.010 --> 00:05:22.440
here's a $1,000 back,
there going to be like yay, right?

99
00:05:22.440 --> 00:05:22.980
>> Yeah.

100
00:05:22.980 --> 00:05:24.570
>> It's going to be really exciting.

101
00:05:24.570 --> 00:05:25.710
The cost avoidance.

102
00:05:25.710 --> 00:05:29.510
If you set out thinking you were going
to spend a certain amount of money and

103
00:05:29.510 --> 00:05:32.310
I'm saying you know what we spent more but
we going to.

104
00:05:32.310 --> 00:05:34.220
We're gonna make it up the next quarter.

105
00:05:34.220 --> 00:05:36.600
I'm already kinda losing my audience,
right?

106
00:05:36.600 --> 00:05:39.530
So I have to really kind of, I don't know,

107
00:05:39.530 --> 00:05:42.550
have my story straight when
I talk about cost avoidance.

108
00:05:42.550 --> 00:05:48.020
Another example of cost avoidance
directly relates to compliance issues.

109
00:05:48.020 --> 00:05:51.020
So, think of some compliance agencies.

110
00:05:51.020 --> 00:05:52.660
There's the EEOC
>> HIPAA.

111
00:05:52.660 --> 00:05:53.350
>> HIPAA.

112
00:05:54.420 --> 00:05:56.350
>> What is the nuclear regulations?

113
00:05:57.932 --> 00:05:59.510
I can't remember the acronym.

114
00:05:59.510 --> 00:06:04.460
But they're definitely prevalent
within that industry, for sure.

115
00:06:04.460 --> 00:06:07.100
It's very bureaucratic and by the book.

116
00:06:07.100 --> 00:06:07.690
>> Exactly.

117
00:06:07.690 --> 00:06:10.005
And then all of us, IRS.

118
00:06:10.005 --> 00:06:11.290
>> Yeah.

119
00:06:11.290 --> 00:06:15.060
>> So if I notice something
that's out of compliance, and

120
00:06:15.060 --> 00:06:18.700
if we get caught we're
gonna have to pay a fine.

121
00:06:18.700 --> 00:06:19.222
Well then,

122
00:06:19.222 --> 00:06:23.100
that process improvement is considered
a cost avoidance process improvement.

123
00:06:23.100 --> 00:06:27.810
And what I like about cost avoidance is
that it's a little easier to explain.

124
00:06:27.810 --> 00:06:29.750
Because there's a lot of
people that have schedules.

125
00:06:29.750 --> 00:06:34.490
So, for example, the EPAs says,
if you make a number one violation,

126
00:06:34.490 --> 00:06:36.420
it's gonna cost you x amount of dollars.

127
00:06:36.420 --> 00:06:37.240
Well, I can go in and

128
00:06:37.240 --> 00:06:41.830
say, I saved us from being fined
that particular amount of money.

129
00:06:41.830 --> 00:06:42.330
So-
>> Sure.

130
00:06:42.330 --> 00:06:43.136
Like you said,

131
00:06:43.136 --> 00:06:47.618
by implementing something ahead of time,
before that cost was actually warranted.

132
00:06:47.618 --> 00:06:48.580
>> Exactly.

133
00:06:48.580 --> 00:06:50.040
Now, another tricky thing, and

134
00:06:50.040 --> 00:06:53.230
this may show up on another slide so
I'll just reiterate it.

135
00:06:53.230 --> 00:06:55.870
Another tricky thing about
making things better, faster and

136
00:06:55.870 --> 00:06:58.560
more cost effective is bottom line,
guess what?

137
00:06:58.560 --> 00:07:00.530
It's all about being cost effective.

138
00:07:00.530 --> 00:07:04.080
So people say well why would I
even try to make something better?

139
00:07:04.080 --> 00:07:08.920
Why would I even try to make something
faster, if it's all about the money?

140
00:07:08.920 --> 00:07:12.090
And that's because, and you'll see
this as you go through these programs,

141
00:07:12.090 --> 00:07:15.950
the tools to make something
better are different,

142
00:07:15.950 --> 00:07:18.210
the tools to make something
faster are different.

143
00:07:18.210 --> 00:07:21.940
So I have to tackle those problems
first and then I have to go back and

144
00:07:21.940 --> 00:07:23.690
say, did it make me money?

145
00:07:23.690 --> 00:07:24.770
Did it save me money?

146
00:07:24.770 --> 00:07:26.610
Did it avoid me spending money?

147
00:07:26.610 --> 00:07:30.250
Now, sometimes I can just go
straight to the money argument.

148
00:07:30.250 --> 00:07:31.010
And it's easier.

149
00:07:31.010 --> 00:07:32.710
>> Essentially, it all boils down to that.

150
00:07:32.710 --> 00:07:34.550
Because if you're able to produce or

151
00:07:34.550 --> 00:07:38.170
provide a service at a more rapid
rate than what you previously were.

152
00:07:38.170 --> 00:07:42.265
Well, I can only assume that you're
increasing your revenue as well.

153
00:07:42.265 --> 00:07:44.414
>> Absolutely.
>> And if I provide you with a quality

154
00:07:44.414 --> 00:07:48.952
product, I may be getting repeat customers
or they may be spreading the word,

155
00:07:48.952 --> 00:07:49.872
word of mouth.

156
00:07:49.872 --> 00:07:52.923
Which would be bringing additional
money into that organization as well.

157
00:07:52.923 --> 00:07:54.028
>> Yeah, absolutely.

158
00:07:54.028 --> 00:07:56.573
Absolutely.

159
00:07:56.573 --> 00:08:00.668
Now, there are other process improvement
programs, and what I think is so

160
00:08:00.668 --> 00:08:04.470
important about these is that
they use that same concept.

161
00:08:04.470 --> 00:08:08.870
We're trying to make an existing process
better, faster, more cost effective.

162
00:08:08.870 --> 00:08:10.600
They just take a different approach.

163
00:08:10.600 --> 00:08:15.670
Now, on the Lean Six Sigma exams, you
just have to have a high level knowledge

164
00:08:15.670 --> 00:08:18.120
of the ones I'm gonna talk about next.

165
00:08:18.120 --> 00:08:19.660
On the Lean exam, and

166
00:08:19.660 --> 00:08:23.920
the Six Sigma Exam, sometimes there's
a few more questions related.

167
00:08:23.920 --> 00:08:28.090
And that's why in your student package,
you're going to get a little

168
00:08:28.090 --> 00:08:32.600
bit more of a breakdown of
these different categories.

169
00:08:32.600 --> 00:08:36.110
On the Lean Six Sigma Exam,
basically, they want you to know that

170
00:08:36.110 --> 00:08:39.340
Lean Six Sigma isn't the only
process improvement program.

171
00:08:39.340 --> 00:08:44.050
But again, especially in Lean,
because so much of Lean comes from TQM.

172
00:08:44.050 --> 00:08:46.500
You could have some
specific TQM questions, and

173
00:08:46.500 --> 00:08:49.250
that's why when you're looking
to your student package,

174
00:08:49.250 --> 00:08:54.040
it might say something good for
the Lean only, or the Six Sigma only exam.

175
00:08:54.040 --> 00:08:57.850
It's interesting reading, I mean,
it won't hurt you to read it for

176
00:08:57.850 --> 00:08:59.020
the Lean Six Sigma exam.

177
00:08:59.020 --> 00:09:01.780
But we mostly want you to
know that Lean Six Sigma,

178
00:09:01.780 --> 00:09:05.890
although it's the best process improvement
program, it's certainly not the only one.

179
00:09:05.890 --> 00:09:09.340
So TQM, we've talked a little
bit about that before.

180
00:09:09.340 --> 00:09:11.170
That's total quality management.

181
00:09:11.170 --> 00:09:13.780
And that's where all process
improvement started.

182
00:09:13.780 --> 00:09:18.443
And it was in a manufacturing environment,
and it was just about being better,

183
00:09:18.443 --> 00:09:22.281
it wasn't about being cost effective,
it wasn't about speed.

184
00:09:22.281 --> 00:09:22.897
>> Okay.

185
00:09:22.897 --> 00:09:26.319
>> It was just about being better, and
it wasn't until the 1980s that any of

186
00:09:26.319 --> 00:09:28.807
the process improvement program said,
you know what?

187
00:09:28.807 --> 00:09:30.582
It's gonna be about the money,

188
00:09:30.582 --> 00:09:33.820
a little bit about how fast we
can get something to market.

189
00:09:34.900 --> 00:09:39.340
ISO, International Standard Organization,
is a set of standards.

190
00:09:39.340 --> 00:09:44.240
In the States, we're mostly familiar
with 9,000 series and the 14,000 series.

191
00:09:44.240 --> 00:09:44.780
>> Sure.

192
00:09:44.780 --> 00:09:45.370
>> However, there's,

193
00:09:45.370 --> 00:09:47.530
if you can believe this-
>> There's a lot.

194
00:09:47.530 --> 00:09:48.590
I don't even know.

195
00:09:48.590 --> 00:09:51.260
>> 350 standards you can get certified in.

196
00:09:51.260 --> 00:09:52.700
>> Wow.
>> I mean, it's just amazing.

197
00:09:52.700 --> 00:09:55.130
But here in the States,
we kinda know about that.

198
00:09:55.130 --> 00:09:59.450
But there is now, for example,
an ISO standard for medical labs,

199
00:09:59.450 --> 00:10:04.470
an ISO standard for medical device,
those types of things.

200
00:10:04.470 --> 00:10:06.270
>> And also, I have a bit of a background.

201
00:10:06.270 --> 00:10:07.960
I worked for a manufacturing company.

202
00:10:07.960 --> 00:10:12.740
But ISO is not constrained or
confined to just a manufacturing,

203
00:10:12.740 --> 00:10:14.810
it can also apply to services as well.

204
00:10:14.810 --> 00:10:17.690
>> Exactly,
ISO works a little differently than TQM.

205
00:10:17.690 --> 00:10:22.120
TQM, it's a lot like
Lean Six Sigma is now.

206
00:10:22.120 --> 00:10:25.420
In the TQM days,
it was very people centric,

207
00:10:25.420 --> 00:10:29.940
because people time didn't cost
quite as much as machine time.

208
00:10:29.940 --> 00:10:32.950
So, the big difference between TQM and

209
00:10:32.950 --> 00:10:38.010
Lean Six Sigma is that Lean Six Sigma
has a lot newer, jazzier tools.

210
00:10:38.010 --> 00:10:42.810
Now, ISO, the way it works is it
gives you a list of best practices.

211
00:10:42.810 --> 00:10:45.370
So, these books are filled with,
in a perfect world,

212
00:10:45.370 --> 00:10:48.040
this is what it should look like.

213
00:10:48.040 --> 00:10:52.294
And the idea of making you better, faster,
