Your investment was 12,
your net profit was 6.

440
00:22:28.750 --> 00:22:32.120
So, you divide those two,
multiply it by 100.

441
00:22:32.120 --> 00:22:35.130
And then you'd have 50%
return on investment.

442
00:22:35.130 --> 00:22:40.290
Now in your student package, we have
other return on investment formulas.

443
00:22:40.290 --> 00:22:43.180
This is just the simplest one.

444
00:22:43.180 --> 00:22:46.110
In some companies,
they're considering things like taxes and

445
00:22:46.110 --> 00:22:48.920
there's all kinds of other
things that you consider.

446
00:22:48.920 --> 00:22:52.880
But if you kind of stick to this, you'll
be able to answer the test questions.

447
00:22:52.880 --> 00:22:57.370
So, let's do another example,
and then we can wrap up.

448
00:22:57.370 --> 00:23:01.750
If I invested $2000 in stock, okay, and

449
00:23:01.750 --> 00:23:05.620
then a year later I sold that stock for
what?

450
00:23:05.620 --> 00:23:06.271
>> No, $1200.

451
00:23:06.271 --> 00:23:08.110
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] So

452
00:23:08.110 --> 00:23:10.360
now my net profit is -$600, right.

453
00:23:10.360 --> 00:23:11.380
That's my -$600.

454
00:23:11.380 --> 00:23:14.630
So, I still use that same formula.

455
00:23:14.630 --> 00:23:16.850
My net profit Is -$600.

456
00:23:16.850 --> 00:23:19.490
My investment was $2000, right.

457
00:23:19.490 --> 00:23:21.160
>> Yes.
>> Okay and

458
00:23:21.160 --> 00:23:25.670
then multiply that by a hundred and
so you'll see the bottom part of this

459
00:23:25.670 --> 00:23:30.240
story is that I have a -30%
return on investment.

460
00:23:30.240 --> 00:23:32.860
So, just to kind of wrap this up on my end

461
00:23:33.930 --> 00:23:37.690
There are some core concepts in process
improvement that are very important.

462
00:23:37.690 --> 00:23:39.890
If you get the core concepts down,

463
00:23:39.890 --> 00:23:42.880
you can answer any test question
that's a lean six sigma.

464
00:23:42.880 --> 00:23:45.817
Or hopefully, the lean six sigma exam.

465
00:23:45.817 --> 00:23:49.494
One of the core concepts is I'm
taking an existing activity.

466
00:23:49.494 --> 00:23:52.169
And I'm trying to make that
activity better, faster, and

467
00:23:52.169 --> 00:23:53.570
more cost effective, right?

468
00:23:53.570 --> 00:23:54.891
And if I can't, I can't.

469
00:23:54.891 --> 00:23:56.996
Then I'm going to go on
to another activity.

470
00:23:56.996 --> 00:24:01.990
So what happens is choosing
the activity becomes very key.

471
00:24:01.990 --> 00:24:03.734
And so Lean Six Sigma has tools,

472
00:24:03.734 --> 00:24:06.964
just like some of the other
process improvement programs,

473
00:24:06.964 --> 00:24:11.440
on how to make sure I'm really working on
the thing I should be working on, right?

474
00:24:11.440 --> 00:24:12.434
>> Awesome.

475
00:24:12.434 --> 00:24:15.737
>> And then the next thing that's
really important is the concept of

476
00:24:15.737 --> 00:24:17.435
return on investment.

477
00:24:17.435 --> 00:24:20.055
I'm going to have a projected
return on investment.

478
00:24:20.055 --> 00:24:22.635
Let's say I bought that used car, right?

479
00:24:22.635 --> 00:24:26.957
And I'm thinking if I use that used car
all year, it has an intrinsic value,

480
00:24:26.957 --> 00:24:28.647
maybe the Blue Book value, right.

481
00:24:28.647 --> 00:24:32.147
>> Or maybe I even become an Uber driver,
and I'm using it as part of an income.

482
00:24:32.147 --> 00:24:32.987
>> Exactly.

483
00:24:32.987 --> 00:24:37.157
But I don't know that for
sure, right, I just think.

484
00:24:37.157 --> 00:24:41.591
So as part of my story to get you to let
me buy this car, whether you're my parent,

485
00:24:41.591 --> 00:24:44.806
or my spouse, or my child,
whoever I may be reporting to.

486
00:24:44.806 --> 00:24:46.624
>> You seem like you've
been through this before.

487
00:24:46.624 --> 00:24:48.050
[LAUGH]
>> Yes, absolutely.

488
00:24:48.050 --> 00:24:52.580
So as part of that argument I'm gonna say,
I think I could make, and

489
00:24:52.580 --> 00:24:54.960
that's all it is,
projected return on investments.

490
00:24:54.960 --> 00:24:59.710
So there's really no formula there,
unless you look at the cost,

491
00:24:59.710 --> 00:25:01.080
you're gonna have that.

492
00:25:01.080 --> 00:25:03.340
But you're kind of guessing
on the benefit, and

493
00:25:03.340 --> 00:25:05.190
that's projected return on investments.

494
00:25:05.190 --> 00:25:08.098
So there's no real formula for
that because you're using your brain.

495
00:25:08.098 --> 00:25:09.530
>> Yeah.

496
00:25:09.530 --> 00:25:13.800
Although you could use a cost benefit
analysis form to kind of get your

497
00:25:13.800 --> 00:25:14.460
hands around it.

498
00:25:14.460 --> 00:25:15.220
You still wouldn't know.

499
00:25:15.220 --> 00:25:16.706
>> Yeah, you could go online and look at,

500
00:25:16.706 --> 00:25:18.475
see what other Uber
drivers in your area make.

501
00:25:18.475 --> 00:25:19.220
>> Exactly.

502
00:25:19.220 --> 00:25:24.020
>> And use that information, but again, it
does tie into the whole human intuition.

503
00:25:24.020 --> 00:25:27.920
>> Absolutely, so your best guess,
right, is your return on investment.

504
00:25:27.920 --> 00:25:29.632
Or your projected return on investment.

505
00:25:29.632 --> 00:25:34.240
When you're talking real return on
investment, your project's done and

506
00:25:34.240 --> 00:25:35.860
you do have some finite numbers.

507
00:25:35.860 --> 00:25:40.578
The thing is is to kind of remember that
your calculator can help you some, but

508
00:25:40.578 --> 00:25:45.297
your calculator is going to come back and
it's going to say negative 30% or

509
00:25:45.297 --> 00:25:48.730
plus 30% or
you made 100% return on investment.

510
00:25:49.730 --> 00:25:53.280
That core number in reports
is gonna be huge, but

511
00:25:53.280 --> 00:25:55.960
you might have to consider some
human factors to your point.

512
00:25:55.960 --> 00:25:56.750
>> All right.

513
00:25:56.750 --> 00:25:58.350
I think that does about wrap it up for

514
00:25:58.350 --> 00:26:01.690
this particular episode unless you
have any other final thoughts?

515
00:26:01.690 --> 00:26:02.269
>> Not really.

516
00:26:02.269 --> 00:26:05.693
>> All right, we were able to go ahead and
take a look at the different governing

517
00:26:05.693 --> 00:26:08.330
bodies that are available and
different options we have.

518
00:26:08.330 --> 00:26:10.348
And sometimes it might not be your option,

519
00:26:10.348 --> 00:26:13.556
it might just be adhering to your
company and what their culture is.

520
00:26:13.556 --> 00:26:15.761
So thank you for
clarifying that, Dr. Stern.

521
00:26:15.761 --> 00:26:16.875
>> Thank you.

522
00:26:16.875 --> 00:26:19.407
>> And we did start to see some formulas.

523
00:26:19.407 --> 00:26:21.351
I think we have a lot more formulas and

524
00:26:21.351 --> 00:26:24.390
tools that we will be looking
at throughout this series.

525
00:26:24.390 --> 00:26:26.638
So thank you guys for
watching but stay tuned.

526
00:26:26.638 --> 00:26:31.110
We have a lot more Green Belt
training headed your way.

527
00:26:31.110 --> 00:26:34.797
That about wraps it up, so I'm gonna
sign off as your host Cherokee Boose.

528
00:26:35.950 --> 00:26:39.820
>> And this is Dr. Tara van
Zansteren with SSD Global Solutions.

529
00:26:39.820 --> 00:26:41.810
>> See you next time here ITProTV

530
00:26:41.810 --> 00:26:49.547
[MUSIC]

531
00:26:49.547 --> 00:26:54.449
Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode you will continue to learn about project charters and project planning. Dr. Terra Vanzant Stern and Cherokee discuss the key differences of a project charter versus a process improvement charter. You will also learn how to generate a LSS project report.  Lastly, you will be presented with examples of an extremely popular project planning tool Work Breakdown Structure (WBS ) .
episodes.title: Process Improvement Basics Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.300 --> 00:00:01.343
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.343 --> 00:00:06.269
I'm your host [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.269 --> 00:00:08.324
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.324 --> 00:00:12.195
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.195 --> 00:00:16.920
>> Welcome to your Lean Six Sigma:
Green Belt Certification Prep series.

6
00:00:16.920 --> 00:00:19.360
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:19.360 --> 00:00:20.710
If you've been following along,

8
00:00:20.710 --> 00:00:25.390
we've already taken a look at
our process improvement basics.

9
00:00:25.390 --> 00:00:29.100
We ran out of a little time with the last
episode, so in this episode we are gonna

10
00:00:29.100 --> 00:00:33.640
be covering a part two and with us today
we have Dr. Terra Stern in the studios.

11
00:00:33.640 --> 00:00:34.820
Thank you for joining us, Dr. Stern.

12
00:00:34.820 --> 00:00:36.750
>> Thank you for having me.

13
00:00:36.750 --> 00:00:38.204
>> So where did we leave off?

14
00:00:38.204 --> 00:00:42.061
I know you had said we would look at some
interesting tools to help us through this

15
00:00:42.061 --> 00:00:46.490
beginning of process improvement, but
where are we gonna be starting today?

16
00:00:46.490 --> 00:00:48.294
>> Okay, well, let's go to my notes.

17
00:00:48.294 --> 00:00:54.630
And as you mentioned,
we're gonna do Process Basics, Part Two.

18
00:00:54.630 --> 00:00:58.546
And to just kind of recap,
in the last session, we talked about,

19
00:00:58.546 --> 00:01:00.409
what is process improvement?

20
00:01:00.409 --> 00:01:04.248
And we determined that that's taking
an existing activity and making it better,

21
00:01:04.248 --> 00:01:06.310
faster, more cost effective.

22
00:01:06.310 --> 00:01:09.850
And we talked about other
process improvement programs.

23
00:01:09.850 --> 00:01:14.580
And we also addressed return on
investment projected versus actual.

24
00:01:14.580 --> 00:01:15.180
>> Correct.
>> And

25
00:01:15.180 --> 00:01:20.500
we said that this is what we
think our project could make,

26
00:01:20.500 --> 00:01:23.720
save or avoid spending,
whereas actual return on investment,

27
00:01:23.720 --> 00:01:27.770
we have the numbers and we know exactly
what we made, saved or avoided spending.

28
00:01:27.770 --> 00:01:32.310
And what we're gonna go through
today is project charters versus

29
00:01:32.310 --> 00:01:36.861
the project report because those
are two separate collaterals.

30
00:01:36.861 --> 00:01:38.739
And we are gonna look
at project planning and

31
00:01:38.739 --> 00:01:42.110
hopefully the work breakdown structure,
which is part of project planning.

32
00:01:44.200 --> 00:01:48.941
So, the first thing that I wanna talk
about is the project charter and

33
00:01:48.941 --> 00:01:53.880
how that is different than
a process improvement charter.

34
00:01:53.880 --> 00:01:56.890
Charters are just a form,
it's just a template.

35
00:01:56.890 --> 00:02:02.030
This comes up a lot on
the Lean Six Sigma exam as

36
00:02:02.030 --> 00:02:07.295
well as the Lean by itself, and Six Sigma
exam, is what is the purpose of a charter?

37
00:02:07.295 --> 00:02:11.699
So, the first thing we wanna think about
is the purpose of the charter is just to

38
00:02:11.699 --> 00:02:14.852
get all the information
collected in one area, right?

39
00:02:14.852 --> 00:02:17.479
And we're saying what we wanna do,
why we wanna do it,

40
00:02:17.479 --> 00:02:20.580
who's going to be working
on that project with us.

41
00:02:20.580 --> 00:02:23.868
When we know the problem and
we know the solution,

42
00:02:23.868 --> 00:02:28.805
then that's really just a straight
project charter because I'm gonna say

43
00:02:28.805 --> 00:02:33.294
this is who's gonna work with me,
this is why I wanna do it, right?

44
00:02:33.294 --> 00:02:37.211
However sometimes we have the problem and
we don't know the solution, and

45
00:02:37.211 --> 00:02:40.830
that's where process improvement
tools come in handy.

46
00:02:40.830 --> 00:02:46.720
If I know the problem, but I don't know
the solution, all I'm trying to get you to

47
00:02:46.720 --> 00:02:52.240
do on my project charter is say it's
okay to work on that particular problem.

48
00:02:52.240 --> 00:02:56.660
I need to time to reason this problem out,
whereas if I already know the answer,

49
00:02:56.660 --> 00:03:00.085
my project charter, even though
they have the same fields, name,

50
00:03:00.085 --> 00:03:02.830
who's gonna work on it,
what are your constraints.

51
00:03:02.830 --> 00:03:05.770
Even though they have the same fields,
I already

52
00:03:05.770 --> 00:03:10.810
have it reasoned out in a regular project
charter what it is I want you to do.

53
00:03:10.810 --> 00:03:14.820
In a process improvement project charter,
I know the problem,

54
00:03:14.820 --> 00:03:16.100
I don't know the solution.

55
00:03:16.100 --> 00:03:19.628
So what I'm trying to get you to do after
you read my project charter is just say

56
00:03:19.628 --> 00:03:21.930
hey, that's a worthwhile
problem to work on.

57
00:03:21.930 --> 00:03:26.146
I think you should see how
to handle that problem.

58
00:03:26.146 --> 00:03:28.572
>> And for
our process improvement charter,

59
00:03:28.572 --> 00:03:32.275
this is something that we would be
submitting to our superiors for

60
00:03:32.275 --> 00:03:36.990
basically approval to verify that we're
going through the proper channels before

61
00:03:36.990 --> 00:03:42.300
we just say, identify this as a potential
problem without getting any approval.

62
00:03:42.300 --> 00:03:46.690
>> Right, exactly, so now, in a regular
project charter, you'd have to have

63
00:03:46.690 --> 00:03:51.680
people signing off, a multiple signing
off sometimes, because you are asking,

64
00:03:51.680 --> 00:03:55.910
I wanna spend x amount of money,
I wanna spend x amount of time.

65
00:03:55.910 --> 00:03:57.360
What I'm just trying to get you to say,

66
00:03:57.360 --> 00:04:00.880
hey, it's okay to spend some
time working on this problem.

67
00:04:00.880 --> 00:04:05.827
I don't have to give as much information,
but I do wanna remember that my process

68
00:04:05.827 --> 00:04:09.103
improvement project charter
is like a proposal, and

69
00:04:09.103 --> 00:04:12.778
I wanna make it interesting,
and I want you to understand.

70
00:04:12.778 --> 00:04:16.124
And that's why a lot of times it includes
something called Projected Return

71
00:04:16.124 --> 00:04:16.868
on Investment.

72
00:04:16.868 --> 00:04:21.780
And our last session we said
Projected Return on Investment is

73
00:04:21.780 --> 00:04:26.708
what I think we could make save or avoid
spending if this project's successful.

74
00:04:26.708 --> 00:04:28.298
>> Sure.
>> If I am able to make this activity

75
00:04:28.298 --> 00:04:31.770
better, faster, and more cost effective,
this is what I can do.

76
00:04:31.770 --> 00:04:33.290
>> Go ahead and strengthen your argument.

77
00:04:33.290 --> 00:04:36.780
>> Exactly, and
whereas an irregular project charter,

78
00:04:36.780 --> 00:04:40.720
I'm actually part of what I'm asking
you for is the money and the time.

79
00:04:40.720 --> 00:04:41.320
>> Okay.

80
00:04:41.320 --> 00:04:42.150
>> Okay.

81
00:04:42.150 --> 00:04:43.410
So, if I know the problem,

82
00:04:43.410 --> 00:04:46.930
and I know the solution, then,
it's just a regular charter.

83
00:04:46.930 --> 00:04:51.020
I just need to do it, right, and
I move immediately to the project plan,

84
00:04:51.020 --> 00:04:53.370
which we'll be talking
about here in a second.

85
00:04:53.370 --> 00:04:57.710
If I know the problem, but I don't know
the solution just trying to get you to let

86
00:04:57.710 --> 00:05:01.420
me work on the problem, I don't
really have a project plan yet, but

87
00:05:01.420 --> 00:05:05.410
at some point, all process improvements
are going to become a project.

88
00:05:05.410 --> 00:05:06.420
That's our goal.

89
00:05:06.420 --> 00:05:09.810
We want a project that people say,
hey, you can do it or not.

90
00:05:09.810 --> 00:05:13.310
In the meantime,
we just need the time to work on it.

91
00:05:13.310 --> 00:05:14.370
What is a Project Charter?

92
00:05:14.370 --> 00:05:18.330
Now this is process improvement or
regular project charter.

93
00:05:18.330 --> 00:05:21.930
It clearly describes the problem, yet

94
00:05:21.930 --> 00:05:25.450
confirms that the team matches
the expectations of senior management.

95
00:05:25.450 --> 00:05:28.130
So a lot of times I've
used project charters

96
00:05:29.730 --> 00:05:34.320
just to kinda go back to if someone came
in and asked me to do something else or

97
00:05:34.320 --> 00:05:36.710
they thought I was going
in a different direction.

98
00:05:36.710 --> 00:05:38.760
I can bring the charter back
that you've signed and said,

99
00:05:38.760 --> 00:05:41.380
well, this is what I thought we agreed to.

100
00:05:41.380 --> 00:05:46.090
And it establishes a timeline, and
it serves as a communication vehicle.

101
00:05:46.090 --> 00:05:47.650
So it does all those things.

102
00:05:49.250 --> 00:05:50.700
>> And when you say communication vehicle,

103
00:05:50.700 --> 00:05:52.870
I just wanna elaborate on
that a little bit more.

104
00:05:52.870 --> 00:05:57.310
So, would it specify who
I needed to contact,

105
00:05:57.310 --> 00:05:59.840
kind of like a hierarchy,
or something like that?

106
00:05:59.840 --> 00:06:02.220
>> Right,
well it's sort of like your promo.

107
00:06:03.490 --> 00:06:06.110
You're kind of putting it out
there almost like a press release.

108
00:06:06.110 --> 00:06:07.925
So kind of think of it
that way like this is-

109
00:06:07.925 --> 00:06:08.602
>> I like that.

110
00:06:08.602 --> 00:06:11.330
>> Yeah.
[LAUGH]

111
00:06:11.330 --> 00:06:13.250
>> Again, it has the same fields.

112
00:06:15.230 --> 00:06:19.237
The process improvement one, again,
I'm kind of repeating myself,

113
00:06:19.237 --> 00:06:20.784
is just more of a proposal.

114
00:06:20.784 --> 00:06:26.146
So project charters can be informal and
when I say informal that means you might

115
00:06:26.146 --> 00:06:31.560
be working in a company that has a project
charter form they want you to use.

116
00:06:31.560 --> 00:06:34.134
Lean Six Sigma is very high on.

117
00:06:34.134 --> 00:06:38.240
If there is a collateral there, if there
is a form, if there is a template, use it.

118
00:06:38.240 --> 00:06:39.920
Now if you have to add some thing to it,
fine.

119
00:06:39.920 --> 00:06:44.420
But you don't know the hours that might
have gone into developing that charter.

120
00:06:44.420 --> 00:06:48.750
So some companies have one, and
everyone just has to use the same form.

121
00:06:48.750 --> 00:06:51.870
Some companies aren't
into project chartering.

122
00:06:51.870 --> 00:06:54.300
Some companies don't
even know what that is.

123
00:06:54.300 --> 00:06:58.635
And so your project charter might take
an informal form, such as an email, or

124
00:06:58.635 --> 00:07:02.550
you write it down in a report and

125
00:07:02.550 --> 00:07:06.380
get signatures from there,
but not a specific thing.

126
00:07:06.380 --> 00:07:07.328
>> That's [INAUDIBLE] letter,
something that you use.

127
00:07:07.328 --> 00:07:08.631
>> Yeah.

128
00:07:08.631 --> 00:07:11.437
And so,
if you did an informal project charter,

129
00:07:11.437 --> 00:07:13.770
you still wanna have those components.

130
00:07:13.770 --> 00:07:14.950
Why am I doing this?

131
00:07:14.950 --> 00:07:15.830
Who's gonna help me?

132
00:07:15.830 --> 00:07:17.350
How long is it gonna take?

133
00:07:17.350 --> 00:07:20.955
And you want some kind of acknowledgment,
a read receipt or

134
00:07:20.955 --> 00:07:24.470
something because once again,
you're gonna constantly be going back

135
00:07:24.470 --> 00:07:27.350
to that project charter saying,
this is what we agreed on.

136
00:07:27.350 --> 00:07:27.857
>> So informal.

137
00:07:27.857 --> 00:07:30.406
We're not talking about just
writing it on a cocktail napkin.

138
00:07:30.406 --> 00:07:32.504
>> Right, right.

139
00:07:32.504 --> 00:07:34.508
[LAUGH] Not quite that informal,
but it could be.

140
00:07:34.508 --> 00:07:36.531
I mean you never know, right?

141
00:07:36.531 --> 00:07:41.784
So when we talk about what would make
a good Lean Six Sigma project in a perfect

142
00:07:41.784 --> 00:07:47.961
world, right, because sometimes things get
assigned to Six Sigma, or Lean Six Sigma.

143
00:07:47.961 --> 00:07:50.700
And they really,
they really are just projects.

144
00:07:50.700 --> 00:07:52.465
We already know what
we are supposed to do.

145
00:07:52.465 --> 00:07:55.379
And so, sometimes the tools are kind
of wasted because we know what we're

146
00:07:55.379 --> 00:07:56.040
supposed to do.

147
00:07:56.040 --> 00:07:57.369
We should go to project plan,

148
00:07:57.369 --> 00:07:59.930
figure out who's gonna do
what when it happens, right?

149
00:07:59.930 --> 00:08:06.600
So in a perfect world,
there's no known solution, At this point.

150
00:08:06.600 --> 00:08:07.265
Okay, sorry.

151
00:08:07.265 --> 00:08:11.680
[LAUGH] The root cause is not known,
and this is really huge.

152
00:08:11.680 --> 00:08:14.541
We don't know why.

153
00:08:14.541 --> 00:08:15.940
We don't know how to solve the problem.

154
00:08:15.940 --> 00:08:18.790
But we don't even know
why is it happening.

155
00:08:18.790 --> 00:08:21.670
The problem's complex and
needs statistical analysis.

156
00:08:21.670 --> 00:08:24.480
Now that's gonna fall more
on the Six Sigma side.

157
00:08:24.480 --> 00:08:28.930
Because remember Lean Six Sigma and
certainly the product that I teach,

158
00:08:28.930 --> 00:08:33.020
Leaner Six Sigma,
says sometimes statistical analysis isn't

159
00:08:33.020 --> 00:08:37.010
as important as Six Sigma
would maybe make it.

160
00:08:37.010 --> 00:08:39.300
The problem is part of a process,

161
00:08:39.300 --> 00:08:44.100
so it could be something that's
just a component of that process.

162
00:08:44.100 --> 00:08:46.600
It's something that we know
is gonna be repeatable,

163
00:08:46.600 --> 00:08:49.390
because what's gonna happen is
if I solve that problem and

164
00:08:49.390 --> 00:08:53.820
I figure out how it's gonna help, then
I can just use it over and over again.

165
00:08:55.370 --> 00:08:57.237
The defect can be defined,
that's another one.

166
00:08:57.237 --> 00:09:00.210
Now, it doesn't have to have all these
components, these are just ideas.

167
00:09:00.210 --> 00:09:04.050
And this sheet, what makes a good
looking Lean Six Sigma project,

168
00:09:04.050 --> 00:09:07.570
is one of the sheets that is
included in your student package.

169
00:09:07.570 --> 00:09:11.710
So kinda keep that in mind and
it doesn't have to be all of these things.

170
00:09:11.710 --> 00:09:15.770
Typical exam questions are gonna say,
name three or four things, right?

171
00:09:15.770 --> 00:09:17.840
So they're not gonna expect
you to name all of them.

172
00:09:17.840 --> 00:09:19.350
So these are some of them.

173
00:09:19.350 --> 00:09:20.950
The project will take 3-6 months.

174
00:09:22.350 --> 00:09:27.440
This is another big difference
between Lean Six Sigma and Six Sigma.

175
00:09:27.440 --> 00:09:30.855
Lean Six Sigma encourages
you to take projects,

176
00:09:30.855 --> 00:09:32.480
now sometimes it doesn't
work out that way, but

177
00:09:32.480 --> 00:09:37.370
it encourages you to take projects
that you can finish within 3-6 months.

178
00:09:37.370 --> 00:09:40.610
Six Sigma projects can be two or
three year projects.

179
00:09:40.610 --> 00:09:44.740
Now the new kind of thinking, the more
innovative thinking is even in those two

180
00:09:44.740 --> 00:09:49.670
to three year projects, it's still
better to chunk it out into two or

181
00:09:49.670 --> 00:09:53.500
three months, and
do a lot of mini projects.

182
00:09:53.500 --> 00:09:56.690
That kind of protects you
because if leadership changes,

183
00:09:56.690 --> 00:09:58.620
then you've got something to show, right?

184
00:09:58.620 --> 00:10:02.570
You're not like in the middle
of a measure or something, yeah.

185
00:10:02.570 --> 00:10:05.960
>> Yeah, and
would you kind of define those?

186
00:10:05.960 --> 00:10:09.760
Could you use the terminology sprints like
we might have seen for smaller segments,

187
00:10:09.760 --> 00:10:12.130
or is that too long to
really define it as that?

188
00:10:13.690 --> 00:10:16.970
>> One of the things that I think
is interesting about Agile in doing

189
00:10:16.970 --> 00:10:20.740
the sprints is that that
naturally parallels with

190
00:10:20.740 --> 00:10:22.650
what Lean Six Sigma wants you to do.

191
00:10:22.650 --> 00:10:25.580
Now, sprints are typically three,
four weeks.

192
00:10:25.580 --> 00:10:28.340
Sometimes in some environments,
they're only two weeks.

193
00:10:28.340 --> 00:10:32.820
But that's the kind of thinking, is that
if you can just kind of get through a body

194
00:10:32.820 --> 00:10:35.650
of work, and then you have
that body of work to present.

195
00:10:35.650 --> 00:10:40.812
Lean Six Sigma promotes that
over really super long projects

196
00:10:40.812 --> 00:10:45.991
that you can't really document that you-
>> As long as you can segment them and

197
00:10:45.991 --> 00:10:49.540
break them down into smaller,
more manageable chunks maybe?

198
00:10:49.540 --> 00:10:51.920
>> Exactly, so that's very lean.

199
00:10:51.920 --> 00:10:52.804
Sprints are very lean.

200
00:10:52.804 --> 00:10:53.850
>> [LAUGH].
Very lean.

201
00:10:53.850 --> 00:10:54.410
Okay, got it.
>> And

202
00:10:54.410 --> 00:10:58.620
the other thing that makes a good Lean Six
Sigma project is that data is available.

203
00:10:58.620 --> 00:11:03.890
Now I'm gonna show you some tricks
a little bit later in the series,

204
00:11:03.890 --> 00:11:08.240
where if you don't have a lot of data, how
you can still do a process improvement.

205
00:11:08.240 --> 00:11:10.270
But certainly when
you're first looking for

206
00:11:10.270 --> 00:11:15.240
a Lean Six Sigma project, what you want to
be looking for are things that have data,

207
00:11:15.240 --> 00:11:18.250
that you have something that
you can kind of fall back on.

208
00:11:18.250 --> 00:11:23.620
So again, in a testing environment,
Lean test,

209
00:11:23.620 --> 00:11:26.350
Six Sigma test, or
the Lean Six Sigma test,

210
00:11:26.350 --> 00:11:28.790
they are not going to expect
that you know all of these.

211
00:11:28.790 --> 00:11:32.380
But what I would suggest is that when
you look at your student package,

212
00:11:32.380 --> 00:11:35.180
pick a few that resonate with you.

213
00:11:35.180 --> 00:11:38.310
And then that way, you'll be able
to answer the questions related to

214
00:11:38.310 --> 00:11:41.490
what makes a good Lean Six Sigma project.

215
00:11:41.490 --> 00:11:44.080
There are a number of different forums and

216
00:11:44.080 --> 00:11:46.870
templates that you can use for
project charters.

217
00:11:46.870 --> 00:11:50.000
If your company already
has a project charter,

218
00:11:50.000 --> 00:11:55.380
you want to use that, even if you
have to add something on to it.

219
00:11:55.380 --> 00:11:59.397
Traditional project charters look
like forms and they have fields and

220
00:11:59.397 --> 00:12:03.891
that's what you, if you're taking
the class through SSD Global Solutions,

221
00:12:03.891 --> 00:12:06.905
you will see a formal
traditional project charter.

222
00:12:06.905 --> 00:12:10.750
And the reason for that is that's
still what most companies are using.

223
00:12:12.008 --> 00:12:15.790
However, there are some very other
clever forms and templates, and

224
00:12:15.790 --> 00:12:19.090
one of them is something called the A3.

225
00:12:19.090 --> 00:12:24.050
Now, the A3 actually has a number of
different ways it can be presented,

226
00:12:24.050 --> 00:12:28.260
but the idea's that you can get
everything on one page, right.

227
00:12:28.260 --> 00:12:31.540
It used to be a page that you printed out.

228
00:12:31.540 --> 00:12:35.360
Now it's on the computer, so
it might still be a number of pages but

229
00:12:35.360 --> 00:12:38.910
you can go over to Excel and
kind of look at these different areas.

230
00:12:38.910 --> 00:12:43.460
And you'll see some of the headings here,
your scope, your goal.

231
00:12:43.460 --> 00:12:47.110
And we're gonna be talking about all of
those things, the customer requirements.

232
00:12:47.110 --> 00:12:52.690
What I want you to concentrate on now
is that the project charter is a form,

233
00:12:52.690 --> 00:12:57.590
or a template, that you submit to get
approval to work on your project.

234
00:12:57.590 --> 00:13:01.830
And that would be if you
knew the project goals,

235
00:13:01.830 --> 00:13:06.450
you're just trying to get the money and
the resources and the timeline approved.

236
00:13:06.450 --> 00:13:07.710
If you don't know, again,

237
00:13:07.710 --> 00:13:13.090
you're just trying to get permission
to work on the actual problem.

238
00:13:13.090 --> 00:13:17.860
So the form that you use
isn't really as important as

239
00:13:17.860 --> 00:13:22.110
the audience that you're presenting it to,
you wanna make sure that they understand.

240
00:13:22.110 --> 00:13:26.463
And if you're doing the informal project
charter, which we just talked about,

241
00:13:26.463 --> 00:13:28.831
then you might still
wanna go look at an A3 or

242
00:13:28.831 --> 00:13:33.396
a traditional project form just to make
sure you're including all the components.

243
00:13:33.396 --> 00:13:34.068
>> Covering all the fields, okay.

244
00:13:34.068 --> 00:13:35.176
>> Yeah.

245
00:13:38.577 --> 00:13:41.730
And again, you know the answer,
project charter.

246
00:13:41.730 --> 00:13:43.800
I know I keep driving this home, but

247
00:13:43.800 --> 00:13:47.980
there's a number of questions on the test
about what is a project charter?

248
00:13:47.980 --> 00:13:49.830
What is a process
improvement project charter?

249
00:13:49.830 --> 00:13:52.739
So this may seem really redundant, but

250
00:13:52.739 --> 00:13:56.896
it's just such a huge piece
of all three of those tests.

251
00:13:59.465 --> 00:14:06.190
Now, the project report has a lot of
the same dynamics as the project charter.

252
00:14:07.390 --> 00:14:09.870
But at this point what you're
doing is a narrative and

253
00:14:09.870 --> 00:14:12.360
you're collecting information
about the project.

254
00:14:12.360 --> 00:14:17.810
So the project charter is one form, And
the project report is your second form.

255
00:14:17.810 --> 00:14:21.050
Sometimes, the people you're working with
are gonna be very interested in your

256
00:14:21.050 --> 00:14:22.240
project report.

257
00:14:22.240 --> 00:14:26.630
Sometimes they're just gonna fast-forward
to the end and read your summary.

258
00:14:26.630 --> 00:14:27.980
They're not gonna really care.

259
00:14:27.980 --> 00:14:30.089
So what I want you to think
of as the project report,

260
00:14:30.089 --> 00:14:33.670
it's another conceptual thing
that will help you with the test.

261
00:14:33.670 --> 00:14:38.910
In essence, the project report is more for
you than it is for them.

262
00:14:38.910 --> 00:14:42.410
You're trying to collect the information,
make sure that your logic's clear,

263
00:14:42.410 --> 00:14:44.880
that you're doing everything,
that you've covered all your bases.

264
00:14:44.880 --> 00:14:49.220
Now, there are gonna be times where
you're working with a company that has,

265
00:14:49.220 --> 00:14:53.990
again, a formal reporting process, and
again, you're gonna wanna use their form.

266
00:14:53.990 --> 00:14:58.700
But a lot of times you're just
gonna write it up as a narrative.

267
00:14:58.700 --> 00:15:01.750
>> And you would probably
store this in a centrally, or

268
00:15:01.750 --> 00:15:05.550
share it out with your co-workers or
project team members.

269
00:15:05.550 --> 00:15:09.393
So if they had a question, you weren't
available, they wouldn't be wasting time.

270
00:15:09.393 --> 00:15:12.417
And they could look at this and say,
look, this is what we need to be doing or

271
00:15:12.417 --> 00:15:13.700
this is who we need to contact.

272
00:15:13.700 --> 00:15:17.780
So it's just kind of documentation,
it's not always fun to write but

273
00:15:17.780 --> 00:15:18.980
it's good to have.

274
00:15:18.980 --> 00:15:22.060
>> Exactly, and a lot of companies
have something called a PMO,

275
00:15:22.060 --> 00:15:25.890
a project management office,
that actually formally collects that.

276
00:15:25.890 --> 00:15:30.020
What I think that you wanna keep in mind
is that even if you don't have that,

277
00:15:30.020 --> 00:15:31.610
just for yourself you wanna collect that.

278
00:15:31.610 --> 00:15:35.775
You wanna always be able to produce
that information if someone asks.

279
00:15:35.775 --> 00:15:41.090
So the project report
is the actual report.

280
00:15:41.090 --> 00:15:42.670
It's a narrative.

281
00:15:42.670 --> 00:15:47.447
And the narrative, typically,
will follow, in Lean Six Sigma,

282
00:15:47.447 --> 00:15:49.594
one of these types of models.

283
00:15:49.594 --> 00:15:53.371
PDCA, DMAIC, or Design for Six Sigma.

284
00:15:53.371 --> 00:15:57.450
So PDCA is Plan Do Check Act,
we're gonna look at that briefly, and

285
00:15:57.450 --> 00:16:00.254
then we'll go into depth
a little bit latter.

286
00:16:00.254 --> 00:16:05.380
DMAIC is the flagship model of
Lean Six Sixma, and also Six Sigma.

287
00:16:05.380 --> 00:16:08.300
So kind of an interesting thing is,
on the Lean side,

288
00:16:08.300 --> 00:16:12.420
if you're just taking the Lean test or
even the project management exam.

289
00:16:12.420 --> 00:16:16.070
You wanna concentrate all of
your efforts on the PDCA.

290
00:16:16.070 --> 00:16:18.140
If you're taking just the Six Sigma,

291
00:16:18.140 --> 00:16:21.520
you want to concentrate most of
your efforts on the DMAIC model.

292
00:16:21.520 --> 00:16:24.260
If you're doing Lean Six Sigma,
you're looking at both, but

293
00:16:24.260 --> 00:16:28.040
DMAIC is still kind of
the king of the hill.

294
00:16:28.040 --> 00:16:29.585
>> Okay, good to know.

295
00:16:29.585 --> 00:16:31.666
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, and the design for Six Sigma,

296
00:16:31.666 --> 00:16:34.528
we're gonna talk a little bit
about that particular model.

297
00:16:34.528 --> 00:16:38.152
But just briefly, that's when you
don't have an existing process, and

298
00:16:38.152 --> 00:16:40.730
you're building something from scratch.

299
00:16:40.730 --> 00:16:42.910
So Lean Six Sigma talks about it.

300
00:16:42.910 --> 00:16:45.150
There's a lot of Lean Six Sigma
tools that you use.

301
00:16:45.150 --> 00:16:47.920
But technically design for
Six Sigma is a whole different program.

302
00:16:49.110 --> 00:16:53.520
And the reason it's different is
because it has that design factor.

303
00:16:53.520 --> 00:16:56.100
So you have to have a phase in
there to actually build one.

304
00:16:56.100 --> 00:16:58.470
>> Creating a new prototype, or
a new product, or a new process, and

305
00:16:58.470 --> 00:17:00.020
it just hasn't been done before.

306
00:17:00.020 --> 00:17:00.910
>> Exactly, exactly.

307
00:17:00.910 --> 00:17:05.204
A Lean Six Sigma model that
we discuss later in depth,

308
00:17:05.204 --> 00:17:10.176
but you can start using right now,
is something called PDCA.

309
00:17:10.176 --> 00:17:13.270
And that stands for plan, do, check, act.

310
00:17:13.270 --> 00:17:14.980
And it feels pretty intuitive.

311
00:17:14.980 --> 00:17:16.730
I'm gonna plan my work.

312
00:17:16.730 --> 00:17:17.840
I'm gonna do it.

313
00:17:17.840 --> 00:17:19.890
Then I'm gonna check and
make sure that it's okay.

314
00:17:19.890 --> 00:17:22.826
And then I'm gonna go back and
I'm gonna either act,

315
00:17:22.826 --> 00:17:25.641
move forward and
follow through with the project.

316
00:17:25.641 --> 00:17:28.439
I'm gonna abandon,
like I'm never gonna do this again.

317
00:17:28.439 --> 00:17:32.710
Or I might adapt it, which means I'm
just gonna go back and tweak it up.

318
00:17:32.710 --> 00:17:35.290
So it seems pretty intuitive.

319
00:17:35.290 --> 00:17:39.530
However, it's a very
historically significant

320
00:17:39.530 --> 00:17:42.648
model because it was a classified
document in World War II.

321
00:17:42.648 --> 00:17:44.205
>> That's really interesting.

322
00:17:44.205 --> 00:17:45.800
[LAUGH]
>> I think so.

323
00:17:45.800 --> 00:17:47.960
So sometimes when we're
looking at the simple stuff,

324
00:17:47.960 --> 00:17:50.600
just keep in mind,
it wasn't always that simple.

325
00:17:51.610 --> 00:17:54.020
But of course in my
program Leaner Six Sigma,

326
00:17:54.020 --> 00:17:57.320
we love it because it just makes so
much sense.

327
00:17:57.320 --> 00:18:00.750
So I just want to take the PDCA and
apply it to certification,

328
00:18:00.750 --> 00:18:04.460
because we are gonna come back to
this model when we talk about models.

329
00:18:04.460 --> 00:18:09.233
There are a lot of questions
related to the PDCA in the Lean,

330
00:18:09.233 --> 00:18:12.775
the Six Sigma, and
the Lean Six Sigma exam.

331
00:18:12.775 --> 00:18:18.320
However, keep in mind PDCA was,
no pun intended, leans more towards Lean.

332
00:18:18.320 --> 00:18:20.200
It's very prevalent in Lean Six Sigma.

333
00:18:20.200 --> 00:18:24.430
And Six Sigma does recognize this model.

334
00:18:24.430 --> 00:18:25.502
>> So pay attention,
in other words, right?

335
00:18:25.502 --> 00:18:27.030
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, really, really,

336
00:18:27.030 --> 00:18:28.220
this is important.

337
00:18:28.220 --> 00:18:31.080
So if I were applying
the PDCA to certification,

338
00:18:31.080 --> 00:18:32.570
the first thing I would do is plan.

339
00:18:32.570 --> 00:18:36.190
And one component of the plan, not all
the components of the plan, but one,

340
00:18:36.190 --> 00:18:39.060
is I'm gonna have to come
up with my timeline, right.

341
00:18:39.060 --> 00:18:43.140
Now my suggestion is that when you come up
with a timeline you divide it by four, so

342
00:18:43.140 --> 00:18:45.900
that you can have four
segments that you can plan.

343
00:18:45.900 --> 00:18:49.124
It makes planning just
a little bit easier.

344
00:18:49.124 --> 00:18:53.060
What do you realistically think that
you can do in that period of time?

345
00:18:53.060 --> 00:18:57.670
Right, now once you actually plan it,
and we're really good planners but

346
00:18:57.670 --> 00:18:58.890
sometimes we don't execute.

347
00:18:58.890 --> 00:19:01.805
And this is another place where
this model comes in very handy,

348
00:19:01.805 --> 00:19:03.520
cuz you can keep yourself on target.

349
00:19:03.520 --> 00:19:05.780
I'm gonna plan it, now I'm gonna go do it.

350
00:19:05.780 --> 00:19:09.940
So now I'm gonna do it, but at some point,
and I would have determined this during my

351
00:19:09.940 --> 00:19:12.890
plan, at some point I
wanna check up on myself.

352
00:19:12.890 --> 00:19:14.060
I wanna take them temperature,

353
00:19:14.060 --> 00:19:16.460
I wanna make sure that I'm
really on the right track.

354
00:19:16.460 --> 00:19:19.409
If I'm on the right track,
I'm gonna just continue doing it,

355
00:19:19.409 --> 00:19:20.868
which is another word for act.

356
00:19:20.868 --> 00:19:24.437
If I'm not on the right track,
I may abandon the idea altogether and

357
00:19:24.437 --> 00:19:26.300
go back to plan, right?

358
00:19:26.300 --> 00:19:30.280
And then, if I like it, but
I just need to fix it, tweak it up,

359
00:19:30.280 --> 00:19:31.290
then I would go to adapt.

360
00:19:33.430 --> 00:19:38.420
So in the plan, technically, I would
need a project charter to move forward.

361
00:19:38.420 --> 00:19:40.940
So, in this case,
if I'm trying to study for an exam,

362
00:19:40.940 --> 00:19:43.570
I might really have to send
a little email to my boss and

363
00:19:43.570 --> 00:19:48.250
say, I'm planning to do this, and see
if I could maybe do it on company time.

364
00:19:48.250 --> 00:19:49.600
I'm not really sure.

365
00:19:49.600 --> 00:19:52.610
So this might be an example of
an informal project charter.

366
00:19:52.610 --> 00:19:54.520
I might need to run it by my family or

367
00:19:54.520 --> 00:19:57.950
someone to let them know this
is what I'm planning to do.

368
00:19:59.670 --> 00:20:03.780
Keep in mind the project charter needs
to say what it is that you wanna do, and

369
00:20:03.780 --> 00:20:05.220
it might have a project plan.

370
00:20:05.220 --> 00:20:08.180
You might have gone ahead in this case,
in this scenario,

371
00:20:08.180 --> 00:20:12.150
mapped out what you're gonna accomplish
in each one of these four segments.

372
00:20:12.150 --> 00:20:16.160
In execute,
you're really just working the plan.

373
00:20:16.160 --> 00:20:17.710
So if you did a really good plan,

374
00:20:17.710 --> 00:20:21.170
all you're really doing is
moving through those steps.

375
00:20:21.170 --> 00:20:25.810
And then check, a lot of times what people
don't think about is in the planning,

376
00:20:25.810 --> 00:20:28.550
you need to think about, well,
what is it that I want to check?

377
00:20:28.550 --> 00:20:30.670
What is it that I want to look at, right?

378
00:20:30.670 --> 00:20:32.700
And then again, you get to the bottom and

379
00:20:33.860 --> 00:20:38.600
your report would explain why you act,
abandon, or adapt.

380
00:20:40.730 --> 00:20:43.520
>> So Dr. Stern,
after our project plan has been approved,

381
00:20:43.520 --> 00:20:45.290
what would be the next step?

382
00:20:45.290 --> 00:20:49.340
>> Well then, what we we're gonna wanna
do is make the actual project plan.

383
00:20:49.340 --> 00:20:50.630
Now I should point out that,

384
00:20:50.630 --> 00:20:55.150
in the PDCA model, I may have done
this in the first phase of the model.

385
00:20:55.150 --> 00:20:57.400
Some other models that we're looking at,

386
00:20:57.400 --> 00:21:02.000
that project plan doesn't happen
until the fourth or fifth stage.

387
00:21:02.000 --> 00:21:08.810
In the PDCA model, we probably would
leave plan with our actual project plan.

388
00:21:08.810 --> 00:21:11.370
In other models we won't
leave until three or

389
00:21:11.370 --> 00:21:14.670
four steps into the model after
we've kind of reasoned it out.

390
00:21:14.670 --> 00:21:16.530
But at some point,
no matter what we're doing,

391
00:21:16.530 --> 00:21:18.490
we're gonna end up with a project plan.

392
00:21:18.490 --> 00:21:22.580
And typically, Lean Six Sigma
prefers something called the work

393
00:21:22.580 --> 00:21:27.530
breakdown structure,
the acronym being WBS.

394
00:21:27.530 --> 00:21:28.040
>> Okay.

395
00:21:28.040 --> 00:21:30.540
>> And you've seen these before.

396
00:21:30.540 --> 00:21:35.212
So for example, if you're on Wikipedia and
you looked up something like IT design,

397
00:21:35.212 --> 00:21:39.840
all right, it's gonna tell you all the
stuff that you can see in that segment.

398
00:21:39.840 --> 00:21:42.240
So a lot of times work
breakdown structures used for

399
00:21:42.240 --> 00:21:45.570
educational purposes as
just an overall outline.

400
00:21:45.570 --> 00:21:48.400
And notice on this outline,
it's gonna give you an overview,

401
00:21:48.400 --> 00:21:50.090
it's gonna give you a history.

402
00:21:50.090 --> 00:21:55.180
And then design principles starts
getting broken down into smaller chunks.

403
00:21:55.180 --> 00:21:58.130
So 3.1, then there's 3.1.1.

404
00:21:58.130 --> 00:21:59.477
>> Pretty specific.

405
00:21:59.477 --> 00:22:06.330
>> Very specific, and if I had something
that went under 3.1.1 it'd be 3.1.2.

406
00:22:06.330 --> 00:22:10.320
Now the reason why we want to break
down things in chunks is that

407
00:22:10.320 --> 00:22:13.387
that way we can look at it
in a more concise way and

408
00:22:13.387 --> 00:22:17.430
come up with a time and a budget for
each one of those items.

409
00:22:17.430 --> 00:22:20.750
But this is just an example that you see
work breakdown structures all the time.

410
00:22:20.750 --> 00:22:23.670
So it's nothing scary.

411
00:22:23.670 --> 00:22:25.910
>> And this would be kind of a visual one.

412
00:22:25.910 --> 00:22:29.250
I'm not gonna keep this slide up for
very long, I just want you to get an idea.

413
00:22:29.250 --> 00:22:33.530
I'm taking a main idea and
I'm just breaking it down.

414
00:22:33.530 --> 00:22:34.458
>> Just a different format.

415
00:22:34.458 --> 00:22:40.923
>> Exactly, so WBSs can be use a lot
of times for strategic thinking.

416
00:22:40.923 --> 00:22:43.972
And the reason why I say that
is if I get up one morning and

417
00:22:43.972 --> 00:22:47.370
I have a to do list,
I could come up with my four major things.

418
00:22:47.370 --> 00:22:49.640
It's a great time management tool too.

419
00:22:49.640 --> 00:22:53.680
I could sit down and I could say, this are
the four things that I need to do today.

420
00:22:53.680 --> 00:22:58.333
And then go back and say under 1,
there's a 1.1, 1.2, 1.3.

421
00:22:58.333 --> 00:23:01.922
And by the way, under 1.3,
I better do a 1.3.1 and

422
00:23:01.922 --> 00:23:06.900
a 1.3.2 I want to break it down as much
as I can, because that's gonna help me

423
00:23:06.900 --> 00:23:11.910
figure out how long things are gonna take,
how much those things are gonna cost.

424
00:23:14.120 --> 00:23:17.110
Work breakdown structure is a good
thing to do for your study plan.

425
00:23:17.110 --> 00:23:19.720
We talked about doing the plan do,
check, act.

426
00:23:19.720 --> 00:23:23.710
Just sitting down and saying these are
the things that I need to study, and then

427
00:23:23.710 --> 00:23:27.830
saying, here's the high level concepts,
and then breaking that down, 1.1, 1.2.

428
00:23:27.830 --> 00:23:28.650
>> Really granular.

429
00:23:28.650 --> 00:23:31.480
>> Exactly, and
I think that takes some pressure off.

430
00:23:31.480 --> 00:23:35.270
Because if you've got a big body of
knowledge to study, you can say, hey,

431
00:23:35.270 --> 00:23:38.506
I'm just gonna knock
out my 1.1.3.20 today.

432
00:23:38.506 --> 00:23:41.570
[LAUGH]
>> Give yourself a little goal.

433
00:23:41.570 --> 00:23:42.580
>> Exactly.

434
00:23:42.580 --> 00:23:47.740
So, let's go back to our example that we
used for the PDCA for getting certified.

435
00:23:47.740 --> 00:23:54.521
If I did it on a work breakdown structure
as opposed to just using that whole PDCA.

436
00:23:54.521 --> 00:23:57.872
Keeping in mind that I might have ended
up with work breakdown structure when I

437
00:23:57.872 --> 00:23:58.399
left plan.

438
00:23:58.399 --> 00:23:59.639
It's very possible.

439
00:23:59.639 --> 00:24:02.341
So determine timeline would be one.

440
00:24:02.341 --> 00:24:05.340
Two, organize my materials.

441
00:24:05.340 --> 00:24:07.280
Three, find an area to study.

442
00:24:07.280 --> 00:24:08.950
We mentioned in another session,

443
00:24:08.950 --> 00:24:11.930
that a great study trick
is to go stage your area.

444
00:24:11.930 --> 00:24:14.520
So that you don't have to study that day,
you're just staging it.

445
00:24:14.520 --> 00:24:15.886
You're just putting everything together.

446
00:24:15.886 --> 00:24:20.400
And then number four design the matrix and
measurements to know if my plan

447
00:24:20.400 --> 00:24:23.280
is working, so that's kind of
the flow that it would follow.

448
00:24:24.790 --> 00:24:27.600
Now, when I'm looking at
I wanna break it down.

449
00:24:27.600 --> 00:24:30.070
I'm saying determine timeline right and

450
00:24:30.070 --> 00:24:35.000
my 1.1 is figure out when I want
that certification in my hand.

451
00:24:35.000 --> 00:24:37.735
But then if I went down further.

452
00:24:37.735 --> 00:24:43.970
1.1.1 and I divide by four, 1.1.2 I
check results after the first session.

453
00:24:43.970 --> 00:24:48.560
This would all be part of my plan,
and 1.2, I'd alert my family and

454
00:24:48.560 --> 00:24:51.350
friends, that I won't be
available during that time.

455
00:24:51.350 --> 00:24:52.500
>> Facebook, I'm signing off.

456
00:24:52.500 --> 00:24:54.150
>> [LAUGH]
>> That's exactly true.

457
00:24:55.190 --> 00:24:59.540
>> So, Work Breakdown Structure is
sort of a magical tool in a way,

458
00:24:59.540 --> 00:25:03.530
because it's used in Lean Six Sigma
to do my project plan.

459
00:25:03.530 --> 00:25:07.213
What I want you to think of,
as far as the exam is concerned,

460
00:25:07.213 --> 00:25:10.615
is WBS in this sense is nothing
more than a to-do list.

461
00:25:10.615 --> 00:25:14.656
However, I can I can use it for

462
00:25:14.656 --> 00:25:19.200
a number of just to get organize.

463
00:25:19.200 --> 00:25:22.280
I can use it write my paper, right?

464
00:25:22.280 --> 00:25:27.240
But in the project plan, when I seen
to do by breaking it down into those

465
00:25:27.240 --> 00:25:31.540
small chunks, I can now go back and
baseline my project.

466
00:25:31.540 --> 00:25:35.130
And what that basically
means is that I can tell you

467
00:25:35.130 --> 00:25:38.960
how long ps this project gonna take and
how much time is it going to.

468
00:25:38.960 --> 00:25:40.090
How much is it gonna cost?

469
00:25:40.090 --> 00:25:42.850
And how long is that going to take?

470
00:25:42.850 --> 00:25:45.920
Because I can go through each
one of those tiny objects and

471
00:25:45.920 --> 00:25:49.940
say it's gonna cost x amount of dollars,
and I can just add up the money, right?

472
00:25:51.380 --> 00:25:53.550
Then I can go back and I can look at time,

473
00:25:53.550 --> 00:25:55.460
there's some things that
can be done together.

474
00:25:55.460 --> 00:25:58.370
So for example if I'm waiting for
a signature for

475
00:25:58.370 --> 00:26:00.318
24 hours I'm obviously
gonna be doing things.

476
00:26:00.318 --> 00:26:02.120
In the in-between, right?

477
00:26:02.120 --> 00:26:03.750
And then I can add up my time.

478
00:26:03.750 --> 00:26:06.670
So that's a little bit about
project planning and your most

479
00:26:06.670 --> 00:26:10.640
important tool in project planning is
your WBS, your work breakdown structure.

480
00:26:10.640 --> 00:26:11.400
>> Well, thank you for that.

481
00:26:11.400 --> 00:26:15.030
In this episode, we were able to
look at our project charter and

482
00:26:15.030 --> 00:26:18.540
how it differentiates between
our process improvement charter.

483
00:26:18.540 --> 00:26:22.250
We were introduced to some planning and

484
00:26:22.250 --> 00:26:26.530
then we also saw our,
we're breakdown structure.

485
00:26:26.530 --> 00:26:29.880
You mentioned different types of
metrics that we may be learning about.

486
00:26:29.880 --> 00:26:31.620
So I think that's what's coming up next.

487
00:26:31.620 --> 00:26:32.670
So don't go anywhere.

488
00:26:32.670 --> 00:26:34.210
We have some really great metrics ahead.

489
00:26:34.210 --> 00:26:36.970
I'm gonna go ahead and
wrap it up for this episode.

490
00:26:36.970 --> 00:26:40.200
And your host,
Cherokee Boose And this is Dr.

491
00:26:40.200 --> 00:26:42.660
Vanzant Stern with SSD Global Solutions.

492
00:26:42.660 --> 00:26:46.031
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

493
00:26:46.031 --> 00:26:51.921
[MUSIC]

494
00:26:51.921 --> 00:26:54.010
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: This episode covers several types of metrics that can be used to measure performance. Specifically, Dr. Terra Vanzant Stern and Cherokee converse over metrics such as, Sigma, COPQ, DPU, DPMO, Cp/Cpk, Cycle Time and Mean/Mode/Median just to name a few!
episodes.title: LSS Metric Basics
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:01.170
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.170 --> 00:00:02.365
I'm your host, Dom.

3
00:00:02.365 --> 00:00:05.934
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:05.934 --> 00:00:08.255
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.255 --> 00:00:12.330
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:12.330 --> 00:00:17.500
>> Welcome to your Lean Six Sigma: Green
Belt Certification Preparation series.

7
00:00:17.500 --> 00:00:19.880
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

8
00:00:19.880 --> 00:00:24.980
In this episode, we'll be looking at
some lean six sigma metrics basics.

9
00:00:24.980 --> 00:00:28.090
With us today we have
Doctor Terra Stern in the studios.

10
00:00:28.090 --> 00:00:29.420
Thank you for being with us, Doctor.

11
00:00:29.420 --> 00:00:30.400
>> Thank you.

12
00:00:30.400 --> 00:00:31.535
>> So, we're going to begin.

13
00:00:31.535 --> 00:00:33.600
What type of metrics
are really important and

14
00:00:33.600 --> 00:00:37.810
what should we be using to make sure
we're being effective in our processes?

15
00:00:37.810 --> 00:00:42.600
>> Perfect, I think one of
the things that's really important

16
00:00:42.600 --> 00:00:45.230
about this section is this is probably of

17
00:00:45.230 --> 00:00:50.400
all lean six sigma program's the part
that is the most complicated for people.

18
00:00:50.400 --> 00:00:53.980
Now my company teaches something
called leaner six sigma.

19
00:00:53.980 --> 00:00:58.273
So I'm going to teach you the concepts
in a much easier way than you might get

20
00:00:58.273 --> 00:00:59.919
them from another program.

21
00:00:59.919 --> 00:01:01.093
>> [LAUGH] I like the sound of that.

22
00:01:01.093 --> 00:01:04.000
[LAUGH] I don't object at all.

23
00:01:04.000 --> 00:01:04.980
>> Okay, good.

24
00:01:04.980 --> 00:01:05.960
But I want to point out,

25
00:01:05.960 --> 00:01:10.410
like in your student package that you
will have kind of the longer way.

26
00:01:10.410 --> 00:01:13.060
My theory is that if you
understand the concept and

27
00:01:13.060 --> 00:01:16.340
it's certainly on the lean
six sigma exams as well.

28
00:01:16.340 --> 00:01:19.520
Then the formulas and all that other
stuff will make a little bit more sense.

29
00:01:19.520 --> 00:01:23.220
So this session is gonna be more
conceptual than anything else.

30
00:01:23.220 --> 00:01:26.440
And then if you need more information,
go to your student package and

31
00:01:26.440 --> 00:01:29.940
you'll see the actual formulas and
statistics behind things.

32
00:01:29.940 --> 00:01:31.780
>> Okay.
>> And if you really wanna square things

33
00:01:31.780 --> 00:01:33.975
and minus them by one and
then times them by the fourth power.

34
00:01:33.975 --> 00:01:35.050
>> [LAUGH]
>> You're going

35
00:01:35.050 --> 00:01:37.420
to have the materials to do that.

36
00:01:38.810 --> 00:01:41.200
We've already talked about
return on investment.

37
00:01:41.200 --> 00:01:44.800
But I just want to briefly
remind you of that because

38
00:01:44.800 --> 00:01:47.410
it will make the other
statistics seem a lot simpler.

39
00:01:47.410 --> 00:01:51.210
But we're gonna look at Sigma,
we're gonna look at cost of poor quality,

40
00:01:51.210 --> 00:01:55.400
we're gonna look at DPUs, DPMOs, Cpks,

41
00:01:55.400 --> 00:02:00.700
Cp, Cycle Time and measures of central
tendency which is Mean, Mode and Median.

42
00:02:00.700 --> 00:02:03.720
>> Wow,
that looks like a menu of alphabet soup.

43
00:02:03.720 --> 00:02:06.710
>> Absolutely and the thing is this

44
00:02:08.460 --> 00:02:12.800
is the hardest, when people get to
this section, they kind of freak.

45
00:02:12.800 --> 00:02:15.910
But at SSD Global where we
teach leaner six sigma,

46
00:02:15.910 --> 00:02:19.020
I'm gonna show you the easy way to
do all of this stuff, so no worries.

47
00:02:19.020 --> 00:02:19.820
>> Perfect.

48
00:02:19.820 --> 00:02:21.790
>> Okay, so as a reminder,

49
00:02:21.790 --> 00:02:25.530
one unit of measurement was
return on investment, right?

50
00:02:25.530 --> 00:02:30.610
Now the reason why we even care is because
in order to show a process improvement,

51
00:02:30.610 --> 00:02:32.020
we have to have a baseline.

52
00:02:32.020 --> 00:02:34.990
We have to be able to say,
hey, this is where we started.

53
00:02:34.990 --> 00:02:37.570
A good place to start is
return on investment.

54
00:02:37.570 --> 00:02:41.890
However, a lot of times we don't
have a return on investment figure.

55
00:02:41.890 --> 00:02:43.300
So we have to use other measurements.

56
00:02:43.300 --> 00:02:47.150
So the first thing I want you to think
about is all these other measurements

57
00:02:47.150 --> 00:02:50.950
we're looking at, it's nothing more
than if you chose return on investment.

58
00:02:50.950 --> 00:02:56.607
So for example, as the reminder for
the formula, we're looking at (Net

59
00:02:56.607 --> 00:03:03.010
Profit / Cost of Investment) and then we
multiply that by 100 to get a percentage.

60
00:03:03.010 --> 00:03:06.665
And the example that we used in the other
session is if you bought a car for

61
00:03:06.665 --> 00:03:12.040
$1,200 and you sold it for
$1,800 your net profit was $600 and so

62
00:03:12.040 --> 00:03:14.790
your return on investment
would be calculated like this.

63
00:03:14.790 --> 00:03:17.418
Investment $1,200, net profit $600, and

64
00:03:17.418 --> 00:03:21.510
again this is kind of a reminder to
kinda get back in the swing of this.

65
00:03:21.510 --> 00:03:26.390
So if I did the formula I had
a 50% return on investment, right?

66
00:03:26.390 --> 00:03:30.910
So on the flip side,
if I sold my stock for $1,200 but

67
00:03:30.910 --> 00:03:35.260
I purchased it for $2,000 then I have
a negative return on investment.

68
00:03:35.260 --> 00:03:38.560
Because I'm still using that same formula,
right?

69
00:03:40.050 --> 00:03:41.510
So now I have a negative.

70
00:03:41.510 --> 00:03:44.630
So, once again we're not doing
anything more than that.

71
00:03:44.630 --> 00:03:48.700
I wanna show you the current picture,
this is what we're making now.

72
00:03:48.700 --> 00:03:51.880
I wanna show you the picture after
I made my process improvement.

73
00:03:51.880 --> 00:03:54.580
Now, this is what we're making
on return on investment.

74
00:03:54.580 --> 00:03:56.300
It's just there's other
ways to look at that.

75
00:03:57.620 --> 00:04:00.460
Keep in mind that lean six
sigma return on investment.

76
00:04:00.460 --> 00:04:02.090
We wanna make things better, faster,

77
00:04:02.090 --> 00:04:06.680
more cost-effective and
that it's still about cost-effectiveness.

78
00:04:06.680 --> 00:04:10.800
So, at some point, even if you
use one of these other tools and

79
00:04:10.800 --> 00:04:13.690
this is really important,
to get your current picture,

80
00:04:13.690 --> 00:04:15.810
that that's the measurement for
your current picture?

81
00:04:15.810 --> 00:04:18.800
It's still gonna come back to
return on investment at some point.

82
00:04:18.800 --> 00:04:21.090
That's why that keeps coming up.

83
00:04:21.090 --> 00:04:22.490
>> Okay.
>> Because no matter what

84
00:04:22.490 --> 00:04:24.500
I use to measure something-
>> Imagine that.

85
00:04:24.500 --> 00:04:26.640
>> I'm still gonna come back to,
what did you make me-

86
00:04:26.640 --> 00:04:27.710
>> It all boils down to money.

87
00:04:27.710 --> 00:04:28.395
>> It does.

88
00:04:28.395 --> 00:04:29.690
>> [LAUGH]
>> What did you make save, or

89
00:04:29.690 --> 00:04:30.510
avoid me spending?

90
00:04:33.920 --> 00:04:37.410
This is a reminder that if you're
taking the Six Sigma Exam,

91
00:04:37.410 --> 00:04:40.520
you also need to know the formulas
of the things that I'm showing you.

92
00:04:40.520 --> 00:04:43.420
And those formulas are gonna
be in your student package.

93
00:04:43.420 --> 00:04:45.140
Lean, not as much, there's one or two.

94
00:04:45.140 --> 00:04:47.610
We have those starred in your
student package, like if you're

95
