down that if you decide to go on and

552
00:28:56.090 --> 00:29:00.460
study higher level statistics it's
gonna make your life so much easier.

553
00:29:00.460 --> 00:29:04.340
So mean is really what we're
familiar with, all the time.

554
00:29:04.340 --> 00:29:08.981
When you were in school your teacher
probably said the average grade in class,

555
00:29:08.981 --> 00:29:13.709
so mean, mean average, and average all
mean the same thing, no pun intended.

556
00:29:13.709 --> 00:29:16.670
>> [LAUGH]
>> But so let's say I gave an exam,

557
00:29:16.670 --> 00:29:21.047
there's 30 exams, I added up the 30 exams.

558
00:29:21.047 --> 00:29:24.797
I divided by 30 and
it came up with an average and I tell you,

559
00:29:24.797 --> 00:29:27.385
okay the average of the class was 85%.

560
00:29:27.385 --> 00:29:31.730
So what that buys me is I know did
I perform above or below average.

561
00:29:31.730 --> 00:29:32.907
>> Are we dropping the lowest score?

562
00:29:32.907 --> 00:29:34.176
>> Yeah.
>> [LAUGH]

563
00:29:34.176 --> 00:29:36.262
>> And you know that's a good point

564
00:29:36.262 --> 00:29:40.973
because sometimes when we get mega data
we have to drop on both ends just to

565
00:29:40.973 --> 00:29:43.460
kind of get that middle data.

566
00:29:43.460 --> 00:29:47.684
So a mode on the other hand is the number
that happens the most frequently.

567
00:29:47.684 --> 00:29:53.600
So in our 30 grades let's say
the most common test score was 82.

568
00:29:53.600 --> 00:29:58.138
So I'm gonna say the mode was
82 well the average was 85, but

569
00:29:58.138 --> 00:30:02.610
the mode, the number that people
made the most often was 82.

570
00:30:02.610 --> 00:30:05.630
And then the median,
that's the number in the middle.

571
00:30:05.630 --> 00:30:08.505
So I want you to visualize, and
I know a lot of you already know this,

572
00:30:08.505 --> 00:30:09.761
we learned it-
>> Elementary school.

573
00:30:09.761 --> 00:30:12.146
>> Some of us learned in third grade,
some of us learned it in fifth grade.

574
00:30:12.146 --> 00:30:12.909
>> [LAUGH]
>> But

575
00:30:12.909 --> 00:30:15.782
we don't use it so
that's why sometimes we have to have

576
00:30:15.782 --> 00:30:17.389
a brief reminder so-
>> Refresher.

577
00:30:17.389 --> 00:30:18.117
>> So [LAUGH] exactly.

578
00:30:18.117 --> 00:30:19.451
>> [LAUGH]
>> So median,

579
00:30:19.451 --> 00:30:25.571
If I were looking at those 30 test grades,
kind of visualize 30 pieces of paper and

580
00:30:25.571 --> 00:30:29.320
I lay all 30 pieces of paper out,
side by side.

581
00:30:29.320 --> 00:30:32.130
The first thing I would do is put them
in sequential order because as I'm

582
00:30:32.130 --> 00:30:35.980
grading them, it's probably not
likely that they came in that order.

583
00:30:35.980 --> 00:30:37.850
So the first thing I'm gonna
do is I'm gonna align them.

584
00:30:37.850 --> 00:30:43.860
So I'm gonna do 65, 65, 75, 82, 82,
cuz we said that was our mode, right?

585
00:30:43.860 --> 00:30:45.400
And so forth and so forth.

586
00:30:45.400 --> 00:30:47.390
And I'm gonna take the one in the middle.

587
00:30:47.390 --> 00:30:52.180
Now because we have an even number
in this example, I can't take.

588
00:30:52.180 --> 00:30:54.467
If I had an odd number like 29 middle,
I'm done.

589
00:30:54.467 --> 00:30:56.903
But because I have an even number,

590
00:30:56.903 --> 00:31:01.700
what I'd wanna do is in the middle
of that take those two in average.

591
00:31:01.700 --> 00:31:05.690
>> So 15 and 16 and
then find the average for those two exams.

592
00:31:05.690 --> 00:31:07.130
>> And that would be the median.

593
00:31:07.130 --> 00:31:09.781
Now, so why do we care and
why is it important?

594
00:31:09.781 --> 00:31:13.028
The big deal is in Six Sigma we're
trying to get to the average,

595
00:31:13.028 --> 00:31:15.860
which is just another
way of saying standard.

596
00:31:15.860 --> 00:31:19.220
And a lot of the statistical measurements,
such as standard deviation and some of

597
00:31:19.220 --> 00:31:25.420
the other things that we'll see later,
have to do with being close to the middle.

598
00:31:25.420 --> 00:31:29.729
However, sometimes the middle is distorted
and you'll have to trust my math on this,

599
00:31:29.729 --> 00:31:31.097
but I can have 30 grades.

600
00:31:31.097 --> 00:31:36.530
The average could be 85, and yet
I could have had five or six people fail.

601
00:31:37.750 --> 00:31:39.980
And, just a number of people
make a really good grade.

602
00:31:39.980 --> 00:31:42.720
So it's, it's kind of
a distorted sense of the middle.

603
00:31:42.720 --> 00:31:46.660
So, if I'm going to use
the middle as my marker,

604
00:31:46.660 --> 00:31:49.980
as my baseline, I want to test it
against the mode and the median.

605
00:31:49.980 --> 00:31:53.397
Now, if they're close, like in our
example, we said the mode was 82 and

606
00:31:53.397 --> 00:31:55.365
the average was 85, eh, pretty close.

607
00:31:55.365 --> 00:31:59.712
But what if the mode had been like 55,
then I'm really showing you

608
00:31:59.712 --> 00:32:04.449
a distorted thing of the middle and
if my objective is to get to the middle.

609
00:32:04.449 --> 00:32:07.978
I wanna be sure that I'm doing
a good picture of that middle,

610
00:32:07.978 --> 00:32:10.330
so I wanna test my mean
against my mode and

611
00:32:10.330 --> 00:32:14.790
my median and if they're pretty
cross then, I'm gonna be okay.

612
00:32:14.790 --> 00:32:18.640
But if there really far part, I just might
wanna use a different form of measurement,

613
00:32:18.640 --> 00:32:21.750
like SOPQ or return on investment.

614
00:32:21.750 --> 00:32:24.494
I mean this is just another
measurement that I can use.

615
00:32:24.494 --> 00:32:25.852
>> Okay.
>> So I think,

616
00:32:25.852 --> 00:32:29.516
that pretty much covers
the most important ones.

617
00:32:29.516 --> 00:32:31.138
>> [LAUGH]
>> There's still some math and

618
00:32:31.138 --> 00:32:33.833
things that we'll be covering,
as we move through the program, but

619
00:32:33.833 --> 00:32:36.120
these are the ones,
that the test pretty much focuses on.

620
00:32:36.120 --> 00:32:39.222
>> We have covered quite a bit and
I thank you for that because,

621
00:32:39.222 --> 00:32:42.832
I really feel like you've been able
to help us digest our alphabets.

622
00:32:42.832 --> 00:32:45.080
See, that was a lot there.

623
00:32:45.080 --> 00:32:49.480
So hopefully you guys are able to go ahead
and look at what we've covered here with

624
00:32:49.480 --> 00:32:53.830
our different metrics and understand that,
by looking at the visuals as well.

625
00:32:53.830 --> 00:32:58.240
So thank you for tuning in, but we do
have some more, our Green Belt training

626
00:32:58.240 --> 00:33:02.280
headed this way for our Lean Six Sigma
Green Belt certification preparation.

627
00:33:02.280 --> 00:33:02.993
I know it's a mouthful.

628
00:33:02.993 --> 00:33:05.654
But we're going to go ahead and
wrap up for this episode.

629
00:33:05.654 --> 00:33:09.280
I'm going to sign off as your host,
Cherokee Boose.

630
00:33:09.280 --> 00:33:11.197
>> And this is Dr. Tara Vanzant Stern.

631
00:33:11.197 --> 00:33:12.656
>> See you next time here at ITPRO.TV.

632
00:33:12.656 --> 00:33:20.628
[MUSIC]

633
00:33:20.628 --> 00:33:25.900
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV

episodes.description: This episode defines and compares key terminology. Dr. Terra Vanzant Stern and Cherokee first speak on the distinctions between methodologies versus tools as well as Waterfall versus Circular Thinking. You also discover proper brainstorming techniques using tools such as the Affinity diagram. Other topics covered are six core principles and popular concepts in Lean Six Sigma.
episodes.title: Core Concepts and Terms
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.230 --> 00:00:01.170
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.170 --> 00:00:03.727
I'm your host-
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:03.727 --> 00:00:06.208
>> Live from San Francisco, California-

4
00:00:06.208 --> 00:00:08.333
>> [CROSSTALK]

5
00:00:08.333 --> 00:00:11.001
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:12.500 --> 00:00:18.000
Welcome to your Lean Six Sigma: Green
Belt Certification Preparation Series.

7
00:00:18.000 --> 00:00:20.370
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

8
00:00:20.370 --> 00:00:24.810
In this episode we're gonna be taking
a look at our Lean Six Sigma Core Concepts

9
00:00:24.810 --> 00:00:25.750
and Terms.

10
00:00:25.750 --> 00:00:27.630
So with us today to go ahead and

11
00:00:27.630 --> 00:00:31.070
define those need-to-knows,
we have Dr Terra Stern in this studios.

12
00:00:31.070 --> 00:00:33.370
Thank you for joining us today, Dr Stern.

13
00:00:33.370 --> 00:00:35.480
>> I'm happy to be here, thank you.

14
00:00:35.480 --> 00:00:38.580
>> So where do we start,
what are some of the core concepts,

15
00:00:38.580 --> 00:00:41.310
some of the basics that
we just can't get around?

16
00:00:41.310 --> 00:00:44.160
>> Well, I'd like to go ahead and
go to my slide deck, if that's okay.

17
00:00:44.160 --> 00:00:44.780
>> Sure.

18
00:00:44.780 --> 00:00:47.240
>> And again it is core concepts.

19
00:00:48.540 --> 00:00:55.110
Kinda keep in mind that the strategy that
my company Leaner has, Leaner Six Sigma,

20
00:00:55.110 --> 00:00:59.190
is that if you get the basic idea of the
concept then the other things just kind of

21
00:00:59.190 --> 00:01:02.210
are easier to understand so
if you get the overall concept.

22
00:01:02.210 --> 00:01:06.730
So the concepts that are really
big in Lean Six Sigma are what is

23
00:01:06.730 --> 00:01:09.790
the difference between a methodology and
a tool?

24
00:01:09.790 --> 00:01:14.240
What is the difference between
waterfall methodology as opposed to

25
00:01:14.240 --> 00:01:16.400
circular thinking methodolog?

26
00:01:16.400 --> 00:01:18.740
And sometimes those
are articulated in different ways,

27
00:01:18.740 --> 00:01:20.460
which we'll talk about that.

28
00:01:20.460 --> 00:01:22.330
What does structured brainstorming mean?

29
00:01:22.330 --> 00:01:25.190
What are some of the core
principles of Lean Six Sigma?

30
00:01:25.190 --> 00:01:29.040
And then finally, what are some
popular concepts in Lean Six Sigma?

31
00:01:29.040 --> 00:01:33.136
And I think if you get this overview and
you understand these basics,

32
00:01:33.136 --> 00:01:36.888
that the test questions are going
to be much easier to process.

33
00:01:39.879 --> 00:01:44.424
Now, one of the things that you want to
remember is that almost everything in

34
00:01:44.424 --> 00:01:46.350
Lean Six Sigma is called a tool.

35
00:01:46.350 --> 00:01:51.550
So if you get a question that says, name
a tool or pick all the tools, probably

36
00:01:51.550 --> 00:01:56.610
everything is a tool because there is
just a tendency to overuse that word.

37
00:01:56.610 --> 00:02:01.510
Everything is tool, so right off the bat,
everything is a tool, okay?

38
00:02:01.510 --> 00:02:06.340
However a methodology is something
that has to be done step by step.

39
00:02:06.340 --> 00:02:10.210
So, a tool might not necessarily
have to be used in a certain order.

40
00:02:10.210 --> 00:02:13.660
It might be a one time
Band-Aid fix type thing.

41
00:02:13.660 --> 00:02:16.853
But if it's a methodology,
you do step one, then you do step two,

42
00:02:16.853 --> 00:02:18.500
then you do step three.

43
00:02:18.500 --> 00:02:22.874
And that's why things like PDCA,
which we covered in another session,

44
00:02:22.874 --> 00:02:25.900
which we're gonna cover
in this session as well.

45
00:02:25.900 --> 00:02:28.691
PDCA has to be done in a certain order.

46
00:02:28.691 --> 00:02:33.720
I have to plan, then I have to do, then
I have to check, and then I have to act.

47
00:02:33.720 --> 00:02:35.736
So even though that is a methodology,

48
00:02:35.736 --> 00:02:40.040
some people refer to PDCAs as
a tool because everything's a tool.

49
00:02:40.040 --> 00:02:43.160
If you ever get stumped,
just remember everything's a tool.

50
00:02:43.160 --> 00:02:44.700
Another thing to keep in mind,

51
00:02:44.700 --> 00:02:49.160
since Lean Six Sigma has a large
project management component,

52
00:02:49.160 --> 00:02:52.970
because at some point your process
improvement is gonna become a project.

53
00:02:54.490 --> 00:02:59.623
Most of your project management tools,
by default, are also Lean Six Sigma tools.

54
00:03:02.483 --> 00:03:06.141
Examples of tools would be graphs,
charts, and

55
00:03:06.141 --> 00:03:10.691
some of those that we're gonna
be looking at, like Pareto,

56
00:03:10.691 --> 00:03:15.620
histograms, scatter diagram,
fishbone other types of tools.

57
00:03:15.620 --> 00:03:19.294
And this where I think it's get a little
bit trickier are things such as

58
00:03:19.294 --> 00:03:20.610
historical documents.

59
00:03:20.610 --> 00:03:23.298
Now if you were working for
a public company,

60
00:03:23.298 --> 00:03:27.610
an example of historical document
might be their annual report.

61
00:03:27.610 --> 00:03:30.180
However if you're just
working in a department,

62
00:03:30.180 --> 00:03:34.900
just the way people put together forms,
and their thinking, and

63
00:03:34.900 --> 00:03:37.950
how things are filed, and
how things are documented.

64
00:03:40.420 --> 00:03:42.278
How did the department come into being?

65
00:03:42.278 --> 00:03:45.252
What need was there to
form that department?

66
00:03:45.252 --> 00:03:46.583
Having that kind of knowledge,

67
00:03:46.583 --> 00:03:49.160
a lot of times, will help you
with your process improvement.

68
00:03:52.010 --> 00:03:54.610
Financial Reports, see Case Tools.

69
00:03:54.610 --> 00:03:56.540
Case tools are kind of
an interesting thing.

70
00:03:56.540 --> 00:04:02.970
In IT, the term was used a lot in
the 80s and 90s, not quite as much now.

71
00:04:02.970 --> 00:04:08.630
But case tools can apply to not just IT,
but to any kind of industry.

72
00:04:08.630 --> 00:04:12.930
And the deal is case tools
are specific to your subject.

73
00:04:12.930 --> 00:04:14.340
So you don't wanna forget that.

74
00:04:14.340 --> 00:04:15.942
That any tools like if
you're making a car,

75
00:04:15.942 --> 00:04:17.775
there's certain tools
that you're gonna need.

76
00:04:17.775 --> 00:04:21.455
Or you're designing a car even, there's
certain tools that you're gonna use.

77
00:04:21.455 --> 00:04:24.740
So case tools, that means specific tools.

78
00:04:24.740 --> 00:04:28.899
Lean Six Sigma allows for
you to integrate those specific tools

79
00:04:29.910 --> 00:04:34.960
at any given time, so
again basically anything that helps you.

80
00:04:34.960 --> 00:04:38.702
Two big tools are brainstorming and
affinity diagrams and

81
00:04:38.702 --> 00:04:42.450
so most of us are familiar
with brainstorming, right?

82
00:04:42.450 --> 00:04:44.520
>> Yeah, at least I think so.

83
00:04:44.520 --> 00:04:45.097
>> Yeah.
>> [LAUGH]

84
00:04:45.097 --> 00:04:46.528
>> Well, I think we often do

85
00:04:46.528 --> 00:04:47.899
brainstorming wrong.

86
00:04:49.993 --> 00:04:52.403
In a typical brainstorming exercise,

87
00:04:52.403 --> 00:04:56.850
the idea is that we just write down
everything that everyone says.

88
00:04:56.850 --> 00:04:58.870
And it doesn't really
matter if it's a repeat.

89
00:05:00.170 --> 00:05:02.990
And usually the most
effective brainstorming

90
00:05:02.990 --> 00:05:06.480
sessions happen if the person
has no idea what's going on.

91
00:05:06.480 --> 00:05:08.310
Someone who's not the boss.

92
00:05:08.310 --> 00:05:11.290
Because sometimes what happens is we
say things that we think the boss

93
00:05:11.290 --> 00:05:11.910
wants to hear.

94
00:05:13.160 --> 00:05:16.730
If you can grab someone from another
department that's not familiar with

95
00:05:16.730 --> 00:05:20.450
what you're trying to brainstorm about,
then that's almost better.

96
00:05:20.450 --> 00:05:25.446
So at one point in our brainstorming,
if there's too many things on the list,

97
00:05:25.446 --> 00:05:28.640
we move to something called
an affinity diagram.

98
00:05:28.640 --> 00:05:32.252
And that means we're just gonna take
all of those brainstorming ideas and

99
00:05:32.252 --> 00:05:34.007
put them into some kinda category.

100
00:05:34.007 --> 00:05:38.226
And in some cases, maybe there is a lot
of things that need to be done that week.

101
00:05:38.226 --> 00:05:42.226
So our categories could be Bob,
Cindy, Nancy, right?

102
00:05:42.226 --> 00:05:45.965
Or maybe it is different departments or
maybe it is timelines,

103
00:05:45.965 --> 00:05:48.860
so I get to decide what those buckets are.

104
00:05:48.860 --> 00:05:52.540
In Lean Six Sigma, there is a lot of times
where we do something called structured

105
00:05:52.540 --> 00:05:57.700
brainstorming which just means the
affinity diagram is made ahead of time.

106
00:05:57.700 --> 00:05:59.960
I'm gonna give you something
to brainstorm, but

107
00:05:59.960 --> 00:06:02.700
I'm gonna give you buckets that
I want you to brainstorm around.

108
00:06:05.140 --> 00:06:07.850
And we'll be looking at some of
those examples in future sessions.

109
00:06:07.850 --> 00:06:08.390
>> It makes sense,

110
00:06:08.390 --> 00:06:12.790
I mean there are certain types of
studying methods, such as brain mapping.

111
00:06:12.790 --> 00:06:14.130
There's a book by Jamie Nass,

112
00:06:14.130 --> 00:06:19.610
where they kind of logically separate off
into branches those brainstorming areas.

113
00:06:19.610 --> 00:06:22.510
So I could see how that
could be a very useful tool.

114
00:06:22.510 --> 00:06:24.740
>> Yeah, and
it just kind of speeds things up.

115
00:06:26.210 --> 00:06:28.260
All right, so methodologies.

116
00:06:28.260 --> 00:06:30.600
Now remember the difference
between a methodology and

117
00:06:30.600 --> 00:06:34.470
a tool is that a methodology
has to be done in a certain.

118
00:06:34.470 --> 00:06:35.300
>> Sequential order.

119
00:06:35.300 --> 00:06:36.720
>> Yeah, sequential order, perfect.

120
00:06:37.750 --> 00:06:42.100
Methodologies, by default, are tools
because everything is a tool, right?

121
00:06:42.100 --> 00:06:46.500
Okay so, methodologies can be circular or
they can be waterfall.

122
00:06:46.500 --> 00:06:49.780
And what you're seeing on the left-hand
side of the screen is the model that we're

123
00:06:49.780 --> 00:06:53.840
gonna be doing a lot of work with in
future sessions, called the DMAIC model.

124
00:06:53.840 --> 00:06:57.860
And I'm gonna begin explaining those
phases of that model a little bit later.

125
00:06:57.860 --> 00:07:02.620
However, now what I want you to
think of is that the DMAIC model

126
00:07:02.620 --> 00:07:04.630
could be handled either way.

127
00:07:04.630 --> 00:07:08.240
In Six Sigma environments,
where it's just Six Sigma,

128
00:07:08.240 --> 00:07:11.660
most of the time the DMAIC model
is handled in a waterfall fashion.

129
00:07:11.660 --> 00:07:15.235
And what that means is phase one
has to be completely done before

130
00:07:15.235 --> 00:07:16.389
you go to phase two.

131
00:07:16.389 --> 00:07:20.063
And phase two has to be completely
done before you go to phase three.

132
00:07:20.063 --> 00:07:21.744
Now in the circular model,

133
00:07:21.744 --> 00:07:26.530
it's the same model that Lean Six Sigma
uses as far as the categories.

134
00:07:26.530 --> 00:07:30.740
But it's circular, because typically
you have a project manager

135
00:07:30.740 --> 00:07:33.450
who's looking at that
process from cradle to grave.

136
00:07:33.450 --> 00:07:36.690
So they're sort of managing
it from define until control.

137
00:07:36.690 --> 00:07:41.560
So if for example, they have to go back
a step, the world is not gonna fall apart,

138
00:07:41.560 --> 00:07:43.410
certainly not the idea.

139
00:07:43.410 --> 00:07:45.610
I wanna finish define and go to measure.

140
00:07:45.610 --> 00:07:48.690
But if I had to back up and
go to define, it's no big deal.

141
00:07:48.690 --> 00:07:51.774
Whereas in the waterfall method,
there could be different departments.

142
00:07:51.774 --> 00:07:55.775
Because remember we had mentioned
in other sessions that Six Sigma

143
00:07:55.775 --> 00:07:57.567
projects are huge projects.

144
00:07:57.567 --> 00:08:02.172
The minimum 250,000 Of make save or
avoid spending,

145
00:08:02.172 --> 00:08:07.090
sometimes the projects are two or
three years long, right?

146
00:08:07.090 --> 00:08:09.770
So the same department that
worked on define might not

147
00:08:09.770 --> 00:08:12.570
be the same department
that worked on measure.

148
00:08:12.570 --> 00:08:15.540
And so it's very,
very important that I wrap it up.

149
00:08:15.540 --> 00:08:19.260
So the leadership might be in define
to decide what the problem is.

150
00:08:19.260 --> 00:08:23.430
Then they might pass that off to someone
like auditors to go out and measure.

151
00:08:23.430 --> 00:08:26.390
What's the true current as is
picture of where we are today?

152
00:08:26.390 --> 00:08:29.826
>> Or there could be an acquisition for
your company and the new owners, and

153
00:08:29.826 --> 00:08:33.000
the problems still exists even
though it's new management.

154
00:08:33.000 --> 00:08:38.520
>> Exactly, exactly, so it's really,
really important that you do these steps,

155
00:08:38.520 --> 00:08:40.950
because you might not even be
involved in the next step.

156
00:08:40.950 --> 00:08:45.570
And that's the purpose for waterfall,
when you hear waterfall methodology.

157
00:08:45.570 --> 00:08:50.170
A lot of compliance issues, like if you've
been zinged for a compliance issue,

158
00:08:50.170 --> 00:08:54.310
you actually wanna see a waterfall method,
they wanna see what was your logic.

159
00:08:54.310 --> 00:08:57.050
What did you do first step,
what did you do second step,

160
00:08:57.050 --> 00:08:58.700
what did you do third step.

161
00:08:58.700 --> 00:09:02.700
In Lean Six Sigma, because you're taking
smaller projects, the person in charge of

162
00:09:02.700 --> 00:09:08.370
the process improvement project is
typically in charge of the entire thing.

163
00:09:08.370 --> 00:09:11.660
And that's why, like I said,
it's okay if you have to move backwards.

164
00:09:11.660 --> 00:09:15.340
You don't want to, I mean,
it's not the idea.

165
00:09:15.340 --> 00:09:19.330
But you certainly can do that without
hurting the project in any way.

166
00:09:19.330 --> 00:09:22.690
So, if you remember the PDCA,

167
00:09:22.690 --> 00:09:28.070
here's an example of PDCA in
that waterfall method, right?

168
00:09:28.070 --> 00:09:32.106
We're gonna plan, we're gonna do,
we're gonna check if we achieved our goal.

169
00:09:32.106 --> 00:09:33.127
>> We can continue.

170
00:09:33.127 --> 00:09:36.700
>> We can continue and
if we don't we go back up to plan, right?

171
00:09:36.700 --> 00:09:38.810
So that's just an example of Water Fall.

172
00:09:38.810 --> 00:09:42.140
But you hear that term a lot,
especially on exams.

173
00:09:42.140 --> 00:09:45.080
Sometimes it's just
thrown into the question.

174
00:09:45.080 --> 00:09:50.610
And when you're reading that question,
if it's asking something,

175
00:09:50.610 --> 00:09:53.640
you wanna think, well they're
thinking in a waterfall context or

176
00:09:53.640 --> 00:09:55.120
they're thinking in circular context.

177
00:09:55.120 --> 00:10:00.130
So it might make your answer
differ on the test if you

178
00:10:00.130 --> 00:10:02.270
kind of understand the example
that they're talking about.

179
00:10:03.922 --> 00:10:06.860
So here's Plan, Do, Check,
Act as a circular model.

180
00:10:08.040 --> 00:10:13.690
And Plan, Do, Check, Act actually,
it's handled as a waterfall

181
00:10:13.690 --> 00:10:18.050
method in a lot of companies, but
I think it probably really was circular.

182
00:10:18.050 --> 00:10:19.719
It was probably ahead of its time.

183
00:10:22.402 --> 00:10:26.690
And again, why it makes a difference is
because I might not be the person that's

184
00:10:26.690 --> 00:10:28.546
working on each step of the model.

185
00:10:28.546 --> 00:10:31.897
>> Okay.
>> So I wanna make absolutely sure,

186
00:10:31.897 --> 00:10:34.810
that if I need to wrap things up.

187
00:10:34.810 --> 00:10:39.230
Now in the DMAIC world, they actually
have things called toll gates.

188
00:10:39.230 --> 00:10:43.690
And so in between those phases there might
be a toll gate review that says are you

189
00:10:43.690 --> 00:10:47.626
sure you did everything that you said
you were gonna do in that phase?

190
00:10:49.861 --> 00:10:53.453
And this being the steps are completed
before you move to the next phase that

191
00:10:53.453 --> 00:10:56.080
would be an example of waterfall.

192
00:10:56.080 --> 00:10:58.396
Now, when we're looking at,

193
00:10:58.396 --> 00:11:03.664
this is another concept in Lean Six Sigma,
is value versus non value.

194
00:11:03.664 --> 00:11:07.020
So one big concept is
structured brainstorming.

195
00:11:07.020 --> 00:11:10.290
And we said that's where they
start with the affinity diagram.

196
00:11:10.290 --> 00:11:15.030
One basic concept is am I going to handle
this project in a waterfall method or

197
00:11:15.030 --> 00:11:16.500
in a circular method?

198
00:11:16.500 --> 00:11:18.770
Keeping in mind that sometimes
you don't have a choice,

199
00:11:18.770 --> 00:11:22.820
because if it's compliance, they might
wanna see a waterfall method, right?

200
00:11:22.820 --> 00:11:27.610
Another big concept is this value
added versus non value added.

201
00:11:27.610 --> 00:11:30.938
And unfortunately it's
a bit of a sticky wicket.

202
00:11:30.938 --> 00:11:34.871
And the reason is because I'm saying
something is non value added,

203
00:11:34.871 --> 00:11:39.080
even though that is the words that
we're taught to use in Lean Six Sigma,

204
00:11:39.080 --> 00:11:42.945
all it means is that particular
activity doesn't have anything to

205
00:11:42.945 --> 00:11:46.858
do with the process I'm working on,
that I'm trying to improve.

206
00:11:46.858 --> 00:11:49.167
>> Okay
>> So it might be a nice to do thing,

207
00:11:49.167 --> 00:11:51.362
that could be a non-value thing.

208
00:11:51.362 --> 00:11:56.360
It might be something that's even
compliance, for example in this case.

209
00:11:56.360 --> 00:12:01.130
It could be anything that doesn't
directly impact the project, product, or

210
00:12:01.130 --> 00:12:02.880
service going out the door.

211
00:12:02.880 --> 00:12:07.358
So a lot of times when you have
value versus non-value discussions,

212
00:12:07.358 --> 00:12:11.270
the non-value added might
be someone's entire job.

213
00:12:11.270 --> 00:12:12.510
But it is necessary.

214
00:12:12.510 --> 00:12:17.280
It is important to the company,

215
00:12:17.280 --> 00:12:21.780
it's just not important to the particular
process that you're trying to improve.

216
00:12:21.780 --> 00:12:24.130
>> So would you say if I were
working on a process and

217
00:12:24.130 --> 00:12:28.860
perhaps were focusing more attention
onto a certain department or process.

218
00:12:28.860 --> 00:12:33.370
And I found something that hadn't
been flagged or noticed before, but

219
00:12:33.370 --> 00:12:36.210
needed to be taken care of,
would that fall under that category?

220
00:12:36.210 --> 00:12:40.360
>> Absolutely and there are some
things that are really non-value added

221
00:12:40.360 --> 00:12:44.020
period that you just wanna smite,
you just wanna get rid of them.

222
00:12:44.020 --> 00:12:46.710
But a lot of non-value added activities

223
00:12:46.710 --> 00:12:49.460
are just ones that don't contribute
directly to that process.

224
00:12:49.460 --> 00:12:51.370
But all of those would
fall under that umbrella.

225
00:12:51.370 --> 00:12:53.955
And I think that even
makes it more confusing,

226
00:12:53.955 --> 00:12:56.949
because I'm looking at eliminating waste,
right?

227
00:12:56.949 --> 00:12:59.420
And sometimes waste is waste.

228
00:12:59.420 --> 00:13:01.070
We shouldn't even be doing it.

229
00:13:01.070 --> 00:13:05.400
But sometimes we're labeling
it as non-value or waste,

230
00:13:05.400 --> 00:13:07.400
which is the other word that they use.

231
00:13:07.400 --> 00:13:10.730
But all I'm saying is not for
what I'm working on.

232
00:13:10.730 --> 00:13:11.836
So I'm just not gonna think about it.

233
00:13:11.836 --> 00:13:14.566
[CROSSTALK]
>> Maybe it aligns with my company core

234
00:13:14.566 --> 00:13:18.619
values, but it isn't monetarily
associated to this project.

235
00:13:18.619 --> 00:13:20.577
>> Exactly, exactly, perfect.

236
00:13:20.577 --> 00:13:22.630
>> [LAUGH]
>> No, like I said,

237
00:13:22.630 --> 00:13:27.518
it's a sticky wicket because
sometimes one of the companies I

238
00:13:27.518 --> 00:13:32.227
worked with labeled the HR Department
as necessary waste.

239
00:13:32.227 --> 00:13:33.322
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH].

240
00:13:33.322 --> 00:13:34.566
>> So it doesn't make you feel good.

241
00:13:34.566 --> 00:13:38.239
So once you get those value
added versus non-value added.

242
00:13:38.239 --> 00:13:40.954
And so here's some other thoughts.

243
00:13:40.954 --> 00:13:44.590
This is another way,
just another way to look at it, okay?

244
00:13:44.590 --> 00:13:48.080
On the value-added side, the customer's
willing to pay for it, okay?

245
00:13:48.080 --> 00:13:52.070
Because, if I come up with a great idea
but my customer doesn't think it's.

246
00:13:52.070 --> 00:13:54.400
And that's how we know if
the customer thinks it's a good idea,

247
00:13:54.400 --> 00:13:55.880
if they're willing to fund it, right?

248
00:13:56.920 --> 00:13:59.038
Actually transforms a product or service.

249
00:13:59.038 --> 00:14:02.810
So a value-added, it makes that product or
service better, faster,

250
00:14:02.810 --> 00:14:06.800
more cost-effective, keeping in mind
one decision is not to do that.

251
00:14:06.800 --> 00:14:10.870
Sometimes it's too expensive to make
something better or faster, right?

252
00:14:10.870 --> 00:14:12.070
It's not cost effective.

253
00:14:13.160 --> 00:14:17.460
Done correctly the first time,
now that's a real value-added thing.

254
00:14:17.460 --> 00:14:22.090
If I can do something and I've built
in enough control so that that activity

255
00:14:22.090 --> 00:14:26.090
happens and it's always happening
correctly, definitely value-added.

256
00:14:26.090 --> 00:14:30.655
And some other ideas of non value-added
stuff, keeping in mind sometimes non

257
00:14:30.655 --> 00:14:35.024
value-added only means that it's not
pertinent to what I'm working on.

258
00:14:35.024 --> 00:14:38.630
It consumes resources without
creating any kind of customer value.

259
00:14:38.630 --> 00:14:42.830
So I'm basically doing busy work and
sometimes I don't even know it's busy work

260
00:14:42.830 --> 00:14:46.380
and that's why it's important to
always be looking at that stuff.

261
00:14:46.380 --> 00:14:48.790
It might just be a report we've
always done on Friday and

262
00:14:48.790 --> 00:14:50.960
no one's reading it, right?

263
00:14:50.960 --> 00:14:55.380
Low percentage of the time work
is complete with accuracy.

264
00:14:55.380 --> 00:14:57.790
So, kinda just the flip side of that.

265
00:14:57.790 --> 00:15:01.867
So just other ways of looking
at value versus non value-added.

266
00:15:01.867 --> 00:15:07.120
And it requires a lot of extra time, or
effort, or resources, anything like that.

267
00:15:07.120 --> 00:15:10.800
So if you're seeing something in
your company where there's two or

268
00:15:10.800 --> 00:15:13.340
three people doing something
that one person could do.

269
00:15:13.340 --> 00:15:14.260
>> Over checking.

270
00:15:14.260 --> 00:15:16.470
>> Over checking is a perfect example.

271
00:15:16.470 --> 00:15:20.860
I do wanna point out that in the old days,
Lean,

272
00:15:20.860 --> 00:15:25.810
in the 1980s, got a bad rap for
eliminating people.

273
00:15:25.810 --> 00:15:28.700
Because Lean as one of their
tools was automation, and

274
00:15:28.700 --> 00:15:31.210
so some people did lose their jobs.

275
00:15:31.210 --> 00:15:35.850
The newer, Leaner Six Sigma is certainly
what we promote at our company when we go

276
00:15:35.850 --> 00:15:40.930
into companies, is that you're not trying
to eliminate resources, human resources.

277
00:15:40.930 --> 00:15:43.920
What you're trying to do is make sure
they're working on meaningful work.

278
00:15:43.920 --> 00:15:48.465
So we tell people, even when they call us,
that Lean Six Sigma now means that you're

279
00:15:48.465 --> 00:15:52.837
just gonna take that resource and put them
on more meaningful work as opposed to,

280
00:15:52.837 --> 00:15:53.562
>> So it's the best use.

281
00:15:53.562 --> 00:15:55.358
>> Yeah, [LAUGH] and it is big.

282
00:15:55.358 --> 00:15:59.434
I mean, Okay, so,
lean's about removing waste, and so

283
00:15:59.434 --> 00:16:04.261
a way of looking at that, in another
session we talked about tact time

284
00:16:04.261 --> 00:16:10.070
being the time of the customer needs
the product or the service, right?

285
00:16:10.070 --> 00:16:15.260
I can look at something simple instead
of making it complicated, and I can

286
00:16:15.260 --> 00:16:20.430
say this is where the request comes in,
and this is where the delivery goes out.

287
00:16:20.430 --> 00:16:22.620
What are the things
that happen in between?

288
00:16:22.620 --> 00:16:26.070
And once again,
back to that value versus non-value,

289
00:16:26.070 --> 00:16:28.280
anything that happens in
between the request and

290
00:16:28.280 --> 00:16:32.490
the deliverable, that doesn't stop- like,
if I took that out of the picture,

291
00:16:32.490 --> 00:16:36.510
it would still get delivered, then I'm
gonna call that non-value added or waste.

292
00:16:36.510 --> 00:16:38.160
But I'm not getting rid of it,
necessarily.

293
00:16:38.160 --> 00:16:40.260
Sometimes, I am, a lot of times I am.

294
00:16:40.260 --> 00:16:42.250
>> And I'm sure it's customer-dependent,
as well.

295
00:16:42.250 --> 00:16:44.530
>> Sure, absolutely, absolutely.

296
00:16:46.160 --> 00:16:49.240
So, now I wanna spend a little
bit of time talking about

297
00:16:49.240 --> 00:16:52.370
the Lean Six Sigma Principles.

298
00:16:52.370 --> 00:16:57.060
What are the reasons I think this is
a huge thing to talk about is, if you get

299
00:16:58.380 --> 00:17:01.630
familiar with the principles, you'll be
able to answer the questions on the exam.

300
00:17:01.630 --> 00:17:04.600
Because a lot of times, the exam,
they are asking you something.

301
00:17:04.600 --> 00:17:08.080
And you go, well, I know one of the things
that's a principle in Lean Six Sigma,

302
00:17:08.080 --> 00:17:11.420
and that goes against the principle,
so that one's going to be false.

303
00:17:11.420 --> 00:17:15.333
So, getting to know the basic
principles of Lean Six Sigma is huge.

304
00:17:15.333 --> 00:17:18.523
There is, even though I'm gonna
go through these very quickly,

305
00:17:18.523 --> 00:17:21.553
this is another one of those
handouts in your student packet.

306
00:17:21.553 --> 00:17:22.081
>> Okay.

307
00:17:22.081 --> 00:17:25.590
>> Okay, and then it'll have
a little bit of explanation.

308
00:17:25.590 --> 00:17:29.010
Now, the first one is really huge,
customer focus.

309
00:17:29.010 --> 00:17:30.120
>> I see, it's in red.

310
00:17:30.120 --> 00:17:31.060
>> Yeah, it's in red.

311
00:17:31.060 --> 00:17:32.960
It's really, really important.

312
00:17:32.960 --> 00:17:39.430
And both Lean and Six Sigma, as separate
methodologies, saw the value in that.

313
00:17:39.430 --> 00:17:42.250
Lean Six Sigma puts it at the top.

314
00:17:42.250 --> 00:17:47.430
And the way I make sure that I've done
my job is that the customer's happy.

315
00:17:47.430 --> 00:17:51.731
Now, this used to be, if you go back and
look at some of the 1950s shows,

316
00:17:51.731 --> 00:17:56.440
Lucy and 50 and 60's shows like Lucy,
and Dick Van Dyke and

317
00:17:56.440 --> 00:17:59.220
some of those older television shows,
they were always saying that,

318
00:17:59.220 --> 00:18:02.370
the customers always right,
the customers always right.

319
00:18:02.370 --> 00:18:04.680
But we kind of lost that
as we moved forward.

320
00:18:04.680 --> 00:18:06.637
Now we're saying customer focus, but

321
00:18:06.637 --> 00:18:09.727
it's just another way of saying
the customers always right.

322
00:18:09.727 --> 00:18:13.930
So, I wanna give you at least
what you think you want, right?

323
00:18:13.930 --> 00:18:17.160
And that's more important
than return on investment.

324
00:18:17.160 --> 00:18:19.590
Now, this will keep a lot of CEOs awake.

325
00:18:19.590 --> 00:18:23.630
And certainly, the assumption is that
if I give the customer what they want,

326
00:18:23.630 --> 00:18:25.690
then I'm gonna make the money that I need.

327
00:18:25.690 --> 00:18:30.620
But Lean Six Sigma puts customer focus,
and what the customer wants above return

328
00:18:30.620 --> 00:18:34.860
on investment, which means sometimes, I
have to give a little to keep my customer.

329
00:18:34.860 --> 00:18:37.570
So, data driven decisions,

330
00:18:37.570 --> 00:18:43.380
a data driven decision means I've got all
the facts before I make the decision.

331
00:18:43.380 --> 00:18:47.110
Now, in Lean Six Sigma,
I might have all the facts on paper, but

332
00:18:47.110 --> 00:18:50.610
I just knows something about my
costumer that you don't know.

333
00:18:50.610 --> 00:18:55.250
Maybe, I know they're going on vacation
next week, or something as silly as that.

334
00:18:55.250 --> 00:18:59.660
So, even though decisions are data driven,
Lean Six Sigma considers all the other

335
00:18:59.660 --> 00:19:04.338
factors as well, but-
>> Taking the quantification analysis and

336
00:19:04.338 --> 00:19:07.770
adding the [LAUGH] what's the other one?

337
00:19:07.770 --> 00:19:10.590
The quantification versus
the qualification?

338
00:19:10.590 --> 00:19:14.270
>> Yeah, absolutely, and
I mean, it's just, but

339
00:19:14.270 --> 00:19:18.200
I think one of the things that we want to
make sure that we don't get away from,

340
00:19:18.200 --> 00:19:23.500
is that a core principle is that I'm still
gonna make my decisions on the data.

341
00:19:23.500 --> 00:19:25.110
>> Okay.
>> I want to consider all that other

342
00:19:25.110 --> 00:19:28.050
stuff, because that's important,
and we know it's important.

343
00:19:28.050 --> 00:19:29.640
And in Six Sigma, it's just data.

344
00:19:29.640 --> 00:19:34.560
[LAUGH] But in Lean Six Sigma,
it's mostly data, there's not really a 50,

345
00:19:34.560 --> 00:19:37.620
50 blend, it's still data,
and then respect.

346
00:19:37.620 --> 00:19:40.690
And this is what I love
about Lean Six Sigma is that

347
00:19:40.690 --> 00:19:44.370
it goes of out its way to talk
about things like respect, and

348
00:19:44.370 --> 00:19:48.670
appreciating people for their gifts and
respecting our company time.

349
00:19:48.670 --> 00:19:52.300
It's a very ethical methodology.

350
00:19:52.300 --> 00:19:55.230
Results, and this is a big one,
because a lot of times,

351
00:19:55.230 --> 00:20:01.010
you'll hear people say things like
especially in Lean environments.

352
00:20:01.010 --> 00:20:03.700
It's more about the process, and it's not.

353
00:20:03.700 --> 00:20:07.180
Lean Six Sigma is about the results,
what I ended up with.

354
00:20:07.180 --> 00:20:10.570
And unfortunately, the best way to,
I shouldn't say unfortunately, but

355
00:20:10.570 --> 00:20:15.625
the way that we save results is by
talking about return on investment.

356
00:20:15.625 --> 00:20:18.860
What did you make me, save me or
avoid me spending, right?

357
00:20:18.860 --> 00:20:22.010
But results are very important, but you
will hear people in some of the people in

358
00:20:22.010 --> 00:20:23.800
Lean environments, it's about the process.

359
00:20:23.800 --> 00:20:29.510
It is, but if the process doesn't lead to
results, then it doesn't really matter.

360
00:20:29.510 --> 00:20:34.040
Accountability, and
that's another huge one is that lots of

361
00:20:34.040 --> 00:20:39.560
the tools in Lean Six Sigma have you
signing off, because what we found

362
00:20:39.560 --> 00:20:43.530
out in a psychological sense,
is that when we sign contracts,

363
00:20:43.530 --> 00:20:46.880
when we check the lists,
we're just a lot more committed.

364
00:20:46.880 --> 00:20:50.300
And when my name is on a a metric,
so it says, a matrix rather,

365
00:20:50.300 --> 00:20:54.300
that says I'm responsible for this task,
probably more likely to do it.

366
00:20:54.300 --> 00:20:57.120
So, a lot of accountability.

367
00:20:57.120 --> 00:21:02.760
We spent about two decades in a society
where we were, okay, this is confidential.

368
00:21:02.760 --> 00:21:03.840
Lean's going the other way.

369
00:21:03.840 --> 00:21:06.750
We should have things out in the open.

370
00:21:06.750 --> 00:21:10.700
If we have too many confidential things,
people don't have accountability.

371
00:21:10.700 --> 00:21:13.110
People get confused, cuz they think
all kinds of things are going on.

372
00:21:13.110 --> 00:21:16.670
So, Lean Six Sigma's on
the other side of the continuum.

373
00:21:16.670 --> 00:21:18.980
No, we will need to know.

374
00:21:18.980 --> 00:21:23.620
We need to take personal accountability,
department accountability, customer, and

375
00:21:23.620 --> 00:21:27.620
that might even morph over into
social responsibility-type things.

376
00:21:27.620 --> 00:21:29.130
And then, excellence.

377
00:21:29.130 --> 00:21:32.550
And what I love about that is,
excellence is so

378
00:21:32.550 --> 00:21:36.480
much different than, I'm gonna do a good
job, I'm gonna do what's expected of me.

379
00:21:36.480 --> 00:21:40.480
Lean Six Sigma really promotes
that you go one step beyond, and

380
00:21:40.480 --> 00:21:43.730
that one step beyond is often
referred to as a delighter.

381
00:21:43.730 --> 00:21:48.560
And I love that word, that it's this
technical program, and that, delighters.

382
00:21:48.560 --> 00:21:50.380
We want to provide delighters.

383
00:21:50.380 --> 00:21:55.091
And what delighters mean is that we kind
of go above what we were told that we had

384
00:21:55.091 --> 00:21:56.766
to do to make it excellent.

385
00:21:58.428 --> 00:22:03.700
So, principle one, customer focus,

It's, kind of keep in mind,

00:27:13.790 --> 00:27:16.730
So, Standard Work, and

But all Standard Work is, is sort of

00:27:28.370 --> 00:27:30.900

When you're thinking about standards,

00:27:34.370 --> 00:27:37.880

00:27:37.880 --> 00:27:42.380
When they say Standard Work, I'm just

00:27:42.380 --> 00:27:43.830

00:27:43.830 --> 00:27:46.100

00:27:46.100 --> 00:27:48.440

00:27:54.030 --> 00:27:57.750
But Standard Work is just a documentation

00:27:57.750 --> 00:28:00.830
And if you find a better way to do it

00:28:00.830 --> 00:28:03.210

Visual Management, Visual Management

I can go and

Rapid improvement events in the service

So if you kinda think

Lean takes standard work super seriously,

581
00:31:50.052 --> 00:31:53.176
Why Visual Management such

582
00:31:53.176 --> 00:31:57.615
Is that in a project, I do the project and

00:31:57.615 --> 00:32:02.307

A project a lot of times starts, ends,

00:32:13.660 --> 00:32:17.790

00:32:19.710 --> 00:32:23.190
Well, a great way to do that
is visual management, right?

591
00:32:23.190 --> 00:32:24.730
Again, trash goes here.

592
00:32:24.730 --> 00:32:26.010
Go through this store.

593
00:32:26.010 --> 00:32:27.360
Exit here, right?

594
00:32:29.410 --> 00:32:35.020
So Lean Six Sigma projects
have areas of focus and

595
00:32:35.020 --> 00:32:39.340
obviously, cuz we've been saying this,
better faster more cost effective.

596
00:32:39.340 --> 00:32:40.640
Cost reduction.

597
00:32:40.640 --> 00:32:42.350
This is just another way of saying them.

598
00:32:42.350 --> 00:32:45.230
But on the exam, it might say stuff,

599
00:32:45.230 --> 00:32:50.690
it might use words instead of cost
reduction, it might use overhead.

600
00:32:50.690 --> 00:32:52.490
It might use scrap or rework.

601
00:32:52.490 --> 00:32:56.981
So, even though the idea is to make
something more cost effective.

602
00:32:56.981 --> 00:32:59.915
On these types of exams,
you'll wanna watch for

603
00:32:59.915 --> 00:33:04.064
those other kinds of words that
because if they say better, faster,

604
00:33:04.064 --> 00:33:06.043
more cost effective-
>> Key words.

605
00:33:06.043 --> 00:33:07.710
>> Yeah, keywords.

606
00:33:07.710 --> 00:33:12.080
And rework is gonna cost you money, right?

607
00:33:12.080 --> 00:33:16.110
So just kind of, cost avoidance,
when we're thinking cost avoidance.

608
00:33:16.110 --> 00:33:19.620
Think about regulatory expenses,
capital equipment needs,

609
00:33:19.620 --> 00:33:23.800
those kind of things, capacity increase.

610
00:33:23.800 --> 00:33:27.830
These are just words that, sometimes
questions on these type of exams,

611
00:33:27.830 --> 00:33:31.510
will use a scenario instead of the word
better, faster, more cost-effective.

612
00:33:31.510 --> 00:33:32.990
They're gonna use other words.

613
00:33:32.990 --> 00:33:35.630
So, you just kinda wanna
keep that in mind.

614
00:33:35.630 --> 00:33:37.957
And like even customer satisfaction,

615
00:33:37.957 --> 00:33:41.790
they might be talking about
on-time delivery or pricing.

616
00:33:41.790 --> 00:33:45.139
And health and safety, they might be
talking about ergonomics, right, and

617
00:33:45.139 --> 00:33:47.160
they might not use the word health and
safety.

618
00:33:47.160 --> 00:33:48.960
So just kinda keep that in mind.

619
00:33:48.960 --> 00:33:49.620
And finally, and

620
00:33:49.620 --> 00:33:52.690
I'm not sure you guys can see that
cuz it's at the bottom of the slide.

621
00:33:52.690 --> 00:33:56.870
Flow is a big deal and it's covered
a lot in the Yellow Belt training.

622
00:33:56.870 --> 00:34:01.620
And that's process speed,
travel distance, on time delivery.

623
00:34:01.620 --> 00:34:05.730
So I think the biggest point that I
wanna make on that is, it is better,

624
00:34:05.730 --> 00:34:07.870
faster, and more cost effective.

625
00:34:07.870 --> 00:34:11.560
And now, we're adding a lot of times,
health and safety.

626
00:34:11.560 --> 00:34:15.050
So it's better, faster and
more cost effective plus be safe.

627
00:34:15.050 --> 00:34:17.680
Be healthy,
a lot of companies are adding that on.

628
00:34:17.680 --> 00:34:22.200
But and if they use those words, it
would be so much leaner, but they don't.

629
00:34:22.200 --> 00:34:25.070
I mean a lot of times instead
of saying something like,

630
00:34:25.070 --> 00:34:28.950
I wanna make something faster,
I want to improve cycle time, right?

631
00:34:28.950 --> 00:34:32.410
So just be listening for different
ways of capturing that information.

632
00:34:33.960 --> 00:34:38.960
So, this schematic is also
included in your student pack.

633
00:34:38.960 --> 00:34:43.020
It's a little bit more in depth than
the one you're seeing here on the screen.

634
00:34:43.020 --> 00:34:48.790
And this is just, this is really more
to help people that are Lean Six Sigma,

635
00:34:48.790 --> 00:34:51.360
but they're going into a lean environment.

636
00:34:51.360 --> 00:34:54.180
So it's kind of a,
it's actually kind of bonus material.

637
00:34:54.180 --> 00:34:57.170
So I'm certified as a Lean Six Sigma
person, but I'm gonna go and

638
00:34:57.170 --> 00:35:00.070
work in an environment
that's primary Lean.

639
00:35:00.070 --> 00:35:02.300
Or I'm certified as
a Lean Six Sigma person,

640
00:35:02.300 --> 00:35:05.070
but I'm gonna go into
an environment that's Six Sigma.

641
00:35:05.070 --> 00:35:07.979
This is happening all the time
throughout our nation because,

642
00:35:09.060 --> 00:35:12.680
people are seeing the value of
Lean Six Sigma certification, but

643
00:35:12.680 --> 00:35:14.900
their company might be just Six Sigma or
Lean.

644
00:35:14.900 --> 00:35:19.370
And if you read ads in the newspaper
right now, that dates me, right?

645
00:35:19.370 --> 00:35:24.740
If you read ads on the internet,
if you read electronic ads right now,

646
00:35:24.740 --> 00:35:27.790
even if they're asking for
a Lean person or a Six Sigma person,

647
00:35:27.790 --> 00:35:31.080
somewhere in there they're saying
must be familiar with the other one.

648
00:35:31.080 --> 00:35:35.110
So, it's not uncommon that as
a Lean Six Sigma person they may have

649
00:35:35.110 --> 00:35:40.110
been attracted to you,
because you have the other side of that.

650
00:35:40.110 --> 00:35:42.710
So there's things like that,
they're just sort of bonus material.

651
00:35:44.030 --> 00:35:48.310
Another term that's used quite
often is something called Kaizen.

652
00:35:48.310 --> 00:35:51.920
And a lot of times,
that refers to a rapid improvement event.

653
00:35:51.920 --> 00:35:55.660
So they might say Kaizen,
or rapid improvement event.

654
00:35:55.660 --> 00:36:00.470
And what that is, is they're
doing a process improvement, but

655
00:36:00.470 --> 00:36:03.430
it needs to be done quickly
just like the name implies.

656
00:36:03.430 --> 00:36:06.390
And they still have to use
a model to do that, so

657
00:36:06.390 --> 00:36:10.380
what are the models that we've
talked about already a lot is PDCA.

658
00:36:10.380 --> 00:36:15.130
And PDCA is, especially if the problem's
not too difficult to solve,

659
00:36:15.130 --> 00:36:18.820
A PDCA following that
methodology is really good.

660
00:36:18.820 --> 00:36:22.740
They can also use DMAIC which we're
gonna be covering in other sessions.

661
00:36:22.740 --> 00:36:25.140
If the problem's kind of complicated and

662
00:36:25.140 --> 00:36:28.400
then there's a separate model called
SCORE which we'll be covering on the next

663
00:36:28.400 --> 00:36:33.248
session, that's designed just for
rapid improvement events.

664
00:36:33.248 --> 00:36:40.910
So, a popular term in Lean Six Sigma is
Kaizen event or rapid improvement event.

665
00:36:40.910 --> 00:36:44.620
And all that means is that in
a very finite period of time,

666
00:36:44.620 --> 00:36:46.840
we have to finish up something, right?

667
00:36:46.840 --> 00:36:50.810
On manufacturing, you can do it in
real time on the manufacturing floor.

668
00:36:50.810 --> 00:36:52.690
When you're looking at service or

669
00:36:52.690 --> 00:36:56.780
transaction, basically anything that's
non-manufacturing, when you're doing

670
00:36:56.780 --> 00:37:02.210
a rapid improvement event, you're trying
to come up with a super good project plan.

671
00:37:02.210 --> 00:37:03.680
So that you can hire some women or

672
00:37:03.680 --> 00:37:07.620
get someone else in the company
to evoke the plan, right?

673
00:37:07.620 --> 00:37:09.710
So all the people are coming together and
they're saying, well,

674
00:37:09.710 --> 00:37:12.690
this is the resources I'll dedicate,
this is the time.

675
00:37:12.690 --> 00:37:16.060
I'm giving you pre-approval so if you
come into the rapid improvement event,

676
00:37:16.060 --> 00:37:18.610
you're not running around going,
is this okay?

677
00:37:18.610 --> 00:37:19.620
>> Right.

678
00:37:19.620 --> 00:37:24.660
>> So the last thing that we're gonna
cover is some popular facilitation tools.

679
00:37:24.660 --> 00:37:26.857
So any other models
that you're working on,

680
00:37:26.857 --> 00:37:29.940
you're gonna still have to work
with people no matter what.

681
00:37:29.940 --> 00:37:33.855
Now, you might be the only
person on your team.

682
00:37:33.855 --> 00:37:35.891
But you're gonna have to reach out and
get information.

683
00:37:35.891 --> 00:37:38.769
The more information that you get,
the better, right?

684
00:37:38.769 --> 00:37:42.911
And so, a lot times the ways you can do
that is by using facilitation tools and

685
00:37:42.911 --> 00:37:47.025
remember, Lean Six Sigma
over-uses that word, tools, right?

686
00:37:47.025 --> 00:37:49.895
So, some popular ones are brainstorming,
and

687
00:37:49.895 --> 00:37:53.700
that's one of the things that we talked
about earlier with the affinity diagram.

688
00:37:53.700 --> 00:37:57.170
And just as a reminder, because again,

689
00:37:57.170 --> 00:38:00.930
this is something that's hit a lot
on the exams about brainstorming.

690
00:38:00.930 --> 00:38:03.050
And so there's some bullets there.

691
00:38:03.050 --> 00:38:06.190
But you wanna ask open ended questions.

692
00:38:06.190 --> 00:38:10.670
My suggestion earlier, if you can get
someone to be the person that's writing on

693
00:38:10.670 --> 00:38:13.320
the flip chart, that if you can
get someone who knows nothing

694
00:38:13.320 --> 00:38:16.670
about what you're doing, then they're
less likely to put judgment in it.

695
00:38:16.670 --> 00:38:19.650
Because typically, you're supposed
to just put anything on the board.

696
00:38:19.650 --> 00:38:21.610
You wanna focus.

697
00:38:21.610 --> 00:38:22.614
You wanna stay loose.

698
00:38:22.614 --> 00:38:25.286
You wanna put, later,
you can combine things.

699
00:38:25.286 --> 00:38:28.360
So if somebody says something that's
repetitive, you just wanna go with it.

700
00:38:30.010 --> 00:38:34.920
So multi-voting is another one
that's very, very popular.

701
00:38:34.920 --> 00:38:39.950
You always, no matter what model you're
working on ultimately you wanna give

702
00:38:39.950 --> 00:38:42.500
your go-to person three solutions.

703
00:38:42.500 --> 00:38:45.424
And the reason you wanna do that is
because that gets their buy-in and

704
00:38:45.424 --> 00:38:47.620
they're picking the solution, right?

705
00:38:47.620 --> 00:38:52.010
But sometimes you get into
a situation where there are a ton

706
00:38:52.010 --> 00:38:53.410
of decisions that could be made.

707
00:38:53.410 --> 00:38:55.590
Instead of just having one or
two and struggling for

708
00:38:55.590 --> 00:38:58.510
that third one,
you just have a lot of things going on.

709
00:38:58.510 --> 00:39:01.410
So you can use a system
called multi-voting.

710
00:39:01.410 --> 00:39:06.115
And what would happen there is,
let's say the scenario would be,

711
00:39:06.115 --> 00:39:10.065
you have eight directions you
could go in for your department.

712
00:39:10.065 --> 00:39:12.435
And you're trying to get an idea
on what we should work on first.

713
00:39:12.435 --> 00:39:15.585
There's eight things we really wanna do
and they're all very, very important.

714
00:39:15.585 --> 00:39:17.925
But what should we be working on first?

715
00:39:17.925 --> 00:39:21.460
So let's say I have 25
people in my department.

716
00:39:21.460 --> 00:39:25.280
And I wanna get that consensus,
I wanna get that buy-in.

717
00:39:25.280 --> 00:39:30.740
So first time around with my eight themes,
I might say you have three votes, right?

718
00:39:30.740 --> 00:39:35.360
Now I'm hoping if you have three votes,
some of that stuff's gonna fall off.

719
00:39:35.360 --> 00:39:40.080
Even if it has only one vote, you have
to stop and ask the person to explain,

720
00:39:40.080 --> 00:39:43.490
because they might be giving you
information that no one considers.

721
00:39:43.490 --> 00:39:46.870
>> Insight, yeah, but only if they have-
>> Exactly, but

722
00:39:46.870 --> 00:39:50.180
if no one chooses that one,
you can just cross that one off the list.

723
00:39:50.180 --> 00:39:53.812
It's still nice to say, is it okay
if I take this off the list, right?

724
00:39:53.812 --> 00:39:55.263
So then the next time around,

725
00:39:55.263 --> 00:39:58.295
the theory is that you'd have
smaller things to choose from.

726
00:39:58.295 --> 00:40:00.526
And so now, everyone has two votes, right?

727
00:40:00.526 --> 00:40:03.140
And it just keeps going until
you get down to the one vote.

728
00:40:03.140 --> 00:40:06.010
And there's no really specific formula.

729
00:40:06.010 --> 00:40:09.870
It's just a way for, especially if you
have a mixed group of supervisors and

730
00:40:09.870 --> 00:40:10.960
employees together.

731
00:40:10.960 --> 00:40:15.510
And people are kind of voting on the side
of maybe their superior or their coworker.

732
00:40:15.510 --> 00:40:17.020
It's a way everybody gets a voice.

733
00:40:17.020 --> 00:40:22.510
So multivoting,
it's a very simple way to get consensus.

734
00:40:22.510 --> 00:40:26.010
Usually before you start
a multivoting exercise,

735
00:40:26.010 --> 00:40:30.885
you wanna remind people that
we're a democratic society, and

736
00:40:30.885 --> 00:40:34.940
will everyone agree that whoever
gets the most votes, wins.

737
00:40:34.940 --> 00:40:37.625
And you get that buy-in first,
and it's kind of fun.

738
00:40:37.625 --> 00:40:40.100
Multivoting's a kind of fun way to do it.

739
00:40:40.100 --> 00:40:44.030
Now, nominal group technique is kind
of the same thing as multivoting.

740
00:40:44.030 --> 00:40:45.930
It's just secret.

741
00:40:45.930 --> 00:40:49.390
And, in the old days,
we used to sit around in a room and

742
00:40:49.390 --> 00:40:51.720
everybody would write
their choice on a sticky.

743
00:40:51.720 --> 00:40:54.605
And then we'd gather it up and
we'd put the sticky's on the board, right?

744
00:40:54.605 --> 00:40:58.270
But now, a lot of times, it's just an
email that goes out to everyone that just

745
00:40:58.270 --> 00:41:01.480
says, look, this is gonna be an aggregate.

746
00:41:01.480 --> 00:41:03.490
We're not gonna say who voted for what.

747
00:41:03.490 --> 00:41:06.748
But it's the same kind of thing,
like if you had two or three choices,

748
00:41:06.748 --> 00:41:07.919
what would you vote for?

749
00:41:10.102 --> 00:41:11.970
And these are just kind of the rules.

750
00:41:11.970 --> 00:41:13.990
This is another thing that's
in your student packet.

751
00:41:13.990 --> 00:41:17.593
You have a flyer that says,
popular facilitation tools,

752
00:41:17.593 --> 00:41:20.324
and it gives you the step-by-step rules.

753
00:41:20.324 --> 00:41:23.200
So you'll notice that some
of this seems kind of long.

754
00:41:23.200 --> 00:41:27.519
Well, no one expects you to memorize this,
but what you would want to know for

755
00:41:27.519 --> 00:41:32.037
the exam is what's the difference between
brainstorming, nominal group, and

756
00:41:32.037 --> 00:41:32.914
multivoting.

757
00:41:32.914 --> 00:41:34.440
That's what you would wanna know.

758
00:41:34.440 --> 00:41:36.510
But then if you actually wanted to do it,
again,

759
00:41:36.510 --> 00:41:39.610
you're sort of getting bonus
material in your student pack.

760
00:41:39.610 --> 00:41:41.911
Because if you're in a situation and
you wanna try it,

761
00:41:41.911 --> 00:41:44.122
you're gonna have
step-by-step instructions.

762
00:41:46.387 --> 00:41:49.074
And I think that leads me to the end.

763
00:41:49.074 --> 00:41:51.460
>> All right,
that was a lot of information we saw.

764
00:41:51.460 --> 00:41:53.740
We were able to look at
different methodologies and

765
00:41:53.740 --> 00:41:57.710
determine if we should choose
a waterfall or a circular.

766
00:41:57.710 --> 00:42:01.360
We looked at structured brainstorming,
such as our affinity diagram.

767
00:42:01.360 --> 00:42:03.960
We were able to look at
our six core principles.

768
00:42:03.960 --> 00:42:04.860
What else?

769
00:42:04.860 --> 00:42:07.970
Our popular concepts,
such as visual management.

770
00:42:07.970 --> 00:42:11.250
And then lastly,
we looked at popular facilitation tools,

771
00:42:11.250 --> 00:42:13.000
our favorite word her so far.

772
00:42:13.000 --> 00:42:15.620
So, definitely go back and re-watch this.

773
00:42:15.620 --> 00:42:18.980
I know we covered a lot, but
we have some really great information, and

774
00:42:18.980 --> 00:42:20.020
we have more headed your way.

775
00:42:20.020 --> 00:42:22.090
So don't go anywhere, get comfortable.

776
00:42:22.090 --> 00:42:24.950
We're gonna go ahead and sign off for
this particular episode, and

777
00:42:24.950 --> 00:42:28.250
I'll sign off as your host,
Cherokee Boose.

778
00:42:28.250 --> 00:42:32.092
>> And I am Dr. Terra Vanzant-Stern
with SSD Global Solutions.

779
00:42:32.092 --> 00:42:36.204
>> See you next time here at ITPRO.TV.

780
00:42:36.204 --> 00:42:41.944
>> [MUSIC]

781
00:42:41.944 --> 00:42:45.107
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: This show focuses on five important methodologies.  Particularly you will see the TYPICAL or STANDARD, DMAIC, PDCA, DFSS and KAIZEN models broken down. Dr. Terra Vanzant Stern emphasizes the significance of the DMAIC model, in which will be covered in depth in future shows within this series.

>> Well I'd like to go over to my

00:00:53.300 --> 00:00:56.000

And pretty much what I wanna do to make

a little more sense is just talk about
how we normally solve problems, and

Which are the DMAIC, PDCA,

and Kaizen which is rapid
improvement events.

24

Now we're going to be going in depth
in the DMAIC model and looking at each

one of those phases, because that's

26
00:01:26.758 --> 00:01:31.430
Over things that are related
to the DMAIC not the dollars

00:01:31.430 --> 00:01:34.051
>> That's a huge percentage there, so

28
00:01:34.051 --> 00:01:37.540
all right, pay attention [LAUGH]
>> Okay so, models and

29
00:01:37.540 --> 00:01:41.850
methodology sometimes are called
things like problem solving models.

30

Sometimes they're called
critical thinking models.

31

Sometimes they're called business models,
so it just don't let that get you

32
00:01:47.180 --> 00:01:49.516
confused, especially if you're
reading a test question.

00:01:49.516 --> 00:01:55.990
So lots of other names for models and

00:02:17.050 --> 00:02:21.990
This typical problem solving model may

00:02:21.990 --> 00:02:25.810
problem solving, structured

Sometimes they're just called business

48
00:02:46.910 --> 00:02:51.930
So the steps in typical problem solving
is that first we identify the problem and

00:02:51.930 --> 00:02:53.670
we come up with a problem statement.

00:02:53.670 --> 00:02:55.752
We say this is what's wrong, okay?

00:02:55.752 --> 00:03:02.071
And then the second thing we do, is we go

00:03:02.071 --> 00:03:05.569
And then after we brainstorm the solution
we pick one, and we say hey,

00:03:05.569 --> 00:03:08.829
that's the one that we wanna go with and
even when we're trying to

00:03:08.829 --> 00:03:12.550

55
00:03:12.550 --> 00:03:16.490
Okay well, here's all the things I

00:03:16.490 --> 00:03:20.610
Then the next step in typical problem
solving is that we go ahead and do it,

00:03:20.610 --> 00:03:23.080

00:03:23.080 --> 00:03:25.980
And then the final step,
which we miss a lot,

I mean a lot of times we don't even

00:03:29.180 --> 00:03:33.940

00:03:33.940 --> 00:03:36.461
In fact sometimes we even evaluate,

00:03:36.461 --> 00:03:39.558
But then we never go back and, [CROSSTALK]
>> I feel like I analyze, and

00:03:39.558 --> 00:03:43.630
I may even tend to over-analyze at times,

00:03:43.630 --> 00:03:46.953
If correct is considered part of that
step, I might not always go back and

00:03:47.996 --> 00:03:49.250
>> Exactly, exactly.

00:03:49.250 --> 00:03:53.540
And so, this is the way, and
this has been used for years, right?

00:03:53.540 --> 00:03:56.160

00:03:56.160 --> 00:03:58.890

00:03:58.890 --> 00:04:01.170
So the difference in the DMAIC model, and

00:04:01.170 --> 00:04:05.020
first I wanna point out, in Lean Six
Sigma, we're looking at the DMAIC model as

00:04:05.020 --> 00:04:09.720
a circular model whereas in Six Sigma,
they're looking at it as Waterfall, right?

00:04:09.720 --> 00:04:10.680
And just as a reminder,

74
00:04:10.680 --> 00:04:14.490
circular means if I do have to go

75
00:04:14.490 --> 00:04:17.950
And if I have to step back a step
It's not a really big deal.

76
00:04:17.950 --> 00:04:21.700
In Waterfall methods you always
finish one step before the next.

77
00:04:21.700 --> 00:04:27.500
But the dynamics in Six Sigma and
Lean Six Sigma are exactly the same.

78
00:04:27.500 --> 00:04:31.500
So in define, which is the first
step in normal problem solving or

79
00:04:31.500 --> 00:04:32.940
typical problem solving.

80
00:04:32.940 --> 00:04:34.860
We just say the problem and we're done.

81
00:04:36.360 --> 00:04:40.940
In the DMAIC model, in define we spend a
significant amount of time trying to make

00:04:40.940 --> 00:04:43.980
sure is that really the problem
that we wanna work on?

83
00:04:43.980 --> 00:04:46.800
We don't just say it and

00:04:46.800 --> 00:04:49.802
We don't make a statement and
then all of a sudden try to go out and

00:04:49.802 --> 00:04:52.145

00:04:52.145 --> 00:04:55.758
So the first step is that we spend a lot

the problem.

They don't necessarily have to agree,

00:05:01.025 --> 00:05:06.260

00:05:06.260 --> 00:05:10.894
Then the next step and this is not
something we do in typical problem

00:05:10.894 --> 00:05:15.218
solving is we get a clear as idea

00:05:15.218 --> 00:05:19.177
Now in typical problem solving we go
straight to brainstorming, we say, okay,

00:05:19.177 --> 00:05:21.625
here's the problem and
these are all the things,

94
00:05:21.625 --> 00:05:23.504
these are all of our options to fix it.

95
00:05:23.504 --> 00:05:27.807
In the DMAIC model once we

00:05:27.807 --> 00:05:31.100
then we say, okay what's going on now?

97
00:05:31.100 --> 00:05:33.670
Because the assumption is,

00:05:33.670 --> 00:05:37.820
if I know what's going on now I can

00:05:37.820 --> 00:05:41.120
So in analyze what I'm doing is I'm trying

00:05:41.120 --> 00:05:42.160
that way?

00:05:42.160 --> 00:05:44.830
What can I do to make that difference,

102
00:05:44.830 --> 00:05:48.150
So after I define,
I measure, and I analyze.

103
00:05:48.150 --> 00:05:51.640
I then come up with my
brainstorm list of solutions.

104
00:05:51.640 --> 00:05:54.850
So whereas in typical problem solving,
that's right off the bat.

105
00:05:54.850 --> 00:05:57.120
This is the problem,
this is what I'm gonna do.

106
00:05:57.120 --> 00:05:59.420
I define, I measure and I analyze.

107
00:05:59.420 --> 00:06:03.200
And what that buys me is, I don't have
anyone in the back of the room saying,

00:06:03.200 --> 00:06:04.980
we tried that last year and

Because I defined, I measured and

00:06:08.430 --> 00:06:12.550
And if I wanna try it again I'm gonna

00:06:12.550 --> 00:06:14.660
I'm not gonna have someone say,

112
00:06:14.660 --> 00:06:18.910
we don't have the resources,
we don't have the intellectual capital,

00:06:18.910 --> 00:06:23.510
because I know that because I defined,

00:06:24.530 --> 00:06:28.500
So the solutions I come up

00:06:28.500 --> 00:06:30.170

There's not gonna be any one offs there,

So then when I move into improve

00:07:03.850 --> 00:07:07.240
And then I can go to that last phase,
and this is never,

00:07:07.240 --> 00:07:11.630
well this is rarely appreciated

00:07:11.630 --> 00:07:13.750
Which is control, sustainability.

00:07:13.750 --> 00:07:18.480
How am I going to make this

00:07:18.480 --> 00:07:21.670
So the DMAIC problem solving model

00:07:21.670 --> 00:07:24.870
is just sort of capitalizes on

it says hey, let's make sure we've really

00:07:29.660 --> 00:07:33.520

I'm piloting my idea, I'm testing

I'm doing my project plan and WBS,

The reason why this is huge is,

DMAIC assumes there's already

The DMADV which is

And sometimes when they
