255
00:14:39.016 --> 00:14:41.886
That yeah, the velocity phases
of the model you're probably

256
00:14:41.886 --> 00:14:45.437
gonna have to get some help but
it's not like you can't do it, right.

257
00:14:45.437 --> 00:14:45.937
>> All right.

258
00:14:47.848 --> 00:14:52.430
>> So, if you were looking at
the difference between DMAIC and

259
00:14:52.430 --> 00:14:58.659
DMADV stressing, again, that even though
DMADV is just an example of design for

260
00:14:58.659 --> 00:15:02.870
Six Sigma and
there's hundreds of other examples.

261
00:15:02.870 --> 00:15:04.500
This is what most people use.

262
00:15:04.500 --> 00:15:06.605
They don't even realize
there are other models.

263
00:15:06.605 --> 00:15:07.286
>> Okay
>> So if you

264
00:15:07.286 --> 00:15:10.990
were doing a comparison
between these two things.

265
00:15:12.020 --> 00:15:16.220
In the DMAIC, we're defining a business
process, we're measuring the current

266
00:15:16.220 --> 00:15:20.380
process, we're trying to figure out what's
the root cause and we're trying to figure

267
00:15:20.380 --> 00:15:24.030
out what kind of improvements can be
done to reduce the defects, right.

268
00:15:24.030 --> 00:15:29.330
But on the DMADV side, we're doing
the design measure and analyze but

269
00:15:29.330 --> 00:15:32.970
then we're getting to the bottom and
we're saying hey, we have to design this.

270
00:15:32.970 --> 00:15:37.210
And then after we design it, we have to
figure out how are we gonna test this,

271
00:15:37.210 --> 00:15:39.080
how are we gonna verify it.

272
00:15:39.080 --> 00:15:44.520
Now, a lot of companies do have their
own design for Six Sigma models.

273
00:15:44.520 --> 00:15:48.282
So they're proprietary,
they belong to that company, and

274
00:15:48.282 --> 00:15:52.118
the fact that they don't have
sustainability in that model,

275
00:15:52.118 --> 00:15:56.415
they don't really care about how to
keep the process end to control.

276
00:15:56.415 --> 00:16:00.405
Sometimes Lean Six Sigma people come
in at the back end of a design for

277
00:16:00.405 --> 00:16:02.250
Six Sigma project.

278
00:16:02.250 --> 00:16:04.471
To maintain that quality control or, okay.

279
00:16:04.471 --> 00:16:06.039
>> Absolutely, and to write that all up.

280
00:16:09.366 --> 00:16:11.629
This just says what I said
about design for Six Sigma,

281
00:16:11.629 --> 00:16:13.400
there's lots of other models out there.

282
00:16:14.800 --> 00:16:17.290
Again, this is just another comparison.

283
00:16:17.290 --> 00:16:21.190
You'll see one of the things that you
get in your student pack is a comparison

284
00:16:21.190 --> 00:16:25.830
between DMAIC and
the DMADV model because the tests and

285
00:16:25.830 --> 00:16:31.360
the exams are always comparing DMAIC like
the Six Sigma exam, not the Lean exam.

286
00:16:31.360 --> 00:16:33.880
But if you're just doing
the Six Sigma exam,

287
00:16:33.880 --> 00:16:36.720
there's a lot of comparisons
between DMAIC and the DMADV.

288
00:16:37.910 --> 00:16:42.040
All I want you to know in
Lean Six Sigma is that there is

289
00:16:42.040 --> 00:16:44.990
another path called Design for Six Sigma.

290
00:16:44.990 --> 00:16:47.970
But since there's a lot of questions
that's why this is included.

291
00:16:47.970 --> 00:16:50.790
There are a lot of questions that
compare the two models and they kinda

292
00:16:50.790 --> 00:16:54.320
leave out that well, this is just one
of the Design for Six Sigma models.

293
00:16:55.850 --> 00:16:58.440
And here again,
just another way to look at it.

294
00:16:58.440 --> 00:17:02.630
Sometimes, if you're having trouble
studying or grasping a concept,

295
00:17:02.630 --> 00:17:04.969
look at different kinds of graphs.

296
00:17:04.969 --> 00:17:08.969
>> Yeah, sure just looking at that the
first thing that pops into my head is to

297
00:17:08.969 --> 00:17:11.498
develop some kind of mnemonic for
that DMADV.

298
00:17:11.498 --> 00:17:12.587
>> I know.
>> So, yeah.

299
00:17:12.587 --> 00:17:13.154
>> I know.

300
00:17:13.154 --> 00:17:14.977
>> In IT we have a lot of acronyms, so

301
00:17:14.977 --> 00:17:18.180
people come up with some pretty
colorful ones sometimes.

302
00:17:18.180 --> 00:17:20.700
So, whatever works for
you stick with it and run with it.

303
00:17:20.700 --> 00:17:26.690
>> Exactly, I know it's a good study too
if you don't understand something go and

304
00:17:26.690 --> 00:17:29.150
look at different ways that it's written.

305
00:17:29.150 --> 00:17:33.024
In my PhD program,
the very first comp class that I took,

306
00:17:33.024 --> 00:17:35.458
I read a paragraph like 50 times.

307
00:17:35.458 --> 00:17:38.430
>> [LAUGH]
>> I just kept reading the same paragraph

308
00:17:38.430 --> 00:17:39.630
over and over again and

309
00:17:39.630 --> 00:17:42.950
I'm like, I'm never gonna be able
to finish the speech D program.

310
00:17:42.950 --> 00:17:46.686
The line of the next paragraph said, most
people don't understand this concept and

311
00:17:46.686 --> 00:17:47.590
then explained it.

312
00:17:47.590 --> 00:17:50.086
>> In a different way, interesting.

313
00:17:50.086 --> 00:17:53.240
>> So just kinda keep in mind
if any of these concepts seem

314
00:17:53.240 --> 00:17:57.000
kind of strange the student pack will help
you because we've got a lot more graphics

315
00:17:57.000 --> 00:17:57.720
than in that.

316
00:17:57.720 --> 00:17:58.660
>> Visual aides.

317
00:17:58.660 --> 00:18:02.350
>> And also just looking things up,
the DMAIC model and

318
00:18:02.350 --> 00:18:05.620
the DMADV model are so popular.

319
00:18:05.620 --> 00:18:09.234
There's all kinds of free stuff on
the Internet repackage this stuff.

320
00:18:09.234 --> 00:18:15.320
And this is just another way I'm going to
define and measure and analyze and design.

321
00:18:15.320 --> 00:18:18.130
Just another way to look at
the DMADV model, and it's,

322
00:18:18.130 --> 00:18:19.880
again, part of your student pack.

323
00:18:23.957 --> 00:18:28.369
So the next thing we're gonna
talk about is Kaizen models, and

324
00:18:28.369 --> 00:18:32.960
that's used to quickly improve
an existing process or service.

325
00:18:34.940 --> 00:18:38.950
And first I have to still figure
out what it is I wanna improve.

326
00:18:38.950 --> 00:18:42.690
What is it that I'm trying to make better,
faster, more cost-effective?

327
00:18:42.690 --> 00:18:45.210
Right, that's the first
thing I have to do.

328
00:18:45.210 --> 00:18:51.010
And I still have to work within the
construct of whatever process improvement

329
00:18:51.010 --> 00:18:52.360
program that company has.

330
00:18:52.360 --> 00:18:56.446
So if that company has ISO or
CMM if they're just a Lean company,

331
00:18:56.446 --> 00:18:59.770
if they're just a Six Sigma company.

332
00:18:59.770 --> 00:19:03.730
A lot of times Lean Six Sigma,
because it's one of the only

333
00:19:03.730 --> 00:19:08.200
methodologies that's a grassroots, so
I can just Lean Six Sigma myself and

334
00:19:08.200 --> 00:19:10.820
I don't have to,
it doesn't have to be top down.

335
00:19:10.820 --> 00:19:15.490
All these other programs, the CEO,
like if I just woke up one day and

336
00:19:15.490 --> 00:19:18.580
I said I wanted to be an ISO
company I couldn't do that.

337
00:19:18.580 --> 00:19:22.850
The CEO would have to make that decision,
or whoever was in charge of my department.

338
00:19:22.850 --> 00:19:26.340
Same thing with just Lean by
itself vs Sigma by itself.

339
00:19:26.340 --> 00:19:30.300
The only process improvement program
where I can Lean Six Sigma myself

340
00:19:31.310 --> 00:19:35.520
even if no one else in my company
Lean Six Sigmas I can do it and

341
00:19:35.520 --> 00:19:39.000
it's just a different way of
approaching my work, right.

342
00:19:39.000 --> 00:19:42.610
But I do wanna remember if I'm
doing a rapid improvement event,

343
00:19:42.610 --> 00:19:45.430
if there's some sort of
umbrella methodology out there,

344
00:19:45.430 --> 00:19:49.340
I wanna pay attention to that, so I don't
violate anything within those constructs.

345
00:19:50.940 --> 00:19:54.610
And this is just a reminder,
we covered this in another session.

346
00:19:54.610 --> 00:19:59.870
But ISO, best practices,
CMM looks at improving by levels.

347
00:19:59.870 --> 00:20:02.910
Lean reduces waste,
Six Sigma reduces mistakes.

348
00:20:02.910 --> 00:20:05.440
Lean Six Sigma says, hey,
why not all of the above?

349
00:20:07.430 --> 00:20:11.890
So, another thing that we wanna
think about before we move into

350
00:20:11.890 --> 00:20:15.780
looking at rapid improving events and
improving the process really quickly

351
00:20:15.780 --> 00:20:20.220
is just kind of the difference between
Traditional thinking and Lean thinking.

352
00:20:20.220 --> 00:20:24.060
And so, on the Traditional side,
it's management by cost.

353
00:20:24.060 --> 00:20:28.340
But on the Lean side it's leading by
delivering value and less errors.

354
00:20:28.340 --> 00:20:31.436
And I know that you guys
can read the schematic, but

355
00:20:31.436 --> 00:20:35.329
the one that's my favorite is
blames people vs blames process.

356
00:20:35.329 --> 00:20:36.188
>> No way.
[LAUGH]

357
00:20:36.188 --> 00:20:37.888
>> Yeah, and company focused,

358
00:20:37.888 --> 00:20:41.360
client focused,
hierchial in traditional environments.

359
00:20:41.360 --> 00:20:43.500
And you may be working in
traditional environment.

360
00:20:43.500 --> 00:20:48.287
Hierchial just means that,
maybe there's only

361
00:20:48.287 --> 00:20:53.550
500 people in the company and
75 of them are VPs.

362
00:20:53.550 --> 00:20:55.460
And then there's a senior VP.

363
00:20:55.460 --> 00:21:00.100
I worked at a company once
where we had a VP of HR and

364
00:21:00.100 --> 00:21:03.008
then they hired a global
VP of HR over her.

365
00:21:03.008 --> 00:21:09.201
[CROSSTALK] They just couldn't
come up with another term, right?

366
00:21:09.201 --> 00:21:10.500
So back to Kaizen.

367
00:21:10.500 --> 00:21:12.120
So those are things to
kind of keep in mind.

368
00:21:12.120 --> 00:21:16.180
I'm doing a rapid improvement event,
I need to think about the culture.

369
00:21:16.180 --> 00:21:18.000
Am I working with a traditional company?

370
00:21:18.000 --> 00:21:22.460
Am I working with a company
that leans more towards Lean?

371
00:21:22.460 --> 00:21:25.830
Are they using a particular
process improvement program?

372
00:21:25.830 --> 00:21:28.690
I need to think about all of those
things before I start doing my rapid

373
00:21:28.690 --> 00:21:29.360
improvement event.

374
00:21:29.360 --> 00:21:31.430
That should all be part of my puzzle.

375
00:21:31.430 --> 00:21:36.647
So the word Kaizen just means change for
the good, and I love the little symbols.

376
00:21:36.647 --> 00:21:38.176
>> Yeah, it really breaks it down and

377
00:21:38.176 --> 00:21:40.400
helps you understand where
that term comes from.

378
00:21:40.400 --> 00:21:42.050
>> Yeah, I love it.

379
00:21:42.050 --> 00:21:46.110
Okay, and so the biggest thing that
I think is the challenge with Kaizen

380
00:21:46.110 --> 00:21:48.180
is which approach am I gonna take?

381
00:21:48.180 --> 00:21:53.450
I could do a Kaizen event with a PDCA or
a DMAIC, and then there's a special one

382
00:21:53.450 --> 00:21:56.690
that's a more traditional model for Kaizen
that we're kind of moving away from.

383
00:21:56.690 --> 00:22:00.040
But it still shows up on some
of the more traditional tests.

384
00:22:00.040 --> 00:22:04.900
In our Lean Six Sigma exam,
pretty much, we say a Kaizen

385
00:22:04.900 --> 00:22:09.130
approach is a PDCA or DMAIC, but
I want you to be a little aware of score,

386
00:22:09.130 --> 00:22:13.090
because on the older, more traditional
tests, it comes up from time to time.

387
00:22:14.510 --> 00:22:18.323
Now again the idea of Kaizen is
instead of taking three or six months,

388
00:22:18.323 --> 00:22:22.730
because a typical Lean Six Sigma project
we're looking at three to six months,

389
00:22:22.730 --> 00:22:25.700
I'm gonna try to solve
this problem in a week.

390
00:22:25.700 --> 00:22:29.134
So on the manufacturing floor
sometimes I can do it because I'm just

391
00:22:29.134 --> 00:22:33.062
literally moving something, or
taking something away or buying the piece-

392
00:22:33.062 --> 00:22:34.110
>> Swapping a different component.

393
00:22:34.110 --> 00:22:36.070
>> Exactly, it's that simple.

394
00:22:36.070 --> 00:22:38.630
But in the non-manfucaturing environments,

395
00:22:38.630 --> 00:22:43.490
I'm spending that week trying to
figure out a good project plan.

396
00:22:43.490 --> 00:22:47.120
So if I take my group, all the players
that would be impacted, and

397
00:22:47.120 --> 00:22:51.950
I run them as a facilitator, I run them
through a PDCA, or a DMAIC, then I'm still

398
00:22:51.950 --> 00:22:55.450
collecting all the information,
I'm just collecting it a lot faster.

399
00:22:55.450 --> 00:22:57.576
We now have things called
Mini Kaizen events.

400
00:22:57.576 --> 00:23:01.909
A Kaizen event used to be five days
typically for non-manufacturing, and

401
00:23:01.909 --> 00:23:05.960
now we're doing Mini Kaizen events
which are two and a half days.

402
00:23:05.960 --> 00:23:10.440
But it's still basically the idea is that
I have a model that I'm working through.

403
00:23:10.440 --> 00:23:14.120
So that helps me work through
this event faster, right?

404
00:23:14.120 --> 00:23:19.890
And so remember the PDCA,
right, the Plan-Do-Check.

405
00:23:19.890 --> 00:23:20.418
And then,

406
00:23:20.418 --> 00:23:24.415
remember the DMAIC which we're gonna spend
a lot of time on in our next sessions.

407
00:23:24.415 --> 00:23:29.530
And that the DMAIC model in
Lean is a circular model.

408
00:23:29.530 --> 00:23:31.260
So those are all things to remember.

409
00:23:31.260 --> 00:23:34.370
So here's the final one that I
wanted to show you and like I said,

410
00:23:34.370 --> 00:23:37.830
this is just because it shows
up a lot in traditional,

411
00:23:37.830 --> 00:23:41.820
the newer exams are not paying
quite as much attention to it.

412
00:23:41.820 --> 00:23:45.998
So SCORE stands for Select,
Clarify, Organize, Run the event,

413
00:23:45.998 --> 00:23:48.040
and Evaluate the results.

414
00:23:48.040 --> 00:23:52.560
It maps fairly closely to
the DMAIC model in my mind.

415
00:23:52.560 --> 00:23:56.540
The timing of SCORE is a little
different because we're told

416
00:23:56.540 --> 00:23:59.920
rapid improvement events are supposed
to happen in a week now.

417
00:23:59.920 --> 00:24:03.460
So on the old models,
this was still considered pretty fast.

418
00:24:03.460 --> 00:24:08.710
I select one day to one week,
I clarify one day to one week.

419
00:24:08.710 --> 00:24:13.020
I organize, I run three to five days,
I evaluate.

420
00:24:13.020 --> 00:24:15.700
But if you add all of
that stuff up it's not

421
00:24:15.700 --> 00:24:18.470
what we're calling rapid
improvement events anymore.

422
00:24:18.470 --> 00:24:20.869
It's a kind of a little
bit longer process.

423
00:24:20.869 --> 00:24:24.492
But if you have more time to do your,
this sounds kind of silly, but

424
00:24:24.492 --> 00:24:27.599
if you have more time to do
your rapid improvement event,

425
00:24:27.599 --> 00:24:31.710
this is a pretty good calendar,
it's still pretty fast.

426
00:24:31.710 --> 00:24:35.220
But a lot of times now people are
expecting to solve the problem in two and

427
00:24:35.220 --> 00:24:37.860
a half to five days.

428
00:24:37.860 --> 00:24:41.900
Now, again if you're looking
at score against DMAIC,

429
00:24:43.649 --> 00:24:48.374
The only part that I would say
doesn't map super well is that

430
00:24:48.374 --> 00:24:52.100
last one cuz it talks about evaluate.

431
00:24:52.100 --> 00:24:53.880
But, in the DMAIC model,

432
00:24:53.880 --> 00:24:56.550
there's really that sustainability
piece that SCORE doesn't have.

433
00:24:57.560 --> 00:25:02.320
So that's pretty much the basic
models in Lean Six Sigma and

434
00:25:02.320 --> 00:25:06.640
again, just kinda keep in mind the DMAIC
is king and I might need to use a PDCA,

435
00:25:06.640 --> 00:25:11.340
cuz it's a simple problem or, I-
>> Yeah, well for

436
00:25:11.340 --> 00:25:13.690
sure, you answered the question that
I had at the beginning of the show.

437
00:25:13.690 --> 00:25:16.080
Is there one we should
really focus more on?

438
00:25:16.080 --> 00:25:21.500
Definitely with DMAIC covering
about 40% of that exam,

439
00:25:21.500 --> 00:25:25.075
I definitely wanna focus my efforts there,
but they're all important as well.

440
00:25:25.075 --> 00:25:28.355
So thank you for taking the time to cover
each one individually of those different

441
00:25:28.355 --> 00:25:30.405
methodologies or models.

442
00:25:30.405 --> 00:25:35.307
But stay tuned, we do have some more green
belt information headed your way, so

443
00:25:35.307 --> 00:25:37.575
I'm gonna go ahead and
sign off for this show.

444
00:25:37.575 --> 00:25:40.861
As you show host, I am Cherokee Boose
>> And I am Dr.

445
00:25:40.861 --> 00:25:44.247
Tara Vanzant Stern
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

446
00:25:44.247 --> 00:25:51.600
[MUSIC]

447
00:25:51.600 --> 00:25:54.444
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode Dr. Terra Vanzant Stern and Cherokee Boose begin to speak about seven different tools of quality. First,  you will see the Fishbone Diagram, also called a Cause and Effect Diagram or Ishikawa Diagram. Second, you will examine several different styles of flowcharts how to effectively use them.
episodes.title: Seven Tools of Quality
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.230 --> 00:00:01.170

00:00:01.170 --> 00:00:03.112

>> So these tools are not
really industry specific, but

how do they really relate
to Lean Six Sigma?

15
00:00:39.460 --> 00:00:42.575
>> I'd like to go to my
slide deck to explain that.

16
00:00:42.575 --> 00:00:46.322
And first,
what I'm going to do is I'm going to bring

00:00:46.322 --> 00:00:50.960
up a number of tools just so
that you can see the actual visual.

00:00:50.960 --> 00:00:53.380
Because many times seeing this visual,

The second thing I'd like to point out is
that these are called in your ASQ exam and

In the Lean Six Sigma exams,
these might be referred to

as a number of different things,
but it's always gonna say seven.

24
00:01:14.710 --> 00:01:17.660
So it's gonna say the seven tools
of process improvement, and

25
00:01:17.660 --> 00:01:18.840
this is just different vendors.

26
00:01:18.840 --> 00:01:22.410
We have a tendency at SSD Global,
if you take our tests,

00:01:22.410 --> 00:01:28.680
we kind of use the most accepted words,
which is seven tools of quality.

28
00:01:28.680 --> 00:01:30.480
But on other Lean Six Sigma exams,

29
00:01:30.480 --> 00:01:33.880
they may refer to these are the seven

00:25:57.272 --> 00:25:59.176
But if you memorize these symbols,

479
00:25:59.176 --> 00:26:02.100
you're fine as far as any
of the exams are concerned.

480
00:26:02.100 --> 00:26:05.280
And that would go for
six sigma only, lean only and

481
00:26:05.280 --> 00:26:09.390
hopefully the one that makes the most
sense, lean six sigma that combines it.

482
00:26:09.390 --> 00:26:14.390
Now the reason why these are the core
symbols are these are universally

483
00:26:14.390 --> 00:26:15.370
accepted symbols.

484
00:26:15.370 --> 00:26:17.870
So if you're working in
a global environment,

485
00:26:17.870 --> 00:26:20.760
everyone agrees on these symbols.

486
00:26:20.760 --> 00:26:22.940
On some of the other symbols,
I think one of the things,

487
00:26:22.940 --> 00:26:27.540
cuz you mentioned Visio,
Visio UK and Visio Australia.

488
00:26:27.540 --> 00:26:31.500
And I don't if there's a Canadian version,
but

489
00:26:31.500 --> 00:26:35.800
the UK version and the Australian version,
even though all three of us speak English,

490
00:26:35.800 --> 00:26:38.870
have some slightly different
symbols in the UK and Australia.

491
00:26:38.870 --> 00:26:41.180
But everyone agrees on these symbols.

492
00:26:41.180 --> 00:26:44.050
And really, if you use these symbols,
you're gonna be fine.

493
00:26:44.050 --> 00:26:48.270
Now most of them are intuitive,
start and stop obviously, operation.

494
00:26:48.270 --> 00:26:52.620
And here in the States we have a tendency
to make most of our operation symbols

495
00:26:52.620 --> 00:26:56.990
rectangles, but internationally,
sometimes you'll see those as circles.

496
00:26:56.990 --> 00:27:00.680
Decision, you know that one, input,
whatever goes into the system.

497
00:27:00.680 --> 00:27:05.490
And notice it only has kind of a slight
deviation, it kind of leans, right?

498
00:27:05.490 --> 00:27:08.840
Sometimes you'll see people do
the output symbol the other way, but

499
00:27:08.840 --> 00:27:12.530
a lot of times they'll use that symbol for
input or output.

500
00:27:12.530 --> 00:27:14.510
So flow kinda puts them together.

501
00:27:14.510 --> 00:27:19.550
Now one that isn't as intuitive is
the difference between transportation and

502
00:27:19.550 --> 00:27:20.350
transmission.

503
00:27:20.350 --> 00:27:22.820
And notice there's just
that little wiggle, right?

504
00:27:22.820 --> 00:27:27.517
And the difference is transportation is
any kind of movement at all, motorized,

505
00:27:27.517 --> 00:27:30.202
manual movement, any physical-
>> Physical movement.

506
00:27:30.202 --> 00:27:34.057
>> Exactly, and transmission, on the other
hand, is anything that we're doing

507
00:27:34.057 --> 00:27:36.862
electronic, so anything-
>> Intellectual property transporting.

508
00:27:36.862 --> 00:27:39.650
[LAUGH]
>> Absolutely, absolutely.

509
00:27:39.650 --> 00:27:42.440
Yeah, things going from one computer,
absolutely.

510
00:27:42.440 --> 00:27:47.770
Okay, measurement is where I have to stop,
and this one isn't as intuitive,

511
00:27:47.770 --> 00:27:51.550
measurement would be any time
I need to stop to do a check.

512
00:27:51.550 --> 00:27:54.370
Because measurement in a DMAIC
model means a little different.

513
00:27:54.370 --> 00:27:58.732
So kinda think, I'm putting
the measurement is a place that I kinda

514
00:27:58.732 --> 00:28:01.035
check myself, it's more of that.

515
00:28:01.035 --> 00:28:03.270
And keep in mind,
everyone doesn't know these symbols.

516
00:28:03.270 --> 00:28:07.073
So sometimes you're gonna see a flowchart
where they're misusing the symbols, right?

517
00:28:07.073 --> 00:28:08.965
But you just don't wanna misuse them.

518
00:28:08.965 --> 00:28:13.690
All right, so delay, it means exactly
what it says, I'm gonna stop.

519
00:28:13.690 --> 00:28:16.510
There's some kind of a reasoning there.

520
00:28:16.510 --> 00:28:20.950
In the old project management books,
they would always use the thing that

521
00:28:20.950 --> 00:28:23.340
you paint the door with primer and
then that dries.

522
00:28:23.340 --> 00:28:25.870
And then you go and
paint the door with the real paint.

523
00:28:25.870 --> 00:28:28.210
But now that we have primer in our paint,
we can't use that.

524
00:28:28.210 --> 00:28:32.777
But sometimes you could have a delay
cuz you're waiting for a signature, or

525
00:28:32.777 --> 00:28:35.000
some validation, or some testing.

526
00:28:35.000 --> 00:28:38.195
I mean, can you think of, what are some
other reasons things might be delayed?

527
00:28:38.195 --> 00:28:39.671
>> Installing software.

528
00:28:39.671 --> 00:28:40.370
>> Exactly.
>> In IT,

529
00:28:40.370 --> 00:28:42.583
we spend a lot of time
waiting on things to happen.

530
00:28:42.583 --> 00:28:44.143
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, exactly, and

531
00:28:44.143 --> 00:28:48.057
so if you're trying to get a high level
idea of how long it's gonna take or

532
00:28:48.057 --> 00:28:51.540
how much it's gonna cost,
those delays are really important.

533
00:28:51.540 --> 00:28:55.330
And then finally, storage, and
that is exactly what it says.

534
00:28:55.330 --> 00:28:58.110
But that one's a misused
symbol all the time, but

535
00:28:58.110 --> 00:29:02.980
storage technically means this is where
I'm gonna stop and collect information.

536
00:29:02.980 --> 00:29:03.828
>> All right.
>> So now,

537
00:29:03.828 --> 00:29:07.592
I think when you're thinking
about these symbols,

538
00:29:07.592 --> 00:29:12.818
it's a lot easier to say to yourself,
because this is just some of them.

539
00:29:12.818 --> 00:29:14.753
As you know on that Vizio,
there were just tons and tons of these.

540
00:29:14.753 --> 00:29:17.936
>> They have individual packages for
specific industries as well.

541
00:29:17.936 --> 00:29:23.080
>> Yeah, so there's tons and
nobody expects you to memorize these.

542
00:29:23.080 --> 00:29:26.830
But if you do memorize this core group,
you're fine and

543
00:29:26.830 --> 00:29:28.290
you can build any flowchart.

544
00:29:28.290 --> 00:29:30.600
And you can communicate
globally with anyone else.

545
00:29:32.303 --> 00:29:35.640
So again, these are just some examples.

546
00:29:35.640 --> 00:29:38.790
It's kinda reminder, high level,
right, and then the detailed one.

547
00:29:43.650 --> 00:29:48.468
So, what I'd like to wrap up this session
with is Value Stream Mapping because

548
00:29:48.468 --> 00:29:52.128
value stream mapping is so
closely related to flowcharts.

549
00:29:52.128 --> 00:29:55.392
Now the biggest difference
in value stream mapping, and

550
00:29:55.392 --> 00:29:59.481
this is a another one of those topics
that tends to be overcomplicated.

551
00:29:59.481 --> 00:30:03.234
What I want you to kind of think
of is that on a process map,

552
00:30:03.234 --> 00:30:08.580
I am truly trying to put every single
thing I can think of on my process map.

553
00:30:08.580 --> 00:30:13.100
On a value stream map, all I'm trying
to do is put the core activities.

554
00:30:13.100 --> 00:30:16.850
If we didn't do this,
the absolutely essential activities, and

555
00:30:16.850 --> 00:30:20.265
that goes back to a discussion
that we had in a previous

556
00:30:20.265 --> 00:30:26.980
session about value versus non-value.

557
00:30:26.980 --> 00:30:30.700
So, what I'm trying to do, I'm looking at
the flowchart and I'm seeing if I took

558
00:30:30.700 --> 00:30:35.530
that box off, that project, product,
or service would not go out the door.

559
00:30:35.530 --> 00:30:38.010
And what I'm left with is
just the essential functions.

560
00:30:38.010 --> 00:30:41.940
Now the purpose behind that is if I'm
gonna try to make things better, faster,

561
00:30:41.940 --> 00:30:46.780
and more cost effective, I want to
concentrate on those core things.

562
00:30:48.070 --> 00:30:53.340
So, value stream mapping, this is the big
thing, they have its own set of symbols.

563
00:30:53.340 --> 00:30:56.560
So it's not using the same
symbols as flowcharting.

564
00:30:56.560 --> 00:30:59.900
However, I maintain if you wanted to
use flowchart symbols, I just don't

565
00:30:59.900 --> 00:31:03.900
think there's a value stream management
police that are gonna come out there.

566
00:31:03.900 --> 00:31:05.620
So it uses its own set.

567
00:31:05.620 --> 00:31:07.920
It tracks only the essential steps,

568
00:31:07.920 --> 00:31:12.220
which we just said, and then we might
do something called a Gemba Walk.

569
00:31:12.220 --> 00:31:16.210
And typically, Gemba Walks are becoming
very, very popular in hospitals.

570
00:31:16.210 --> 00:31:19.960
And typically,
I have some sort of process map in hand.

571
00:31:19.960 --> 00:31:24.250
Some kind of high level idea at least
of how the process is supposed to work.

572
00:31:24.250 --> 00:31:29.600
So I go walk the process, but
in that walk, I take people with me.

573
00:31:29.600 --> 00:31:33.466
Why do you think I would take
people with me to walk the process?

574
00:31:33.466 --> 00:31:35.851
>> So, if you were the person
who created that process,

575
00:31:35.851 --> 00:31:38.087
you probably think it's
a really great process.

576
00:31:38.087 --> 00:31:40.942
But for example in IT,
if I were someone who designed,

577
00:31:40.942 --> 00:31:42.556
if I were a network engineer and

578
00:31:42.556 --> 00:31:46.282
I designed my network and I implemented
all these security controls and

579
00:31:46.282 --> 00:31:50.564
I thought no one can break into my network
I normally would hire a third party person

580
00:31:50.564 --> 00:31:54.630
to a perform penetration test because
it's really just another set of eyes.

581
00:31:54.630 --> 00:31:57.186
And another, I guess, angle or opinion,

582
00:31:57.186 --> 00:32:00.630
to point something out that
you may not have recognized?

583
00:32:00.630 --> 00:32:02.960
>> Yeah absolutely, absolutely.

584
00:32:02.960 --> 00:32:07.514
And again, just like we said that there
are people, Lean 6 Sigma certified,

585
00:32:07.514 --> 00:32:11.250
green and black belts, that go in and
all they do is process map.

586
00:32:12.610 --> 00:32:15.551
There's a whole group of
people now that as a business,

587
00:32:15.551 --> 00:32:18.126
as a consulting business,
just do Gemba Walks.

588
00:32:18.126 --> 00:32:23.690
Because the thinking is, I have no bias,
I have no idea what's going on.

589
00:32:23.690 --> 00:32:25.894
And I'm gonna come up with those steps.

590
00:32:25.894 --> 00:32:30.450
Now in a Gemba Walk what happens is after
the walk has taken place, typically you

591
00:32:30.450 --> 00:32:34.466
come back to something, we call it
a war room in a lot of environments.

592
00:32:34.466 --> 00:32:36.385
But you come back to a conference room and

593
00:32:36.385 --> 00:32:40.080
you put your sticky notes up on all
the different steps that you took.

594
00:32:40.080 --> 00:32:42.240
And then what you're doing
is you're trying to say,

595
00:32:42.240 --> 00:32:43.875
how long did it take from step one to two?

596
00:32:43.875 --> 00:32:45.284
How much did it cost?

597
00:32:45.284 --> 00:32:46.614
What were the resources?

598
00:32:46.614 --> 00:32:50.575
So the other thing about value
stream mapping you wanna remember,

599
00:32:50.575 --> 00:32:53.770
is that there's a a current and
a future map.

600
00:32:53.770 --> 00:32:58.525
Now in process mapping, sometimes
you'll see an as is process map and

601
00:32:58.525 --> 00:32:59.822
a 2B process map.

602
00:32:59.822 --> 00:33:02.598
That's where want we move to, but

603
00:33:02.598 --> 00:33:07.150
always in value streams we
have a current and a future.

604
00:33:07.150 --> 00:33:11.535
And the current, again, is the one that
just includes those essential steps.

605
00:33:11.535 --> 00:33:15.446
Because we're saying if we don't do these,
the process isn't gonna work.

606
00:33:15.446 --> 00:33:18.798
So we have to work around
those particular processes.

607
00:33:18.798 --> 00:33:21.708
So here's some general icons.

608
00:33:21.708 --> 00:33:25.754
Some of the icons make perfect
sense like go see, I love that one.

609
00:33:25.754 --> 00:33:29.917
And there's a lot more,
you'll see kind of cartoon icons.

610
00:33:29.917 --> 00:33:34.692
But now we've morphed into having
some very sophisticated ones like

611
00:33:34.692 --> 00:33:39.900
the eye glasses, are real eye glass,
or real glasses that you might wear.

612
00:33:39.900 --> 00:33:44.168
But some of them kind of makes sense.

613
00:33:44.168 --> 00:33:49.303
Material flow icons, if you're not
familiar with manufacturing environments,

614
00:33:49.303 --> 00:33:52.256
some of these icons will
not make as much sense.

615
00:33:52.256 --> 00:33:57.366
In Visio, the default and
in a lot of graphic packages,

616
00:33:57.366 --> 00:34:00.209
not just the Microsoft Visio.

617
00:34:00.209 --> 00:34:01.578
But that's one we mentioned.

618
00:34:01.578 --> 00:34:07.150
So in a lot of graphic packages
the default's gonna be the flow chart.

619
00:34:07.150 --> 00:34:10.649
But there's gonna be a tab that
says value string mapping symbols.

620
00:34:10.649 --> 00:34:11.685
And it works the same way.

621
00:34:11.685 --> 00:34:14.455
If you hover over the symbol it's
gonna tell you what the symbol is.

622
00:34:14.455 --> 00:34:19.305
Now some people don't like the symbols
because they think it makes it too much

623
00:34:19.305 --> 00:34:20.582
like a story board.

624
00:34:20.582 --> 00:34:24.088
So I still wanna say that if you don't
use the symbols I think you can still

625
00:34:24.088 --> 00:34:25.776
do the theory of the value stream.

626
00:34:25.776 --> 00:34:27.424
>> Convey your message.

627
00:34:27.424 --> 00:34:28.379
>> Yes.

628
00:34:28.379 --> 00:34:29.646
And so here's information flow icons.

629
00:34:29.646 --> 00:34:32.703
And like I said,
if you just kinda take a quick look,

630
00:34:32.703 --> 00:34:36.817
some of these make perfect sense,
some of them you'd have to look up.

631
00:34:36.817 --> 00:34:40.630
>> Now will we need to know these for
the exam?

632
00:34:40.630 --> 00:34:42.206
Would we see it?
>> What a great question.

633
00:34:42.206 --> 00:34:43.860
What you need to know for

634
00:34:43.860 --> 00:34:48.831
the Lean Six Sigma exam is that there's
another way to do a process map.

635
00:34:48.831 --> 00:34:50.770
That you can do a value stream map.

636
00:34:50.770 --> 00:34:53.214
And that value stream maps
have their own symbols.

637
00:34:53.214 --> 00:34:56.029
If you are taking the Lean exam.

638
00:34:56.029 --> 00:35:01.370
Because right now the Lean exam is very
heavily oriented to our manufacturing.

639
00:35:01.370 --> 00:35:06.083
You want to take a moment to at least
memorize some of the manufacturing.

640
00:35:06.083 --> 00:35:10.079
On the student package,
you're gonna have a sheet that has all of

641
00:35:10.079 --> 00:35:13.990
the value stream mapping tools
the most the popular ones.

642
00:35:13.990 --> 00:35:16.226
And it will have right underneath,
that's what this is.

643
00:35:16.226 --> 00:35:18.636
So if you're taking a Lean exam,
definitely.

644
00:35:18.636 --> 00:35:22.542
Six Sigma, again,
same thing as the Lean Six Sigma exam,

645
00:35:22.542 --> 00:35:27.140
if you know the concept of
the value stream map, you're fine.

646
00:35:27.140 --> 00:35:27.968
So great question.

647
00:35:27.968 --> 00:35:32.190
If you are taking the Lean only
exam you wanna know these symbols.

648
00:35:32.190 --> 00:35:32.886
>> Okay.

649
00:35:32.886 --> 00:35:34.530
>> So perfect question, thank you.

650
00:35:35.890 --> 00:35:40.580
All right, and Gemba walk, just like
what we said, it's just to access or

651
00:35:40.580 --> 00:35:42.480
create your value stream.

652
00:35:42.480 --> 00:35:47.333
And your value stream is,
the things that absolutely have to happen,

653
00:35:47.333 --> 00:35:50.631
to make your product or
project go out the door.

654
00:35:50.631 --> 00:35:53.990
So I think we're gonna cover the other
seven tools in our next session.

655
00:35:53.990 --> 00:35:57.085
>> [LAUGH] Yeah we got to two
of the seven, so that's not bad.

656
00:35:57.085 --> 00:36:00.590
We went into a really a lot of
detail by looking at examples and

657
00:36:00.590 --> 00:36:05.020
looking at the variations of these
different tools available to us.

658
00:36:05.020 --> 00:36:07.754
So we're gonna go ahead and
wrap it up for this particular episode.

659
00:36:07.754 --> 00:36:10.545
But stay tuned,
we have a lot more information for

660
00:36:10.545 --> 00:36:12.930
our seven quality tools headed your way.

661
00:36:12.930 --> 00:36:17.249
I'm gonna go ahead and
sign off as your host, Cherokee Boose.

662
00:36:17.249 --> 00:36:19.821
>> And this is Dr. Tara VanZant-Stern
with SSD Global Solutions.

663
00:36:19.821 --> 00:36:22.019
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

664
00:36:22.019 --> 00:36:29.900
[MUSIC]

665
00:36:29.900 --> 00:36:31.585
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: This episode is a continuation of the seven tools of quality. Dr. Terra Vanzant Stern and Cherokee Boose examine ways to use tools such as check sheets as to do lists, tollgates, as a list before an activity starts or even as a way a way to gather information for charts like histograms or Pareto Charts.
episodes.title: Seven Tools of Quality Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.230 --> 00:00:05.540
Welcome to ITProTV, I'm your

2
00:00:05.540 --> 00:00:10.910
host [CROSSTALK]
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

3
00:00:10.910 --> 00:00:12.337
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:12.337 --> 00:00:17.550
>> Welcome to your Lean Six Sigma Green
Belt Certification Preparation series.

5
00:00:17.550 --> 00:00:20.020
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:20.020 --> 00:00:21.940
This is actually a part two.

7
00:00:21.940 --> 00:00:25.630
In the previous episode we were
looking at our seven quality tools.

8
00:00:25.630 --> 00:00:27.160
We only got through a couple so

9
00:00:27.160 --> 00:00:30.930
we're gonna spend some more time focusing
on the remainder of those tools.

10
00:00:30.930 --> 00:00:34.480
With us in studio today is Dr.
Tara Van Zant Stern.

11
00:00:34.480 --> 00:00:36.340
Thank you for joining us today Dr. Tara.

12
00:00:36.340 --> 00:00:37.090
>> Thank you, Cherokee.

13
00:00:38.250 --> 00:00:42.820
>> So at the end of the episode we
were mentioning, again, the lock.

14
00:00:42.820 --> 00:00:44.870
And we really didn't go
into extreme detail, and

15
00:00:44.870 --> 00:00:48.180
I just wanted to make sure I
fully understood that concept.

16
00:00:48.180 --> 00:00:51.820
So in IT we have this term,
it's called the sneaker net.

17
00:00:51.820 --> 00:00:56.270
And it's kind of a joke, but it really
means getting up out of your chair and

18
00:00:56.270 --> 00:00:59.650
walking over to a situation
to try to solve the problem.

19
00:00:59.650 --> 00:01:01.800
Is that similar, am I on track here?

20
00:01:01.800 --> 00:01:02.980
>> Yes, absolutely.

21
00:01:02.980 --> 00:01:08.000
So what I'm doing is I'm just
basically walking the process.

22
00:01:08.000 --> 00:01:10.010
And if I can go to one in my slides,

23
00:01:10.010 --> 00:01:14.120
I'll show you the end result
looks something like this.

24
00:01:14.120 --> 00:01:18.450
So as I walk through the process,
I record my steps.

25
00:01:18.450 --> 00:01:20.280
And this is just one method of doing it.

26
00:01:20.280 --> 00:01:22.440
Some people do different methods.

27
00:01:22.440 --> 00:01:27.568
But one method is I would walk, and step
one, step two and I'd put my stickies out.

28
00:01:27.568 --> 00:01:31.540
And in between the stickies what I'm
looking at is how long did that take?

29
00:01:31.540 --> 00:01:34.660
How much did it cost, how many resources?

30
00:01:34.660 --> 00:01:37.610
>> It looks like you have some sort
kind of color coding going on here.

31
00:01:37.610 --> 00:01:38.250
>> Exactly,

32
00:01:38.250 --> 00:01:43.190
and this is all kind of up to the group
of people that you're working with.

33
00:01:43.190 --> 00:01:48.560
A lot of times, as a Lean Six Sigma
person, you're facilitating the exercise.

34
00:01:48.560 --> 00:01:52.770
And you might not really know,
the topic that they're researching.

35
00:01:52.770 --> 00:01:55.650
So, I look for a lot of input,
here's another example.

36
00:01:55.650 --> 00:01:59.530
I look for a lot of input from them
about what do we wanna call this?

37
00:01:59.530 --> 00:02:00.810
How do we wanna color code it?

38
00:02:00.810 --> 00:02:02.770
How do we wanna do these different things.

39
00:02:02.770 --> 00:02:05.150
So the good news,
as far as that's concerned,

40
00:02:05.150 --> 00:02:10.450
is that the gemba walk process itself,
a little messy, but easy to do.

41
00:02:10.450 --> 00:02:15.450
Now when you take that same
gemba walk thing and you put it

42
00:02:15.450 --> 00:02:21.480
on a flowchart, that's when you go back to
using those symbols and things like that.

43
00:02:21.480 --> 00:02:23.970
So, on our last session
we were talking about,

44
00:02:23.970 --> 00:02:28.670
I'm just move up a few slides, we were
talking about fishbone, flowchart and

45
00:02:28.670 --> 00:02:34.260
as Cherokee said we're gonna move on to
those other areas, the seven tools and

46
00:02:34.260 --> 00:02:37.490
I'm just gonna advance here quickly and
get us where we need to be.

47
00:02:38.560 --> 00:02:42.070
One of the things that we were
talking about on during our break.

48
00:02:42.070 --> 00:02:46.820
The seven tools are so important that
if you were a Lean Six Sigma person

49
00:02:46.820 --> 00:02:51.800
going in to an environment that's never
had a process improvement specialist,

50
00:02:51.800 --> 00:02:56.090
a lot of times the screening questions
are gonna be around the seven tools.

51
00:02:56.090 --> 00:02:58.030
Because that's what's
promoted out on the Internet.

52
00:02:58.030 --> 00:02:59.900
So let's say you're an HR person and

53
00:02:59.900 --> 00:03:04.720
you're trying to screen a process
improvement person for the IT department.

54
00:03:04.720 --> 00:03:07.760
You're probably going to
have the IT person there

55
00:03:07.760 --> 00:03:11.030
that's able to ask you the IT
related questions, but

56
00:03:11.030 --> 00:03:15.500
the HR person might be the only one that's
asking anything to do with Lean Six Sigma.

57
00:03:15.500 --> 00:03:18.710
And if they're not familiar with it,
There is a tendency or

58
00:03:18.710 --> 00:03:22.710
a trend for them to ask you questions
[LAUGH] related to these seven tools.

59
00:03:22.710 --> 00:03:26.490
Now, even though on the exam,
well the tools do,

60
00:03:26.490 --> 00:03:30.670
I would say pick up
a big part of the exam.

61
00:03:30.670 --> 00:03:34.300
But most of the exam has to do with
the models and the methodology and

62
00:03:34.300 --> 00:03:37.820
the concepts But
in interviewing situations

63
00:03:37.820 --> 00:03:41.250
there is a tendency to rely
on knowledge of your tools.

64
00:03:41.250 --> 00:03:43.990
These seven tools,
as we mentioned in the session before.

65
00:03:43.990 --> 00:03:46.780
Also, called the seven
tools of critical thinking,

66
00:03:46.780 --> 00:03:49.320
the seven tools of data analysis.

67
00:03:49.320 --> 00:03:52.020
Some times they're called the seven
business processing tools,

68
00:03:52.020 --> 00:03:53.770
just they go by lots of different names.

69
00:03:53.770 --> 00:03:54.980
So, very important tools.

70
00:03:56.030 --> 00:03:58.530
One of the things I think is interesting

71
00:03:58.530 --> 00:04:01.680
is that one of the seven tools
is just called a check sheet.

72
00:04:01.680 --> 00:04:04.730
And we use check sheets all the time,
we call them to do lists, right.

73
00:04:04.730 --> 00:04:10.640
And it's interesting that a check sheet
would make it on the seven tools,

74
00:04:10.640 --> 00:04:12.240
something that simple.

75
00:04:12.240 --> 00:04:15.850
But there's been a lot of
research over the past decades.

76
00:04:15.850 --> 00:04:16.400
And so for

77
00:04:16.400 --> 00:04:20.480
some reason when we write something down
It's like a contract with ourselves and

78
00:04:20.480 --> 00:04:24.100
we're much more likely to remember and
much more likely to actually do it.

79
00:04:24.100 --> 00:04:25.830
>> Well, sure.
Like you even mentioned before,

80
00:04:25.830 --> 00:04:28.860
if you have to even add a signature line,

81
00:04:28.860 --> 00:04:33.790
you're kind of giving your word that you,
in fact, accomplished this task so

82
00:04:33.790 --> 00:04:37.300
it makes it even a little, you know,
you're just adding that accountability.

83
00:04:37.300 --> 00:04:41.930
>> Exactly, and so some other examples of
check sheets would be something like this.

84
00:04:41.930 --> 00:04:45.350
Like, number of minutes spent
studying math facts, right?

85
00:04:45.350 --> 00:04:46.217
And we use this.

86
00:04:46.217 --> 00:04:47.514
>> No.

87
00:04:47.514 --> 00:04:48.370
>> [LAUGH] Yeah.

88
00:04:48.370 --> 00:04:52.480
And this is kind of something that
a lot of elementary school teachers

89
00:04:52.480 --> 00:04:54.290
use to explain to their students.

90
00:04:54.290 --> 00:04:56.990
The more that you study,
the better you're going to do on test.

91
00:04:56.990 --> 00:05:00.130
Buy I'm just doing a check
sheet at this point.

92
00:05:00.130 --> 00:05:02.870
You'll notice on typical check sheets.

93
00:05:02.870 --> 00:05:05.240
But a to do list is a check sheet right?

94
00:05:05.240 --> 00:05:07.340
On check sheets where I'm
gathering information,

95
00:05:08.500 --> 00:05:11.380
we are encouraged to put a tick mark okay?

96
00:05:11.380 --> 00:05:16.110
So for example when we're doing
brainstorming, and we go around and

97
00:05:16.110 --> 00:05:22.290
we ask how many other people think this
is valuable, for trying to get that idea.

98
00:05:22.290 --> 00:05:26.350
If we're trying to multi voting, which
we covered under the facilitation tools,

99
00:05:26.350 --> 00:05:29.969
the tick mark is really important
because that says my vote counted.

100
00:05:32.120 --> 00:05:35.550
So, a to do list is a good example.

101
00:05:35.550 --> 00:05:38.220
A toll gate which we mentioned
in a session before,

102
00:05:38.220 --> 00:05:42.210
in some companies especially those six
sigma companies where there's a very

103
00:05:42.210 --> 00:05:46.180
complicated process that they're
trying to improve sometimes after each

104
00:05:46.180 --> 00:05:50.110
phase in the model that they're using,
there'll be something called a toll gate.

105
00:05:50.110 --> 00:05:51.970
And basically,
that's a check sheet that says,

106
00:05:51.970 --> 00:05:55.140
did I really do everything I was
supposed to do in that phase?

107
00:05:55.140 --> 00:06:00.030
In some industries that are heavy
in compliance, sometimes

108
00:06:00.030 --> 00:06:04.810
there's compliance related things to that
phase that people just want to make sure.

109
00:06:04.810 --> 00:06:08.040
Or they could be SOPs,
standard operating procedures.

110
00:06:08.040 --> 00:06:10.350
So those are kinds of things
that make toll gates.

111
00:06:10.350 --> 00:06:11.980
Because a lot of times, people will say,

112
00:06:11.980 --> 00:06:15.530
well, you know what you're
supposed to do in that phase.

113
00:06:15.530 --> 00:06:18.820
Absolutely, but if you're in
a particular industry, there could be

114
00:06:18.820 --> 00:06:20.870
extra things that have to be done before-
>> Right.

115
00:06:20.870 --> 00:06:23.730
And what really kind of
resonates with me is,

116
00:06:23.730 --> 00:06:26.660
in my family I have people who
work in the power industry.

117
00:06:26.660 --> 00:06:29.210
So if they're working on large turbines or
something,

118
00:06:29.210 --> 00:06:33.190
maybe they've never worked on that piece
of equipment, but someone else has.

119
00:06:33.190 --> 00:06:34.660
>> Exactly.
>> Documented the process, so

120
00:06:34.660 --> 00:06:35.660
now they're just saying hey,

121
00:06:35.660 --> 00:06:38.099
make sure you [LAUGH] put all
the pieces back together here.

122
00:06:38.099 --> 00:06:40.130
[LAUGH]
>> And in some of those industries,

123
00:06:40.130 --> 00:06:42.690
there's actually toll gate reviewers.

124
00:06:42.690 --> 00:06:44.792
They're like compliance people [CROSSTALK]
>> The quality assurance, and

125
00:06:44.792 --> 00:06:45.319
that's their only function.

126
00:06:45.319 --> 00:06:49.030
>> Exactly, yeah.

127
00:06:49.030 --> 00:06:52.280
It's not a good job if you

128
00:06:52.280 --> 00:06:56.470
don't like being criticized because people
are always like, no the compliance person.

129
00:06:56.470 --> 00:06:57.990
But it's a job, right?

130
00:06:59.690 --> 00:07:04.770
Another way that we can use check
sheets is to gather information for

131
00:07:04.770 --> 00:07:07.770
a pareto chart or a histogram informally.

132
00:07:07.770 --> 00:07:12.920
So, sometimes we're just trying to
figure out Is there actually a problem.

133
00:07:12.920 --> 00:07:15.810
And we're not really trying
to do a big scientific study.

134
00:07:15.810 --> 00:07:18.580
We're just trying to gather enough
information to see should I've been

135
00:07:18.580 --> 00:07:20.790
looking in that particular direction.

136
00:07:20.790 --> 00:07:23.120
And then sometimes,

137
00:07:23.120 --> 00:07:26.579
there's a listed things that we
have to do before we get started.

138
00:07:27.960 --> 00:07:31.340
I've always loved, when I talk about
check sheets I always love some

139
00:07:31.340 --> 00:07:35.950
of the old Steve Covey material that says
what they're gonna do is a not to do list.

140
00:07:35.950 --> 00:07:38.270
I'm gonna write down all of
the things I'm never gonna do again.

141
00:07:38.270 --> 00:07:40.480
And I'm gonna carry that
around in my purse or wallet.

142
00:07:41.850 --> 00:07:44.760
So here's another easy example

143
00:07:44.760 --> 00:07:48.199
of a check sheet where they're
looking at telephone interruptions.

144
00:07:49.800 --> 00:07:50.946
So check sheet's very simple.

145
00:07:50.946 --> 00:07:54.458
But again, just like the Fishbone,
just like the process mount,

146
00:07:54.458 --> 00:07:58.912
simple tools that sometimes we don't pay
attention to, that are just mammoth as far

147
00:07:58.912 --> 00:08:02.069
as Making things better,
faster and more cost effective.

148
00:08:02.069 --> 00:08:07.470
Which is of course the whole
concept of process improvement.

149
00:08:07.470 --> 00:08:09.100
And here's another check sheet.

150
00:08:09.100 --> 00:08:14.840
The reason I included this one is that
check sheets can get sophisticated.

151
00:08:14.840 --> 00:08:19.910
So in this particular example,
what we're looking is at the diameter of

152
00:08:19.910 --> 00:08:23.560
a pin that's supposed to fit
into another piece of equipment.

153
00:08:23.560 --> 00:08:27.920
Someone can come in and say,
we've got a lot of scrap on the floor.

154
00:08:27.920 --> 00:08:31.530
We have a lot of pins that
are either too big or too little.

155
00:08:31.530 --> 00:08:35.070
And when the manufacturer comes
to buy them, if that's the case,

156
00:08:35.070 --> 00:08:38.250
they might not buy our lots and
material, right?

157
00:08:38.250 --> 00:08:43.290
So, in this case, I put an upper and
lower control limit on the check sheet,

158
00:08:43.290 --> 00:08:45.690
and physically,
just have someone go out and count.

159
00:08:45.690 --> 00:08:46.670
>> And measure them.

160
00:08:46.670 --> 00:08:47.580
>> And measure them.

161
00:08:47.580 --> 00:08:49.540
Now, in this case we are pretty lucky,

162
00:08:49.540 --> 00:08:53.080
because what this shows is something
called normal distribution.

163
00:08:53.080 --> 00:08:56.030
So, sometimes histograms are used to show.

164
00:08:56.030 --> 00:08:59.080
As long as it looks like a bell,
and it fits between the upper and

165
00:08:59.080 --> 00:09:01.240
lower control limits, you are pretty safe.

166
00:09:01.240 --> 00:09:04.570
So someone who's run in and
said there's a lot of scrap on the floor.

167
00:09:04.570 --> 00:09:08.030
There's a lot of pins that
we're just throwing away.

168
00:09:08.030 --> 00:09:10.380
I could do a simple check
sheet to see if that's true.

169
00:09:10.380 --> 00:09:12.690
Now you might still
wanna keep an eye on it.

170
00:09:12.690 --> 00:09:13.240
Right?

171
00:09:13.240 --> 00:09:19.150
But in this case I haven't gone
into full resolution mode,

172
00:09:19.150 --> 00:09:20.420
how are we gonna solve this problem?

173
00:09:20.420 --> 00:09:24.130
Because I need information, I need to
make sure that that's really a problem.

174
00:09:24.130 --> 00:09:27.610
And this particular check sheet
would indicate not probably.

175
00:09:27.610 --> 00:09:29.970
>> It's an acceptable
amount of defects or-

176
00:09:29.970 --> 00:09:30.710
>> Absolutely,

177
00:09:30.710 --> 00:09:33.700
because you're gonna have some defects,
right?

178
00:09:33.700 --> 00:09:39.030
So check sheets can be a little
bit more sophisticated.

179
00:09:39.030 --> 00:09:43.040
The next tool we're going to talk about,
Cherokee, is histograms.

180
00:09:43.040 --> 00:09:48.760
One thing that I want to point out with
histograms is on the Six Sigma exam only,

181
00:09:48.760 --> 00:09:51.330
there's a lot more questions
about histograms than on

182
00:09:51.330 --> 00:09:52.799
the Lean Six Sigma test.

183
00:09:54.010 --> 00:09:57.192
And actually the lean,
or Lean Six Sigma test.

184
00:09:57.192 --> 00:09:59.984
I'm gonna give you
the information that you need for

185
00:09:59.984 --> 00:10:01.960
those exams in your student packet.

186
00:10:01.960 --> 00:10:05.390
They are going to be talking
to you about histograms.

187
00:10:05.390 --> 00:10:09.210
Because there is a statistical
formula to make this graph appear.

188
00:10:09.210 --> 00:10:11.910
In Lean Six Sigma, as well as lean.

189
00:10:11.910 --> 00:10:13.930
The fact that you can make the graph.

190
00:10:13.930 --> 00:10:15.190
Is good enough, right?

191
00:10:15.190 --> 00:10:17.070
And we let Excel make the graph.

192
00:10:17.070 --> 00:10:18.940
But in the Six Sigma programs,

193
00:10:18.940 --> 00:10:23.610
a lot of times they want to know, all of
these graphs have statistics behind them.

194
00:10:23.610 --> 00:10:29.210
So when I see any kind of
graph other than like say,

195
00:10:29.210 --> 00:10:32.470
a flow chart and a fish bone.

196
00:10:32.470 --> 00:10:35.304
If I see a graph such as a histogram,
a Pareto chart,

197
00:10:35.304 --> 00:10:37.827
a scatter diagram, there's actually math.

198
00:10:37.827 --> 00:10:38.530
>> They wanna see the work.

199
00:10:38.530 --> 00:10:40.760
>> Behind that and
they wanna see the math, okay?

200
00:10:40.760 --> 00:10:42.570
So I will point that out.

201
00:10:42.570 --> 00:10:47.140
The other thing that I wanna point
out is that, in Lean Six Sigma,

202
00:10:47.140 --> 00:10:51.150
you pretty much are using histograms
to track the history of an event.

203
00:10:51.150 --> 00:10:53.540
So that makes it easy
to remember on an exam.

204
00:10:53.540 --> 00:10:55.080
There are other ways, and

205
00:10:55.080 --> 00:10:59.460
we'll look at a couple of those ways
that you might use a histogram.

206
00:10:59.460 --> 00:11:02.140
One of them was the one we just looked at.

207
00:11:02.140 --> 00:11:05.610
I might use a histogram to
determine distribution.

208
00:11:05.610 --> 00:11:08.130
So, I'm gathering information and
when I put my chart together,

209
00:11:08.130 --> 00:11:11.000
as long as it's a nice, pretty bell and
it fits between my upper and

210
00:11:11.000 --> 00:11:14.430
lower control limits,
I can say that process is stable.

211
00:11:14.430 --> 00:11:17.420
So that's one way a histogram is used.

212
00:11:17.420 --> 00:11:21.440
Another way a histogram can be used
is to collect buckets of information.

213
00:11:21.440 --> 00:11:22.660
How many people made an A?

214
00:11:22.660 --> 00:11:23.900
How many people made a B?

215
00:11:23.900 --> 00:11:26.340
How many people made a C in that class?

216
00:11:26.340 --> 00:11:28.900
However typically in Lean Six Sigma,

217
00:11:28.900 --> 00:11:34.090
histograms are used just like it says,
to track the history of events.

218
00:11:34.090 --> 00:11:35.515
How many broken light bulbs?

219
00:11:35.515 --> 00:11:40.150
How many people came to
the library during a week?

220
00:11:40.150 --> 00:11:41.780
>> How many shows we record in a week?

221
00:11:41.780 --> 00:11:43.430
>> Exactly, that type of thing.

222
00:11:43.430 --> 00:11:46.140
So that's, I think, kind of a fun thing,

223
00:11:46.140 --> 00:11:49.720
is just to remember that
it is just the history.

224
00:11:49.720 --> 00:11:52.760
So it's not a big thing to remember.

225
00:11:52.760 --> 00:11:55.020
Okay, so what you're looking at right now,

226
00:11:55.020 --> 00:11:59.760
I wanna point out the simple concept
of how a histogram is constructed.

227
00:11:59.760 --> 00:12:04.220
On the left hand side of the screen
you're looking at very non-sophisticated

228
00:12:04.220 --> 00:12:07.230
example of a frequency diagram.

229
00:12:07.230 --> 00:12:10.540
So in statistics this is
known as frequency diagram.

230
00:12:10.540 --> 00:12:14.270
And we're seeing blue shows up 5 times,
yellow shows up two times.

231
00:12:14.270 --> 00:12:18.120
Back in the day when we
taught basic statistics,

232
00:12:18.120 --> 00:12:21.980
we used to have these blue and
red pegs, and yellow pegs.

233
00:12:21.980 --> 00:12:24.410
And we mix them all together,
and we do things.

234
00:12:24.410 --> 00:12:26.910
Like, this is how you do sampling,
and stuff like that.

235
00:12:26.910 --> 00:12:30.940
And we would use it to demonstrate things,
such as frequency diagrams.

236
00:12:30.940 --> 00:12:35.490
And then there was the period of
time that all of us were using M&Ms.

237
00:12:35.490 --> 00:12:40.710
Because M&M were not standard, if you
opened the pack you might have a different

238
00:12:40.710 --> 00:12:44.610
amount of red than you had of yellow,
but that started getting standard and so

239
00:12:44.610 --> 00:12:47.440
we went back to the peg system
to look at sampling and

240
00:12:47.440 --> 00:12:52.920
frequency diagrams plus people were eating
the M&M are getting sick after they touch

241
00:12:52.920 --> 00:12:54.680
so, frequency diagram.

242
00:12:54.680 --> 00:12:56.912
This is statistics 101, right?

243
00:12:56.912 --> 00:13:00.135
So, all I'm really doing is I'm
taking my frequency diagram and

244
00:13:00.135 --> 00:13:03.370
then making a graphic out of it,
that's all I'm doing, right?

245
00:13:05.160 --> 00:13:10.230
Now, what I'm looking at in this
histogram is I'm looking at travel time,

246
00:13:10.230 --> 00:13:14.920
and so if you look at the y,
if you look at the y axis, and

247
00:13:14.920 --> 00:13:18.220
the y is always,
this is where we just say a third grade,

248
00:13:18.220 --> 00:13:23.180
the y is this right, so
you would remember it's along the side.

249
00:13:23.180 --> 00:13:27.020
We're looking at thousands of
people per minute intervals.

250
00:13:27.020 --> 00:13:30.970
And then if we were looking at the x axis,
which is along the bottom,

251
00:13:30.970 --> 00:13:34.870
what we're looking at is travel time
per minute, travel time in minutes,

252
00:13:34.870 --> 00:13:37.170
I should say, right?

253
00:13:37.170 --> 00:13:42.020
So how do you see this
histogram helping anyone?

254
00:13:42.020 --> 00:13:45.440
>> I can just quickly and
visually look at this diagram.

255
00:13:45.440 --> 00:13:52.425
And perhaps determine where I can
reconfigure my itinerary, or something.

256
00:13:52.425 --> 00:13:53.425
>> Exactly.
>> To help, yeah,

257
00:13:53.425 --> 00:13:55.825
just make that travel
process go a little smoother.

258
00:13:55.825 --> 00:13:57.155
>> Right, exactly.

259
00:13:57.155 --> 00:14:00.235
And on these charts on purpose,
we don't have a whole lot of detail,

260
00:14:00.235 --> 00:14:02.025
cuz we're trying to make them generic.

261
00:14:02.025 --> 00:14:06.655
But if you were in charge of this type
of thing, like say you were a train,

262
00:14:06.655 --> 00:14:09.965
or airplanes, or something like that,
you would know all kinds of things,

263
00:14:09.965 --> 00:14:11.085
like how much staff?

264
00:14:11.085 --> 00:14:12.560
When's our busy time?

265
00:14:12.560 --> 00:14:13.070
Right?
>> Yeah,

266
00:14:13.070 --> 00:14:15.490
and you could find any kind
of correlations there.

267
00:14:15.490 --> 00:14:18.800
Another question I did wanna ask you
though, in the slide before the one we

268
00:14:18.800 --> 00:14:22.190
were just looking at,
there was a space in between your columns.

269
00:14:22.190 --> 00:14:25.850
And in the second one they
were just pushed together.

270
00:14:25.850 --> 00:14:29.270
Is there a standard,
the one with the red, one more forward.

271
00:14:31.340 --> 00:14:32.540
Yes, that one right there.

272
00:14:32.540 --> 00:14:33.778
So there's a gap.

273
00:14:33.778 --> 00:14:39.110
Is it basically going to be by the book
that those columns have to be touching?

274
00:14:39.110 --> 00:14:41.320
Or are gaps acceptable?

275
00:14:41.320 --> 00:14:42.860
>> Gaps are acceptable.

276
00:14:42.860 --> 00:14:46.350
And a lot of it has to do with
the graphics program that you're using.

277
00:14:46.350 --> 00:14:49.310
The cool thing about histograms is
that you don't really even need

278
00:14:49.310 --> 00:14:50.270
a graphics program.

279
00:14:50.270 --> 00:14:55.190
So if you're in Excel,
you could put red, blue, yellow,

280
00:14:55.190 --> 00:14:58.750
orange on the top line on line one.

281
00:14:58.750 --> 00:15:02.870
And underneath that you could go ahead and
just put your numbers, highlight it,

282
00:15:02.870 --> 00:15:07.070
press F11 cuz that's your default key,
and then these are gonna come up.

283
00:15:07.070 --> 00:15:09.880
And they'll look,
they'll have gaps between them.

284
00:15:09.880 --> 00:15:12.870
In some statistical software programs,

285
00:15:12.870 --> 00:15:15.460
it's just the default is
that they're touching.

286
00:15:15.460 --> 00:15:17.720
But you can always go into the default and
change it.

287
00:15:17.720 --> 00:15:18.950
But to answer your question,

288
00:15:18.950 --> 00:15:22.990
it has more to do with what
the x-axis is trying to indicate.

289
00:15:22.990 --> 00:15:27.289
So if you have thing,
let's say you were looking at things

290
00:15:27.289 --> 00:15:30.898
typically that cost $1, $2, $3, $4.

291
00:15:30.898 --> 00:15:35.781
So obviously you're gonna have things
that are maybe in the $1.75 or

292
00:15:35.781 --> 00:15:39.482
something like that, so
that's where on the x-axis,

293
00:15:39.482 --> 00:15:44.870
it might be kind of right between
$1.75 and let's say $1.76 in cents.

294
00:15:44.870 --> 00:15:48.740
So what you're really looking for
is that x-axis.

295
00:15:48.740 --> 00:15:50.060
How does that relate.

296
00:15:50.060 --> 00:15:51.790
So you could do it either way.

297
00:15:51.790 --> 00:15:52.481
>> Okay.

298
00:15:52.481 --> 00:15:56.499
>> There is a tendency when
you make graphs in Excel for

299
00:15:56.499 --> 00:16:00.998
them to kinda make it prettier for
you and easier to read.

300
00:16:00.998 --> 00:16:02.288
But you can change that.

301
00:16:04.539 --> 00:16:06.885
Good question.

302
00:16:06.885 --> 00:16:09.313
Okay, so here's a histogram of testing.

303
00:16:09.313 --> 00:16:14.320
And this is when we're using this
to do buckets of information.

304
00:16:14.320 --> 00:16:15.780
Because remember,

305
00:16:15.780 --> 00:16:19.840
in Lean Six Sigma we're typically
tracking the history of the event.

306
00:16:19.840 --> 00:16:23.842
But this is just an example of how it
would look if we used a histogram in

307
00:16:23.842 --> 00:16:24.467
this way.

308
00:16:27.684 --> 00:16:29.570
And here's kind of just a fun one.

309
00:16:29.570 --> 00:16:32.320
This is another one of those
buckets of information.

310
00:16:32.320 --> 00:16:35.420
And if you'll see
the counter participants,

311
00:16:35.420 --> 00:16:40.280
flavor of ice cream, male versus female,
but just having this information if

312
00:16:40.280 --> 00:16:43.230
I really were an ice cream
shop might be kind of cool.

313
00:16:43.230 --> 00:16:45.170
>> Yeah, and it doesn't take much time

314
00:16:46.610 --> 00:16:49.120
to understand what you're
trying to convey here.

315
00:16:49.120 --> 00:16:49.860
You can just look at it,

316
00:16:49.860 --> 00:16:53.360
the colors are directly relating,
that's pretty easy to understand.

317
00:16:53.360 --> 00:16:56.900
>> Exactly, and this also goes
back to the discussion we had in

318
00:16:56.900 --> 00:16:58.679
the first session on the seven tools.

319
00:16:59.750 --> 00:17:02.780
Kinda keep in mind,
if I wanna show this as a presentation,

320
00:17:02.780 --> 00:17:04.530
this is really pretty, right?

321
00:17:04.530 --> 00:17:05.700
If I'm just doing it for

322
00:17:05.700 --> 00:17:10.630
my critical thinking,
I wanna just go do it quickly in Excel.

323
00:17:10.630 --> 00:17:15.272
Top line, line one, list whatever
it is I'm counting, the topics,

324
00:17:15.272 --> 00:17:20.390
the subjects, and in line two,
the amounts highlight, press F11.

325
00:17:20.390 --> 00:17:22.820
So just as a reminder,
it is kinda quick and dirty.

326
00:17:22.820 --> 00:17:25.870
It might not be as pretty
because the default is

327
00:17:25.870 --> 00:17:28.700
not gonna have all the graphics
stuff that I can put into it.

328
00:17:28.700 --> 00:17:31.850
But if I'm just quickly trying
to reason through something,

329
00:17:31.850 --> 00:17:33.290
I don't need it to make it look pretty.

330
00:17:37.380 --> 00:17:43.040
This is just a reminder that you can also
use a histogram to determine distribution.

331
00:17:43.040 --> 00:17:44.464
This is normal distribution.

332
00:17:44.464 --> 00:17:48.353
Another word for normal distribution is
that the process is stable and kinda keep

333
00:17:48.353 --> 00:17:52.356
in mind what you're always looking for is
like the pretty bell between the upper and

334
00:17:52.356 --> 00:17:55.700
lower control, and this histogram
can definitely be used for that.

335
00:17:56.830 --> 00:17:59.690
Okay, so the next one we're
gonna talk about is Pareto.

336
00:17:59.690 --> 00:18:04.020
Now, whereas a histogram talks
about the history of an event,

337
00:18:04.020 --> 00:18:07.530
the Pareto chart talks
about the type of event.

338
00:18:07.530 --> 00:18:11.488
So let's say you were getting
a lot of calls here at ITProTV.

339
00:18:11.488 --> 00:18:13.066
You're getting tons of calls.

340
00:18:13.066 --> 00:18:19.150
And so the person managing the incoming
calls say I have a ton of calls, right.

341
00:18:19.150 --> 00:18:20.416
So you do a histogram and

342
00:18:20.416 --> 00:18:25.260
you find out on the histogram that most
of those calls are coming in on Thursday.

343
00:18:25.260 --> 00:18:28.160
So your job is to try to fix that problem.

344
00:18:29.170 --> 00:18:33.161
And maybe what they would like you
to do is to hire an extra person to

345
00:18:33.161 --> 00:18:34.844
handle the calls, right?

346
00:18:34.844 --> 00:18:38.340
And that might be what you do, but
you're looking for other solutions.

347
00:18:38.340 --> 00:18:39.300
You do a histogram.

348
00:18:39.300 --> 00:18:43.070
You ask them every time a call comes
in on Monday, do a tick mark, Tuesday,

349
00:18:43.070 --> 00:18:44.320
Wednesday, Thursday.

350
00:18:44.320 --> 00:18:47.330
And then maybe after three weeks,
you average them together, and

351
00:18:47.330 --> 00:18:49.990
you find out Thursday has the most calls.

352
00:18:49.990 --> 00:18:53.990
So what are some other solutions
just based on a simple histogram?

353
00:18:53.990 --> 00:18:59.490
>> Maybe if you hired someone specifically
for Thursday and not a full-time employee.

354
00:18:59.490 --> 00:19:01.240
Help relieve that load.

355
00:19:01.240 --> 00:19:03.410
>> Exactly, and so
there's one alternative.

356
00:19:03.410 --> 00:19:06.840
So they've already offered you one,
let's hire someone.

357
00:19:06.840 --> 00:19:09.903
One of your solutions is let's
hire someone on Thursday.

358
00:19:09.903 --> 00:19:12.410
And then if we wanted
a third solution cuz we only

359
00:19:12.410 --> 00:19:15.922
have to come up with three solutions,
is that maybe on Thursdays,

360
00:19:15.922 --> 00:19:19.202
I'll get someone else in
the department to help out, right?

361
00:19:19.202 --> 00:19:22.570
So let's say we feel like we have
a good handle on the problem.

362
00:19:22.570 --> 00:19:27.810
We know it's busy on Thursdays, so
heck, we've solved the problem.

363
00:19:27.810 --> 00:19:31.922
But let's say the person answering
the phone says something such as,

364
00:19:31.922 --> 00:19:34.890
guess what,
I have too many calls everyday?

365
00:19:34.890 --> 00:19:35.750
You are right.

366
00:19:35.750 --> 00:19:40.170
On Thursdays,
it's worse than any other day, right?

367
00:19:40.170 --> 00:19:43.006
So I might tackle it
from another standpoint.

368
00:19:43.006 --> 00:19:45.940
I might say, well, could we get
a handle on the types of calls,

369
00:19:45.940 --> 00:19:47.780
what kinds of calls are you getting?

370
00:19:47.780 --> 00:19:50.354
So if you were at
the front desk of ITProTV,

371
00:19:50.354 --> 00:19:52.437
what kind of calls do you guys get?

372
00:19:52.437 --> 00:19:54.954
>> [LAUGH] I don't work
in customer service, but

373
00:19:54.954 --> 00:19:57.479
I have worked in almost
a help desk capacity.

374
00:19:57.479 --> 00:20:02.783
And you do see a lot of repetitive
types of tickets that would come into

375
00:20:02.783 --> 00:20:08.271
a help desk, things like, I forgot
my password, you need to reset it,

376
00:20:08.271 --> 00:20:13.050
or I've run out of disk space
on my system, things like that.

377
00:20:13.050 --> 00:20:13.920
>> Yeah, exactly.

378
00:20:15.490 --> 00:20:19.837
And if I were at the front of ITProTV, I
might just get, let's just say for example

379
00:20:19.837 --> 00:20:24.140
purposes, a lot of calls on directions
because you have a new location, right?

380
00:20:24.140 --> 00:20:25.803
So I might get a bunch of those calls.

381
00:20:25.803 --> 00:20:27.974
So let's say I get all of
these different calls.

382
00:20:27.974 --> 00:20:29.493
I get a lot of calls for IT and

383
00:20:29.493 --> 00:20:33.760
I get a lot of IT questions cuz I'm
the first person answering the phone.

384
00:20:33.760 --> 00:20:35.880
So I'm gonna have to transfer you.

385
00:20:35.880 --> 00:20:38.010
So another thing is that
I get a lot of calls for

386
00:20:38.010 --> 00:20:41.650
IT and I have to transfer you,
get a lot of calls for directions, right?

387
00:20:41.650 --> 00:20:44.970
Well, now I have a piece of
the puzzle that I didn't have before.

388
00:20:44.970 --> 00:20:47.030
So now that I know, and
just for this example,

389
00:20:47.030 --> 00:20:50.450
we're gonna say I get just
a ton of calls for location.

390
00:20:50.450 --> 00:20:53.337
So one of the things I could do is what?

391
00:20:53.337 --> 00:20:56.473
Maybe-
>> Have an automated prompt and say,

392
00:20:56.473 --> 00:20:58.410
press two for directions.

393
00:20:58.410 --> 00:20:59.660
>> Exactly.
>> Or something like that, yeah.

394
00:20:59.660 --> 00:21:02.437
>> Exactly, and
because I want three solutions,

395
00:21:02.437 --> 00:21:07.100
so my second solution might be I give
better directions on the website, right?

396
00:21:07.100 --> 00:21:08.439
>> Yes.
>> Well, the cool thing, and

397
00:21:08.439 --> 00:21:10.185
this is what I love about Lean Six Sigma.

398
00:21:10.185 --> 00:21:13.342
They say give three solutions,
but if number one and

399
00:21:13.342 --> 00:21:18.400
number two are not mutually exclusive,
my third solution is, I'm gonna do both.

400
00:21:18.400 --> 00:21:21.002
So I won.
It almost feels like cheating, right?

401
00:21:21.002 --> 00:21:23.330
>> But also don't forget,
you had the other option, right,

402
00:21:23.330 --> 00:21:24.780
of not doing anything else.

403
00:21:24.780 --> 00:21:26.248
So technically,
you're giving them a report.

404
00:21:26.248 --> 00:21:28.572
>> You are, and we can always add that.

405
00:21:28.572 --> 00:21:32.438
And I think that's such a big deal, is
that we often forget one of our solutions

406
00:21:32.438 --> 00:21:35.510
is, you know what,
maybe we need to leave it alone.

407
00:21:35.510 --> 00:21:42.540
Absolutely, so the types of
questions that I see most frequently

408
00:21:42.540 --> 00:21:47.210
on exams, now keep in mind,
at SSD Global Solution,

409
00:21:47.210 --> 00:21:51.200
we have a bank of 1,500 questions,
and you're gonna get 200 of them.

410
00:21:51.200 --> 00:21:55.050
So it's hard to just study
every single question.

411
00:21:55.050 --> 00:21:59.570
But the ones that I see most often through
my own company and through other companies

412
00:21:59.570 --> 00:22:03.540
is a lot of comparisons between what's
the difference between a Pareto chart and

413
00:22:03.540 --> 00:22:04.510
a histogram.

414
00:22:04.510 --> 00:22:07.940
And we already know before we look at
Pareto charts, the biggest difference

415
00:22:07.940 --> 00:22:12.807
is that the histogram typically
tracks the history of events,

416
00:22:12.807 --> 00:22:17.050
whereas the Pareto chart
tracks the types of events.

417
00:22:17.050 --> 00:22:20.670
And then the only other extra thing we
have to remember is that histograms

418
00:22:20.670 --> 00:22:21.910
can be used for other things.

419
00:22:21.910 --> 00:22:25.850
I can use it to collect buckets of
information, which in statistics,

420
00:22:25.850 --> 00:22:28.070
are called bins of information.

421
00:22:28.070 --> 00:22:31.318
I can use it to look at
distribution models.

422
00:22:31.318 --> 00:22:34.932
So whereas histograms have
some other applications,

423
00:22:34.932 --> 00:22:38.000
Pareto charts are pretty
much Pareto charts.

424
00:22:38.000 --> 00:22:42.954
So a Pareto chart is gonna track
the type of the event, and

425
00:22:42.954 --> 00:22:45.750
here is just sort of an example.

426
00:22:45.750 --> 00:22:48.094
I'll let you look at that.

427
00:22:48.094 --> 00:22:52.296
>> And the name of these types of charts
actually has a really cool back story,

428
00:22:52.296 --> 00:22:53.640
if you wouldn't mind.

429
00:22:53.640 --> 00:22:55.681
I remember in our class you did
give a bit of a back story.

430
00:22:55.681 --> 00:22:56.812
I thought it was interesting.

431
00:22:58.330 --> 00:23:02.820
>> It was designed by Villo,
I can never remember.

432
00:23:02.820 --> 00:23:03.430
>> Vilfredo?

433
00:23:03.430 --> 00:23:05.100
>> Yeah, Vilfredo Pareto.

434
00:23:05.100 --> 00:23:06.769
>> Or Wilfredo, it's something like that.

435
00:23:06.769 --> 00:23:10.288
>> Right, Pareto, and remember again,
a lot of times in Lean,

436
00:23:10.288 --> 00:23:12.940
they use the person who
popularized the tool.

437
00:23:12.940 --> 00:23:15.722
And the reason why he's so
popular or why this is so

438
00:23:15.722 --> 00:23:17.985
popular is that whole 80/20 rule.

439
00:23:17.985 --> 00:23:18.501
>> Yeah.

440
00:23:18.501 --> 00:23:21.720
>> And
the 80/20 rule says we should be focusing.

441
00:23:21.720 --> 00:23:22.910
We should laser focus.

442
00:23:22.910 --> 00:23:25.740
So this Pareto chart kind

443
00:23:25.740 --> 00:23:29.980
was birthed out of the whole concept
of let's focus on the important 80%.

444
00:23:29.980 --> 00:23:32.725
>> Yeah, and it was something that
was developed a long time ago.

445
00:23:32.725 --> 00:23:33.814
>> Yeah.
>> I think, what was it?

446
00:23:33.814 --> 00:23:37.709
He had seen 80% of
the citizens in his village or

447
00:23:37.709 --> 00:23:41.523
20% of the citizens owned 80% of the land.

448
00:23:41.523 --> 00:23:44.136
But even every day,
this rule still applies, so

449
00:23:44.136 --> 00:23:46.254
that's why it's such a cool concept.

450
00:23:46.254 --> 00:23:47.695
>> Yeah, I think so, too.

451
00:23:50.719 --> 00:23:53.909
One of the other things that you
wanna remember about Pareto charts is

452
00:23:53.909 --> 00:23:57.044
that in a histogram, because I'm
tracking the history of events,

453
00:23:57.044 --> 00:24:00.361
I really do wanna know what happened
on Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday.

454
00:24:00.361 --> 00:24:02.488
I wanna know what happened
in plant one plant two.

455
00:24:02.488 --> 00:24:04.520
Library one library two.

456
00:24:05.980 --> 00:24:07.370
Different groceries stores, right.

457
00:24:07.370 --> 00:24:10.610
I want to know that in
order of a time sequence.

458
00:24:10.610 --> 00:24:15.620
In a Pareto chart, I'm going to put my my
biggest thing first, and then go down.

459
00:24:15.620 --> 00:24:16.320
>> Okay.
>> So,

460
00:24:16.320 --> 00:24:19.290
what ever I collect the most
information on, and

461
00:24:19.290 --> 00:24:23.320
our example was we were getting the most
calls on where are you located.

462
00:24:23.320 --> 00:24:28.010
So that would represent that-
>> Lower hanging fruit, I guess.

463
00:24:28.010 --> 00:24:29.300
>> Right.
Exactly.

464
00:24:29.300 --> 00:24:32.090
And so we wanna arrange
these kind of sequentially.

465
00:24:32.090 --> 00:24:33.230
Like what's the most?

466
00:24:33.230 --> 00:24:34.410
What's the second?

467
00:24:34.410 --> 00:24:38.720
Now there's a general thing in statistics
that some of you may have already

468
00:24:38.720 --> 00:24:43.300
been aware of,
that the examples are pretty dismal.

469
00:24:43.300 --> 00:24:48.522
For example, if they're trying to explain
something like probability theory, they'll

470
00:24:48.522 --> 00:24:53.219
say something like the rabid dog bit
person A, but didn't bite person B, right?

471
00:24:53.219 --> 00:24:56.205
And what are the likelihood
of person B getting rabies?

472
00:24:56.205 --> 00:25:02.500
Or they love using cancer examples,
like false positives and false negatives.

473
00:25:02.500 --> 00:25:06.540
So what I want you to keep in mind is
that even though most statistic books

474
00:25:06.540 --> 00:25:11.320
are packaged in that way, this bar could
represent your biggest opportunity too.

475
00:25:11.320 --> 00:25:16.238
So if you were looking at what
sells in my store, right, And

476
00:25:16.238 --> 00:25:20.700
there's one that sells over the other
items, well, that's an opportunity, right?

477
00:25:20.700 --> 00:25:21.590
>> We want a way to identify that.

478
00:25:21.590 --> 00:25:22.170
>> Exactly.
So

479
00:25:22.170 --> 00:25:24.340
it doesn't always have to
be your biggest problem,

480
00:25:24.340 --> 00:25:27.759
but that's pretty much the way
it's packaged on your exams.

481
00:25:29.010 --> 00:25:32.040
If you where trying to find your biggest
problem, what chart would you use?

482
00:25:32.040 --> 00:25:33.710
And you would say Pareto chart, right?

483
00:25:33.710 --> 00:25:36.740
But I just wanted everyone to know
that it does not have to be a problem,

484
00:25:36.740 --> 00:25:37.980
it can be something positive.

485
00:25:37.980 --> 00:25:40.970
>> But if you think about it, if
everything is going great within a company

486
00:25:40.970 --> 00:25:44.990
or organization, they might not see
a need to hire an external professional.

487
00:25:44.990 --> 00:25:49.740
But when things start to get rough,
then they look for help right so.

488
00:25:49.740 --> 00:25:51.790
>> Yeah, exactly, perfect example.

489
00:25:51.790 --> 00:25:55.590
Okay, so on this one,
we're looking at causes of poor quality

490
00:25:55.590 --> 00:25:58.260
on this particular slide that
you're looking at right now.

491
00:25:58.260 --> 00:26:02.119
And you'll see it's saying
the biggest problem is what?

492
00:26:03.580 --> 00:26:04.430
>> Your poor design.

493
00:26:04.430 --> 00:26:09.640
>> Right, so
the idea is if I tackle that poor design,

494
00:26:09.640 --> 00:26:12.530
I've set aside a lot of the issues.

495
00:26:12.530 --> 00:26:17.610
So on some Pareto charts what happens is
if you'll notice there at the bottom,

496
00:26:17.610 --> 00:26:21.170
they'll put a line to kind of
help you make that decision.

497
00:26:21.170 --> 00:26:23.249
So in this particular example,

498
00:26:23.249 --> 00:26:28.408
that first line if you looked all the way
across it, starts at the top of the bar,

499
00:26:28.408 --> 00:26:32.490
and I don't know if you can see
the little number one on the bar.

500
