00:26:32.490 --> 00:26:37.960
But it starts at the top, and if I we're
to just go in a lateral way across,

501
00:26:37.960 --> 00:26:40.440
it would say that if I
took care of problem A,

502
00:26:40.440 --> 00:26:45.120
I would probably solve about what,
maybe 50, 52% of my problems.

503
00:26:46.480 --> 00:26:47.450
>> Yeah.

504
00:26:47.450 --> 00:26:50.260
>> And so, we're gonna look at something
that makes it make a little bit

505
00:26:50.260 --> 00:26:51.130
more sense.

506
00:26:51.130 --> 00:26:55.880
So, here again, if I looked at the top
that first blue bar on the left

507
00:26:55.880 --> 00:26:59.010
all the way across,
I would have percentages.

508
00:26:59.010 --> 00:27:01.930
I don't have them written in right now,
but if I had a percentage,

509
00:27:01.930 --> 00:27:05.130
then I could say to you,
I know that if we solved this problem,

510
00:27:05.130 --> 00:27:07.740
we would solve
>> We would only be left with this

511
00:27:07.740 --> 00:27:08.870
percentage of issues.

512
00:27:08.870 --> 00:27:10.180
>> Exactly.

513
00:27:10.180 --> 00:27:11.840
So let's put the percentages in now.

514
00:27:11.840 --> 00:27:12.400
>> Okay.

515
00:27:12.400 --> 00:27:14.580
>> It makes it even more easier.

516
00:27:14.580 --> 00:27:18.300
I just kind of want to lead you up to
you're gonna have to come up with that

517
00:27:18.300 --> 00:27:19.140
On the other side.

518
00:27:19.140 --> 00:27:23.590
So, in this case,
we're looking at just problems,

519
00:27:23.590 --> 00:27:28.370
and this looks like problems
in an IT department.

520
00:27:28.370 --> 00:27:29.270
Looks like it to me.

521
00:27:29.270 --> 00:27:30.418
And the first one is-
>> Sorry,

522
00:27:30.418 --> 00:27:32.840
I'm trying to like squint here,
I'm like, what does that say?

523
00:27:32.840 --> 00:27:34.492
>> So it says, unable to download.

524
00:27:34.492 --> 00:27:35.390
>> Okay.

525
00:27:35.390 --> 00:27:41.340
>> So that's my problem, and you'll see
that my little dot is right in that bar.

526
00:27:41.340 --> 00:27:42.992
So, if I looked across.

527
00:27:42.992 --> 00:27:44.100
>> Almost [INAUDIBLE].

528
00:27:44.100 --> 00:27:46.560
>> Yeah.
And that's huge, because if I go in and

529
00:27:46.560 --> 00:27:53.480
I tell you, If we take care of this one
thing, look at how far ahead we are.

530
00:27:53.480 --> 00:27:56.140
Now, some people have to look at this.

531
00:27:56.140 --> 00:27:59.390
Here's unsatisfactory customer service.

532
00:27:59.390 --> 00:28:02.330
So, I get a lot of questions, like,
does it matter where we put this stuff?

533
00:28:02.330 --> 00:28:06.280
You wanna put it wherever it makes sense,
as long as the largest bar is first, and

534
00:28:06.280 --> 00:28:07.410
then it goes down.

535
00:28:07.410 --> 00:28:11.970
Now, if you get a flat, little tiny skinny
bar, then what you're gonna, probably,

536
00:28:11.970 --> 00:28:14.590
do is discount that.

537
00:28:14.590 --> 00:28:18.730
And, if you're in a statistical program
that's making your Pareto chart,

538
00:28:18.730 --> 00:28:22.750
it's gonna ask you, do you want us
to get rid of the one off bars?

539
00:28:22.750 --> 00:28:26.670
Now if you're doing this in Excel,
remember in Excel, that the way we build

540
00:28:26.670 --> 00:28:32.840
a histogram, a quick and dirty histogram,
is that on line one, we put the topics.

541
00:28:32.840 --> 00:28:36.650
On line two, we put the numerical
information that we gathered.

542
00:28:36.650 --> 00:28:38.550
Highlight, press F11.

543
00:28:38.550 --> 00:28:41.190
Well, Pareto chart's pretty
much the same thing.

544
00:28:41.190 --> 00:28:45.280
And the only thing that's different is
that you're gonna have to manually move

545
00:28:45.280 --> 00:28:49.200
those columns around before you hit F11,
because you want to make sure.

546
00:28:49.200 --> 00:28:52.915
You might be collecting the information,
and the things in column 5-

547
00:28:52.915 --> 00:28:54.765
>> But, they are in the descending order.

548
00:28:54.765 --> 00:28:57.855
>> Exactly, so that's the only thing you
are doing is that you are manually moving

549
00:28:57.855 --> 00:28:58.955
those things around.

550
00:28:58.955 --> 00:29:02.025
So sometimes you really don't need
a statistical package to build something

551
00:29:02.025 --> 00:29:06.085
like this, and especially if it's just
something that you are using for yourself,

552
00:29:06.085 --> 00:29:08.125
a paper and pencil tool.

553
00:29:08.125 --> 00:29:09.460
>> Okay.
>> Right, so.

554
00:29:11.271 --> 00:29:12.850
Here's just another example.

555
00:29:12.850 --> 00:29:15.250
I think we're about to wrap
up on our histograms and

556
00:29:15.250 --> 00:29:19.470
Pareto charts, but
here's just another example.

557
00:29:19.470 --> 00:29:24.531
It says Pareto chart of late
arrivals by reported cause, right?

558
00:29:27.316 --> 00:29:31.280
And the next one we're gonna be
discussing in session, in part three.

559
00:29:31.280 --> 00:29:31.800
>> Part three.

560
00:29:31.800 --> 00:29:33.110
I think we made it to part three.

561
00:29:33.110 --> 00:29:34.070
>> I think so.
>> We have what left?

562
00:29:34.070 --> 00:29:36.960
We have scattered diagrams and
control charts.

563
00:29:36.960 --> 00:29:40.000
And there's really a lot of information
that we don't want to short change you on.

564
00:29:40.000 --> 00:29:44.050
So let's just go ahead and
wrap up for this particular episode.

565
00:29:44.050 --> 00:29:46.800
But we do have these other topics and
tools to cover.

566
00:29:46.800 --> 00:29:48.110
So please don't go anywhere.

567
00:29:48.110 --> 00:29:48.680
Stay tuned.

568
00:29:48.680 --> 00:29:50.510
We have a lot more headed your way.

569
00:29:50.510 --> 00:29:53.630
But I'm gonna go ahead and
sign off as your host Cherokee Boose.

570
00:29:53.630 --> 00:29:57.240
>> And this is Dr. Tara Vanzant Stern
with SSD Global Solutions.

571
00:29:57.240 --> 00:29:59.099
>> We'll see you next
time here at ITPRO.TV.

572
00:30:00.858 --> 00:30:06.702
[MUSIC]

573
00:30:06.702 --> 00:30:10.040
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: This episode is a continuation of the seven tools of quality. Dr. Terra Vanzant Stern and Cherokee Boose identify practical applications for Scatter Diagrams to help identify correlations or the absence of a correlation. They also examine line charts, run charts, and control charts.
episodes.title: Seven Tools of Quality Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:06.481
Welcome to ITPro.TV, I'm your host,
Don Pezet [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:06.481 --> 00:00:08.280
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.280 --> 00:00:12.460
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

4
00:00:12.460 --> 00:00:17.630
>> Welcome to your Lean Six Sigma Green
Belt Certification Preparation series.

5
00:00:17.630 --> 00:00:20.120
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:20.120 --> 00:00:21.790
This is actually a part three,

7
00:00:21.790 --> 00:00:26.180
we made it all the way to a part
three of our seven quality tools.

8
00:00:26.180 --> 00:00:30.220
Here we have Dr. Terra Vanzant Stern
in studios to go ahead and

9
00:00:30.220 --> 00:00:32.820
wrap up those last couple of
tools that we had lingering.

10
00:00:32.820 --> 00:00:33.993
Thank you for being with us today.

11
00:00:33.993 --> 00:00:35.370
>> Thank you Cherokee.

12
00:00:35.370 --> 00:00:40.490
And I think, I'd like to just remind
people, if we can go to my slide deck.

13
00:00:40.490 --> 00:00:44.570
That there are a number of the tools
that we have already covered.

14
00:00:44.570 --> 00:00:49.360
So the ones that are in red,
we've actually talked about.

15
00:00:49.360 --> 00:00:53.576
And just briefly as we move into those
last two tools I just want to do kind of

16
00:00:53.576 --> 00:00:57.122
a quick synopsis of those tools
that we've already covered.

17
00:00:57.122 --> 00:00:57.659
>> Sure.

18
00:00:58.800 --> 00:01:02.114
The first one of course was
the Fishbone Diagram and

19
00:01:02.114 --> 00:01:07.369
this is just an example of what that would
look like and this is using that 6M's.

20
00:01:07.369 --> 00:01:11.641
We said in the other session that
you could also use the 3P's or

21
00:01:11.641 --> 00:01:17.270
you could just use whatever you wanted for
those major contributors.

22
00:01:17.270 --> 00:01:20.180
And then we looked at flowcharts and
we said that really,

23
00:01:20.180 --> 00:01:21.580
the big thing about flowcharting.

24
00:01:21.580 --> 00:01:25.750
Which a lot of times in Lean Six Sigma,
means we're doing a process map.

25
00:01:25.750 --> 00:01:28.780
That is if we stick to these symbols and
we memorize these symbols.

26
00:01:28.780 --> 00:01:31.003
We're pretty okay on any test.

27
00:01:32.412 --> 00:01:34.841
Then we talked a little
bit about histogram.

28
00:01:34.841 --> 00:01:38.956
And one of the things that I wanted to
remind you of is the frequency diagram.

29
00:01:38.956 --> 00:01:40.867
If you are taking the Six Sigma test,

30
00:01:40.867 --> 00:01:44.060
there's questions related
to frequency diagrams.

31
00:01:44.060 --> 00:01:46.970
If you kinda cycled back to,
it's really a simple concept.

32
00:01:46.970 --> 00:01:51.570
It's just a lot of times frequency
diagrams have a lot of huge numbers and so

33
00:01:51.570 --> 00:01:53.010
it seems kind of complicated.

34
00:01:53.010 --> 00:01:56.700
But all I'm trying to do is say,
how often does blue show up, right?

35
00:01:56.700 --> 00:02:01.320
So I think if you kind of concentrate
on that in the lean six sigma exams and

36
00:02:01.320 --> 00:02:03.820
certainly the ones through SSD Global.

37
00:02:03.820 --> 00:02:08.750
What we're wanting you to know is that
a histogram typically, in lean six sigma,

38
00:02:08.750 --> 00:02:11.070
is used to track the history of events.

39
00:02:11.070 --> 00:02:14.217
And here's an example of that,
that we saw on one of the other sessions.

40
00:02:15.560 --> 00:02:18.205
And then we went on to Pareto Charts and

41
00:02:18.205 --> 00:02:23.423
we said there are a lot of questions on
the exam that on all of it, all exams.

42
00:02:23.423 --> 00:02:27.615
Leaning Six Sigma and Lean Six Sigma about
the differences between Pareto Charts and

43
00:02:27.615 --> 00:02:28.274
Histogram.

44
00:02:28.274 --> 00:02:31.450
So you're gonna at least probably see
one or two of those kind of questions.

45
00:02:31.450 --> 00:02:35.430
And we said that a Pareto chart basically
tracks the type of events, right?

46
00:02:35.430 --> 00:02:38.190
As opposed to the history of those events.

47
00:02:38.190 --> 00:02:41.012
We did also talk about check sheets.

48
00:02:41.012 --> 00:02:43.067
Even though I didn't show you.

49
00:02:43.067 --> 00:02:43.994
>> It's a to do list [LAUGH].

50
00:02:43.994 --> 00:02:45.000
>> A to do list, right.

51
00:02:45.000 --> 00:02:46.019
So we talked about that.

52
00:02:46.019 --> 00:02:50.691
And then when we left up when we finished
in our previous session we were just about

53
00:02:50.691 --> 00:02:52.627
to talk about scatter diagrams.

54
00:02:55.994 --> 00:03:00.949
So the first thing I want you to know
about scatter diagrams is that a lot of

55
00:03:00.949 --> 00:03:06.148
people, when they do the seven tools
of quality, instead of saying scatter

56
00:03:06.148 --> 00:03:11.690
diagram, they'll say a correlation
analysis or a correlation chart.

57
00:03:11.690 --> 00:03:15.744
However scatter diagrams can be used for
a number of different things.

58
00:03:15.744 --> 00:03:20.222
Now again in lean six sigma I'm
mostly using it for correlation.

59
00:03:20.222 --> 00:03:26.463
Now a lot of you from stat 101 remember
that correlation and causation.

60
00:03:26.463 --> 00:03:31.337
Correlation doesn't necessarily mean
causation they make you memorize

61
00:03:31.337 --> 00:03:36.790
that backwards and forwards, In Six Sigma,
that's correct, and in Lean.

62
00:03:36.790 --> 00:03:39.620
In Lean Six Sigma it's really not so

63
00:03:39.620 --> 00:03:42.940
much the correlation that we're
looking for, is the triggers.

64
00:03:42.940 --> 00:03:46.910
So we're almost saying,
correlation is kind of causation,

65
00:03:46.910 --> 00:03:50.300
even though technically that's
not correct in statistical terms.

66
00:03:50.300 --> 00:03:54.624
So if you look at the patterns,
the one that I see most often when I do

67
00:03:54.624 --> 00:03:59.426
a correlation study or an analysis is
that when this says no correlation.

68
00:03:59.426 --> 00:04:03.173
And I'm always so excited if I
see the data points moving up or

69
00:04:03.173 --> 00:04:06.935
down that demonstrates positive or
negative correlation.

70
00:04:06.935 --> 00:04:12.304
So an example of that, a popular example
I use is that let's say the boss

71
00:04:12.304 --> 00:04:17.062
says every time it rains or
snows people are late to work I mean.

72
00:04:17.062 --> 00:04:20.530
And so you do a correlation study, and you
sit there and you use your check sheet.

73
00:04:20.530 --> 00:04:24.260
You just start watching,
rainy day, who's late, right?

74
00:04:24.260 --> 00:04:26.720
And then you put it together
in a correlation diagram, and

75
00:04:26.720 --> 00:04:29.300
maybe you come up with no correlation.

76
00:04:29.300 --> 00:04:31.500
It's that there's a perceived correlation.

77
00:04:31.500 --> 00:04:36.750
So one way that you would be using
correlation diagrams in Lean Six Sigma,

78
00:04:36.750 --> 00:04:39.460
is kind of a funny way
to disprove something.

79
00:04:39.460 --> 00:04:43.020
So if you have a solution,
and the person says,

80
00:04:43.020 --> 00:04:46.080
well, every single time we do that,
this happens.

81
00:04:46.080 --> 00:04:48.637
You might do a correlation analysis,
and find out.

82
00:04:48.637 --> 00:04:49.376
>> To verify of that's true.

83
00:04:49.376 --> 00:04:50.600
>> Yeah, exactly.

84
00:04:50.600 --> 00:04:53.750
And there's one tip that we
always use in Lean Six Sigma,

85
00:04:53.750 --> 00:04:57.900
if the data that you have to
deliver in the chart is negative,

86
00:04:57.900 --> 00:05:02.570
or contradictory to what
your boss is saying.

87
00:05:02.570 --> 00:05:05.450
So, it's either negative data or
your boss is wrong.

88
00:05:05.450 --> 00:05:07.600
You wanna make sure that you
put the data on the screen and

89
00:05:07.600 --> 00:05:12.015
then, step away from the data and
say the data reflex, as oppose.

90
00:05:12.015 --> 00:05:14.875
Because it really is still
as Lean Six Sigma person,

91
00:05:14.875 --> 00:05:18.255
you're doing a lot of problem solving and
it really is easy for

92
00:05:18.255 --> 00:05:21.184
people to get into that kill
the messenger syndrome.

93
00:05:21.184 --> 00:05:24.996
>> Right, you're not trying to point
the blame on anyone, you just wanna convey

94
00:05:24.996 --> 00:05:27.968
that message or letting the data
convey the message for you.

95
00:05:27.968 --> 00:05:30.510
[LAUGH]
>> Exactly, exactly.

96
00:05:30.510 --> 00:05:33.400
So you'll see that, back to the diagram,

97
00:05:33.400 --> 00:05:38.580
you'll see that positive correlation
the data points are moving up.

98
00:05:38.580 --> 00:05:43.990
Now in the set, look at the very
first one on the left-hand side.

99
00:05:43.990 --> 00:05:48.154
Now, if you look at the second one,
the data points are moving together, but

100
00:05:48.154 --> 00:05:49.579
they're not real tight.

101
00:05:49.579 --> 00:05:50.836
>> Right.
>> Right, okay, so

102
00:05:50.836 --> 00:05:53.480
there could be positive correlation.

103
00:05:53.480 --> 00:05:56.240
Now, in the Six Sigma exams,

104
00:05:56.240 --> 00:06:00.880
keep in mind that they're going to want
to know the formulas behind these graphs.

105
00:06:00.880 --> 00:06:02.610
We've build these graphs in Excel,

106
00:06:02.610 --> 00:06:06.840
and all the statistical data is just
being prepared in the background for us.

107
00:06:06.840 --> 00:06:07.850
We don't see it.

108
00:06:07.850 --> 00:06:14.720
On the Six Sigma exams you wanna be aware
of the numbers involved with correlation.

109
00:06:14.720 --> 00:06:21.620
So correlation has a schedule similar to
the Sigma schedule and the CPK schedule.

110
00:06:21.620 --> 00:06:26.081
And I'll remind you on the Sigma
schedule there's six Sigmas, so

111
00:06:26.081 --> 00:06:29.540
one through six, so there's no seven.

112
00:06:29.540 --> 00:06:34.205
On the CPK schedule,
the number index is one to two.

113
00:06:34.205 --> 00:06:38.564
So on six sigma you're not going to have a
zero, you're not going to have a 6.5, you

114
00:06:38.564 --> 00:06:43.030
can only have a number one to six, you're
not going to have any negative numbers.

115
00:06:43.030 --> 00:06:48.476
Okay on the CPK scale you
have a number one to two.

116
00:06:48.476 --> 00:06:52.720
So CPK is gonna fall somewhere 1.1,
1.2, all.

117
00:06:52.720 --> 00:06:56.590
It can't get any higher than two or
any lower than one.

118
00:06:56.590 --> 00:07:03.860
On a correlation schedule, what I'm
looking at is if my correlation is a 0.8.

119
00:07:03.860 --> 00:07:08.190
Or higher that indicates
positive correlations.

120
00:07:08.190 --> 00:07:13.415
And that's because on the correlation
scale the index is plus one,

121
00:07:13.415 --> 00:07:16.880
is minus one, through plus one, okay.

122
00:07:16.880 --> 00:07:20.600
So, those are the kinda things in the six
sigma world that you wanna be just

123
00:07:20.600 --> 00:07:21.310
cognizant of.

124
00:07:21.310 --> 00:07:24.720
That's gonna be in your student package
if you're studying for those exams.

125
00:07:24.720 --> 00:07:28.010
We are so used to, like I said,
punching some buttons and

126
00:07:28.010 --> 00:07:29.240
getting the scattered diagram.

127
00:07:29.240 --> 00:07:31.450
But they're really is some math and
science behind that.

128
00:07:34.080 --> 00:07:37.290
Now, here's just another
kind of fun example.

129
00:07:37.290 --> 00:07:40.540
I think it's a little easier to read.

130
00:07:40.540 --> 00:07:44.520
So you're gonna have your Y-axis,
and your X-axis, and

131
00:07:44.520 --> 00:07:46.620
then you're gonna have your
degrees of correlation.

132
00:07:46.620 --> 00:07:50.830
The tighter they are together,
the more they are positive or negative.

133
00:07:50.830 --> 00:07:53.348
So you're looking for that tightness.

134
00:07:53.348 --> 00:07:57.893
Now, when we're looking
at correlation analysis,

135
00:07:57.893 --> 00:08:02.946
we're looking at how the Y And
the xs relate to one another.

136
00:08:02.946 --> 00:08:06.556
When we're looking at
a regression analysis,

137
00:08:06.556 --> 00:08:12.370
we're looking at how does the inputs,
which are the xs, impact the ys.

138
00:08:12.370 --> 00:08:13.510
That's the difference.

139
00:08:13.510 --> 00:08:17.435
So we can use that for our thing as well.

140
00:08:17.435 --> 00:08:22.361
Okay, so on a scatter diagram,
now this scatter diagram is collecting

141
00:08:22.361 --> 00:08:26.950
information about water consumption
based on the temperature.

142
00:08:26.950 --> 00:08:29.340
And what does this one indicate?

143
00:08:29.340 --> 00:08:31.700
>> Well, the higher the temperature,
the more the consumption.

144
00:08:31.700 --> 00:08:37.020
Let's see here, on the left hand side,
what are we reflecting by?

145
00:08:37.020 --> 00:08:37.530
Ounces.

146
00:08:37.530 --> 00:08:40.880
Okay, so
[LAUGH] I feel like turning my head here.

let's say I was tracking

371
00:21:04.260 --> 00:21:09.050
patient falls at a hospital or
mistakes in IT department.

372
00:21:10.100 --> 00:21:12.460
The same person could fall twice,

373
00:21:12.460 --> 00:21:15.180
the same person could call
the help desk twice, right?

374
00:21:15.180 --> 00:21:15.810
>> Yes.
>> So

375
00:21:15.810 --> 00:21:20.660
I'm looking at incidents versus multiple
incidents from the same person.

376
00:21:20.660 --> 00:21:24.990
So each one of those have a different
strategy of gaining information and

377
00:21:24.990 --> 00:21:28.800
in the Lean and Six Sigma tests, they're
pretty married to the fact that you need

378
00:21:28.800 --> 00:21:32.640
to know the strategy to put
the control chart together.

379
00:21:32.640 --> 00:21:36.550
In Lean Six Sigma,
because the output of that control chart.

380
00:21:36.550 --> 00:21:39.120
It doesn't really matter if
it's an mp-chart, a p-chart,

381
00:21:39.120 --> 00:21:43.390
an x chart, all those charts that are in
your student package that explain this.

382
00:21:43.390 --> 00:21:46.110
It doesn't really matter,
the output's gonna look the same.

383
00:21:46.110 --> 00:21:50.140
So in Lean Six Sigma, we say, okay, well,
there's gonna be an upper control limit.

384
00:21:50.140 --> 00:21:52.080
There's gonna be a lower control limit.

385
00:21:52.080 --> 00:21:55.640
And you're gonna have a middle line that
you're kind of judging against, right?

386
00:21:55.640 --> 00:21:58.960
>> Right.
>> So even though there's all these

387
00:21:58.960 --> 00:22:02.640
different types of charts,
it's more about the strategy on how to

388
00:22:02.640 --> 00:22:06.280
build that chart and collect information
than what the chart actually looks like.

389
00:22:06.280 --> 00:22:08.290
>> Okay.
>> Lean Six Sigma has a tendency to

390
00:22:08.290 --> 00:22:12.350
use simple control charts as opposed
to the more complicated ones.

391
00:22:12.350 --> 00:22:16.090
Now there's a lot of statistical packages
that help you with control charts.

392
00:22:16.090 --> 00:22:19.480
But the trend,
even in statistical packages these days,

393
00:22:19.480 --> 00:22:22.640
is that you highlight the information
on your Excel spreadsheet.

394
00:22:22.640 --> 00:22:25.600
You press a button and
it gives you multiple control charts, and

395
00:22:25.600 --> 00:22:26.860
you pick the one that you want.

396
00:22:26.860 --> 00:22:29.545
>> Okay.
>> So, that's why it's not as big a deal.

397
00:22:29.545 --> 00:22:32.170
Again,there's all kinds of math and

398
00:22:32.170 --> 00:22:35.500
statistics behind developing
all these different things.

399
00:22:35.500 --> 00:22:41.170
So if I'm looking at the percentage of
defects within a particular unit, there's

400
00:22:41.170 --> 00:22:45.600
a kind of mathematical formula that I'm
looking at to create the control chart.

401
00:22:45.600 --> 00:22:50.370
In Lean Six Sigma, the cool thing is that,
we just care about the chart.

402
00:22:50.370 --> 00:22:53.550
It's just the chart, and we're saying,
okay, there's an upper and

403
00:22:53.550 --> 00:22:57.210
lower control limit, or upper and
lower specification limit.

404
00:22:58.690 --> 00:23:02.670
Sometimes there's an upper and lower
tolerance limit for a piece of equipment,

405
00:23:02.670 --> 00:23:07.290
and we're just gonna track the activity
inside that upper and lower control limit.

406
00:23:07.290 --> 00:23:10.770
Now when we're talking about
the difference between a run chart and

407
00:23:10.770 --> 00:23:14.700
a control chart you'll notice that
the control chart also has a middle line.

408
00:23:14.700 --> 00:23:15.670
So if we can go back and

409
00:23:15.670 --> 00:23:21.590
look at my slide, you'll notice that
the control chart has a middle line.

410
00:23:21.590 --> 00:23:25.420
The big thing is that in a run chart
it's almost always an average and

411
00:23:25.420 --> 00:23:28.810
it could be a median, right.

412
00:23:28.810 --> 00:23:32.610
In a control chart that little line
can represent a myriad of things.

413
00:23:32.610 --> 00:23:34.930
Fortunately, it's usually an average.

414
00:23:34.930 --> 00:23:35.470
>> Okay.

415
00:23:35.470 --> 00:23:41.660
>> However, it could be a mean, it could
be a mode, it could be a benchmark.

416
00:23:41.660 --> 00:23:42.190
>> A goal.

417
00:23:42.190 --> 00:23:47.020
>> It could be a goal, it could be a line
that the customer came up with that has

418
00:23:47.020 --> 00:23:50.220
absolutely no science at all,
this is what I want, right?

419
00:23:51.250 --> 00:23:55.649
So, kind of keep in mind that you want to
know what that middle line means, right.

420
00:23:55.649 --> 00:23:59.407
Now, when you're working on
a statistical package, and

421
00:23:59.407 --> 00:24:04.318
you have the statistical package create
the control chart for you, The stat

422
00:24:04.318 --> 00:24:09.613
package is automatically gonna set that
upper and lower control limit, upper and

423
00:24:09.613 --> 00:24:15.550
lower specification limit, or upper and
lower tolerance limit at three sigma.

424
00:24:15.550 --> 00:24:17.000
So what I want you to think of is,

425
00:24:17.000 --> 00:24:22.590
a control chart is nothing more than
distribution turned on its side.

426
00:24:22.590 --> 00:24:27.370
So if you looked at a distribution model,
and remember we talked a lot about

427
00:24:27.370 --> 00:24:32.440
how we've got a pretty little bell between
the upper and lower control limits.

428
00:24:32.440 --> 00:24:34.730
Then our process is in control.

429
00:24:34.730 --> 00:24:37.040
Well, so,
if you take those distribution models and

430
00:24:37.040 --> 00:24:40.620
you flip them on their side,
voila, you have a control chart.

431
00:24:40.620 --> 00:24:43.409
It's just easier to look at
more specific data that way.

432
00:24:43.409 --> 00:24:43.909
>> Okay.

433
00:24:45.120 --> 00:24:48.660
>> Now,
we used to believe that the way, and

434
00:24:48.660 --> 00:24:51.810
I'm just gonna leave this up as
I'm speaking, this next chart.

435
00:24:52.830 --> 00:24:58.590
We used to believe that as long as the
data points behaved within the upper and

436
00:24:58.590 --> 00:25:01.990
lower control limit,
then our process was in control.

437
00:25:01.990 --> 00:25:05.700
And statistical process
control is an entire science

438
00:25:05.700 --> 00:25:10.420
of how the data points behave in
the upper and lower control limits.

439
00:25:10.420 --> 00:25:12.870
In the lean test only,
you don't have to worry about that.

440
00:25:12.870 --> 00:25:15.190
In the six sigma test, lots and

441
00:25:15.190 --> 00:25:19.020
lots of questions about how the data
points behave within the upper and

442
00:25:19.020 --> 00:25:24.390
lower control limits, and the math that
goes behind how those data points behave.

443
00:25:24.390 --> 00:25:27.710
In Lean Six Sigma,
we're pretty much looking for patterns.

444
00:25:27.710 --> 00:25:29.050
We're saying you know what?

445
00:25:29.050 --> 00:25:32.780
We know that just because the data
points are within the upper and

446
00:25:32.780 --> 00:25:36.610
lower control limit, doesn't necessarily
mean we're out of the woods.

447
00:25:36.610 --> 00:25:41.710
For example, if I had a bunch of data
points moving, say, from the lower control

448
00:25:41.710 --> 00:25:47.110
limit up to the, well,
this one doesn't show that, okay.

449
00:25:47.110 --> 00:25:47.825
Well, nevermind.

450
00:25:47.825 --> 00:25:50.990
You're just gonna have to
visualize this with me.

451
00:25:50.990 --> 00:25:55.180
If I had a data point that was starting
at the lower control limit and

452
00:25:55.180 --> 00:25:59.070
slowly moving to the upper control limit,
what is that indicating?

453
00:26:00.290 --> 00:26:01.650
>> Some kind of rise, a trend.

454
00:26:01.650 --> 00:26:02.540
>> Yeah, exactly.

455
00:26:02.540 --> 00:26:05.923
>> I'm running out of, like I said,
with my help desk calls,

456
00:26:05.923 --> 00:26:09.317
I'm slowly running out of
storage space in my system, so.

457
00:26:09.317 --> 00:26:12.222
>> Exactly, and
looking at a trend is huge,

458
00:26:12.222 --> 00:26:16.622
because that next data point
might go over your upper control.

459
00:26:16.622 --> 00:26:20.887
But up to this point,
if you remember our PIN example,

460
00:26:20.887 --> 00:26:24.688
where the PINs could be
a little bit too small, or

461
00:26:24.688 --> 00:26:28.780
a little bit too big, but
they would still fit.

462
00:26:28.780 --> 00:26:33.410
But if they were too big or too little,
they were actually gonna fit.

463
00:26:33.410 --> 00:26:36.740
So lets say we were looking at that, and
instead of seeing that pretty bell that

464
00:26:36.740 --> 00:26:41.860
indicated we're doing pretty well, if we
turned it on side and started tracking

465
00:26:41.860 --> 00:26:45.750
it and notice, you know what, the next
data point is gonna go out of control.

466
00:26:45.750 --> 00:26:49.300
So everything I'm working on that month,
maybe the manufacturer isn't going to buy.

467
00:26:49.300 --> 00:26:55.170
Now, there's a lot of reasons that
companies go under and go bankrupt.

468
00:26:55.170 --> 00:26:59.220
But a lot of times, it's because their
process is slowly going out of control,

469
00:26:59.220 --> 00:27:02.800
and they don't know it, because they're
still functioning within that upper and

470
00:27:02.800 --> 00:27:03.750
lower control limit.

471
00:27:03.750 --> 00:27:05.220
So they think they're fine.

472
00:27:05.220 --> 00:27:07.190
>> So
we're talking not just a one time deal.

473
00:27:07.190 --> 00:27:10.675
This is something you probably wanna
continually monitor and maintain if,

474
00:27:10.675 --> 00:27:12.696
well, you don't wanna go out of business.

475
00:27:12.696 --> 00:27:14.560
[LAUGH]
>> Exactly, exactly.

476
00:27:14.560 --> 00:27:15.940
And the thing is,

477
00:27:15.940 --> 00:27:19.220
is that there are other patterns
too that you need to watch out for.

478
00:27:19.220 --> 00:27:24.870
Keep in mind, in Six Sigma, statistical
process control is a whole science

479
00:27:24.870 --> 00:27:28.570
around how those data points behave, and
you wanna get very familiar with that.

480
00:27:28.570 --> 00:27:32.000
We're gonna give you some really good
guidance in your student packet.

481
00:27:33.130 --> 00:27:36.770
Some kind of learning tips,
if you're taking the Six Sigma test only.

482
00:27:36.770 --> 00:27:42.180
But in Lean Six Sigma,
the only thing we really care about is

483
00:27:42.180 --> 00:27:46.320
that they stay inside those limits,
and then how those data points react.

484
00:27:46.320 --> 00:27:49.920
So a trend would be a perfect example
of something we wouldn't want.

485
00:27:49.920 --> 00:27:52.937
>> Right.
>> However, another thing that's touching

486
00:27:52.937 --> 00:27:57.570
the upper and lower control limits,
what if it looks like a shark's tooth.

487
00:27:57.570 --> 00:27:59.920
Like it went to the top, then it went
to the bottom, then it went to the top,

488
00:27:59.920 --> 00:28:01.540
and then went to the bottom.

489
00:28:01.540 --> 00:28:04.920
Technically, I'm still within my upper and
lower control limits,

490
00:28:04.920 --> 00:28:08.480
so I need the condition that
my processes is in control.

491
00:28:08.480 --> 00:28:10.720
But, what could that be telling us?

492
00:28:10.720 --> 00:28:13.346
>> A piece of equipment
isn't calibrated correctly.

493
00:28:13.346 --> 00:28:14.289
>> Exactly.
Perfect.

494
00:28:14.289 --> 00:28:16.920
>> [LAUGH]
>> And so, just because our data points,

495
00:28:16.920 --> 00:28:19.830
and that's what I want you to
remember from Lean Six Sigma,

496
00:28:19.830 --> 00:28:23.380
the whole lesson that we're getting
from statistical process control

497
00:28:23.380 --> 00:28:27.490
that's a little bit more
complicated on the Six Sigma side.

498
00:28:27.490 --> 00:28:32.040
In Lean Six Sigma,
we wanna look at the pattern of the data

499
00:28:32.040 --> 00:28:34.139
as much as we look at-
>> Where it falls.

500
00:28:34.139 --> 00:28:36.100
[CROSSTALK]
>> Where it falls, absolutely.

501
00:28:36.100 --> 00:28:38.868
>> Okay.
>> And then, another thing is what you

502
00:28:38.868 --> 00:28:43.550
brought up, Cherokee, earlier,
is that I wanna look at a range.

503
00:28:43.550 --> 00:28:50.910
So let's say I look at my control chart,
and it looks shark toothish,

504
00:28:50.910 --> 00:28:56.270
and it's actually called the shark tooth
pattern, a data point's at the top,

505
00:28:56.270 --> 00:28:58.790
it's at the bottom, it's at the top,
it's at the bottom.

506
00:28:58.790 --> 00:29:01.860
That'd be a perfect example where
I might wanna look at a range,

507
00:29:01.860 --> 00:29:07.028
because maybe it evens itself out
a little bit longer, as I move forward.

508
00:29:07.028 --> 00:29:09.923
Maybe [CROSSTALK]
>> [CROSSTALK] replaced a part, and

509
00:29:09.923 --> 00:29:13.284
it needs to, yeah, work itself out or
something like that.

510
00:29:13.284 --> 00:29:13.790
>> Exactly.

511
00:29:13.790 --> 00:29:15.540
>> Wear it down a little bit.

512
00:29:15.540 --> 00:29:19.460
>> And when you're looking
the concept behind control charts,

513
00:29:19.460 --> 00:29:21.900
is that if I don't do anything positive or

514
00:29:21.900 --> 00:29:26.700
negative to that process, I can predict
what's gonna happen next month.

515
00:29:26.700 --> 00:29:30.270
So I'm looking at my control chart,
looking for process improvement areas,

516
00:29:30.270 --> 00:29:30.780
and I'm saying,

517
00:29:30.780 --> 00:29:34.370
if I get a good handle on what's
happening now, I do nothing positive or

518
00:29:34.370 --> 00:29:39.420
negative, it's probably gonna look pretty
close to the same thing the next month.

519
00:29:39.420 --> 00:29:41.870
The other thing that I'm looking for
in control charts is,

520
00:29:41.870 --> 00:29:46.050
I want to look at the data points
naturally falling close to the middle.

521
00:29:46.050 --> 00:29:47.920
And we call that a random pattern.

522
00:29:47.920 --> 00:29:51.760
Now, if they're falling too close to
the middle, that's another red flag.

523
00:29:51.760 --> 00:29:55.440
Because I either don't have my
controls properly calibrated or

524
00:29:55.440 --> 00:29:59.000
I don't have my upper and
lower controls in a good place.

525
00:29:59.000 --> 00:30:02.303
Or someone's maybe making up the data.

526
00:30:02.303 --> 00:30:02.988
>> Fudging it, yeah.

527
00:30:02.988 --> 00:30:03.975
>> Yeah.

528
00:30:03.975 --> 00:30:08.030
So, you know, when I'm looking at
a control chart, if I really wanna

529
00:30:08.030 --> 00:30:12.040
say a process is in control, I'm looking
at that kind of random pattern, but

530
00:30:12.040 --> 00:30:16.820
everything's kind of falling close to that
middle line, then that's when I'm safe.

531
00:30:16.820 --> 00:30:20.120
And then the last thing I wanna
say about control charts,

532
00:30:20.120 --> 00:30:24.886
keeping in mind that people do them wrong
all the time, so they might not be aware.

533
00:30:24.886 --> 00:30:26.232
Well, actually, I've two things.

534
00:30:26.232 --> 00:30:30.139
One thing is, that in some cases
you can have a control chart and

535
00:30:30.139 --> 00:30:32.810
have no upper limit or lower limit.

536
00:30:32.810 --> 00:30:35.020
So, for example, of having no lower limit,

537
00:30:35.020 --> 00:30:39.900
if I'm tracking accidents in my warehouse,
if I have no injuries, that's fine.

538
00:30:39.900 --> 00:30:43.070
I'm not gonna have a lower limit.

539
00:30:43.070 --> 00:30:47.740
But I would have an upper limit,
because if I have more accidents

540
00:30:47.740 --> 00:30:52.790
than prescribed, my insurance could go up,
and people could be getting hurt.

541
00:30:52.790 --> 00:30:54.620
>> Then you need to look
at your environment.

542
00:30:54.620 --> 00:30:55.200
>> RIght.
And

543
00:30:55.200 --> 00:30:58.670
if I were doing a controlled chart on
my stocks, like our first example, I'm

544
00:30:58.670 --> 00:31:02.760
probably not gonna have an upper control
limit on how much money I make, right?

545
00:31:02.760 --> 00:31:03.670
So I wanted to say that.

546
00:31:03.670 --> 00:31:08.580
And then this is the part I'd like
to finish with, is that controls and

547
00:31:08.580 --> 00:31:12.880
specifications, cuz you're gonna
see upper control limits, CUL,

548
00:31:12.880 --> 00:31:15.660
lower control limit, LCL.

549
00:31:15.660 --> 00:31:17.420
>> For their acronyms.

550
00:31:17.420 --> 00:31:19.140
>> For acronyms, right.

551
00:31:19.140 --> 00:31:24.400
But sometimes you're gonna see lower
specification and upper specification.

552
00:31:24.400 --> 00:31:28.990
So specifications generally
come from the industry.

553
00:31:28.990 --> 00:31:30.140
They're telling you.

554
00:31:31.530 --> 00:31:33.720
Controls come from within.

555
00:31:33.720 --> 00:31:34.820
I'm saying, my controls.

556
00:31:34.820 --> 00:31:39.730
So my controls can be better
than my specifications,

557
00:31:39.730 --> 00:31:42.800
but not less,
because people aren't gonna by my product.

558
00:31:42.800 --> 00:31:46.910
>> Okay, so like in IT,
if I'm creating some cabling,

559
00:31:46.910 --> 00:31:52.030
some wiring, and I have the IETF, and they
say, it has to fall within this diameter,

560
00:31:52.030 --> 00:31:56.030
and I just wanna have it really,
really tight and perfect internally.

561
00:31:56.030 --> 00:32:00.980
That would be my controls from the
industry, that would be my specification.

562
00:32:00.980 --> 00:32:01.830
>> Perfect.
>> All right, good to go.

563
00:32:01.830 --> 00:32:03.270
>> Perfect.

564
00:32:03.270 --> 00:32:06.110
>> So I think that about wraps it up for
this particular episode.

565
00:32:06.110 --> 00:32:08.012
We looked at our different
types of control charts,

566
00:32:08.012 --> 00:32:12.360
at our different scatter diagrams and
when we should in fact be using them.

567
00:32:12.360 --> 00:32:13.750
So stay tuned.

568
00:32:13.750 --> 00:32:17.160
We do have some more
Lean Six Sigma Green Belt certification

569
00:32:17.160 --> 00:32:19.380
preparation information headed your way.

570
00:32:19.380 --> 00:32:22.170
We gonna go ahead and
sign off for this episode.

571
00:32:22.170 --> 00:32:24.320
And I'm your host Cherokee Boose.

572
00:32:24.320 --> 00:32:27.650
>> And I'm Dr. Terra Vanzant-Stern
with SSD Global Solutions.

573
00:32:27.650 --> 00:32:31.505
>> See you next time here at ITPRO.TV.

574
00:32:31.505 --> 00:32:37.428
[MUSIC]

575
00:32:37.428 --> 00:32:40.773
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode you will examine the 8 Areas of waste including defects such as overproduction, waiting, non-utilized staff talent, transportation, inventory, motion, and extra processing. You also learn of tools such as TIM WOODS to help identify waste.
episodes.title: Waste, Voices and CTQs
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.012 --> 00:00:01.533
Welcome to IT Pro TV.

2
00:00:01.533 --> 00:00:06.335
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.335 --> 00:00:08.355
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.355 --> 00:00:12.483
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

5
00:00:12.483 --> 00:00:17.178
>> Welcome to your Lean Six Sigma:
Green Belt Certification series.

6
00:00:17.178 --> 00:00:18.940
I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:20.490 --> 00:00:24.490
In this episode, we'll be taking
a look at our areas of waste,

8
00:00:24.490 --> 00:00:27.701
we'll be looking at our voices,
and our CTQs.

9
00:00:28.740 --> 00:00:33.220
With us today in studios, we have Dr.
Terra Vanzant-Stern.

10
00:00:33.220 --> 00:00:34.690
Thank you for joining us, Doctor.

11
00:00:34.690 --> 00:00:35.667
>> Thank you.

12
00:00:35.667 --> 00:00:36.380
>> So, where do we start?

13
00:00:36.380 --> 00:00:37.885
What are we gonna be looking at first?

14
00:00:37.885 --> 00:00:43.010
>> Well, I'd like to go over to my slide
deck, and before we even get started,

15
00:00:43.010 --> 00:00:47.360
kind of explain the concept of waste and
mistakes.

16
00:00:47.360 --> 00:00:51.830
On the Six Sigma side,
we're mostly talking about reducing or

17
00:00:51.830 --> 00:00:53.610
eliminating mistakes.

18
00:00:53.610 --> 00:00:57.610
On the Lean side, we're talking
about reducing or eliminating waste.

19
00:00:57.610 --> 00:01:00.589
And waste is kind of a subjective thing.

20
00:01:00.589 --> 00:01:04.788
So for example, if there's a mistake,
like you walk into a room and

21

agree, you know what, that's a mistake.

22
00:01:10.104 --> 00:01:14.470

time talking about, is it mistake really?

23
00:01:14.470 --> 00:01:16.910
Right, everyone's just gonna agree.

24
00:01:16.910 --> 00:01:20.530
So you'll notice that when we're
trying to uncover mistakes,

25
00:01:20.530 --> 00:01:25.040
there's not as many tools as there are for
when we try to uncover waste,

26
00:01:25.040 --> 00:01:26.780
because waste is subjective.

27
00:01:26.780 --> 00:01:31.550
So for example, if I'm standing in line

35
00:01:53.845 --> 00:01:55.733

>> So it might not wasteful for them.

00:01:55.733 --> 00:01:59.710
Because as I'm standing there,

00:02:01.963 --> 00:02:04.408

>> So it's not wasteful to them.

makes the argument of reducing or

00:02:08.481 --> 00:02:11.844

42
00:02:11.844 --> 00:02:14.860
So we're gonna talk about

Because Lean Six Sigma has a tendency

00:02:24.480 --> 00:02:26.670

00:02:26.670 --> 00:02:29.410

So for example,
if I were trying to process and

00:02:35.990 --> 00:02:37.440
What would make me better?

00:02:38.630 --> 00:02:40.660
What would make me more cost efficient?

00:02:40.660 --> 00:02:42.983

>> Right?

>> [LAUGH]
>> But maybe when I go ahead and

[LAUGH]
>> That's perfect, that's perfect.

Try to think of a time,

that's exactly what I was thinking too.

So, because it is around that time

I think I ordered more chocolate

Something at our homes where we're

>> But you know it is kind of
interesting about laundry because.

00:26:41.680 --> 00:26:45.810
That's a perfect example, there used to

And there's still some, like you know

But there was a time in our history,
in the 50s and 60s, that dye was so

00:27:01.360 --> 00:27:04.710
And these days most of the time, you

522
00:27:04.710 --> 00:27:07.890
So You could be overprocessing by-

523
00:27:07.890 --> 00:27:09.040
then having to resort?

524
00:27:09.040 --> 00:27:09.870
>> Yeah, exactly.

525
00:27:09.870 --> 00:27:11.490
>> Okay.
>> You could be over processing,

526
00:27:13.180 --> 00:27:17.640
what are some other areas where

00:27:19.670 --> 00:27:22.720
>> I don't know, maybe just picking up or

I mean how many times to we have to

00:27:27.245 --> 00:27:29.170
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] For her children or

That's just,
I mean we're touching that too many times.

There's got to be a place

534
00:27:34.580 --> 00:27:35.130
Right?

535
00:27:35.130 --> 00:27:36.860
That's gonna be more efficient.

536
00:27:36.860 --> 00:27:38.550
Okay, so then defects.

Think of things at your home

That are just wrong and
so you have to redo them.

539

>> Maybe my son with his homework.

540
00:27:48.420 --> 00:27:49.120
>> Yeah.

541
00:27:49.120 --> 00:27:51.895
>> If some of those questions
aren't the right answers.

542
00:27:51.895 --> 00:27:56.080
Mm-hm, good question,
let me try to think of some other defects.

543
00:27:56.080 --> 00:27:59.620
Dinner, if it doesn't come out the way

544
00:27:59.620 --> 00:28:03.438
So I might have to redo that, or

545
00:28:03.438 --> 00:28:05.170
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, exactly.

546
00:28:05.170 --> 00:28:10.610
One of the things that a friend gave
me these things that heat up or they

00:28:10.610 --> 00:28:14.530
get cold and you can put them on, cuz I'm
always doing different exercise programs.

548
00:28:14.530 --> 00:28:15.990
I'm into Tai Chi right now.

549
00:28:15.990 --> 00:28:19.830
So I always have some
anomaly ache somewhere.

550
00:28:19.830 --> 00:28:23.620
So these things you either heat up or
you put it in the refrigerator.

551
00:28:23.620 --> 00:28:28.025
So I'm constantly overheating my thing and
it's having to wait.

552
00:28:28.025 --> 00:28:30.235
[LAUGH] And then I can't use it.

553
00:28:30.235 --> 00:28:31.974
[CROSSTALK] Too hot.

554
00:28:31.974 --> 00:28:34.100
>> Exactly. [LAUGH] >> So
I have to put it back in.

555
00:28:34.100 --> 00:28:37.060
So you know I'm constantly trying
to save steps by throwing the thing

556
00:28:37.060 --> 00:28:40.080
in the microwave and
making it hotter than it's supposed to be.

557
00:28:40.080 --> 00:28:41.860
But then when I get ready to use it,
it's too hot.

558
00:28:41.860 --> 00:28:45.890
You know so I have to keep redoing it,
and I'm gonna get better at that.

559
00:28:45.890 --> 00:28:51.130
Okay, skills are were you have
skills that are either being

560
00:28:51.130 --> 00:28:54.100
underutilized, or overutilized.

561
00:28:54.100 --> 00:28:59.600
So for example,
if you think about things that,

562
00:28:59.600 --> 00:29:02.070
like for example house cleaning, right.

563
00:29:02.070 --> 00:29:06.110
If you look at your hourly rate, what
you would pay yourself to do something,

564
00:29:06.110 --> 00:29:08.780
sometimes it really does make
sense to have a housekeeper.

565
00:29:08.780 --> 00:29:09.280
>> True.

566
00:29:09.280 --> 00:29:10.250
Right.

567
00:29:10.250 --> 00:29:13.180
So skills would be thing
that you're doing or

568
00:29:13.180 --> 00:29:15.290
not doing that could be
wasteful at your home.

569
00:29:15.290 --> 00:29:18.890
Can you think of any things other than
house keeping graphs when they come to my

570
00:29:18.890 --> 00:29:22.885
mind and
that how I justify house keepers [LAUGH]

571
00:29:22.885 --> 00:29:26.465
>> Okay, yeah I really don't have anything

572
00:29:26.465 --> 00:29:30.907
coming to mind maybe So

573
00:29:30.907 --> 00:29:35.150
maybe I decide I'm gonna paint a room for
example.

574
00:29:35.150 --> 00:29:38.790
It's actually might be
wasting more of my time

575
00:29:38.790 --> 00:29:42.360
than finding someone else to paint my room
for me because they have that expertise.

576
00:29:42.360 --> 00:29:45.440
And so if I paint the room-
>> So they can do it in a shorter period

577
00:29:45.440 --> 00:29:47.210
of time versus-
>> Right, so

578
00:29:47.210 --> 00:29:51.520
if I actually looked at
>> Getting the magazine on how to paint my

579
00:29:51.520 --> 00:29:55.660
room, buying all of the supplies,
allotting the time to do it.

580
00:29:55.660 --> 00:29:59.070
It might actually, at least I just

581
00:29:59.070 --> 00:30:02.120
If you have this sense, you wanna go
accomplish something that you're home.

582
00:30:02.120 --> 00:30:05.100
Something it just feels
good to do something.

583
00:30:05.100 --> 00:30:09.150
But when you have a task at your home

584

you longer and it's gonna be more

585
00:30:13.180 --> 00:30:14.110
>> Okay.
>> Stuff like that.

586
00:30:14.110 --> 00:30:14.690
>> All right.

587

>> Okay, so that was just an example and

there's lots of tools like this that you

589
00:30:20.980 --> 00:30:24.100
So I think we're wrapping up right now,
and we're gonna be talking about

00:30:24.100 --> 00:30:29.030
how to take CTQs and voices and

591
00:30:29.030 --> 00:30:29.580
>> Sounds great.

592
00:30:29.580 --> 00:30:30.630
I'm excited.

593
00:30:30.630 --> 00:30:31.900
So, don't go anywhere.

594

Stay tuned.

595
00:30:32.510 --> 00:30:35.960
We're gonna taking a look, like Dr.

But, we are out of time for this episode.

00:30:50.800 --> 00:30:54.690
