episodes.description: Being able to shift your thinking and see thru the lens of others or even inanimate objects may offer insight you otherwise may never of considered. In this episode you learn how to gain perspective from the voice of the customer (VOC), voice of the employee (VOE), voice of the process (VOP), and the voice of the business (VOB). You also learn how to identify critical to quality (CTQ) components.
episodes.title: Waste, Voices and CTQs Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:08.289
Welcome to ITPRO.TV, I'm your host-
>> [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:08.289 --> 00:00:12.227
>> You are watching ITPRO.TV.

3
00:00:12.227 --> 00:00:17.056
>> Welcome to your lean Six Sigma, Green
Belt Certification preparation series.

4
00:00:17.056 --> 00:00:19.567
I'm your host, Cherokee Boose.

5
00:00:19.567 --> 00:00:23.948
This is actually a part two, where
previously we were looking at our ways or

6
00:00:23.948 --> 00:00:25.530
eight areas of ways.

7
00:00:25.530 --> 00:00:29.670
In this segment, we'll be looking
at our voices, and also our CTQs.

8
00:00:29.670 --> 00:00:34.970
Now, I understand that CTQ is for Critical
Tech Quality, but in studios today,

9
00:00:34.970 --> 00:00:39.640
we have Dr. Terra Vanzant-Stern, and
I'm really hoping that she can explain and

10
00:00:39.640 --> 00:00:42.130
really break down this term for
us a little more in depth.

11
00:00:42.130 --> 00:00:43.910
So let's go ahead and get started.

12
00:00:43.910 --> 00:00:44.960
Thank you for being here today.

13
00:00:44.960 --> 00:00:46.670
>> Well thank you, Cherokee.

14
00:00:46.670 --> 00:00:51.008
And as Cherokee mentioned,
we're gonna talk about CTQs, but first,

15
00:00:51.008 --> 00:00:54.040
what I'd like to do is go
over to my slideshow, and

16
00:00:54.040 --> 00:00:58.547
remind you that we were talking about
when we left off in the last section.

17
00:00:58.547 --> 00:01:01.718
If we,
we were talking about Tim Woods, and

18
00:01:01.718 --> 00:01:07.055
that was one model that we could use
to determine the eight areas of waste.

19
00:01:07.055 --> 00:01:09.558
The other model was called downtime,
right?

20
00:01:09.558 --> 00:01:14.640
And so I'm gonna use this to kinda give
you a high level idea of what CTQs are.

21
00:01:14.640 --> 00:01:19.880
So CTQs are critical to quality,
critical to success.

22
00:01:19.880 --> 00:01:24.100
Now, in the last session, we said Tim
Woods, we could use it to identify waste.

23
00:01:24.100 --> 00:01:28.830
That's what it's most commonly used, as a
way to remember the eight areas of waste.

24
00:01:29.940 --> 00:01:32.940
We're not saying that solving the problem,
we're not even for

25
00:01:32.940 --> 00:01:34.390
sure saying that it is waste.

26
00:01:34.390 --> 00:01:36.270
We're just using it as a-
>> Try to identify it, right.

27
00:01:36.270 --> 00:01:39.800
>> Right, well, another way that we
could use Tim Woods is we could go back,

28
00:01:39.800 --> 00:01:43.630
and we could look at
transportation issues, right?

29
00:01:43.630 --> 00:01:47.520
And say, for example,
what is critical to the success,

30
00:01:47.520 --> 00:01:51.800
critical to satisfaction to make
those transportation issues work?

31
00:01:51.800 --> 00:01:56.460
So I could go back, and I could say, all
right, we have a problem in inventory, or

32
00:01:56.460 --> 00:01:58.770
we have a problem in overproduction.

33
00:01:58.770 --> 00:02:01.930
And if I wanna correct that,
what's critical to quality,

34
00:02:01.930 --> 00:02:03.840
what's critical to success?

35
00:02:03.840 --> 00:02:10.080
Now, CTQs by customer requirements,
what the customer wants.

36
00:02:10.080 --> 00:02:14.990
By default, are gonna be CTQs, so
customer requirements are CTQs.

37
00:02:14.990 --> 00:02:20.250
So, if you were asked on a Lean Six Sigma,
or Lean Six Sigma exam,

38
00:02:20.250 --> 00:02:24.600
critical to quality if it's a customer
requirement absolutely no question.

39
00:02:24.600 --> 00:02:26.640
>> Okay.
>> This is critical to quality,

40
00:02:26.640 --> 00:02:32.420
where it gets kind of dicey is
almost in a Steve Covey sense of it.

41
00:02:32.420 --> 00:02:35.830
Is that in order to be successful,
we have to find out

42
00:02:35.830 --> 00:02:39.490
what make other people successful,
what do they need for their satisfaction.

43
00:02:39.490 --> 00:02:40.764
If they play into our project,

44
00:02:40.764 --> 00:02:43.523
which makes it a little bit more
selfish than the Steve Covey work.

45
00:02:43.523 --> 00:02:46.860
Cuz the Steve Covey work
is all about giving, right?

46
00:02:46.860 --> 00:02:49.050
But if you kind of think of it, and

47
00:02:49.050 --> 00:02:53.360
there's a lot of motivational
speakers that will tell you this.

48
00:02:53.360 --> 00:02:54.820
If you want to be successful,

49
00:02:54.820 --> 00:02:58.260
then anyone that's playing into your
success make sure they're successful too.

50
00:02:58.260 --> 00:03:00.300
So, kind of think of CTQs in that way.

51
00:03:01.300 --> 00:03:06.610
So, a CTQ, critical to quality, critical
to success, critical to satisfaction,

52
00:03:06.610 --> 00:03:10.700
there was a small movement in the 80s
to call it critical to price,

53
00:03:10.700 --> 00:03:15.820
critical to speed,
critical to being better, right?

54
00:03:15.820 --> 00:03:19.469
But now we just use CTQ as
kind of the umbrella term.

55
00:03:19.469 --> 00:03:23.702
All right, so if I were looking
at the Tim Woods' model, and

56
00:03:23.702 --> 00:03:29.097
let's say I identified an over processing
issue, there might be some things

57
00:03:29.097 --> 00:03:33.998
that are critical to quality for
it not to be an over processing issue.

58
00:03:33.998 --> 00:03:37.896
So, maybe that critical to quality that
these people need education that they

59
00:03:37.896 --> 00:03:42.170
shouldn't, that everyone doesn't need
to sign that change order, right?

60
00:03:42.170 --> 00:03:44.640
So, kind of think of it
from that perspective.

61
00:03:44.640 --> 00:03:47.260
So CTQ, critical to quality.

62
00:03:47.260 --> 00:03:48.640
The big thing that you want to know for

63
00:03:48.640 --> 00:03:52.380
the exam,
customer requirements are always CTQs.

64
00:03:52.380 --> 00:03:57.500
Now, critical to quality, success,
satisfaction, speed, cost effectiveness.

65
00:03:57.500 --> 00:04:01.330
Kind of a reminder, a little early
reminder, what I want you to do is,

66
00:04:01.330 --> 00:04:04.020
I want you to think from the other side.

67
00:04:04.020 --> 00:04:08.210
So, for example,
if I'm housekeeping at a hotel,

68
00:04:08.210 --> 00:04:12.290
I want you to think of housekeeping
as a voice, all right?

69
00:04:12.290 --> 00:04:14.022
So, housekeeping is a voice, and

70
00:04:14.022 --> 00:04:18.900
there's maybe, at the hotel I'm staying
at, probably a dozen housekeepers.

71
00:04:18.900 --> 00:04:20.960
But I'm gonna think of them as a voice.

72
00:04:20.960 --> 00:04:26.886
Now, if I'm the manager of that hotel,
my CTQs from the housekeeping,

73
00:04:26.886 --> 00:04:31.855
I want rooms turned over fast,
so I can get other patrons in.

74
00:04:31.855 --> 00:04:34.337
I want them to be clean, right?

75
00:04:34.337 --> 00:04:36.130
>> Right [LAUGH].

76
00:04:36.130 --> 00:04:41.360
>> I think pretty much,
I might have a couple of ancillary things,

77
00:04:41.360 --> 00:04:45.560
I want to make sure that the air's not on,
if there's no one is in the room.

78
00:04:45.560 --> 00:04:48.680
Stuff like that,
cuz why should I be heating or

79
00:04:48.680 --> 00:04:50.780
air conditioning a room if
I don't even have a guest?

80
00:04:50.780 --> 00:04:53.770
Right, so there might be some
of those ancillary things.

81
00:04:53.770 --> 00:04:57.270
But if I were housekeeping,
and housekeeping could speak,

82
00:04:57.270 --> 00:05:00.590
what's critical to their success
to make that happen for me?

83
00:05:00.590 --> 00:05:01.790
What do they need from me?

84
00:05:01.790 --> 00:05:06.590
>> The proper supplies,
the cleaning materials, proper,

85
00:05:06.590 --> 00:05:09.910
I guess linens would kind of
fall under that category.

86
00:05:09.910 --> 00:05:11.564
>> Sure.
>> What else would they need?

87
00:05:11.564 --> 00:05:14.660
Maybe any kind of training on the ways
that they want something performed.

88
00:05:14.660 --> 00:05:20.170
>> Exactly, and probably in the form
of training, just an expectation list.

89
00:05:20.170 --> 00:05:23.110
>> Right.
>> I stay at hotels fairly regularly, and

90
00:05:23.110 --> 00:05:26.070
I can tell you the housekeepers
that have just a list.

91
00:05:26.070 --> 00:05:28.240
[LAUGH] I mean, some are just better.

92
00:05:28.240 --> 00:05:33.260
Even at the same hotel stay, I can come in
and my room might not be as clean, right?

93
00:05:33.260 --> 00:05:38.410
Okay, so the theory in
Lean Six Sigma is that it is my job.

94
00:05:38.410 --> 00:05:42.210
If I'm the manager of that hotel,
and I want rooms turned over,

95
00:05:42.210 --> 00:05:47.420
I want them turned over fast, I want them
to be clean, I want everything to work,

96
00:05:47.420 --> 00:05:51.420
that yeah, it is my job to make sure that
housekeeping has everything they need.

97
00:05:51.420 --> 00:05:54.560
Now, I don't have to physically have
to go and get them their linens, or

98
00:05:54.560 --> 00:05:58.540
their supplies, or even, I might have
someone else make up a checklist that

99
00:05:58.540 --> 00:06:00.920
has more of a subject matter expertise.

100
00:06:00.920 --> 00:06:05.400
But bottom line,
the idea is that yeah, it is my job.

101
00:06:05.400 --> 00:06:07.540
If I wanna be successful,
if I wanna make things better,

102
00:06:07.540 --> 00:06:11.670
faster, more cost effective, I can't
walk around going, well I did my part.

103
00:06:11.670 --> 00:06:13.490
>> Right.
>> I said what I wanted.

104
00:06:13.490 --> 00:06:15.410
Okay, so let's do another one.

105
00:06:15.410 --> 00:06:16.720
Rental car agency.

106
00:06:16.720 --> 00:06:17.535
>> [LAUGH]
>> So,

107
00:06:17.535 --> 00:06:22.720
if I go to the rental car agency,
what I want is a clean car.

108
00:06:22.720 --> 00:06:27.140
I want to get it fast,
I want it to have gas in it.

109
00:06:27.140 --> 00:06:28.400
>> [LAUGH] I'm sorry, I'm laughing.

110
00:06:28.400 --> 00:06:31.540
I just have never had good
experiences with rental car agencies.

111
00:06:31.540 --> 00:06:33.920
>> Right, well,
if you were the rental car agency,

112
00:06:33.920 --> 00:06:39.370
if the rental car agency could speak,
and you know what I want as a customer?

113
00:06:39.370 --> 00:06:41.350
What's critical to quality
if the rental agency?

114
00:06:42.610 --> 00:06:43.850
>> Well, for sure on time,

115
00:06:43.850 --> 00:06:46.176
that's one of the main reason
why you're getting a rental car.

116
00:06:46.176 --> 00:06:49.250
I was stranded somewhere with my child for

117
00:06:49.250 --> 00:06:52.424
a very long time because they just,
they never showed up on time.

118
00:06:52.424 --> 00:06:54.050
>> Exactly.
>> That was a huge problem.

119
00:06:54.050 --> 00:06:58.420
>> Yeah, it is, and so you're CTQ is
you're not gonna be stranded, right?

120
00:06:58.420 --> 00:07:03.427
That's a CTQ, but if you were thinking
from the perspective of the rental

121
00:07:03.427 --> 00:07:08.291
car agency, so kinda think I am the,
and I have a voice, I'm a person.

122
00:07:08.291 --> 00:07:10.550
What do I need from you?

123
00:07:10.550 --> 00:07:12.470
>> I wanna have decent vehicles.

124
00:07:12.470 --> 00:07:14.790
>> Right, I want nice vehicles, perfect.

125
00:07:14.790 --> 00:07:16.300
What's another here?

126
00:07:16.300 --> 00:07:16.981
>> Clean vehicles.

127
00:07:16.981 --> 00:07:18.356
>> I want them clean,
they need to be clean.

128
00:07:18.356 --> 00:07:19.047
>> Insured.

129
00:07:19.047 --> 00:07:22.866
>> Insured, and then what do I want
specifically from you as a customer?

130
00:07:22.866 --> 00:07:24.530
>> Gas [LAUGH].

131
00:07:24.530 --> 00:07:26.900
>> I wanna make sure there's
gas on the property.

132
00:07:26.900 --> 00:07:28.990
What do I need you as
a customer to tell me?

133
00:07:30.380 --> 00:07:32.300
>> Well,
I know they always ask about the mileage.

134
00:07:32.300 --> 00:07:34.290
Is that we're, [LAUGH]-
>> Right, exactly.

135
00:07:34.290 --> 00:07:35.890
So I need to know those kinds of things.

136
00:07:35.890 --> 00:07:38.830
And I need to know when you wanna pick
the car up, what kind of car you want.

137
00:07:38.830 --> 00:07:39.940
Those types of things, right?

138
00:07:39.940 --> 00:07:40.620
>> Accommodations.

139
00:07:40.620 --> 00:07:43.320
>> Accommodations, okay, so
we're gonna do just two more.

140
00:07:43.320 --> 00:07:45.160
>> Okay. [LAUGH] >> I'm a supermarket.

141
00:07:45.160 --> 00:07:48.636
Okay, so I'm the patron,
I go to the supermarket.

142
00:07:48.636 --> 00:07:51.566
I really don't like going
to the supermarket,

143
00:07:51.566 --> 00:07:53.476
but I just wanna get in and out.

144
00:07:53.476 --> 00:07:56.969
I wanna be safe, I'm gonna wanna
park in a nice, safe place.

145
00:07:56.969 --> 00:07:57.911
>> Well-lit area.

146
00:07:57.911 --> 00:08:01.575
I want to get checked out quickly.

147
00:08:01.575 --> 00:08:06.040
I want variety but not so
much variety that I'm overwhelmed.

148
00:08:06.040 --> 00:08:10.480
But if you were the supermarket and
the supermarket could speak,

149
00:08:10.480 --> 00:08:13.750
what does it want from you as
a customer to be successful?

150
00:08:14.830 --> 00:08:15.670
>> Your money?

151
00:08:15.670 --> 00:08:17.976
>> Yeah, I want your money, right?

152
00:08:17.976 --> 00:08:21.100
So I don't want bad checks, okay?

153
00:08:21.100 --> 00:08:22.846
I don't want, although hardly
anybody writes checks anymore.

154
00:08:22.846 --> 00:08:23.539
>> Right.

155
00:08:23.539 --> 00:08:25.013
>> But I want your credit card.

156
00:08:25.013 --> 00:08:28.437
>> Identification, if you're
purchasing any kind of adult beverage.

157
00:08:28.437 --> 00:08:33.840
>> Absolutely, exactly, that kind
of stuff, right, to be successful.

158
00:08:33.840 --> 00:08:38.960
So the idea behind Lean Six Sigma is that
whatever you're trying to make better,

159
00:08:38.960 --> 00:08:40.620
faster, more cost effective.

160
00:08:40.620 --> 00:08:42.940
If I'm the manager of a supermarket and

161
00:08:42.940 --> 00:08:46.730
I'm trying to make that supermarket
better, faster, more cost effective.

162
00:08:46.730 --> 00:08:50.580
Then I need to also think from
the voice of the supermarket.

163
00:08:50.580 --> 00:08:52.380
If I were the supermarket, what do I need?

164
00:08:52.380 --> 00:08:54.954
And then I need to make sure
that those things are happening.

165
00:08:54.954 --> 00:08:55.674
>> Okay.
>> Okay?

166
00:08:55.674 --> 00:08:59.530
Now like I said, some obvious CTQs,
like what does the customer want.

167
00:08:59.530 --> 00:09:03.490
If the customer comes every day and
says you're out of, like in Texas,

168
00:09:03.490 --> 00:09:05.414
we have this drink called Big Red.

169
00:09:05.414 --> 00:09:09.630
And you can get diet Big Red,
it taste kind of like bubble gum.

170
00:09:09.630 --> 00:09:11.705
>> Interesting.
>> So if you keep going and asking for

171
00:09:11.705 --> 00:09:13.763
this product, that's a CTQ right.

172
00:09:13.763 --> 00:09:16.772
If you get enough people asking for
some offbeat product like,

173
00:09:16.772 --> 00:09:20.817
why aren't you carrying this kind of
butter or, right, that's definitely a CTQ.

174
00:09:20.817 --> 00:09:25.414
But you wanna stretch your brain
a little bit past that and say,

175
00:09:25.414 --> 00:09:29.590
if I were a supermarket and
I could speak, what do I want?

176
00:09:29.590 --> 00:09:31.670
Well, I want floors that aren't slippery.

177
00:09:31.670 --> 00:09:32.610
>> Right.
>> Right?

178
00:09:32.610 --> 00:09:35.630
All those things, and
you'll be writing all of this stuff down.

179
00:09:35.630 --> 00:09:38.290
Not that there aren't things
you're gonna take off your list.

180
00:09:38.290 --> 00:09:40.520
This is just a brainstorming, remember.

181
00:09:40.520 --> 00:09:44.540
A structured brainstorming kind
of way to critically think.

182
00:09:44.540 --> 00:09:47.640
And then if there's something that
keeps coming up, then you know hey,

183
00:09:47.640 --> 00:09:49.580
that's a CTQ I need to pay attention to.

184
00:09:49.580 --> 00:09:53.030
All right, so we'll do one more,
hospital emergency room.

185
00:09:53.030 --> 00:09:56.200
So certainly, if I cut my finger and

186
00:09:56.200 --> 00:10:01.070
I go into the hospital emergency room,
I want attention fast.

187
00:10:02.810 --> 00:10:03.870
I don't wanna get [INAUDIBLE] infection.

188
00:10:03.870 --> 00:10:08.707
That's the infection that you get like
you didn't have it before you went into

189
00:10:08.707 --> 00:10:12.230
the hospital and
somebody with dirty hands touched you.

190
00:10:12.230 --> 00:10:13.418
>> So cleanliness, proper triage.

191
00:10:13.418 --> 00:10:17.234
>> Right.
>> Proper education from their staff for

192
00:10:17.234 --> 00:10:18.320
sure.

193
00:10:18.320 --> 00:10:24.270
>> And I want a place to park where
I can not worry that my car's

194
00:10:24.270 --> 00:10:28.190
going to get towed off while I'm in the
emergency room getting my hand bandaged.

195
00:10:28.190 --> 00:10:33.238
So if I were the hospital emergency
room though and I could speak.

196
00:10:33.238 --> 00:10:37.333
So I'm all the staff, I'm the brick and
mortar, I'm everything, and

197
00:10:37.333 --> 00:10:41.850
I'm the hospital emergency room and
I want to be successful, what would I say?

198
00:10:43.400 --> 00:10:46.030
>> Low temperatures to reduce
the amount of bacterias,

199
00:10:46.030 --> 00:10:47.320
it's always cold there, right?

200
00:10:47.320 --> 00:10:48.110
>> Perfect.

201
00:10:48.110 --> 00:10:51.410
>> A fully stocked, with their equipment.

202
00:10:51.410 --> 00:10:52.280
>> Okay, good.

203
00:10:52.280 --> 00:10:54.650
>> Okay, fully staffed.

204
00:10:54.650 --> 00:10:55.310
>> Perfect.

205
00:10:55.310 --> 00:10:57.260
>> Really just a clean environment.

206
00:10:57.260 --> 00:10:58.020
>> Exactly.
>> Okay.

207
00:10:58.020 --> 00:11:01.139
>> Okay, so if I'm managing
that hospital emergency room,

208
00:11:02.600 --> 00:11:07.820
I can pretty much say I can put
myself in the place of the patient.

209
00:11:07.820 --> 00:11:10.801
Because maybe I'd be a patient
myself even though I'm the manager.

210
00:11:10.801 --> 00:11:12.464
>> [CROSSTALK] experience, right.

211
00:11:12.464 --> 00:11:13.190
>> Right, so I've got that down.

212
00:11:13.190 --> 00:11:16.444
And all of those things are so important
cuz I need to check those out if I'm

213
00:11:16.444 --> 00:11:19.370
trying to be better, faster,
more cost effective.

214
00:11:19.370 --> 00:11:23.580
But where I want to stretch as a Lean Six
Sigma person is I want to think well,

215
00:11:23.580 --> 00:11:27.180
if a hospital emergency room
could speak what would it say?

216
00:11:27.180 --> 00:11:28.730
And then I want to check
those things out too,

217
00:11:28.730 --> 00:11:32.660
because there may be a possible
process improvement.

218
00:11:32.660 --> 00:11:35.520
There may be something in that mix
that I can make better, faster,

219
00:11:35.520 --> 00:11:36.880
more cost effective.

220
00:11:36.880 --> 00:11:40.340
And to Cherokee's point, there may be
some low-lying fruit that I'm just not

221
00:11:40.340 --> 00:11:43.140
thinking about because I'm not
thinking from that perspective.

222
00:11:43.140 --> 00:11:45.230
There might be some things
that I can knock out.

223
00:11:45.230 --> 00:11:47.790
Now the advantage of knocking
out the low-lying fruit, and

224
00:11:47.790 --> 00:11:49.380
that's stuff that you can fix right away.

225
00:11:49.380 --> 00:11:52.850
You don't have to do a project,
you just can go fix it.

226
00:11:52.850 --> 00:11:55.880
Is that it increases your credibility
as a process improvement person.

227
00:11:55.880 --> 00:11:58.070
So the more of those kinds
of things you can do,

228
00:11:58.070 --> 00:12:00.860
especially the visual ones,
the better off, right.

229
00:12:01.990 --> 00:12:06.480
Okay, so another way if you're
trying to think of what CTQs,

230
00:12:06.480 --> 00:12:08.780
you're trying to flesh it
out a little bit more.

231
00:12:08.780 --> 00:12:11.991
You can use something called a CTQ Tree.

232
00:12:11.991 --> 00:12:16.360
And I'm gonna put and example to this to
make it a little easier to understand.

233
00:12:16.360 --> 00:12:17.010
But right now,

234
00:12:17.010 --> 00:12:21.270
I would put the need sort of like that at
the head of the fish, what is the problem.

235
00:12:21.270 --> 00:12:24.640
In this case, I would put,
what is the need.

236
00:12:24.640 --> 00:12:27.730
And then I would say,
what drives that need.

237
00:12:27.730 --> 00:12:30.700
And then from the drivers,
what are the requirements.

238
00:12:30.700 --> 00:12:33.440
And then those requirements
would become my CTQs.

239
00:12:33.440 --> 00:12:38.420
So if I'm trying to think it out, another
way of processing CTQs would be like this.

240
00:12:38.420 --> 00:12:41.671
So for example, if where it says need,

241
00:12:41.671 --> 00:12:46.411
if what I had was a better
coffee experience, all right.

242
00:12:46.411 --> 00:12:48.940
I want a better coffee experience.

243
00:12:48.940 --> 00:12:51.800
So I have coffee every day,
I want a better experience.

244
00:12:51.800 --> 00:12:55.020
So my drivers, let's see if we have any.

245
00:12:55.020 --> 00:12:56.110
Whoops, we don't.

246
00:12:56.110 --> 00:12:58.900
Okay, so we're just gonna have to
come up with these on our own.

247
00:12:58.900 --> 00:13:00.200
[LAUGH] I think we'll do fine, okay.

248
00:13:00.200 --> 00:13:04.470
So part of my better coffee experience
is maybe I want a pretty place to

249
00:13:04.470 --> 00:13:05.290
have coffee.

250
00:13:05.290 --> 00:13:07.940
>> Sure.
>> Okay, so what would be another driver?

251
00:13:07.940 --> 00:13:09.695
>> I can think of one.

252
00:13:09.695 --> 00:13:14.830
Here off of, [LAUGH] Newberry,
the Starbucks is always, always passed.

253
00:13:14.830 --> 00:13:18.580
I've even seen baristas in
their aprons directing traffic.

254
00:13:18.580 --> 00:13:22.468
So, I wanna make sure that there's not
a 30 minute wait, because normally it's in

255
00:13:22.468 --> 00:13:25.494
the morning before work and
I don't wanna be late to work, right?

256
00:13:25.494 --> 00:13:28.149
>> Okay, so we've got two drivers.

257
00:13:28.149 --> 00:13:30.315
I want a nice pretty
place to have my coffee,

258
00:13:30.315 --> 00:13:34.090
I want a place that's not crowded
that I can get in and out, right?

259
00:13:34.090 --> 00:13:37.090
And then another driver,
almost always, a driver and

260
00:13:37.090 --> 00:13:41.510
you might think of some other ones but
almost always a driver is price.

261
00:13:41.510 --> 00:13:43.680
I want a reasonably priced cup of coffee..

262
00:13:43.680 --> 00:13:46.773
>> I'm such a nerd,
I was thinking enough bandwidth.

263
00:13:46.773 --> 00:13:49.410
Because most coffee offer free WiFi,
right?

264
00:13:49.410 --> 00:13:50.138
>> And that could be driver four.

265
00:13:50.138 --> 00:13:52.922
We only have three drivers
in our diagram but

266
00:13:52.922 --> 00:13:56.370
if you have more drivers,
that's okay, right?

267
00:13:56.370 --> 00:13:57.060
>> All right.
>> So

268
00:13:57.060 --> 00:13:59.120
what we're trying to get to is the CTQ,

269
00:13:59.120 --> 00:14:03.210
the critical to quality,
what are the requirements.

270
00:14:03.210 --> 00:14:05.575
So first I say what is the need.

271
00:14:05.575 --> 00:14:06.570
Better coffee experience.

272
00:14:06.570 --> 00:14:07.900
Well then, what are the drivers?

273
00:14:07.900 --> 00:14:13.140
And then we said pretty, price,
not crowded, bandwidth, right?

274
00:14:13.140 --> 00:14:17.310
So then you take each one of those and
you would go what would facilitate that?

275
00:14:17.310 --> 00:14:21.980
So price is a little bit more solid,
right?

276
00:14:21.980 --> 00:14:27.430
So the critical to quality requirement for
price, I could almost transfer over.

277
00:14:27.430 --> 00:14:31.190
It could almost be without
having to think that extra step.

278
00:14:31.190 --> 00:14:33.920
But what are some things
that play into price?

279
00:14:33.920 --> 00:14:35.510
>> Your competitors' prices.

280
00:14:35.510 --> 00:14:37.200
>> Exactly, absolutely.

281
00:14:37.200 --> 00:14:41.830
So critical to quality is that I need
to know my competitor's prices, right?

282
00:14:41.830 --> 00:14:45.515
When I'm thinking about price,
and I think we're all this way,

283
00:14:45.515 --> 00:14:49.941
is that we don't really mind paying extra
if we get something in quality back.

284
00:14:49.941 --> 00:14:51.927
>> Right.
>> I mean there are some people out,

285
00:14:51.927 --> 00:14:55.550
that we're always looking for
the best deal or the cheapest deal.

286
00:14:55.550 --> 00:14:58.530
But I think as a rule, most of us
are saying I just want to pay for

287
00:14:58.530 --> 00:15:00.230
the level of quality I get.

288
00:15:00.230 --> 00:15:03.760
So if I get a nice cup of coffee,
and it's easy to win me over.

289
00:15:03.760 --> 00:15:07.650
They give me a napkin, or a,
they had stevia at our coffee shop.

290
00:15:07.650 --> 00:15:09.565
They've got a customer, right?

291
00:15:09.565 --> 00:15:16.155
Okay, so let's say the driver
is a little less tangible.

292
00:15:16.155 --> 00:15:18.043
Because pretty,
a pretty place to have coffee.

293
00:15:18.043 --> 00:15:19.269
>> We might have different
perspectives on that.

294
00:15:19.269 --> 00:15:20.439
>> [CROSSTALK] what pretty is, right?

295
00:15:20.439 --> 00:15:24.740
Okay, so sometimes when you're working
with things that are a little intangible

296
00:15:24.740 --> 00:15:27.183
like that,
you have to come up with more CTQs.

297
00:15:27.183 --> 00:15:30.580
Because it's not as definitive as price,
right?

298
00:15:30.580 --> 00:15:33.590
Okay, so, pretty, so
what would be a driver of pretty?

299
00:15:33.590 --> 00:15:37.190
What do you consider
pretty in a coffee place?

300
00:15:37.190 --> 00:15:41.340
>> Maybe spacious, like an open
floor plan or something like that.

301
00:15:41.340 --> 00:15:42.580
>> Okay, perfect.

302
00:15:42.580 --> 00:15:45.850
And then I might think of color.

303
00:15:45.850 --> 00:15:47.830
I want a soft color or
something like that.

304
00:15:47.830 --> 00:15:50.343
So, I mean,
I think you kind of get the gist of this.

305
00:15:50.343 --> 00:15:52.388
And this is just if you
can't think of the CTQ.

306
00:15:52.388 --> 00:15:55.892
Cuz sometimes you come right up,
you know what's critical to quality,

307
00:15:55.892 --> 00:15:57.392
what's critical to success.

308
00:15:57.392 --> 00:16:01.626
But if you need a little help, one of the
strategies that you can use, is you can go

309
00:16:01.626 --> 00:16:06.073
back to models like Tim Woods and say,
okay, what's critical to transportation?

310
00:16:06.073 --> 00:16:07.610
What's critical to inventory?

311
00:16:07.610 --> 00:16:09.400
What's critical to motion?

312
00:16:09.400 --> 00:16:13.610
Another strategy that you can take is
thinking from the voices standpoint.

313
00:16:13.610 --> 00:16:16.770
If I were housekeeping,
if I were the emergency room.

314
00:16:16.770 --> 00:16:18.940
And yet another way to come up with CTQs,

315
00:16:18.940 --> 00:16:22.710
and keep in mind if you come up with them
right away, you don't need these, right?

316
00:16:22.710 --> 00:16:24.130
It's leaner just to write them down.

317
00:16:24.130 --> 00:16:29.470
But if you're kind of in
a situation where you can't think,

318
00:16:29.470 --> 00:16:33.720
another thing that you could do is
a CTQ tree where you put the need.

319
00:16:33.720 --> 00:16:35.914
And then you say well
what drives that need.

320
00:16:35.914 --> 00:16:37.055
>> [CROSSTALK] From the drivers.

321
00:16:37.055 --> 00:16:37.720
>> Than the CTQ.

322
00:16:37.720 --> 00:16:41.250
So it's just a way to help
your critical thought.

323
00:16:41.250 --> 00:16:44.630
Because Lean Six Sigma believes
a lot of the answers are inside you,

324
00:16:44.630 --> 00:16:46.450
you just need some help structuring them.

325
00:16:46.450 --> 00:16:47.390
>> Okay.

326
00:16:47.390 --> 00:16:49.830
>> So now that brings us to voices.

327
00:16:49.830 --> 00:16:52.440
And we've already talked
a little bit about this.

328
00:16:52.440 --> 00:16:58.160
Lean Six Sigma for example, if I were
trying to improve a customer service form.

329
00:16:58.160 --> 00:17:02.261
What are those forms that you
see when you go to fast food or

330
00:17:02.261 --> 00:17:06.090
to a restaurant,
that says how can we do better?

331
00:17:06.090 --> 00:17:06.910
>> Like a survey?

332
00:17:06.910 --> 00:17:07.831
>> Yeah, like a survey.

333
00:17:07.831 --> 00:17:08.740
>> Okay
>> And so

334
00:17:08.740 --> 00:17:13.610
they have something on the table
will you fill up this survey for us?

335
00:17:13.610 --> 00:17:17.230
>> Right
>> Now Lean Six Sigma says the best way to

336
00:17:17.230 --> 00:17:22.240
improve that form is to kind of
think of yourself as the form.

337
00:17:22.240 --> 00:17:28.150
If I were a customer service form or
survey, what do I need to be successful?

338
00:17:28.150 --> 00:17:32.040
Now in my age group,
the print needs to be kinda bigger.

339
00:17:32.040 --> 00:17:35.870
You know when the print's really tiny
I'm not gonna fill that out, right?

340
00:17:35.870 --> 00:17:39.490
So what is important to
the success of the form?

341
00:17:39.490 --> 00:17:41.830
So for me the font being large enough.

342
00:17:41.830 --> 00:17:45.980
What are some other things that
might make your form successful?

343
00:17:45.980 --> 00:17:49.740
>> Accessibility or trendiness,
so if I have like a QR code and

344
00:17:49.740 --> 00:17:52.670
I just scan it with my smartphone or
go to their website.

345
00:17:52.670 --> 00:17:55.040
Then they could fill it out very easily.

346
00:17:55.040 --> 00:17:58.290
>> Exactly, so and that's thinking
from the standpoint of the form.

347
00:17:58.290 --> 00:18:00.590
If I'm the form,
what's gonna make me successful?

348
00:18:01.610 --> 00:18:04.330
Another example would be incentives.

349
00:18:04.330 --> 00:18:05.550
My father.
>> There you go.

350
00:18:05.550 --> 00:18:07.590
>> My father loves to go to Chili's.

351
00:18:07.590 --> 00:18:11.510
And if the Chili's that he goes to in San
Antonio, I don't know if they all do this,

352
00:18:11.510 --> 00:18:14.250
but the one he goes to, if you fill
out that customer service form,

353
00:18:14.250 --> 00:18:16.140
next time you come back,
you get free nachos.

354
00:18:16.140 --> 00:18:18.380
>> [LAUGH]
>> So it's like, hey.

355
00:18:18.380 --> 00:18:20.552
>> Who doesn't like free nachos?

356
00:18:20.552 --> 00:18:24.360
>> Exactly, so but the idea is,
I'm thinking from this standpoint.

357
00:18:24.360 --> 00:18:29.310
If I were the form and the form could
speak, what do I need to be successful?

358
00:18:29.310 --> 00:18:32.310
And if I'm trying to do
a process improvement, and

359
00:18:32.310 --> 00:18:34.940
I want to make that form better,
faster and more cost effective.

360
00:18:34.940 --> 00:18:37.980
I know what I think should be on the form.

361
00:18:37.980 --> 00:18:42.070
But if I think from the form standpoint
of view, I might be more successful.

362
00:18:42.070 --> 00:18:45.980
>> A little more open minded maybe or
thinking outside the box there.

363
00:18:45.980 --> 00:18:47.130
>> Absolutely.

364
00:18:47.130 --> 00:18:48.530
So, moving on from there.

365
00:18:48.530 --> 00:18:51.770
There are four primary voices,
other than just thinking.

366
00:18:51.770 --> 00:18:53.530
This table has a voice.

367
00:18:53.530 --> 00:18:54.980
This book has a voice.

368
00:18:54.980 --> 00:18:55.665
Right?

369
00:18:55.665 --> 00:18:59.685
There are four primary voices, and

370
00:18:59.685 --> 00:19:04.647
those voices are VOC, VOE, VOP, and VOB.

371
00:19:04.647 --> 00:19:06.750
>> [LAUGH]
>> Now VOC,

372
00:19:06.750 --> 00:19:10.610
which is voice of the customer,
is the one we hear all the time.

373
00:19:10.610 --> 00:19:16.700
However there is a belief in Lean Six
Sigma that one of the reasons why we have

374
00:19:16.700 --> 00:19:21.330
lost a little bit of ground is because
we forgot how important the customer is.

375
00:19:23.000 --> 00:19:26.430
Lean Six Sigma puts all of
the emphasis on the customer.

376
00:19:26.430 --> 00:19:31.210
If the customer doesn't get what they
think they want, then you have lost it.

377
00:19:32.450 --> 00:19:35.435
Years ago the customer
was always right but now.

378
00:19:35.435 --> 00:19:36.920
>> [LAUGH]
>> Not so much.

379
00:19:36.920 --> 00:19:37.460
>> Right.
>> And

380
00:19:37.460 --> 00:19:41.330
IT has even a special challenge
because sometimes a customer asks for

381
00:19:41.330 --> 00:19:45.150
something and
they have no clue what they're asking for.

382
00:19:45.150 --> 00:19:49.105
So, or they don't realize how complicated
it is because they watched a bunch of

383
00:19:49.105 --> 00:19:49.970
sci-fi movies.

384
00:19:49.970 --> 00:19:52.290
And they've come in and they said,
well, I just need this.

385
00:19:52.290 --> 00:19:56.700
>> Or how unsecure it is,
how it defies your security policy, and.

386
00:19:56.700 --> 00:19:57.504
>> Absolutely.

387
00:19:57.504 --> 00:19:58.625
>> [LAUGH]
>> All of those things.

388
00:19:58.625 --> 00:20:01.570
So, It is hard to recognize
the voice of the customer.

389
00:20:01.570 --> 00:20:04.120
The big thing about voice of the customer

390
00:20:04.120 --> 00:20:09.060
that's on all of the exams is that we
have internal and external customers.

391
00:20:09.060 --> 00:20:11.870
And I think that's something
we've probably all heard, but

392
00:20:11.870 --> 00:20:16.590
just to kinda stay cognizant your internal
customers are anyone you have to keep

393
00:20:16.590 --> 00:20:18.160
happy inside the company.

394
00:20:18.160 --> 00:20:20.200
This is the fastest way to think about it.

395
00:20:20.200 --> 00:20:24.740
External people are, customers
are people that play into your company,

396
00:20:24.740 --> 00:20:26.350
buy your product, that type of thing.

397
00:20:26.350 --> 00:20:26.940
>> Okay.

398
00:20:26.940 --> 00:20:29.880
>> So that's a big thing
about voice of the customer.

399
00:20:29.880 --> 00:20:35.050
The second one, VOE, stands for
voice of the employee.

400
00:20:35.050 --> 00:20:40.010
Now the thing that Lean Six Sigma
does differently than Lean by itself,

401
00:20:40.010 --> 00:20:42.590
well Lean by itself does
a little bit of this, but

402
00:20:42.590 --> 00:20:47.440
Six Sigma doesn't really mention it
as much, is voice of the employee.

403
00:20:47.440 --> 00:20:53.960
And why the voice of the employee is so
important to the success of the business.

404
00:20:53.960 --> 00:20:59.340
Can you think of why do we really need
to listen to the voice of the employee?

405
00:20:59.340 --> 00:21:01.150
>> If the employee becomes disgruntled,

406
00:21:01.150 --> 00:21:02.830
they're not gonna put
forth as much effort.

407
00:21:02.830 --> 00:21:07.430
Especially if you see any kind
of external promotions and

408
00:21:07.430 --> 00:21:11.910
then hiring external rather than promoting
the people who've already been there that

409
00:21:11.910 --> 00:21:15.250
have tenure and they've been devoting
a lot of their time to that company.

410
00:21:15.250 --> 00:21:19.250
>> Yeah exactly, so And
sometimes a voice of the employee might,

411
00:21:19.250 --> 00:21:21.210
because they're touching
the process all the time,

412
00:21:21.210 --> 00:21:22.200
they might know-
>> Sure.

413
00:21:22.200 --> 00:21:24.490
>> Information that I don't have, right?

414
00:21:24.490 --> 00:21:29.700
So the next one is VOP,
which stands for voice of the process.

415
00:21:29.700 --> 00:21:33.070
And this goes back to that
inanimate object thing.

416
00:21:33.070 --> 00:21:36.990
If you're asking the process something
to do that it's not capable of doing,

417
00:21:36.990 --> 00:21:39.520
remember we had that whole
session on process capability.

418
00:21:39.520 --> 00:21:40.040
>> Right.
>> Then

419
00:21:40.040 --> 00:21:41.600
we have to address that right then.

420
00:21:41.600 --> 00:21:44.510
Is the process even capable of doing that?

421
00:21:44.510 --> 00:21:48.490
So just to make it a simple example,
if you have a printer and

422
00:21:48.490 --> 00:21:53.350
the printer has the capability of
processing 11 pages per minute, but

423
00:21:53.350 --> 00:21:56.250
you want it to produce
20 pages per minute,

424
00:21:56.250 --> 00:21:59.220
it doesn't have that capability
without extra hardware.

425
00:21:59.220 --> 00:21:59.960
>> Hardware.

426
00:21:59.960 --> 00:22:03.160
>> Exactly, so
listening to the voice of the process, And

427
00:22:03.160 --> 00:22:05.430
the voice of the process can
tell us a whole lot of things.

428
00:22:05.430 --> 00:22:09.590
I just watched The Wizard of Oz last
night again for like the hundredth time.

429
00:22:09.590 --> 00:22:10.720
>> Yay!
That's a great movie.

430
00:22:10.720 --> 00:22:13.830
>> And the voice of the process
can be seen like the wicked witch,

431
00:22:13.830 --> 00:22:14.845
help me I'm melting.

432
00:22:14.845 --> 00:22:17.060
>> Right.
>> But the voice of the process could be

433
00:22:17.060 --> 00:22:18.150
telling us other things.

434
00:22:18.150 --> 00:22:19.830
Can you think of anything, Cherokee,

435
00:22:19.830 --> 00:22:24.300
that if the process could speak,
other things it might be telling us?

436
00:22:24.300 --> 00:22:25.680
>> Well let's think about this for
a second.

437
00:22:25.680 --> 00:22:30.650
The process might say that,
hey not enough people know about me.

438
00:22:30.650 --> 00:22:31.265
>> Exactly.

439
00:22:31.265 --> 00:22:34.390
>> [LAUGH]
>> No one understands the process.

440
00:22:34.390 --> 00:22:36.025
They haven't been told the process.

441
00:22:36.025 --> 00:22:42.290
And you would be amazed in business how
many stellar processes are in place,

442
00:22:42.290 --> 00:22:43.640
but no one knows the rules.

443
00:22:43.640 --> 00:22:45.420
>> Sure.
>> Right, so that's a big one.

444
00:22:45.420 --> 00:22:49.470
It could also be telling
us things like I'm broken.

445
00:22:49.470 --> 00:22:51.040
I'm old.

446
00:22:51.040 --> 00:22:52.390
>> Yeah.
>> All those kinds of things.

447
00:22:52.390 --> 00:22:53.190
>> I'm too confusing.

448
00:22:53.190 --> 00:22:54.360
>> I'm too confusing.

449
00:22:54.360 --> 00:22:55.920
That's a big one.

450
00:22:55.920 --> 00:22:58.460
Okay and
then finally it's voice of the business.

451
00:22:58.460 --> 00:23:02.750
And this one's a little tricky
because when it shows up on an exam,

452
00:23:02.750 --> 00:23:07.250
because we keep talking about voices and
the inanimate object.

453
00:23:07.250 --> 00:23:10.950
It would be easier to think that voice of
the business would be your business which

454
00:23:10.950 --> 00:23:14.730
I think it's cool, that will be
more like the voice of the culture.

455
00:23:14.730 --> 00:23:17.980
And I think that's really huge when you
are trying to make a process improvement

456
00:23:17.980 --> 00:23:20.630
to think of the company,
what is the company voice?

457
00:23:20.630 --> 00:23:21.380
What are they saying?

458
00:23:21.380 --> 00:23:23.040
What are their goals?

459
00:23:23.040 --> 00:23:26.870
However voice of the business
traditionally and

460
00:23:26.870 --> 00:23:31.320
on the test, really means more
like voice of the industry.

461
00:23:31.320 --> 00:23:32.920
What is the industry telling us?

462
00:23:32.920 --> 00:23:38.180
So the industry could be telling us things
about our product, such as compliance

463
00:23:38.180 --> 00:23:41.735
like, that's a really great process
improvement, but it's illegal.

464
00:23:41.735 --> 00:23:42.753
>> [LAUGH]
>> So

465
00:23:42.753 --> 00:23:46.407
there's some things that
it could be telling us.

466
00:23:46.407 --> 00:23:48.611
Can we think of any other types of things?

467
00:23:48.611 --> 00:23:50.492
I want you guys to be
thinking out there too.

468
00:23:50.492 --> 00:23:53.123
What are some of the things
that the industry,

469
00:23:53.123 --> 00:23:57.680
our industry might be telling us
about our product or our service?

470
00:23:57.680 --> 00:24:00.910
>> Sure, I actually, and I'm just
going off of past experiences here.

471
00:24:00.910 --> 00:24:06.260
I also worked for a newspaper company and
it's kind of a dying art because people,

472
00:24:06.260 --> 00:24:09.770
because of the Internet,they're really
reaching out to other methods to

473
00:24:09.770 --> 00:24:11.520
get that real time news.

474
00:24:11.520 --> 00:24:17.130
So maybe there might be some alternatives
for that company to still continue.

475
00:24:17.130 --> 00:24:19.240
>> Exactly, yeah, that's really good.

476
00:24:19.240 --> 00:24:21.140
Yeah, I like that example.

477
00:24:21.140 --> 00:24:24.680
So voice of the industry,
what is the industry telling you?

478
00:24:24.680 --> 00:24:28.040
The industry could be
telling you it's outdated and

479
00:24:28.040 --> 00:24:31.590
that you need to come up with different
media to get your message out.

480
00:24:31.590 --> 00:24:35.960
So a lot of times like I said
compliance issues, that type of thing.

481
00:24:35.960 --> 00:24:38.700
So those are the four primary voices.

482
00:24:38.700 --> 00:24:43.490
The nice thing about we're just looking
at the voice of the customer questions.

483
00:24:43.490 --> 00:24:46.720
This is a handout that you receive
in your student package so

484
00:24:46.720 --> 00:24:50.250
I'm not expecting you to read or
memorize any of this stuff.

485
00:24:50.250 --> 00:24:54.570
It's just some ideas of what you
might want to ask a customer.

486
00:24:54.570 --> 00:24:57.010
What I think is kinda cool about
the voice of the customer,

487
00:24:57.010 --> 00:25:01.810
voice of the employee is that you can use
the same tools to gather up information.

488
00:25:01.810 --> 00:25:05.310
So if I wanna know what my customer is
thinking or my employee is thinking,

489
00:25:05.310 --> 00:25:07.680
what are some ways I could
get that information?

490
00:25:07.680 --> 00:25:08.870
I could do.

491
00:25:08.870 --> 00:25:10.368
>> So let me just clarify.

492
00:25:10.368 --> 00:25:13.680
You just said voice of my customer or
voice of my employee, but if we have

493
00:25:13.680 --> 00:25:19.970
a separate VOE, what differentiates VOC
employee versus VOE, if that makes sense?

494
00:25:19.970 --> 00:25:23.270
>> Yeah, so voice of the customer
would be your external customer or

495
00:25:23.270 --> 00:25:25.740
your internal customer that
you have to report to.

496
00:25:25.740 --> 00:25:28.670
Voice of the employee would be
actually the worker people.

497
00:25:28.670 --> 00:25:30.840
The people that are actually
employed there.

498
00:25:30.840 --> 00:25:33.756
>> Just making sure.

499
00:25:33.756 --> 00:25:34.586
>> Yeah this is for customer.

500
00:25:34.586 --> 00:25:35.789
Like when we are talking about tools.

501
00:25:35.789 --> 00:25:39.798
But when we are talking about tools like
how to get this information, we can use

502
00:25:39.798 --> 00:25:44.000
the same tools to get the information
from customers that we do from employees.

503
00:25:44.000 --> 00:25:46.240
>> Yeah, I have taken internal surveys.

504
00:25:46.240 --> 00:25:46.810
>> Surveys, right.

505
00:25:46.810 --> 00:25:48.980
>> We have talked about using surveys for
customers but

506
00:25:48.980 --> 00:25:50.980
as employees I have also done surveys, so.

507
00:25:50.980 --> 00:25:51.740
>> Exactly.

508
00:25:51.740 --> 00:25:54.140
So surveys, interviews, small forums.

509
00:25:54.140 --> 00:25:58.130
So the vehicle to get the information
that you need is pretty much the same.

510
00:25:58.130 --> 00:26:01.250
And these are just some things that
you might wanna ask your customer.

511
00:26:03.890 --> 00:26:08.470
So when we're looking at what voice
of the customer or employee, even

512
00:26:08.470 --> 00:26:12.650
though that's not what the slide says,
here are some things that could happen.

513
00:26:12.650 --> 00:26:17.150
We could improve our quality,
we could reduce errors, we could

514
00:26:17.150 --> 00:26:22.500
eliminate ambiguity, which is what you
were saying about, it's just so confusing.

515
00:26:22.500 --> 00:26:26.880
All right, we could eliminate the unknown,
we could improve data integrity.

516
00:26:26.880 --> 00:26:30.710
So by paying attention to the customer and
the employee,

517
00:26:30.710 --> 00:26:36.050
these are really incredible things that we
could determine, by a survey sometimes.

518
00:26:36.050 --> 00:26:40.110
Sometimes by, my goodness, it is
picking up the phone and asking them.

519
00:26:40.110 --> 00:26:43.160
>> Well I know just recently we
had a survey here at IT ProTV,

520
00:26:43.160 --> 00:26:47.450
some of you guys and
gals may even receive this survey.

521
00:26:47.450 --> 00:26:48.880
It was a one question survey and

522
00:26:48.880 --> 00:26:52.690
it just said what could we
do to our site to improve?

523
00:26:52.690 --> 00:26:53.360
>> Yeah.
>> So

524
00:26:53.360 --> 00:26:55.820
even little things like that
could potentially help.

525
00:26:55.820 --> 00:26:59.350
>> Right, and I love those kinds
of surveys that are one question.

526
00:26:59.350 --> 00:27:02.470
What I don't like are those ones that will
only take you five minutes to fill out

527
00:27:02.470 --> 00:27:02.980
this survey.

528
00:27:02.980 --> 00:27:04.529
And like question 30
your start [CROSSTALK].

529
00:27:04.529 --> 00:27:05.210
>> They lie.

530
00:27:05.210 --> 00:27:06.029
>> To believe it anymore.

531
00:27:06.029 --> 00:27:10.330
[LAUGH] So, some other things that
voice of the customer can do and

532
00:27:10.330 --> 00:27:14.710
some of these also apply to voice of the
employee it that you can improve delivery,

533
00:27:14.710 --> 00:27:19.030
identify true dates of delivery,
shorten turn around time.

534
00:27:19.030 --> 00:27:23.190
I know you guys can read all these, so
I'm just kinda going quickly through them.

535
00:27:23.190 --> 00:27:26.360
Help set priorities and organize tasks.

536
00:27:26.360 --> 00:27:28.290
It's just,

537
00:27:28.290 --> 00:27:33.950
we forget that the customer as well as our
employees have all kinds of information.

538
00:27:33.950 --> 00:27:37.740
We're out there trying to do process
improvement and our most obvious voice

539
00:27:37.740 --> 00:27:41.610
that we should be listening to is
the customer and the employee, right?

540
00:27:41.610 --> 00:27:47.290
Now when we're trying to get the voice of
the customer, we can just do our homework.

541
00:27:47.290 --> 00:27:48.840
There's some things that we can look at.

542
00:27:48.840 --> 00:27:53.420
For example, we can look at the statement
of work, we can look at purchase orders.

543
00:27:53.420 --> 00:27:55.300
We can look at requests for quotes.

544
00:27:55.300 --> 00:27:58.780
Even if we don't get the job,
what are people asking for?

545
00:28:00.150 --> 00:28:01.900
Why didn't we get it?

546
00:28:01.900 --> 00:28:03.330
Right?
So sometimes,

547
00:28:03.330 --> 00:28:08.290
a lot of times when a customer
requests a quote from us or

548
00:28:08.290 --> 00:28:11.980
a bid and we don't get the job, then it's
just yeah, well, we didn't get that one.

549
00:28:13.200 --> 00:28:17.170
But if there's a lot of repetitive
requests and we're not getting them.

550
00:28:17.170 --> 00:28:19.150
Well, you know why, right?

551
00:28:19.150 --> 00:28:21.540
And then technical specifications.

552
00:28:21.540 --> 00:28:25.370
When I'm looking at voice of the customer,
and this kind of plays into a concept

553
00:28:25.370 --> 00:28:31.960
called House of Quality, and the deal
is that the customer wants some thing.

554
00:28:31.960 --> 00:28:34.960
And I have to make sure I have
the technical requirements to fulfill

555
00:28:34.960 --> 00:28:36.030
that, right?

556
00:28:36.030 --> 00:28:39.160
So going on with the voices,
voice of the employee.

557
00:28:39.160 --> 00:28:43.510
A lot of times you want to think
employee engagement as well.

558
00:28:43.510 --> 00:28:45.970
If the employee is getting that
little bit more of attention,

559
00:28:45.970 --> 00:28:48.240
you know that they might be more engaged.

560
00:28:48.240 --> 00:28:52.270
Voice of the Business, I just wanna remind
you that that means compliance like

561
00:28:52.270 --> 00:28:55.630
looking at compliance and trends and
things such of that nature.

562
00:28:55.630 --> 00:28:56.960
And then Voice of the Process,

563
00:28:56.960 --> 00:29:00.470
we always wanna make sure
that the process is capable.

564
00:29:00.470 --> 00:29:02.530
So I just wanna kinda tie
all of this together.

565
00:29:02.530 --> 00:29:07.090
We had a part one and part two of ways,
CTQs and voices, right?

566
00:29:07.090 --> 00:29:09.230
>> Yes.
>> The idea is that CTQ and

567
00:29:09.230 --> 00:29:14.310
voices can be used in
conjunction with Tim Woods.

568
00:29:14.310 --> 00:29:18.920
So if I were trying to look at
transportation issues, let's

569
00:29:18.920 --> 00:29:22.940
say I wasn't using it as a pure waste
model, I am just trying to look at issues.

570
00:29:22.940 --> 00:29:25.200
Well, what are the voice of the customer?

571
00:29:25.200 --> 00:29:28.240
What is the voice of the employee
about that transportation issue?

572
00:29:28.240 --> 00:29:30.120
What is the process?

573
00:29:30.120 --> 00:29:33.430
What is the business,
the industry, in other words?

574
00:29:33.430 --> 00:29:37.070
I could be looking at it
from a CTQ standpoint.

575
00:29:37.070 --> 00:29:41.390
What does transportation need
from me to be successful?

576
00:29:41.390 --> 00:29:45.890
So you'll also notice that we're gonna
use CTQ and Voices on other models, but

577
00:29:45.890 --> 00:29:48.440
the first model was Tim Wood's.

578
00:29:48.440 --> 00:29:51.630
>> Yeah, and I don't think it's
necessarily a bad thing now if you say,

579
00:29:51.630 --> 00:29:54.038
I hear voices that really aren't there.

580
00:29:54.038 --> 00:29:55.850
[LAUGH] Inanimate objects.

581
00:29:55.850 --> 00:29:59.030
People might look at you strange but
if they have watched this video, then I'm

582
00:29:59.030 --> 00:30:03.360
sure they will understand because you have
covered that as well as CTQs in depth.

583
00:30:03.360 --> 00:30:07.680
I appreciate that and I appreciate you for
staying tuned, but don't go anywhere.

584
00:30:07.680 --> 00:30:10.540
We do have a lot more headed your way,
so stay tuned.

585
00:30:10.540 --> 00:30:12.880
But I am going to go ahead and
wrap up for this episode and

586
00:30:12.880 --> 00:30:15.560
sign off as your host, Cherokee Boose.

587
00:30:15.560 --> 00:30:19.080
>> And I'm Dr Terra Vanzant Stern
with SSD Global Solutions.

588
00:30:19.080 --> 00:30:22.536
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

589
00:30:22.536 --> 00:30:28.951
[MUSIC]

590
00:30:28.951 --> 00:30:30.610
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode you understand how being cognizant and thinking of your suppliers, inputs, processes, outputs and customers can make you a stronger Project Manager. SIPOC is another example of the many flexible tools you learn in this series. We can use SIPOC to do things like perform stakeholders’ Analysis to comparisons.
episodes.title: Suppliers Inputs Process Outputs Customers
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.230 --> 00:00:02.695
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.695 --> 00:00:08.370
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.370 --> 00:00:12.530
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.530 --> 00:00:16.825
>> Welcome to your Lean Six Sigma: Green
Belt Certification preperation series.

5
00:00:16.825 --> 00:00:19.850
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:19.850 --> 00:00:24.350
And in this episode, we're gonna
be looking at suppliers inputs.

7
00:00:24.350 --> 00:00:25.280
What's next?

8
00:00:25.280 --> 00:00:29.010
Processes, outputs, customers,
and yes, that's a mouthful,

9
00:00:29.010 --> 00:00:31.490
so that's why we normally just say SIPOC.

10
00:00:31.490 --> 00:00:33.620
With us today in studios we have Dr.

11
00:00:33.620 --> 00:00:38.720
Terra Vanzant Stern to really explain and
break down SIPOC.

12
00:00:38.720 --> 00:00:40.620
So thank you for
being with us today, Doctor.

13
00:00:40.620 --> 00:00:41.900
>> Thank you, Cherokee.

14
00:00:41.900 --> 00:00:43.635
I'm looking forward to explaining SIPOC.

15
00:00:43.635 --> 00:00:45.850
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] And this one's pretty easy.

16
00:00:45.850 --> 00:00:47.302
We know where to start, right?

17
00:00:47.302 --> 00:00:49.068
>> We do.
>> With the S, suppliers, so-

18
00:00:49.068 --> 00:00:51.544
>> That's correct.

19
00:00:51.544 --> 00:00:53.940
[LAUGH] Okay.

20
00:00:53.940 --> 00:00:56.770
So, in this session,
we're gonna talk about SIPOC.

21
00:00:56.770 --> 00:01:01.405
And then I wanna tie SIPOC to some of
the concepts that we've already discussed,

22
00:01:01.405 --> 00:01:04.730
CTQs, voices, stakeholders,
and customer analysis.

23
00:01:04.730 --> 00:01:05.380
>> Okay.
>> Okay?

24
00:01:06.440 --> 00:01:13.150
So sometimes the SIPOC
process is called COPIS.

25
00:01:13.150 --> 00:01:18.070
But SIPOC is what you're
gonna hear on any of

26
00:01:18.070 --> 00:01:21.180
the Lean Six Sigma or
Lean Six Sigma exams.

27
00:01:21.180 --> 00:01:22.080
>> Okay.

28
00:01:22.080 --> 00:01:25.011
>> But just so you know that
sometimes it's called other things.

29
00:01:25.011 --> 00:01:31.170
Now, SIPOC stands for suppliers,
input, process, output, and customer.

30
00:01:31.170 --> 00:01:35.240
And the first thing that I wanna point out
is that it's structured brainstorming.

31
00:01:35.240 --> 00:01:38.600
And one of the things that we said
about structured brainstorming is one,

32
00:01:38.600 --> 00:01:40.200
you can't do it wrong.

33
00:01:40.200 --> 00:01:43.710
It's just a vehicle to help you think.

34
00:01:43.710 --> 00:01:45.780
So who are all the suppliers involved?

35
00:01:45.780 --> 00:01:48.960
What's the input, what's the process,
that type of thing?

36
00:01:48.960 --> 00:01:51.510
So it's a structured brainstorming.

37
00:01:51.510 --> 00:01:54.010
Things can show up in multiple categories.

38
00:01:54.010 --> 00:01:55.950
If you have something
in multiple categories,

39
00:01:55.950 --> 00:01:59.780
remember, in structured brainstorming,
that is actually a good thing.

40
00:01:59.780 --> 00:02:03.920
Because that helps you prioritize
what you're gonna look at.

41
00:02:03.920 --> 00:02:06.630
Another thing I'd like to point
out before we get started

42
00:02:06.630 --> 00:02:10.620
is that we were talking a lot about
that fishbone diagram, where we put

43
00:02:10.620 --> 00:02:15.120
the problem in the head of the fish, and
then we named the bones certain things.

44
00:02:15.120 --> 00:02:18.251
This is another strategy for
naming those major bones,

45
00:02:18.251 --> 00:02:21.392
keeping in mind that you could
just name them yourself.

46
00:02:21.392 --> 00:02:24.170
You could just randomly pick out things.

47
00:02:24.170 --> 00:02:28.480
But if you wanted to, you could name
a bone supplier and put output.

48
00:02:28.480 --> 00:02:32.980
Or you could use that three Ps we talked
about, or the six Ms. So SIPOC's just

49
00:02:32.980 --> 00:02:38.550
another option if you're trying to
come to the root cause of a problem.

50
00:02:38.550 --> 00:02:41.000
This might be a strategy that you use.

51
00:02:41.000 --> 00:02:45.810
Now, suppliers are vendors for
sure, so vendors by default.

52
00:02:45.810 --> 00:02:47.950
Just like when we were talking about CTQs,

53
00:02:47.950 --> 00:02:51.910
a customer requirement
by default is a CTQ.

54
00:02:51.910 --> 00:02:55.590
Although there's other CTQs, but
we know customer requirements.

55
00:02:55.590 --> 00:02:57.950
So suppliers is like that.

56
00:02:57.950 --> 00:03:01.400
If you have a supplier,
it's kind of a manufacturing term.

57
00:03:01.400 --> 00:03:04.810
All vendors would be considered suppliers.

58
00:03:04.810 --> 00:03:08.038
However, you may have someone
internally that's supplying.

59
00:03:08.038 --> 00:03:14.530
So a supplier is anyone that you have to
depend on to get your work done, okay?

60
00:03:14.530 --> 00:03:18.290
So if I have to get a signature
from you before I can move forward,

61
00:03:18.290 --> 00:03:20.630
you become a supplier to me, okay?

62
00:03:20.630 --> 00:03:22.500
So vendors always supplier.

63
00:03:22.500 --> 00:03:26.030
Anyone internally that I have to
get stuff from them before I can

64
00:03:26.030 --> 00:03:27.034
move forward would be-
>> Like someone

65
00:03:27.034 --> 00:03:28.030
in the purchasing department?

66
00:03:28.030 --> 00:03:28.650
>> Exactly.

67
00:03:28.650 --> 00:03:29.862
They would be my supplier, right?

68
00:03:29.862 --> 00:03:30.961
>> Okay.

69
00:03:30.961 --> 00:03:35.260
>> So input is anything
that goes into the system.

70
00:03:35.260 --> 00:03:38.020
Anything that goes into the system.

71
00:03:38.020 --> 00:03:42.290
A lot of times those are referred
to in Lean Six Sigma as exes.

72
00:03:42.290 --> 00:03:46.840
Now in my literature, in the Leaner
Six Sigma, we just call them inputs.

73
00:03:46.840 --> 00:03:50.570
But you hear a lot of words for
inputs, so exes might be one.

74
00:03:51.570 --> 00:03:54.130
The vital few exes, sometimes they'll say.

75
00:03:56.701 --> 00:03:59.820
Key input process variables.

76
00:03:59.820 --> 00:04:04.735
I mean, you're just gonna hear inputs
said a lot of different ways, okay?

77
00:04:04.735 --> 00:04:09.434
Any of the processes, rather,
that are happening within the major

78
00:04:09.434 --> 00:04:14.143
process output anything that you're
pushing out to the customer.

79
00:04:14.143 --> 00:04:18.603
Any documents, any deliverables,
any product, any service,

80
00:04:18.603 --> 00:04:20.884
anything that goes out, right?

81
00:04:20.884 --> 00:04:25.215
And then customer,
you just wanna kind of think of customer,

82
00:04:25.215 --> 00:04:30.710
your internal as well as your external
customers, as being customers.

83
00:04:30.710 --> 00:04:35.120
Now, if you were looking at a SIPOC map,
it would look something like this.

84
00:04:35.120 --> 00:04:39.600
And this is the collateral that
you'll get in your student package,

85
00:04:39.600 --> 00:04:41.400
because it kind of breaks
it down a little bit.

86
00:04:41.400 --> 00:04:44.590
Just like you have one for
TIM WOODS, it breaks it down so

87
00:04:44.590 --> 00:04:47.610
that you're not just looking
at the word SIPOC, right?

88
00:04:47.610 --> 00:04:50.640
So it kind of helps you when
we're thinking suppliers,

89
00:04:50.640 --> 00:04:53.480
we're looking at people,
functions, systems.

90
00:04:53.480 --> 00:04:57.690
When we're looking at inputs,
materials, procedures.

91
00:04:57.690 --> 00:05:01.640
So this diagram is just to kinda help
you even think a little bit further.

92
00:05:01.640 --> 00:05:04.253
If you're thinking I don't even
know where to start with inputs,

93
00:05:04.253 --> 00:05:06.037
I don't know where to
start with processes.

94
00:05:07.306 --> 00:05:11.921
So again, what I think is kinda fun about
SIPOC, remember what we're trying to do is

95
00:05:11.921 --> 00:05:16.920
we're trying to make things better,
faster, and more cost effective.

96
00:05:16.920 --> 00:05:20.880
There is a theory of thought that, if we
know every one that touches what we're

97
00:05:20.880 --> 00:05:24.550
doing, that that's gonna give us
some information right off the back.

98
00:05:24.550 --> 00:05:25.999
It's gonna give us some education.

99
00:05:25.999 --> 00:05:31.110
It might help us identify someone who
will help us or maybe be our champion.

100
00:05:31.110 --> 00:05:35.350
It might help us identify challenges
that are gonna get in the way.

101
00:05:35.350 --> 00:05:38.660
So there's just value knowing
who touches the process.

102
00:05:38.660 --> 00:05:44.080
In the days of TQM when all of this
first started in the late 40s and

103
00:05:44.080 --> 00:05:48.950
50s, they did, and some companies still do
this, something called a Quality Circle.

104
00:05:48.950 --> 00:05:52.520
Where you get everyone together
that touched the process.

105
00:05:52.520 --> 00:05:56.770
What's happened in more modern times is
that, especially with global presence,

106
00:05:56.770 --> 00:06:00.390
it might just be too hard to get
everyone in the same room, right?

107
00:06:00.390 --> 00:06:03.989
And we've got time frames and even just
getting to another building sometimes.

108
00:06:03.989 --> 00:06:05.388
Like, I live in Denver now.

109
00:06:05.388 --> 00:06:08.715
And sometimes with the snow,
even if the building's next door,

110
00:06:08.715 --> 00:06:13.070
just getting everyone physically
together is kind of a big deal, right?

111
00:06:13.070 --> 00:06:15.860
So, what I'd like to do is I'd
like to do something similar

112
00:06:15.860 --> 00:06:19.970
that we did with TIM WOODS just to
get us into the swing of things.

113
00:06:19.970 --> 00:06:22.920
I'd like to apply SIPOC to my home.

114
00:06:22.920 --> 00:06:26.310
Now remember,
all of these tools are ultimately designed

115
00:06:26.310 --> 00:06:31.070
to make our existing processes better,
faster, more cost effective, right?

116
00:06:31.070 --> 00:06:34.564
But if we were using the SIPOC
model towards our home,

117
00:06:34.564 --> 00:06:37.446
I would like to do this
again with Cherokee.

118
00:06:37.446 --> 00:06:38.441
>> [LAUGH]
>> And just,

119
00:06:38.441 --> 00:06:40.290
I think it's a fast way
to learn the model.

120
00:06:40.290 --> 00:06:41.006
>> Okay.

121
00:06:41.006 --> 00:06:42.080
>> All right, so I'm at home.

122
00:06:42.080 --> 00:06:45.720
One of the strategies I could use
to make my home better, faster,

123
00:06:45.720 --> 00:06:49.010
more cost effective,
is I could try to identify waste.

124
00:06:49.010 --> 00:06:50.580
That's one way to do it.

125
00:06:50.580 --> 00:06:53.205
I could maybe say, what are the CTQs?

126
00:06:53.205 --> 00:06:56.452
I could maybe look at my home, and
I could go to those voices, right?

127
00:06:56.452 --> 00:06:58.750
There's lots of different strategies, but

128
00:06:58.750 --> 00:07:02.530
one strategy I might use
is the SIPOC strategy.

129
00:07:02.530 --> 00:07:05.930
So I'm going to try to figure out
everyone who touches my home.

130
00:07:05.930 --> 00:07:10.403
So when we think about suppliers or
vendors, who do we depend upon, or on,

131
00:07:10.403 --> 00:07:10.973
rather?

132
00:07:10.973 --> 00:07:13.364
Who do we, good thing they
don't let me teach English.

133
00:07:13.364 --> 00:07:16.875
>> [LAUGH]
>> Who do we depend on to keep our home

134
00:07:16.875 --> 00:07:17.700
going?

135
00:07:17.700 --> 00:07:19.060
>> Sure, all right.

136
00:07:19.060 --> 00:07:23.583
So, some of these are more,
not necessarily necessities, but

137
00:07:23.583 --> 00:07:25.186
just average things.

138
00:07:25.186 --> 00:07:30.840
Okay, so maybe my carriers,
like for USPS and UPS.

139
00:07:30.840 --> 00:07:31.510
>> Absolutely.

140
00:07:33.780 --> 00:07:35.346
Obviously my utilities companies.

141
00:07:35.346 --> 00:07:37.183
>> Sure.
>> So here in Gainesville, it's GRU,

142
00:07:37.183 --> 00:07:39.240
Gainesville Regional Utilities.

143
00:07:39.240 --> 00:07:44.309
I also have internet, so
that provider is Cox Cabling.

144
00:07:44.309 --> 00:07:49.621
And groundskeepers, hm.

145
00:07:49.621 --> 00:07:50.785
I think that's about it.
>> Yeah, that's good.

146
00:07:50.785 --> 00:07:52.041
>> Okay.
>> That's good.

147
00:07:52.041 --> 00:07:54.483
And, so
when you think about input to your home,

148
00:07:54.483 --> 00:07:57.770
what I want you to visualize is
who walks through your front door.

149
00:08:01.490 --> 00:08:02.024
Family.

150
00:08:02.024 --> 00:08:02.711
>> Children for sure.

151
00:08:02.711 --> 00:08:09.130
>> Yeah, friends, and maybe some service
technicians, plumbers if need be.

152
00:08:09.130 --> 00:08:10.190
That's probably about it.

153
00:08:10.190 --> 00:08:11.160
[LAUGH]
>> Okay, good.

154
00:08:11.160 --> 00:08:13.440
Now you're looking at processes.

155
00:08:13.440 --> 00:08:18.060
And we discussed in another example,
the washing clothes process.

156
00:08:18.060 --> 00:08:20.150
So other than the washing clothes process,

157
00:08:20.150 --> 00:08:23.030
what are some other processes
that happen in your home?

158
00:08:23.030 --> 00:08:25.160
>> Okay, so I'm not too exciting.

159
00:08:25.160 --> 00:08:25.940
But I'll go through-
>> Okay.

160
00:08:25.940 --> 00:08:26.610
>> Them anyways.

161
00:08:26.610 --> 00:08:27.230
>> Okay, that's okay.

162
00:08:27.230 --> 00:08:29.950
>> I have putting away the groceries
when you buy them from the store.

163
00:08:29.950 --> 00:08:30.540
>> Absolutely.

164
00:08:30.540 --> 00:08:34.900
>> Making dinner, doing the dishes
>> Getting ready for bed,

165
00:08:34.900 --> 00:08:36.650
the brushing the teeth process.

166
00:08:36.650 --> 00:08:39.200
And then, of course, in the morning,
just the opposite of that.

167
00:08:39.200 --> 00:08:42.130
Getting up and getting ready for
school and for work.

168
00:08:42.130 --> 00:08:44.580
So I think that's about it.

169
00:08:44.580 --> 00:08:46.455
>> Perfect, so what goes
>> Out of your home?

170
00:08:46.455 --> 00:08:48.365
What walks out that front door?

171
00:08:48.365 --> 00:08:51.365
We talked about walked in, what walks out?

172
00:08:51.365 --> 00:08:54.405
>> Again, I would say the same category.

173
00:08:54.405 --> 00:08:59.430
So family, of course, friends,
and potential contractors.

174
00:08:59.430 --> 00:09:04.390
>> Right, and one that doesn't come in,
that goes out hopefully is trash.

175
00:09:04.390 --> 00:09:05.000
>> Yeah, right.

176
00:09:05.000 --> 00:09:06.420
>> So there are some things.

177
00:09:06.420 --> 00:09:09.330
When you're thinking,
because what Cherokee capitalized on,

178
00:09:09.330 --> 00:09:12.710
is a lot of your inputs are going
to somehow be your outputs.

179
00:09:12.710 --> 00:09:16.990
But in both cases, there's going to
be some inputs that don't leave.

180
00:09:16.990 --> 00:09:19.065
Because one of the inputs
is certainly groceries.

181
00:09:19.065 --> 00:09:22.740
And they're not probably going to go out
because you're going to consume them.

182
00:09:22.740 --> 00:09:25.720
One of the outputs would
be something such as trash.

183
00:09:25.720 --> 00:09:28.620
So a lot of times people say, well,

184
00:09:28.620 --> 00:09:33.050
I don't really get how valuable is it
thinking about inputs and outputs.

185
00:09:33.050 --> 00:09:34.760
It's incredibly valuable.

186
00:09:34.760 --> 00:09:38.310
All Lean Six Sigma is based on what
we put in the system, what we get

187
00:09:38.310 --> 00:09:41.600
out of the system, and studying those
variations and how that all works.

188
00:09:41.600 --> 00:09:43.510
So really, really important.

189
00:09:43.510 --> 00:09:45.200
>> Okay so customers.

190
00:09:45.200 --> 00:09:48.670
Now when you think of
customers in the model,

191
00:09:48.670 --> 00:09:51.690
anyone you have to keep happy-
>> [LAUGH]

192
00:09:51.690 --> 00:09:53.017
>> To keep your home going,

193
00:09:53.017 --> 00:09:54.600
is going to be your customer.

194
00:09:54.600 --> 00:09:57.408
So who do you have to keep
happy to make the home work?

195
00:09:57.408 --> 00:10:01.110
>> Okay, [LAUGH] this is a good one.

196
00:10:01.110 --> 00:10:05.930
So, I have to keep my supplier's happy.

197
