428
00:21:45.410 --> 00:21:47.720
into a job you knew nothing about, right?

429
00:21:47.720 --> 00:21:51.810
Well, certainly, one model you
could use is back to Tim Woods.

430
00:21:51.810 --> 00:21:54.900
You could say, well, what kind of
transportation impacts this department?

431
00:21:54.900 --> 00:21:57.808
What kind of Inventory,
what kind of weighty.

432
00:21:57.808 --> 00:22:01.980
But another good self education
tool is to approach from a SIPOC.

433
00:22:01.980 --> 00:22:03.970
So it's my first day at the job, and

434
00:22:03.970 --> 00:22:07.390
maybe it's just a part time job through
the holidays to supplement my income.

435
00:22:07.390 --> 00:22:09.900
And so they really aren't spending
a lot of time training me.

436
00:22:09.900 --> 00:22:13.650
They're just saying, go do this at
the cash register, or something, right?

437
00:22:13.650 --> 00:22:17.776
So if I wanna quickly get on board,
who supplies this company?

438
00:22:17.776 --> 00:22:21.280
Who are the suppliers,
who are the major vendors?

439
00:22:21.280 --> 00:22:23.670
Where does the input come from?

440
00:22:23.670 --> 00:22:28.270
How do I get stuff into my store or
into my service or to my desk,

441
00:22:28.270 --> 00:22:29.410
how does that happen?

442
00:22:29.410 --> 00:22:32.330
What kind of processes
are happening around this office?

443
00:22:32.330 --> 00:22:34.330
What are some of the mini processes?

444
00:22:34.330 --> 00:22:35.630
What is the final product?

445
00:22:35.630 --> 00:22:37.870
What goes out the door, right?

446
00:22:37.870 --> 00:22:40.530
And then finally, who are the customers?

447
00:22:40.530 --> 00:22:44.120
Who are the customers that
patronize this particular facility?

448
00:22:45.170 --> 00:22:49.320
So that's when we come into customer
analysis versus stakeholder's

449
00:22:49.320 --> 00:22:51.050
analysis, okay?

450
00:22:51.050 --> 00:22:52.820
So it's actually kind
of a different topic.

451
00:22:52.820 --> 00:22:58.370
We've been talking about SIPOC,
we've been talking about how SIPOC can

452
00:22:58.370 --> 00:23:03.390
be used to just identify who we touch,
who's part of the process.

453
00:23:03.390 --> 00:23:06.130
Which is huge because we might
be able to find friends and

454
00:23:06.130 --> 00:23:08.980
foes and
all kinds of information we didn't know.

455
00:23:08.980 --> 00:23:12.170
We said we could use it as
a self-orientation tool.

456
00:23:12.170 --> 00:23:16.890
Still, no matter how we use it, it comes
down to that final thing customer, and so

457
00:23:16.890 --> 00:23:18.740
when we're looking at customers,

458
00:23:18.740 --> 00:23:23.020
how does a customer analysis change
from a stakeholder's analysis?

459
00:23:23.020 --> 00:23:27.030
Well, when we think about
a customer analysis,

460
00:23:27.030 --> 00:23:29.430
it's an important piece
of the business plan.

461
00:23:29.430 --> 00:23:33.550
Who are our customers,
who are our competitors?

462
00:23:33.550 --> 00:23:36.095
I've had people tell me
we have no competitors.

463
00:23:36.095 --> 00:23:39.245
[LAUGH] I think that's kinda funny,
because we all have competitors.

464
00:23:39.245 --> 00:23:41.570
>> [LAUGH]
>> What is the demographics of our

465
00:23:41.570 --> 00:23:42.570
customer?

466
00:23:42.570 --> 00:23:43.590
Where are they at?

467
00:23:43.590 --> 00:23:44.860
What do they do?

468
00:23:44.860 --> 00:23:48.420
How long have they been my customer or
your customer?

469
00:23:48.420 --> 00:23:50.980
So that's all a customer
analysis is doing.

470
00:23:50.980 --> 00:23:55.350
And a SIPOC kinda makes
us go in that direction.

471
00:23:55.350 --> 00:23:57.650
I wanna think about my customer, right?

472
00:23:57.650 --> 00:23:59.760
So who is my customer really?

473
00:23:59.760 --> 00:24:02.212
Who's competing?
How long have they been around?

474
00:24:02.212 --> 00:24:05.236
So it forces us into
thinking about our customer.

475
00:24:05.236 --> 00:24:08.099
And sometimes, when you're doing a SIPOC.

476
00:24:08.099 --> 00:24:12.540
The answer to who is my customer is super
simple, so you don't even have to worry.

477
00:24:12.540 --> 00:24:14.580
I've worked in several situations,
however,

478
00:24:14.580 --> 00:24:17.950
where people were really struggling
with who is my customer.

479
00:24:17.950 --> 00:24:23.130
One of the most recent ones in
an unnamed state, I was working for

480
00:24:24.280 --> 00:24:28.420
child support services, and we were trying
to make that service better, faster,

481
00:24:28.420 --> 00:24:31.460
and more cost effective
in this particular state.

482
00:24:31.460 --> 00:24:34.590
And so I started the session with,
who's our customer?

483
00:24:34.590 --> 00:24:37.140
In my mind, the customer's the child.

484
00:24:37.140 --> 00:24:40.697
But I had people getting up,
yelling out the governor's name and

485
00:24:40.697 --> 00:24:43.810
various other people when I said,
who's the customer?

486
00:24:43.810 --> 00:24:49.707
And we spent really, seriously,
two hours defining who is the customer.

487
00:24:49.707 --> 00:24:53.084
Well, you can't make a process
improvement, if don't have a customer,

488
00:24:53.084 --> 00:24:54.920
if you don't know who your customer is.

489
00:24:54.920 --> 00:24:55.867
And sometimes,

490
00:24:55.867 --> 00:25:00.471
it actually takes a customer analysis to
determine who is my customer, really.

491
00:25:00.471 --> 00:25:01.073
>> Sure.

492
00:25:01.073 --> 00:25:02.989
>> So just something to keep in mind.

493
00:25:02.989 --> 00:25:08.380
And when we're talking about SIPOC versus
a stakeholders' analysis, in project

494
00:25:08.380 --> 00:25:13.810
management, stakeholders' analysis
takes kind of a weird turn in my mind.

495
00:25:13.810 --> 00:25:16.370
And if you're taking
the project management test,

496
00:25:16.370 --> 00:25:21.450
pay attention [LAUGH] to the way we
talk about stakeholders' analysis.

497
00:25:21.450 --> 00:25:26.200
So traditionally, a stakeholders' analysis
is supposed to list everyone who has a key

498
00:25:26.200 --> 00:25:28.890
stake in that particular project.

499
00:25:28.890 --> 00:25:32.880
So you are stakeholder for sure,
your boss is usually a stakeholder.

500
00:25:32.880 --> 00:25:35.900
But it's just kinda
the major stakeholders.

501
00:25:35.900 --> 00:25:40.225
So how that relates to SIPOC is SIPOC is
sort of like a stakeholders' analysis

502
00:25:40.225 --> 00:25:43.698
on steroids because it's telling
you all the stakeholders.

503
00:25:43.698 --> 00:25:48.458
Now you're gonna maybe put some of your
stakeholders on your project charter.

504
00:25:48.458 --> 00:25:49.363
And as a reminder,

505
00:25:49.363 --> 00:25:53.640
your project charter is that form you fill
out to say can I work on this project?

506
00:25:53.640 --> 00:25:57.130
So you're probably still gonna
just put the major stakeholders.

507
00:25:57.130 --> 00:25:59.425
But it's valuable to
know all the people and

508
00:25:59.425 --> 00:26:01.978
all the things that have
a stake in your project.

509
00:26:01.978 --> 00:26:07.273
And that's how stakeholders'
analysis relates to the SIPOC.

510
00:26:07.273 --> 00:26:10.513
However, even the stakeholders' analysis,

511
00:26:10.513 --> 00:26:15.430
we do the SIPOC, it's like
stakeholders' analysis on steroids.

512
00:26:15.430 --> 00:26:18.800
When we do stakeholders' analysis, it's a
little different than project management.

513
00:26:18.800 --> 00:26:22.109
So I'm gonna go back to what I was saying,
in project management,

514
00:26:22.109 --> 00:26:24.603
stakeholders' analysis says,
who has a stake?

515
00:26:24.603 --> 00:26:27.660
And then it says are they for
you or against you?

516
00:26:27.660 --> 00:26:29.930
Are they for you, but
they're not gonna help you?

517
00:26:29.930 --> 00:26:31.840
Are they against, or
you're not gonna get in the way?

518
00:26:31.840 --> 00:26:34.290
That’s a traditional
stakeholders' analysis.

519
00:26:34.290 --> 00:26:38.110
Personally, that makes me a little nervous
about having a document like that floating

520
00:26:38.110 --> 00:26:42.460
around, so I don't know, but that’s
a traditional stakeholders' analysis.

521
00:26:42.460 --> 00:26:46.650
In Lean Six Sigma, we have a tendency to
think of the SIPOC as our stakeholders'

522
00:26:46.650 --> 00:26:51.070
analysis and the stakeholders'
analysis as a communication tool.

523
00:26:51.070 --> 00:26:55.740
So let's say I'm working on a lot of
different projects, then in that case,

524
00:26:55.740 --> 00:27:00.240
I might need to know that Bob only
wants analytical information,

525
00:27:00.240 --> 00:27:03.090
he is only interested in graphs and
charts.

526
00:27:03.090 --> 00:27:05.970
And maybe Matthew says, I don't care,

527
00:27:05.970 --> 00:27:09.360
don't even bother me unless
the project's going out of control.

528
00:27:09.360 --> 00:27:12.524
And then maybe Cindy says,
I just need a status report on Fridays.

529
00:27:12.524 --> 00:27:15.792
So if I've got multiple projects going on,
if I only have one project and

530
00:27:15.792 --> 00:27:17.935
I'm working with the same
people all the time,

531
00:27:17.935 --> 00:27:20.683
this isn't gonna be that
valuable of a communication tool.

532
00:27:20.683 --> 00:27:24.606
Because I'm gonna know this
person likes phone calls,

533
00:27:24.606 --> 00:27:29.124
this person never reads their email,
they want me to text them.

534
00:27:29.124 --> 00:27:31.020
I'm gonna know that, right?

535
00:27:31.020 --> 00:27:33.410
But if I'm working on multiple projects,

536
00:27:33.410 --> 00:27:37.140
it might be helpful to
have this as a reminder.

537
00:27:37.140 --> 00:27:39.030
This is what each one
of these people want.

538
00:27:40.060 --> 00:27:45.630
So stakeholder analysis, who has
the major interest on your project,

539
00:27:45.630 --> 00:27:47.720
just like we said, you, the sponsor,

540
00:27:47.720 --> 00:27:52.340
and the sponsor in Lean Six Sigma is
always the one that signs the check.

541
00:27:52.340 --> 00:27:55.860
So the tricky thing about
your sponsor is that

542
00:27:55.860 --> 00:27:58.820
it could be your boss's boss's boss,
right?

543
00:27:58.820 --> 00:28:02.550
So sponsors always, who said it's okay,
who allocated the money,

544
00:28:02.550 --> 00:28:04.310
who said that you can move forward.

545
00:28:04.310 --> 00:28:07.230
But they're always gonna be a stakeholder,
right?

546
00:28:07.230 --> 00:28:12.100
And then others who are impacted,
and the way others are impacted

547
00:28:12.100 --> 00:28:15.750
is you go through your SIPOC, and
you figure what others are impacted.

548
00:28:15.750 --> 00:28:19.460
The advantage of a SIPOC over
a traditional stakeholders' analysis

549
00:28:19.460 --> 00:28:23.465
is that SIPOC also identifies
the nonhuman resources.

550
00:28:23.465 --> 00:28:26.470
Stakeholders' analysis, you're never gonna
see something like if you're building

551
00:28:26.470 --> 00:28:29.760
a deck, you're not gonna
see as stakeholder lumber.

552
00:28:29.760 --> 00:28:33.450
But in the SIPOC, you might, right?

553
00:28:33.450 --> 00:28:37.520
So traditional versus the leaner way,
I already covered that.

554
00:28:37.520 --> 00:28:40.480
The project management version
versus the Lean Six Sigma.

555
00:28:40.480 --> 00:28:43.790
But in a nutshell, the project management
version, if you're sitting for

556
00:28:43.790 --> 00:28:47.790
the PMBOK, you wanna go back and
make sure that you read that carefully.

557
00:28:47.790 --> 00:28:52.418
Because it says, for, against, help me,
not help me type kind of thing.

558
00:28:52.418 --> 00:28:55.867
But in Lean Six Sigma,
we use it more as a communication tool.

559
00:28:55.867 --> 00:28:56.819
>> All right.

560
00:28:56.819 --> 00:29:04.070
>> So I think we've come to the end of
this discussion about SIPOC suppliers.

561
00:29:04.070 --> 00:29:08.260
>> All right, if you don't have any other
thoughts, then we'll go ahead and wrap up

562
00:29:08.260 --> 00:29:12.388
for this particular episode, but I want
you guys to go ahead and stay tuned, we do

563
00:29:12.388 --> 00:29:15.919
have more information headed your way
>> But we are gonna go ahead and

564
00:29:15.919 --> 00:29:20.277
wrap up for this episode, and I'll
sign out as your host, Cherokee Boose.

565
00:29:20.277 --> 00:29:24.583
>> And this is Dr. Terra Vanzant Stern
with SSD Global Solutions.

566
00:29:24.583 --> 00:29:27.451
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

567
00:29:27.451 --> 00:29:33.756
[MUSIC]

568
00:29:33.756 --> 00:29:35.810
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: It’s no secret graphs and charts are great visual aids that can really make a presentation pop! This episode covers several different ways to convey your data and ideas.
episodes.title: Important Graphs and Charts
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.940 --> 00:00:05.289
Welcome to ITProTV.
I'm your host

2
00:00:05.289 --> 00:00:10.490
[CROSSTALK]
>> You're watching ITProTV.

3
00:00:12.340 --> 00:00:17.270
>> Welcome to your Lean Six Sigma: Green
Belt Certification Preparation series.

4
00:00:17.270 --> 00:00:19.700
I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

5
00:00:19.700 --> 00:00:24.190
In this episode we're gonna be looking
at some important graphs and charts.

6
00:00:24.190 --> 00:00:27.450
And to go ahead and demonstrate and
show us some of those charts and

7
00:00:27.450 --> 00:00:31.500
graphs we have in studios Dr.
Terra Vanzant Stern.

8
00:00:31.500 --> 00:00:32.780
Thank you for joining us today.

9
00:00:32.780 --> 00:00:34.270
>> Thank you, Cherokee.

10
00:00:34.270 --> 00:00:35.620
It's a pleasure to be here.

11
00:00:35.620 --> 00:00:38.770
>> So graphs and charts always add a nice,

12
00:00:38.770 --> 00:00:43.010
additional visual element to any kind of
presentation, to help convey your message,

13
00:00:43.010 --> 00:00:46.520
so are there any types of charts
that might be more influential,

14
00:00:46.520 --> 00:00:50.150
or used in specific instances,
or where should we start?

15
00:00:50.150 --> 00:00:51.980
>> Well I'd like to go
to my slide deck and

16
00:00:51.980 --> 00:00:57.070
the first thing that I want to mention is
that remember, we've already looked at

17
00:00:57.070 --> 00:01:02.020
seven tools that are chart-like and
graph-like in nature.

18
00:01:02.020 --> 00:01:04.800
And those are up on the screen right now.

19
00:01:04.800 --> 00:01:08.180
So those are still the most
important graphs and charts.

20
00:01:08.180 --> 00:01:12.460
And I maintain that you can do
an entire Lean Six Sigma project

21
00:01:12.460 --> 00:01:15.470
by just even using part of these, right?

22
00:01:15.470 --> 00:01:20.000
But there are some other different charts,
and in this session these are popular

23
00:01:20.000 --> 00:01:24.180
charts that are used in project
management as well as Lean Six Sigma.

24
00:01:24.180 --> 00:01:28.850
So those would be Gantt charts,
PERT diagrams, your Burn Down Chart,

25
00:01:28.850 --> 00:01:32.720
which is mostly an agile one,
a relationship diagram,

26
00:01:32.720 --> 00:01:35.370
swindling charts and spaghetti diagrams.

27
00:01:35.370 --> 00:01:38.856
And even though that sounds like
a mouthful because mostly I'm gonna be

28
00:01:38.856 --> 00:01:42.241
showing you the pictures of these things,
it should go pretty fast.

29
00:01:42.241 --> 00:01:43.520
>> Okay.

30
00:01:43.520 --> 00:01:47.890
>> One of the things that I wanna point
out, is that we do have templates for

31
00:01:47.890 --> 00:01:54.320
these types of chart on our
site at www.ssdglobal.net.

32
00:01:54.320 --> 00:01:58.130
However, any of these charts if
you were to write in the word and

33
00:01:58.130 --> 00:02:02.520
template in any search engine,
it's gonna come back with other templates.

34
00:02:02.520 --> 00:02:03.700
We tried it.

35
00:02:03.700 --> 00:02:08.110
In fact, we get a lot of student input
about our templates on our website.

36
00:02:08.110 --> 00:02:10.060
So we're always getting new ones.

37
00:02:10.060 --> 00:02:13.410
And we're always kind of playing
around with charts and graphs.

38
00:02:13.410 --> 00:02:16.146
So we like to think that we
have the most current ones, but

39
00:02:16.146 --> 00:02:18.830
sometimes you just find one
that you like to use better.

40
00:02:20.790 --> 00:02:25.440
Gantt charts, this kind of goes back to

41
00:02:25.440 --> 00:02:30.549
the whole thing about how Lean likes
to give the chart or the graph.

42
00:02:31.620 --> 00:02:32.527
>> Credit where credit is due.

43
00:02:32.527 --> 00:02:35.666
>> Exactly, exactly, so
Henry Gantt did this, but

44
00:02:35.666 --> 00:02:40.525
back in the old days with Gantt charts,
they had butcher block paper that they

45
00:02:40.525 --> 00:02:45.050
would literally tape on the walls and
people would draw on the paper.

46
00:02:45.050 --> 00:02:45.770
>> Interesting.

47
00:02:45.770 --> 00:02:47.767
>> Now we have a-
>> Digital.

48
00:02:47.767 --> 00:02:49.690
>> It's a lot easier.
Yeah, we have digital stuff.

49
00:02:49.690 --> 00:02:55.010
So, this is kinda how it would of
looked in 1918, the Basic Gantt Chart.

50
00:02:55.010 --> 00:02:59.730
You have your project tasks, and so,
you'll see on the left-hand side,

51
00:02:59.730 --> 00:03:02.790
you would have all the things
that you need to do, right?

52
00:03:02.790 --> 00:03:06.900
And in this case, the basic project stuff,
the research for that project,

53
00:03:06.900 --> 00:03:10.120
the development, the prototype production.

54
00:03:10.120 --> 00:03:14.023
And then along the top
where you see that J, F, M.

55
00:03:14.023 --> 00:03:17.239
That's just short for January,
February, and March, right?

56
00:03:17.239 --> 00:03:21.730
And so you'll notice that some
of the bars overlap, right,

57
00:03:21.730 --> 00:03:24.470
because research is still going on.

58
00:03:24.470 --> 00:03:26.030
The project, that first one,

59
00:03:26.030 --> 00:03:29.370
is encompassing the entire project,
that first bar.

60
00:03:29.370 --> 00:03:33.126
Then the second bar says at that first
part of the project, that's where

61
00:03:33.126 --> 00:03:37.325
the research element's gonna happen,
and then you move over the development.

62
00:03:37.325 --> 00:03:40.409
And you'll notice then finally
the prototype production, but

63
00:03:40.409 --> 00:03:43.034
if you look at the bars
there's some overlap, right,

64
00:03:43.034 --> 00:03:46.010
because then things are starting up as-
>> To happen in tandem.

65
00:03:46.010 --> 00:03:49.090
>> Exactly, and
some things can happen in tandem.

66
00:03:49.090 --> 00:03:53.230
So when we're thinking about the evolution
of Gantt charts, this is where it started,

67
00:03:53.230 --> 00:03:55.410
and this was all it was, okay?

68
00:03:55.410 --> 00:03:59.700
And so the reason why I mention that is
sometimes people have seen Gantt charts

69
00:04:00.810 --> 00:04:05.880
in packages such as MS Project, and there
are some extra things that that gives you.

70
00:04:05.880 --> 00:04:07.540
But we'll be talking about those.

71
00:04:07.540 --> 00:04:09.780
So this is just the same thing again.

72
00:04:09.780 --> 00:04:13.690
Just to show you here
that basic Gantt chart,

73
00:04:13.690 --> 00:04:18.930
it showed the timeline of your
work breakdown structure.

74
00:04:18.930 --> 00:04:23.904
So, in that left-hand column, a lot of
times what you're gonna see is Task 1, 2,

75
00:04:23.904 --> 00:04:27.234
3, 4, and then under those tasks,
1.1, 1.2.

76
00:04:27.234 --> 00:04:31.339
So, in the basic Gantt chart,
you're just seeing the timeline for

77
00:04:31.339 --> 00:04:32.970
each one of those tasks.

78
00:04:32.970 --> 00:04:37.260
And then at the lower right-hand, it's
showing you where we are in that task.

79
00:04:37.260 --> 00:04:41.950
So that blue bar is representing this is
how long the task is supposed to take and

80
00:04:41.950 --> 00:04:43.370
this is where we're at.

81
00:04:43.370 --> 00:04:48.220
Because a lot of times we over or
underestimate a task, and

82
00:04:48.220 --> 00:04:52.020
we're just saying we think this is
how long it's gonna take, right?

83
00:04:52.020 --> 00:04:55.300
So, Gantt charts are really
kinda helpful in that way.

84
00:04:55.300 --> 00:05:01.400
So, a basic Gantt chart these days
sometimes also includes the milestones,

85
00:05:01.400 --> 00:05:03.130
and it's really interesting.

86
00:05:03.130 --> 00:05:07.373
Because even in project management,
where they talk about milestones and

87
00:05:07.373 --> 00:05:10.472
deliverables, sometimes
seasoned project managers

88
00:05:10.472 --> 00:05:14.190
will disagree on what's a milestone and
what's a deliverable.

89
00:05:14.190 --> 00:05:16.238
The easiest way for me to explain it,

90
00:05:16.238 --> 00:05:19.280
is a deliverable is anything
you promise the client.

91
00:05:19.280 --> 00:05:22.840
So, if you promise them a status report,
that's a deliverable, right?

92
00:05:22.840 --> 00:05:26.180
Certainly when the project's over and
you're done, that's a deliverable.

93
00:05:26.180 --> 00:05:30.160
But anything that you're actually
outputting, you're giving to the client.

94
00:05:30.160 --> 00:05:32.470
A milestone is a phase
that you go through.

95
00:05:32.470 --> 00:05:35.330
So, if you were looking at the PDCA model,

96
00:05:35.330 --> 00:05:38.460
you might mention
a milestone between P and D.

97
00:05:38.460 --> 00:05:40.930
Remember, it was Plan, Do, Check, Act.

98
00:05:40.930 --> 00:05:44.362
So, as I move from Plan to Do,
that might be my milestone.

99
00:05:44.362 --> 00:05:45.480
>> Okay.

100
00:05:45.480 --> 00:05:51.650
>> A lot of times,
milestones can be the time of year, too.

101
00:05:51.650 --> 00:05:54.620
We're passing from the fall
quarter into the winter quarter.

102
00:05:54.620 --> 00:05:57.130
So milestones are just
things that we're passing.

103
00:05:57.130 --> 00:05:58.670
Well, on today's Gantt chart,

104
00:05:58.670 --> 00:06:04.270
a lot of times those milestones
are recorded on the actual chart itself.

105
00:06:05.750 --> 00:06:09.250
Now, this is called a combination chart,
and

106
00:06:09.250 --> 00:06:11.870
only because it's tracking and
the milestones.

107
00:06:11.870 --> 00:06:13.920
So if you had something
in project management,

108
00:06:13.920 --> 00:06:16.910
especially called a milestone chart,
all you're gonna

109
00:06:16.910 --> 00:06:20.850
have on a thing that looks a little like
a Gantt chart, is just the milestones.

110
00:06:20.850 --> 00:06:24.230
But on a combination chart,
it's kind of silly, but

111
00:06:24.230 --> 00:06:25.960
on combination chart you have everything.

112
00:06:25.960 --> 00:06:27.590
And that's leaner, right?

113
00:06:27.590 --> 00:06:30.240
It's leaner just to have
everything on the same chart.

114
00:06:30.240 --> 00:06:31.670
>> One quick, quick glance.

115
00:06:31.670 --> 00:06:34.590
>> Exactly,
that's the whole purpose of it.

116
00:06:34.590 --> 00:06:38.290
And then remember,
on a combination chart you could also have

117
00:06:39.390 --> 00:06:42.290

118
00:06:42.290 --> 00:06:45.710
I think it's kind of interesting cuz a lot
of times people put Gantt charts together,

119
00:06:45.710 --> 00:06:50.160

record where they are in that task.

120
00:06:50.160 --> 00:06:53.630
That's kind of sad because this is
a good way to know if you're ahead or

121
00:06:53.630 --> 00:06:54.730
behind in schedule.

122
00:06:56.510 --> 00:07:00.840
So Gantt charts are constructed

00:07:17.460 --> 00:07:22.120

00:07:22.120 --> 00:07:22.620

And then the vertical access generally

If I wanted to graphically

00:08:47.780 --> 00:08:50.950

00:13:47.640 --> 00:13:53.220

And it's another kind of simple concept.

00:13:59.300 --> 00:14:02.045
But remember when we were

00:14:02.045 --> 00:14:05.060

00:14:05.060 --> 00:14:08.072
Well, for the Army, PDCA, well,

PERT was the classified document for

00:14:11.600 --> 00:14:12.170

So, PERT is a tool to use to schedule.

And basically what I'm looking at

00:14:21.340 --> 00:14:23.110

00:14:25.972 --> 00:14:27.934

00:14:27.934 --> 00:14:31.180

00:14:36.340 --> 00:14:41.390
So if one of these tasks slips time-wise,

It's not gonna be delivered on time.

00:14:43.060 --> 00:14:45.710

00:14:51.580 --> 00:14:52.150

00:15:13.585 --> 00:15:18.419

00:15:22.600 --> 00:15:26.549
That would be your drop-dead date,

00:15:27.900 --> 00:15:29.240
Now, oops.

302
00:15:54.170 --> 00:15:55.970
that's called your critical path.

If those slip, the whole project slips.

00:15:57.920 --> 00:16:02.912

00:16:07.070 --> 00:16:07.600
>> Okay.

00:16:07.600 --> 00:16:08.470
Yeah.

00:16:08.470 --> 00:16:09.592
So the first thing,

getting your duration, getting all

00:16:13.424 --> 00:16:18.397
Another good example of PERT is that
if I'm gonna have a holiday party at my

If I wanted to have a party, I'd have to

539
00:29:24.840 --> 00:29:28.740
process improvement, the biggest ares for
process improvement lies.

540
00:29:30.510 --> 00:29:36.110
So here's an office visit workflow
template and then this one, you can see,

541
00:29:36.110 --> 00:29:43.680
it's the patient, the medical
professional, the provider, and the nurse.

542
00:29:43.680 --> 00:29:44.787
>> Don't strain yourself.

543
00:29:44.787 --> 00:29:47.772
[LAUGH] I mean you're gonna end up with
a crook in your neck, looking at that.

544
00:29:47.772 --> 00:29:50.005
>> I know, looking sideways like that.

545
00:29:50.005 --> 00:29:51.725
Well, and usually they're a lot bigger.

546
00:29:51.725 --> 00:29:56.045
In your packet,
this'll be a little bit more readable.

547
00:29:56.045 --> 00:29:59.585
Because we like to show you, once again,
we like to show you the graphs and

548
00:29:59.585 --> 00:30:04.295
charts that are related to some things,
so it's a little easier to read.

549
00:30:04.295 --> 00:30:12.950
But in this one, you'll see that
the medical professional and the provider.

550
00:30:12.950 --> 00:30:14.270
There's a lot of boxes there.

551
00:30:14.270 --> 00:30:18.520
So, I probably wouldn't,
if I were trying to improve this process,

552
00:30:18.520 --> 00:30:21.920
I probably wouldn't be looking at
the patient or the nursing at this point,

553
00:30:21.920 --> 00:30:24.390
I'd probably concentrate on this two.

554
00:30:24.390 --> 00:30:28.090
So, sometimes you can have a flow
chart that's as simple as Monday,

555
00:30:28.090 --> 00:30:28.900
Tuesday, Wednesday,

556
00:30:28.900 --> 00:30:33.840
Thursday and these are the activities that
have to happen on those particular days.

557
00:30:33.840 --> 00:30:36.810
So this one, finally,
is one I think we can read.

558
00:30:36.810 --> 00:30:39.950
This is,
current state of a pizza place, right?

559
00:30:39.950 --> 00:30:42.590
And you see all the different
things that are happening.

560
00:30:42.590 --> 00:30:47.560
So based on that theory that I had that
where the most activity is happening is

561
00:30:47.560 --> 00:30:50.070
the most opportunity for
process improvement.

562
00:30:50.070 --> 00:30:52.100
That would be in the prep
part of the pizza.

563
00:30:53.130 --> 00:30:54.420
So I'll give you a second to digest.

564
00:30:54.420 --> 00:30:57.720
This is the first one that we
can actually read comfortably.

565
00:30:57.720 --> 00:31:00.958
Again, the other ones will
be in your student pack.

566
00:31:00.958 --> 00:31:03.972
>> Dough, storage, stove.

567
00:31:03.972 --> 00:31:04.870
What does the orange?

568
00:31:07.030 --> 00:31:07.560
>> Fridge.

569
00:31:07.560 --> 00:31:08.250
>> Fridge and oven.

570
00:31:08.250 --> 00:31:09.025
Okay.
>> Yeah.

571
00:31:09.025 --> 00:31:11.198
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

572
00:31:12.370 --> 00:31:14.090
>> So, the idea, the biggest difference,

573
00:31:14.090 --> 00:31:16.740
the takeaway is how a swim lane

574
00:31:16.740 --> 00:31:20.460
is different from just
a regular detailed process map.

575
00:31:20.460 --> 00:31:25.624
Is the swim lane has actual lanes, and
they can be horizontal or vertical.

576
00:31:25.624 --> 00:31:30.542
There's all kinds of templates out there
on search engines also on our student page

577
00:31:30.542 --> 00:31:31.816
at SSDGlobal.net.

578
00:31:31.816 --> 00:31:34.665
So there's all kinds of
templates that you can use but

579
00:31:34.665 --> 00:31:38.715
the idea is I'm trying to see how
the process goes to different categories,

580
00:31:38.715 --> 00:31:42.230
different departments or
handled by different people.

581
00:31:42.230 --> 00:31:42.906
That type of thing.

582
00:31:42.906 --> 00:31:44.289
>> Okay.

583
00:31:44.289 --> 00:31:49.880
>> So, I think this is close to the the
last diagram, is the Spaghetti Diagram.

584
00:31:49.880 --> 00:31:52.150
And I kind of really love this one.

585
00:31:52.150 --> 00:31:56.450
Here's an example of a Spaghetti Diagram
just drawn on paper.

586
00:31:56.450 --> 00:32:01.518
So the idea of a Spaghetti Diagram is I'm
trying to physically track the process.

587
00:32:01.518 --> 00:32:06.430
So I'm putting my pencil kind of like
an old game that was played many,

588
00:32:06.430 --> 00:32:07.609
many years ago.

589
00:32:07.609 --> 00:32:09.394
I'm putting my pencil on a piece of paper.

590
00:32:09.394 --> 00:32:13.436
I'm trying to not take the pencil off
until I connect all the dots, right?

591
00:32:13.436 --> 00:32:15.943
>> Yes.
>> Because what I'm doing is I'm trying to

592
00:32:15.943 --> 00:32:18.557
figure out how things move
from one area to another.

593
00:32:18.557 --> 00:32:22.052
And if there's an opportunity
to improve that process.

594
00:32:22.052 --> 00:32:24.440
>> Reduce the waste by
reducing the motion?

595
00:32:24.440 --> 00:32:25.110
>> Exactly.

596
00:32:25.110 --> 00:32:26.600
>> All right.
>> Absolutely.

597
00:32:26.600 --> 00:32:30.500
And here's one, you know, again,
I can't stress this enough,

598
00:32:30.500 --> 00:32:32.320
we've talked about it in other sessions.

599
00:32:32.320 --> 00:32:35.790
Most of these tools,
were meant to be paper and

600
00:32:35.790 --> 00:32:37.840
pencil tools to help
our critical thinking.

601
00:32:37.840 --> 00:32:40.000
And then over the years,
they became computerized and

602
00:32:40.000 --> 00:32:43.840
they became templates, and
now we use them in presentations.

603
00:32:43.840 --> 00:32:50.570
But don't discount just drawing something
out just to help your thinking process.

604
00:32:50.570 --> 00:32:54.841
So here's another one,
just looking at some different movements.

605
00:32:59.251 --> 00:33:00.890
And then that one's kind of pretty.

606
00:33:00.890 --> 00:33:03.556
I mean, it doesn't look like
a lot of things are going on.

607
00:33:06.361 --> 00:33:11.880
Now, as you see in example one,
that's before.

608
00:33:11.880 --> 00:33:13.430
That's all the movement before.

609
00:33:13.430 --> 00:33:15.530
And then it's all cleaned up.

610
00:33:15.530 --> 00:33:16.860
>> Yeah.
>> In the second one.

611
00:33:18.856 --> 00:33:20.712
>> Maybe they organize by departments.

612
00:33:20.712 --> 00:33:21.381
>> Yeah.

613
00:33:21.381 --> 00:33:22.540
>> [LAUGH]
>> And

614
00:33:22.540 --> 00:33:25.850
again, these are just examples
of spaghetti diagrams.

615
00:33:25.850 --> 00:33:30.030
Now, there are programs, I think we may
even see a graph, well I guess not.

616
00:33:30.030 --> 00:33:33.310
There are programs that take
the spaghetti diagram and

617
00:33:33.310 --> 00:33:35.630
make it look more like a flow chart.

618
00:33:35.630 --> 00:33:41.010
And so they're clean, so
it shows you the process, it

619
00:33:41.010 --> 00:33:45.710
shows you the process all messed up, using
flow chart symbols, and then it shows that

620
00:33:46.810 --> 00:33:51.900
all fixed using flow chart symbols, and
usually, there's less boxes, right?

621
00:33:51.900 --> 00:33:55.750
But I think that there is some value
sometime in actually drawing it out,

622
00:33:55.750 --> 00:34:00.530
and letting people know on a flow
chart like how crazy it is.

623
00:34:00.530 --> 00:34:02.100
>> [LAUGH]
>> I think sometimes when you do

624
00:34:02.100 --> 00:34:06.200
that spaghetti diagram and you use flow
chart symbols, it doesn't look that bad.

625
00:34:06.200 --> 00:34:08.500
And if you're trying to say look,
it is really bad, and

626
00:34:08.500 --> 00:34:11.160
now it's like really better
because we cleaned it up,

627
00:34:11.160 --> 00:34:13.290
then sometimes just drawing
it out really does help.

628
00:34:13.290 --> 00:34:17.560
>> Well that was a lot of different types
of charts and graphs that we looked at and

629
00:34:17.560 --> 00:34:21.140
I definitely feel more inspired and
I'm thinking in different ways.

630
00:34:21.140 --> 00:34:25.330
And so I appreciate you taking the time to
show us all of those different examples.

631
00:34:25.330 --> 00:34:29.800
And I appreciate you guys for staying here
with us for our Green Belt Training but we

632
00:34:29.800 --> 00:34:34.280
do have more really great content headed
your way so please don't go anywhere,

633
00:34:34.280 --> 00:34:37.840
get comfortable, but we're gonna go
ahead and wrap up for this episode.

634
00:34:37.840 --> 00:34:41.340
I'll sign off as your
show host Cherokee Boose.

635
00:34:41.340 --> 00:34:45.410
>> And this is Doctor Terra Vanzant-Stern
with SSD Global Solutions.

636
00:34:45.410 --> 00:34:48.942
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

637
00:34:48.942 --> 00:34:54.933
[MUSIC]

638
00:34:54.933 --> 00:35:00.500
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: The DMAIC model is a very popular mythology that should be fully understood. In this episode Dr. Terra Vanzant Stern and Cherokee Boose introduce the Define phase. The key aspects of the design phase are to make sure you are working on the right problem and to make sure the people involved understand what you are working on.
episodes.title: DMAIC Model - Define Phase
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.230 --> 00:00:01.366
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.366 --> 00:00:06.346
I'm your host [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.346 --> 00:00:08.274
[MUSIC].

4
00:00:08.274 --> 00:00:12.150
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.150 --> 00:00:17.910
>> Welcome to your Lean Six Sigma Green
Belt Certification Preparation series.

6
00:00:17.910 --> 00:00:20.690
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:20.690 --> 00:00:23.940
Now, we're gonna be taking
a look at the DMAIC Model.

8
00:00:23.940 --> 00:00:27.250
And well, it only seems logical
to start at the beginning.

9
00:00:27.250 --> 00:00:31.590
So here we have Dr Terra Vanzant-Stern
in studios with us today.

10
00:00:31.590 --> 00:00:33.520
Welcome, thank you for being here Doctor.

11
00:00:33.520 --> 00:00:34.590
>> Thank you, Cherokee.

12
00:00:34.590 --> 00:00:36.590
>> So I was thinking we would go ahead and
start at well,

13
00:00:36.590 --> 00:00:39.800
the Define Phase because
that's at the beginning.

14
00:00:39.800 --> 00:00:41.870
So-
>> Absolutely.

15
00:00:41.870 --> 00:00:47.020
And the thing is that you want to remember
about the DMAIC Model, it is almost,

16
00:00:47.020 --> 00:00:52.470
it's like 40 to 45% of the test
relates to things in the DMAIC Model.

17
00:00:52.470 --> 00:00:55.060
A lot of the tools and
things we've already covered.

18
00:00:55.060 --> 00:00:58.050
So we're gonna be talking about where
you would use them in different

19
00:00:58.050 --> 00:01:01.670
phases of the model to kind of
make those tools resonate a bit.

20
00:01:01.670 --> 00:01:05.243
But if you have time,
you wanna spend it in define.

21
00:01:05.243 --> 00:01:09.969
Now obviously if you've got a deadline,
you're gonna have to temper that,

22
00:01:09.969 --> 00:01:13.169
but the more time you can
spend in Define the better,

23
00:01:13.169 --> 00:01:15.930
because that really sets the stage.

24
00:01:15.930 --> 00:01:24.941
So if we could just go to my slide deck,
As Cherokee said,

25
00:01:24.941 --> 00:01:30.380
we're in the Define Phase,
this is phase one of the DMAIC Model.

26
00:01:30.380 --> 00:01:33.730
Remember, there are other models
that Lean Six Sigma recognizes.

27
00:01:33.730 --> 00:01:36.200
One is the PDCA, right?

28
00:01:36.200 --> 00:01:39.364
And the other is designed for Six Sigma.

29
00:01:39.364 --> 00:01:43.749
PDCA, a lot of times as a Lean Six Sigma
professional in the workplace,

30
00:01:43.749 --> 00:01:46.100
that's gonna be the one that you use.

31
00:01:46.100 --> 00:01:48.970
Because the problem's simple or
perhaps you have to

32
00:01:48.970 --> 00:01:53.710
get the project done by Monday, so
there could be some time sensitivity.

33
00:01:53.710 --> 00:01:56.910
But the DMAIC is really
the flagship of Lean Six Sigma.

34
00:01:58.170 --> 00:02:02.543
And so in this session, we're just gonna
quickly review the DMAIC so that you can

35
00:02:02.543 --> 00:02:06.936
see where Define fits in, and then we
won't be doing that on the other sessions.

36
00:02:06.936 --> 00:02:09.114
>> Okay.
>> But we'll kinda start there, and

37
00:02:09.114 --> 00:02:12.112
then we'll concentrate mostly
on Define and Decision.

38
00:02:15.986 --> 00:02:19.493
And that's just a reminder
that there's other phases,

39
00:02:19.493 --> 00:02:22.440
Measure, Analyze, Improve, and Control.

40
00:02:22.440 --> 00:02:23.820
It's five phases.

41
00:02:23.820 --> 00:02:25.820
Define is phase one.

42
00:02:25.820 --> 00:02:28.790
Now you'll remember that
we said in Six Sigma,

43
00:02:28.790 --> 00:02:34.000
the biggest deal about
the DMAIC Model is that in Define,

44
00:02:34.000 --> 00:02:37.860
we get a very clear idea
of what the problem is.

45
00:02:37.860 --> 00:02:40.760
Whereas, in typical problem solving
sometimes we just throw it out,

46
00:02:40.760 --> 00:02:44.390
we're very reactive and we just go and
try and solve that problem.

47
00:02:44.390 --> 00:02:48.130
Define has a big commitment to making
sure that we're actually working on

48
00:02:48.130 --> 00:02:49.570
the right thing.

49
00:02:49.570 --> 00:02:53.900
Then we go to Measure and we get a clear
as-is picture of where we are today.

50
00:02:53.900 --> 00:02:55.450
Then we go to Analyze.

51
00:02:55.450 --> 00:03:00.110
It's at the end of Analyze, after we've
Defined, and Measured, and Analyzed,

52
00:03:00.110 --> 00:03:03.140
that we come up with our
brainstorm list of solutions.

53
00:03:03.140 --> 00:03:07.900
In typical problem solving, we throw out
that problem, we have a list of solutions,

54
00:03:07.900 --> 00:03:09.550
and then we pick one, right?

55
00:03:09.550 --> 00:03:13.830
But in the DMAIC Model, we Define,
we Measure, we Analyze, and

56
00:03:13.830 --> 00:03:19.100
what that buys us, is that our list of
solutions is pretty well thought-out.

57
00:03:19.100 --> 00:03:23.190
And then we move into Improve,
where the project actually happens.

58
00:03:23.190 --> 00:03:27.570
And even though I just told you, you wanna
spend as much time as you can in Define,

59
00:03:27.570 --> 00:03:32.770
kinda keep in mind that it's Improve where
the actual project is being tested and

60
00:03:32.770 --> 00:03:33.270
rolled out.

61
00:03:33.270 --> 00:03:37.090
So you wanna make sure that you allow
yourself enough time to actually do that.

62
00:03:37.090 --> 00:03:37.880
>> Actually do that.

63
00:03:37.880 --> 00:03:38.730
>> Absolutely.

64
00:03:38.730 --> 00:03:43.150
And then Control is just
mostly how to sustain.

65
00:03:43.150 --> 00:03:47.645
Why that's such a big deal,
is that when you compare the DMAIC against

66
00:03:47.645 --> 00:03:52.080
typical problem solving,
even though we say we evaluate an update.

67
00:03:52.080 --> 00:03:54.259
Sometimes we don't even update but

68
00:03:54.259 --> 00:03:57.451
we rarely look at how to
keep that process into play,

69
00:03:57.451 --> 00:04:03.600
that sustainability is sometimes left out
all together on typical problem solving.

70
00:04:03.600 --> 00:04:08.173
We also said that the DMAIC Model
in Lean Six Sigma is circular, and

71
00:04:08.173 --> 00:04:13.165
what we mean by that is you're
the project manager from cradle to grave.

72
00:04:13.165 --> 00:04:18.263
And so if you go to one phase, to another
phase, and you figure out, you know what?

73
00:04:18.263 --> 00:04:21.009
I need to go back and
check something in Measure or Define,

74
00:04:21.009 --> 00:04:23.690
the whole world isn't
gonna fall apart on you.

75
00:04:23.690 --> 00:04:25.040
However that's not the goal.

76
00:04:25.040 --> 00:04:27.720
The goal is to finish each phase and
go to the next phase,

77
00:04:27.720 --> 00:04:32.180
it's just you're not really hurting the
process, if you have to take a step back.

78
00:04:32.180 --> 00:04:35.660
Whereas, if you're looking at
the DMAIC in a waterfall method,

79
00:04:35.660 --> 00:04:37.590
which is what Six Sigma uses,

80
00:04:37.590 --> 00:04:41.880
it might, these phases might be handled
by totally different departments.

81
00:04:41.880 --> 00:04:45.508
And so that's why it's really
important to wrap it up.

82
00:04:45.508 --> 00:04:48.920
But in the Lean Six Sigma,
you're responsible for

83
00:04:48.920 --> 00:04:50.400
the project through all the phases.

84
00:04:50.400 --> 00:04:53.040
And that's why you can kind of
take a step back, if you need to.

85
00:04:55.160 --> 00:05:00.090
Now, it's a good idea to have
the DMAIC Model handy if you're working

86
00:05:00.090 --> 00:05:01.857
on a number of projects.

87
00:05:01.857 --> 00:05:05.070
And it can be something really simple,
or it can be something like this,

88
00:05:05.070 --> 00:05:06.346
that's very complicated.

89
00:05:06.346 --> 00:05:09.920
So I'm going to get back to
the simple model first, maybe.

90
00:05:12.010 --> 00:05:15.520
Okay, so the simple model,
that's just if you can remember

91
00:05:15.520 --> 00:05:18.910
all the different phases and stuff,
it's just handy to have that around.

92
00:05:18.910 --> 00:05:23.030
And the reason is because
the social dynamics in the model

93
00:05:23.030 --> 00:05:24.450
start becoming different.

94
00:05:24.450 --> 00:05:27.330
In Define, you're behind closed doors,
you're working on the problem,

95
00:05:27.330 --> 00:05:29.310
no one really knows what you're doing.

96
00:05:29.310 --> 00:05:32.710
When you move into Measure, a lot of
times you're out on the shop floor or

97
00:05:32.710 --> 00:05:35.120
you're in the office, or
you're in the grocery store, or

98
00:05:35.120 --> 00:05:37.770
you're at the hospital, and
you're collecting information.

99
00:05:37.770 --> 00:05:42.120
And you're asking people to give
you information that they may

100
00:05:42.120 --> 00:05:44.820
either not have or
might not feel comfortable giving you.

101
00:05:44.820 --> 00:05:49.220
And so sometimes, even though you
have people excited in Define,

102
00:05:49.220 --> 00:05:51.910
they're a little bit more
suspicious in Measure.

103
00:05:51.910 --> 00:05:54.300
Now Analyze,
you go back behind closed doors and

104
00:05:54.300 --> 00:05:57.780
the worse anyone is gonna say is,
what are they doing back there, right?

105
00:05:57.780 --> 00:06:00.300
Well in Improve,
when you're rolling out the project,

106
00:06:00.300 --> 00:06:04.750
there is a psychological dynamic
where we can plan, plan, plan.

107
00:06:04.750 --> 00:06:08.910
But when it gets ready to execute,
sometimes everybody kinda freezes up.

108
00:06:08.910 --> 00:06:13.180
So knowing what phase of the model
you're in, I think is really valuable.

109
00:06:13.180 --> 00:06:16.020
So especially if you've got
multiple projects going, and

110
00:06:16.020 --> 00:06:20.070
if you can remember what the different
phases are, something simple like this,

111
00:06:20.070 --> 00:06:24.750
just on a three by five card close to
your computer, could be very helpful.

112
00:06:24.750 --> 00:06:29.630
Now in this more complicated,
complex model, where this comes in handy,

113
00:06:29.630 --> 00:06:33.650
and I think it's very helpful,
as I mentioned in some other sessions,

114
00:06:33.650 --> 00:06:37.670
that the trend right now
is to take Lean Six Sigma.

115
00:06:37.670 --> 00:06:42.620
And to test for Lean Six Sigma, SSD Global
Solutions has a test that you can take on

116
00:06:42.620 --> 00:06:45.650
our website, for a fee, obviously.

117
00:06:45.650 --> 00:06:53.040
Other vendors have Lean Six Sigma as well,
right?

118
00:06:53.040 --> 00:06:57.160
However there's a lot of people that
are just Six Sigma or just Lean.

119
00:06:57.160 --> 00:07:01.557
Now those environments are still trying
to recruit Lean Six Sigma people, but

120
00:07:01.557 --> 00:07:05.761
you could be Lean Six Sigma certified and
end up in a Six Sigma environment.

121
00:07:05.761 --> 00:07:09.056
And they wanted you there to
bring that other expertise.

122
00:07:09.056 --> 00:07:15.000
You could be in a Lean environment,
and be a primarily Lean environment.

123
00:07:15.000 --> 00:07:18.417
So what this shows you is
the DMAIC Model and it says hey,

124
00:07:18.417 --> 00:07:21.919

00:21:18.440 --> 00:21:22.450
Now, another place that you can start,

00:21:22.450 --> 00:21:27.700
And in this case, you may or may not have

00:22:55.840 --> 00:22:57.410

00:23:02.320 --> 00:23:06.850

00:23:06.850 --> 00:23:10.270

00:23:10.270 --> 00:23:13.610
That goes back to process capability,

415
00:23:13.610 --> 00:23:16.640
So, when I'm in define, and
all these topics we've talked about in

416
00:23:16.640 --> 00:23:19.910

00:23:21.550 --> 00:23:23.750
Can I achieve what the customer wants?

418
00:23:23.750 --> 00:23:26.700
Is my process even capable of doing that?

00:23:26.700 --> 00:23:29.630
And these are things I wanna think
about when I'm in the defined phase.

420
00:23:32.470 --> 00:23:34.170
I wanna acknowledge the right people,

421
00:23:34.170 --> 00:23:36.710
I wanna make sure the right
people are working with me.

422
00:23:36.710 --> 00:23:40.560
There's the Jim Collins,

423
00:23:40.560 --> 00:23:44.250
The reality, as a Lean Six Sigma
practitioner, is a lot of times,

00:23:44.250 --> 00:23:47.300

425
00:23:47.300 --> 00:23:50.934
And I don't have anyone working with me,
but if you can,

00:23:50.934 --> 00:23:55.654
you want that collective intelligence,
because that gives you better.

00:23:55.654 --> 00:23:59.006

if you are brought in as a third-party,

00:23:59.006 --> 00:24:02.179
you don't wanna step on any toes,
you want them to be open.

429
00:24:02.179 --> 00:24:04.779
And be working with you not against you,
right?

430
00:24:04.779 --> 00:24:06.439
>> Absolutely.

431
00:24:06.439 --> 00:24:10.346
And one of the things that I might want

We address the stakeholder's

As a reminder it's the main people

The thing is that project management
has a little bit different

435
00:24:24.020 --> 00:24:27.800

00:24:29.750 --> 00:24:30.823
But obviously,

00:24:30.823 --> 00:24:35.661
at the beginning, we need to know who

439
00:24:38.876 --> 00:24:42.778
And the way we're going to figure out all
of that kind of stuff is we're going to

440
00:24:42.778 --> 00:24:46.743

441
00:24:46.743 --> 00:24:50.490
such as Process Map, Value Stream Map,

442
00:24:50.490 --> 00:24:55.270
Now, I do want to point out that earlier
I said, in Define, it's very creative.

443
00:24:55.270 --> 00:24:57.390
I mean, I get to figure out
what I want to work on and

444
00:24:57.390 --> 00:25:00.070
I get to figure out what
tools I want to work on.

445
00:25:00.070 --> 00:25:01.670
There's only a couple of rules.

446
00:25:01.670 --> 00:25:05.750
One rule is that I start with a process
map, a high level process map.

447
00:25:05.750 --> 00:25:09.180
And remember,
if we were thinking in terms of a WBS,

00:25:09.180 --> 00:25:13.420
we would say things like step one,
step two, step three, step four.

449
00:25:13.420 --> 00:25:18.690
So I have to have a process map and I have
to end Define with a project charter.

450
00:25:18.690 --> 00:25:21.110
Wherever I developed it,
I just can't leave.

451
00:25:21.110 --> 00:25:23.140
So there's two rules in Define.

452
00:25:23.140 --> 00:25:28.140
The process map rule, which we could
also look at a value stream map or

453
00:25:28.140 --> 00:25:29.240
a swim lane chart.

454
00:25:29.240 --> 00:25:33.130
The idea is that,
which I think makes a lot of sense but

455
00:25:33.130 --> 00:25:38.120
people skip this, I have to have a high
level idea of what's going on now.

00:25:38.120 --> 00:25:38.650
>> Sure.

00:25:38.650 --> 00:25:40.430
>> If I want to determine what
the problem is [INAUDIBLE].

458
00:25:40.430 --> 00:25:40.930
>> A picture, yeah.
You

459
00:25:40.930 --> 00:25:43.890
have to have a picture of
what's happening or a baseline.

460
00:25:43.890 --> 00:25:47.300
Otherwise, you're not even gonna be
able to measure if anything has changed

461
00:25:47.300 --> 00:25:48.290
at the end of your project.

462
00:25:48.290 --> 00:25:49.230
>> Exactly.

463
00:25:49.230 --> 00:25:52.140
And perception is such a crazy thing.

464
00:25:52.140 --> 00:25:54.195
We perceive that we know what's going on.

465
00:25:54.195 --> 00:25:55.900
>> [LAUGH]
>> Without the tool.

466
00:25:55.900 --> 00:25:57.880
We're always just amazed.

467
00:25:57.880 --> 00:26:01.230
And I mentioned in other sessions that
there are people that just go in and

00:26:01.230 --> 00:26:05.050
do process mapping and sometimes
the CEO of that company is like really,

469
00:26:05.050 --> 00:26:07.900
they had no idea, right?

00:26:07.900 --> 00:26:12.340
>> I was pretty, I was just, I was
astonished actually whenever I found that

471
00:26:12.340 --> 00:26:17.040

00:26:17.040 --> 00:26:21.320

ways that they're doing the same thing.

473
00:26:21.320 --> 00:26:24.210
But they should be following it's
just a little crazy when you think

474
00:26:24.210 --> 00:26:25.120
of it like that.

475
00:26:25.120 --> 00:26:26.710
>> Exactly.

476
00:26:26.710 --> 00:26:29.830
And then another thing
remember we were saying that

00:26:29.830 --> 00:26:32.570
the number one reason why
people don't buy into our

00:26:32.570 --> 00:26:36.090

00:26:36.090 --> 00:26:41.750
So some tools that will help us

00:26:41.750 --> 00:26:46.340
So if you'll remember that,
well and voice of the employee.

00:26:46.340 --> 00:26:47.670
And voice of the employee's huge.

00:26:47.670 --> 00:26:52.550
I mean, there's some major companies that

483
00:26:52.550 --> 00:26:56.880
Marriott, that say that they base

484
00:26:56.880 --> 00:26:57.780

485
00:26:57.780 --> 00:27:01.330
>> Yeah, I think that's cool and
they make that statement quite frequently.

486
00:27:02.700 --> 00:27:05.440
Another thing that I
wanna make sure that I do

487
00:27:05.440 --> 00:27:10.170
is that I align my goals with
the business objectives.

488
00:27:10.170 --> 00:27:15.110
And the reason why I wanna do that is
because if there's a change in leadership,

489
00:27:15.110 --> 00:27:17.060
I'm gonna have to defend my project.

490
00:27:17.060 --> 00:27:20.820
And seriously, it doesn't have
to be a dot to dot connection to

491
00:27:20.820 --> 00:27:25.170
the business objectives in your department
or into the company as a whole.

492
00:27:25.170 --> 00:27:27.658
It can connect to something
that connects to something.

493
00:27:27.658 --> 00:27:31.130
But if you're working on something and
it's not in some way

494
00:27:31.130 --> 00:27:35.190
meeting those business objectives,
you're kind of dead in the water anyway.

495
00:27:35.190 --> 00:27:40.440
So and if someone gives you something,
and you might wanna say this

496
00:27:40.440 --> 00:27:44.560
in an eloquent way because supervisors
sometimes don't wanna be challenged.

497
00:27:44.560 --> 00:27:45.870
But if you're working on something and

498
00:27:45.870 --> 00:27:50.090
you honestly don't see the connection
to the major business objectives,

499
00:27:50.090 --> 00:27:52.510
that's a fair conversation to have,
I think, Cherokee.

500
00:27:54.200 --> 00:27:58.513
>> Definitely, you always make to sure
that you have your morals in line with

501
00:27:58.513 --> 00:28:02.340
everything that the company,
well their mission statement, or

502
00:28:02.340 --> 00:28:03.745
their company values.

503
00:28:03.745 --> 00:28:08.140
>> Yeah, and now we're gonna come back,
I know I've said this a bunch,

504
00:28:08.140 --> 00:28:10.972
but in accelerated
learning we do this a lot,

505
00:28:10.972 --> 00:28:15.891
where we repeat facts that are really
important especially ones that will show

506
00:28:15.891 --> 00:28:20.230
up on your exam in the Lean Six Sigma
certification process.

507
00:28:20.230 --> 00:28:22.180
There are 2 rules in DEFINE.

508
00:28:22.180 --> 00:28:24.764
I have to have a Process Map and
they have to have a Project Charter.

509
00:28:26.901 --> 00:28:30.480
Now all these other tools that
we talk about, for example,

510
00:28:30.480 --> 00:28:33.274
the voices and
the SIPOC which we addressed and

511
00:28:33.274 --> 00:28:37.480
the tinwoods and all of those other tools,
those are optional.

512
00:28:37.480 --> 00:28:40.730
Those are tools that are supposed to
get you from what's happening now,

513
00:28:40.730 --> 00:28:44.810
what's the process map to the project
charter, what do I want to work on, right?

514
00:28:44.810 --> 00:28:47.190
Those are all kind of ancillary tools.

515
00:28:47.190 --> 00:28:51.830
Now in the project charter and in this
case think of when I'm leaving Define.

516
00:28:51.830 --> 00:28:54.200
Because I'm leaving Define
with my project charter.

517
00:28:54.200 --> 00:28:58.190
But the main thing when I'm leaving
Define is I want to make sure

518
00:28:58.190 --> 00:29:00.060
I have my problem statement.

519
00:29:00.060 --> 00:29:02.260
Okay and
that's how we say it mostly in IT.

520
00:29:02.260 --> 00:29:03.860
What's my problem statement?

521
00:29:03.860 --> 00:29:06.080
In Lean Six Sigma, what is it?

522
00:29:06.080 --> 00:29:09.810
What activities specifically am I
trying to make better, faster or

523
00:29:09.810 --> 00:29:10.740
more cost effective?

524
00:29:10.740 --> 00:29:13.810
In some cases all three, some cases two.

525
00:29:13.810 --> 00:29:17.540
Remember we talked about how it all
boils down to money in the end but

526
00:29:17.540 --> 00:29:18.470
what is your objective?

527
00:29:18.470 --> 00:29:21.010
What is your first objective?

528
00:29:21.010 --> 00:29:24.710
And so this is called the Y
statement in Lean Six Sigma.

529
00:29:24.710 --> 00:29:29.030
So my Y statement,
because Y is the major output.

530
00:29:29.030 --> 00:29:32.900
I don't want to leave Define without
a clearly defined Y statement.

531
00:29:32.900 --> 00:29:36.170
Now that should be on my project charter,
but even if it's not

532
00:29:37.190 --> 00:29:41.280
clearly articulated or it took me
a long time to explain my Y statement,

533
00:29:41.280 --> 00:29:45.150
I really need just a simple statement so
that people stop me in the hall and

534
00:29:45.150 --> 00:29:46.180
they say, what are you working on?

535
00:29:46.180 --> 00:29:49.740
I can say I'm working on
making enrollment faster.

536
00:29:49.740 --> 00:29:53.850
I'm working on getting
hotel rooms cleaned faster.

537
00:29:53.850 --> 00:29:58.210
I'm working on answering the phone
in a more efficient way, right?

538
00:29:58.210 --> 00:30:01.237
I want to be ready to answer
those kinds of questions.

539
00:30:01.237 --> 00:30:06.420
So the xs that you see in
this Y=f(x) statement,

540
00:30:06.420 --> 00:30:08.310
I think I mentioned it in another session.

541
00:30:08.310 --> 00:30:10.130
It looks like math, but it's not.

542
00:30:10.130 --> 00:30:13.840
So my Y statement is,
what is it I'm trying to do?

543
00:30:13.840 --> 00:30:17.410
What am I trying to make better,
faster, more cost effective?

544
00:30:17.410 --> 00:30:18.991
The xs are the inputs and

545
00:30:18.991 --> 00:30:24.230
you'll notice that it's a small x because
very rarely is it gonna be one big X.

546
00:30:24.230 --> 00:30:27.940
If I do this one thing,
I'm gonna have a positive outcome.

547
00:30:27.940 --> 00:30:30.170
Now it can happen and,
hey that's awesome, right.

548
00:30:30.170 --> 00:30:32.310
If all I have to do is
change this one thing and

549
00:30:32.310 --> 00:30:35.250
have a positive outcome that's Lean.

550
00:30:35.250 --> 00:30:38.300
And there's a lot of things in our
personal life and in our business

551
00:30:38.300 --> 00:30:43.770
departments that, yeah, if we change
this one thing, it's one big X, right?

552
00:30:43.770 --> 00:30:45.210
So kind of keep that in mind.

553
00:30:45.210 --> 00:30:48.545
But usually it's gonna be several inputs,
right?

554
00:30:48.545 --> 00:30:49.150
>> Okay.

555
00:30:49.150 --> 00:30:52.630
>> And the example that we used in
the other session is if I wanted to make

556
00:30:52.630 --> 00:30:57.300
the perfect birthday cake some of the x's
I would need would be what, Cherokee?

557
00:30:57.300 --> 00:31:04.890
>> The x's for my input would be the eggs,
the flour, the sugar, oil, milk.

558
00:31:04.890 --> 00:31:05.770
I don't know [LAUGH].

559
00:31:05.770 --> 00:31:08.080
>> Exactly, all those kinds of things.

560
00:31:08.080 --> 00:31:09.790
And then we have to consider, and

561
00:31:09.790 --> 00:31:13.410
this is where the f comes in,
How did those function?

562
00:31:13.410 --> 00:31:16.455
Now what I think, so
do the eggs have to be fresh?

563
00:31:16.455 --> 00:31:18.550
>> Right.
>> Do they have to be a certain size?

564
00:31:18.550 --> 00:31:20.990
So, that was kind of the gist of it,
right?

565
00:31:20.990 --> 00:31:24.560
But what I think is kinda cool in Define,
is let's say,

566
00:31:24.560 --> 00:31:26.030
because this happens all the time.

567
00:31:26.030 --> 00:31:29.730
We take the stance that we got
to develop the project and

568
00:31:29.730 --> 00:31:31.140
we get to do all these stuff.

569
00:31:31.140 --> 00:31:34.240
A lot of times people just hand us
something to take care of, right?

570
00:31:34.240 --> 00:31:36.560
Our boss just says,
I want you to fix this.

571
00:31:36.560 --> 00:31:37.160
>> Yeah.

572
00:31:37.160 --> 00:31:37.990
>> And so-
>> Delegation.

573
00:31:37.990 --> 00:31:38.960
>> Exactly.

574
00:31:38.960 --> 00:31:40.900
And so I didn't get a choice in it,
at all.

575
00:31:40.900 --> 00:31:44.520
I didn't get to look at voice of
the customer, or SIPOC, or Tim Woods.

576
00:31:44.520 --> 00:31:47.170
My boss just said,
this is what I want you to fix.

577
00:31:47.170 --> 00:31:51.260
So essentially what I'm doing is
I'm starting in the second phase

578
00:31:51.260 --> 00:31:51.960
of the domain.

579
00:31:51.960 --> 00:31:54.530
I have to start measure because
they already said the y statement.

580
00:31:54.530 --> 00:31:57.790
Whether it's a good y statement or
not, this is what my boss-

581
00:31:57.790 --> 00:31:58.602
>> Your job is.

582
00:31:58.602 --> 00:31:59.496
>> Exactly.

583
00:31:59.496 --> 00:32:04.986
And so, one of the things that you
can do in Define is to step back and

584
00:32:04.986 --> 00:32:10.340
say Do I have the xs,
do I have the capability to achieve y?

585
00:32:10.340 --> 00:32:15.550
So in this case, if I were trying to
make the perfect birthday cake, and

586
00:32:15.550 --> 00:32:20.250
I have no oven, right, I could have all
the eggs and sugar and milk that I wanted.

587
00:32:20.250 --> 00:32:20.760
>> Right.
[LAUGH]

588
00:32:20.760 --> 00:32:22.690
>> But I don't have an oven, right.

589
00:32:22.690 --> 00:32:26.720
And so this is where I want to
start going back to my employer.

590
00:32:26.720 --> 00:32:31.440
And I wanna say to them, you know, this is
what you want me to do, and I made a list.

591
00:32:31.440 --> 00:32:34.590
And I would suggest write it down or
type it out.

592
00:32:34.590 --> 00:32:38.335
I made a list of all the things
we need to accomplish y, and

593
00:32:38.335 --> 00:32:41.095
the ones I have checked
are ones we don't have.

594
00:32:41.095 --> 00:32:43.495
>> Okay.
>> And so, what would you like me to do?

595
00:32:43.495 --> 00:32:46.605
So I'm putting the onus back on
the person who's asked me to

596
00:32:46.605 --> 00:32:48.595
this rather ridiculous thing.

597
00:32:48.595 --> 00:32:50.135
So sometimes what's happened,

598
00:32:50.135 --> 00:32:54.050
and I'm sure everyone's been in this
situation, their boss asked them.

599
00:32:54.050 --> 00:32:55.690
They didn't know, so
they're gonna ask you.

600
00:32:55.690 --> 00:32:57.310
They're gonna put it on you, right?

601
00:32:57.310 --> 00:33:00.200
>> Yeah.
>> So you're giving them some logic to go

602
00:33:00.200 --> 00:33:02.810
up the hierarchy too.

603
00:33:02.810 --> 00:33:06.250
So you go back and you say, these are some
of the things that we don't have.

604
00:33:06.250 --> 00:33:09.720
In fact, what you're saying is my
process isn't really capable right now,

605
00:33:09.720 --> 00:33:11.780
because I don't have these core xs.

606
00:33:11.780 --> 00:33:16.850
Now, I always think it's a good idea in
define, someone ask you to do something,

607
00:33:16.850 --> 00:33:21.080
you go ahead and you look at the xs, you
realize you don't have the score things.

608
00:33:21.080 --> 00:33:24.590
I think it's always good to be
able to offer some suggestions.

609
00:33:24.590 --> 00:33:30.170
So, if a core x doesn't exist, keep in
mind, you can still buy that x, right?

610
00:33:30.170 --> 00:33:32.060
You can go out and buy it.

611
00:33:32.060 --> 00:33:33.540
Or outsource it.

612
00:33:33.540 --> 00:33:38.980
You can develop it internally by training,
right, or you can do a work around.

613
00:33:38.980 --> 00:33:40.740
Maybe they have an idea.

614
00:33:40.740 --> 00:33:42.500
Hey, I don't have an oven.

615
00:33:43.660 --> 00:33:45.600
What are gonna do here, right.

616
00:33:45.600 --> 00:33:48.240
So it's not like you're saying no.

617
00:33:48.240 --> 00:33:52.850
You're saying that this present time we
just don't have this core capabilities.

618
00:33:52.850 --> 00:33:56.840
Now what's beautiful about getting
that y statement and let's say and

619
00:33:56.840 --> 00:34:01.090
define you have determined that
you have the appropriate access

620
00:34:02.230 --> 00:34:03.800
to facilitate the problem.

621
00:34:03.800 --> 00:34:05.030
You still don't know how to do, but

622
00:34:05.030 --> 00:34:08.180
at least you got the core things
that you think you need, right?

623
00:34:08.180 --> 00:34:09.200
>> Yes.

624
00:34:09.200 --> 00:34:13.420
>> Then I have to look at how
do this core things function So

625
00:34:13.420 --> 00:34:17.970
let's say, and this might be something
that I save until measure, right?

626
00:34:17.970 --> 00:34:20.330
So I'll bring it back up when
we're talking about measure but

627
00:34:20.330 --> 00:34:22.300
I might save this part for then.

628
00:34:22.300 --> 00:34:29.920
Because as long as I have the basic
stuff to create the positive outcome.

629
00:34:29.920 --> 00:34:32.010
I probably would be willing
to move forward, right?

630
00:34:32.010 --> 00:34:33.940
I might not know until I got to measure.

631
00:34:33.940 --> 00:34:38.740
But the idea of the f is that now I
need to know how those things function.

632
00:34:38.740 --> 00:34:41.890
So, remember if the eggs are fresh or
not, so

633
00:34:41.890 --> 00:34:44.630
I have to kind of think
about that functionality.

634
00:34:44.630 --> 00:34:46.520
So let's just do another.

635
00:34:46.520 --> 00:34:51.230
And if I'm picking something
such as temperature,

636
00:34:51.230 --> 00:34:54.300
the temperature may have some variation.

637
00:34:54.300 --> 00:34:57.890
So I could look at that variation,
as well, as part of my capability study or

638
00:34:57.890 --> 00:35:00.470
part of my measure statement, right?

639
00:35:00.470 --> 00:35:03.530
So, let's just quickly do another example.

640
00:35:03.530 --> 00:35:06.180
>> I'm gonna go ahead and
ask if we pause right there, so

641
00:35:06.180 --> 00:35:08.730
that we can spend a little more time.

642
00:35:08.730 --> 00:35:11.220
Because define is such
an important phase that I

643
00:35:11.220 --> 00:35:15.270
really wanna make sure we spend
enough time covering all the details.

644
00:35:15.270 --> 00:35:18.570
So, in this episode, we were able
to really look at our two rules,

645
00:35:18.570 --> 00:35:20.480
our two components that we need there.

646
00:35:20.480 --> 00:35:24.660
We need to have our process map and
we need to have our process charter.

647
00:35:24.660 --> 00:35:26.820
But don't go anywhere because we are,

648
00:35:26.820 --> 00:35:29.530
we're gonna spend a little
more time in define phase.

649
00:35:29.530 --> 00:35:31.960
I think it's really important so
don't go anywhere.

650
00:35:31.960 --> 00:35:34.290
But we're gonna go ahead and
wrap up for this particular episode.

651
00:35:34.290 --> 00:35:38.660
So I'm gonna sign off as your host,
Cherokee Boose.

652
00:35:38.660 --> 00:35:42.200
And this is Dr Terra Vanzant Stern
with SSD Global Solutions.

653
00:35:42.200 --> 00:35:45.761
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

654
00:35:45.761 --> 00:35:51.480
[MUSIC]

655
00:35:51.480 --> 00:35:54.713
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode Dr. Terra Vanzant Stern and Cherokee Boose spend extra time discussing the define phase to make sure you deeply understand this phase. In addition to using tools you have learned in previous shows you will also learn new tools such as House of Quality, QFD, and Kano Analysis.
episodes.title: DMAIC Model - Define Phase Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:01.301
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.301 --> 00:00:02.969
I'm your host Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.969 --> 00:00:06.305
Coming to you live from San Francisco.

4
00:00:06.305 --> 00:00:08.275
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.275 --> 00:00:12.320
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:12.320 --> 00:00:17.170
>> Welcome to your Lean Six Sigma: Green
Belt Certification Preparation series.

7
00:00:17.170 --> 00:00:19.700
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

8
00:00:19.700 --> 00:00:23.470
If you've been following along, we've
already taken a look at the Define phase;

9
00:00:23.470 --> 00:00:28.010
however, we wanted to spend a little
extra time in this very important phase.

10
00:00:28.010 --> 00:00:29.840
So we'll go ahead and start that now.

11
00:00:29.840 --> 00:00:32.520
In the studios, we have Dr.
Terra Vanzant Stern.

12
00:00:32.520 --> 00:00:34.920
Thank you for joining us today, Dr.
>> Thank you.

13
00:00:34.920 --> 00:00:36.440
Thank you for having me.

14
00:00:36.440 --> 00:00:38.300
>> So let's go ahead and get started and

15
00:00:38.300 --> 00:00:43.290
look at the defined details
>> Okay,

16
00:00:43.290 --> 00:00:45.550
if we could just go to
my deck very quickly.

17
00:00:45.550 --> 00:00:50.110
When we left off in our
last session we were

18
00:00:50.110 --> 00:00:53.670
talking about the Y = f(x) relationship.

19
00:00:53.670 --> 00:00:57.190
And what we said is Y is
like the problem statement.

20
00:00:57.190 --> 00:00:59.660
So in IT we say the problem statement.

21
00:00:59.660 --> 00:01:03.440
And remember, a problem statement
doesn't necessarily mean it's a problem.

22
00:01:03.440 --> 00:01:06.240
The problem statement means this
is what we're gonna work on.

23
00:01:06.240 --> 00:01:08.990
In Lean Six Sigma, that's the activity and

24
00:01:08.990 --> 00:01:12.880
what we're gonna do if we wanna make it
better, faster, and more cost effective.

25
00:01:12.880 --> 00:01:15.830
So I've got some examples
on the other screen.

26
00:01:15.830 --> 00:01:18.040
I want to make enrollment faster.

27
00:01:18.040 --> 00:01:20.520
I want to clean my house more efficiently.

28
00:01:20.520 --> 00:01:21.190
>> Don't we all?

29
00:01:21.190 --> 00:01:21.935
>> Yeah, really.

30
00:01:21.935 --> 00:01:24.370
>> [LAUGH]
>> I want to make my expenses more cost

31
00:01:24.370 --> 00:01:25.430
effective.

32
00:01:25.430 --> 00:01:27.450
I want to make the birthday party better.

33
00:01:27.450 --> 00:01:29.070
Right?
So those are some examples.

34
00:01:29.070 --> 00:01:34.900
So I'm going to go back to
our Y=f(x) relationship.

35
00:01:34.900 --> 00:01:38.920
One of the things that we said
in the last session is that

36
00:01:38.920 --> 00:01:43.710
it's possible I'm in Define,
but my employer, or my boss, or

37
00:01:43.710 --> 00:01:48.670
my client, gives me what they want to
make better, faster, more cost effective.

38
00:01:48.670 --> 00:01:51.570
So they've already determined the why,
right.

39
00:01:51.570 --> 00:01:54.700
Now if I get to be part of Define,
I get to come up with why,

40
00:01:54.700 --> 00:01:58.230
by using all those great tools that
we talked about in the last session.

41
00:01:58.230 --> 00:02:00.950
But let's say I don't,
they just hand it to me.

42
00:02:00.950 --> 00:02:05.710
One of the ways this formula can be
effective is I can take a step back and

43
00:02:05.710 --> 00:02:12.140
I can say, do I have all the inputs
necessary to accomplish the Y statement?

44
00:02:12.140 --> 00:02:16.440
And the x's represent anything that
I have to do to make that happen.

45
00:02:16.440 --> 00:02:21.400
So if I find out that I don't have all the
core x's, I'm not saying no to my boss.

46
00:02:21.400 --> 00:02:23.790
I'm not going back and saying,
hey, we can't accomplish this.

47
00:02:23.790 --> 00:02:27.310
I'm saying these are some
of the things that we lack,

48
00:02:27.310 --> 00:02:30.420
this is some of the process
capability that we don't have.

49
00:02:30.420 --> 00:02:32.620
Now we're not exactly,

50
00:02:32.620 --> 00:02:36.100
when we're doing this we're not
exactly saying it can't happen.

51
00:02:36.100 --> 00:02:38.860
Because we could buy the expertise,
we could outsource it,

52
00:02:38.860 --> 00:02:40.740
we could train it internally.

53
00:02:40.740 --> 00:02:43.550
So we're not saying, no forever.

54
00:02:43.550 --> 00:02:45.660
I'm just saying no for right now.

55
00:02:45.660 --> 00:02:48.570
And what we were talking about
when we ended the last session

56
00:02:48.570 --> 00:02:52.390
is that it's also how these x's function.

57
00:02:52.390 --> 00:02:54.960
Now the Y equals x.

58
00:02:54.960 --> 00:02:57.110
We were gonna work it within Define.

59
00:02:57.110 --> 00:03:01.725
Some of the stuff that we could
work within Define, y = f(x),

60
00:03:01.725 --> 00:03:03.320
we could also use in measure.

61
00:03:03.320 --> 00:03:05.500
We might not even look at
it till we get to measure.

62
00:03:05.500 --> 00:03:10.190
But if we're looking at it now in Define,
and we're seeing it's not

63
00:03:10.190 --> 00:03:15.450
always just having the x's available,
it's how those x's function.

64
00:03:15.450 --> 00:03:18.630
And in our first example we said that we
are trying to make the perfect birthday

65
00:03:18.630 --> 00:03:23.600
cake and so we needed eggs and
an oven and flour and sugar and

66
00:03:23.600 --> 00:03:25.100
all these kinds of things.

67
00:03:25.100 --> 00:03:28.130
And the example we use is that
eggs had to be a certain size and

68
00:03:28.130 --> 00:03:30.070
they had to be fresh, okay.

69
00:03:30.070 --> 00:03:32.980
So we're just gonna do one more
example before we move on so

70
00:03:32.980 --> 00:03:36.790
that we kind of tie this to
the other things in Define.

71
00:03:36.790 --> 00:03:41.855
So let's say our problems statement on the
fire department and my problem statement.

72
00:03:41.855 --> 00:03:46.205
My why is that I want to put
the house fire out faster?

73
00:03:46.205 --> 00:03:48.025
Now that sounds pretty reasonable right?

74
00:03:48.025 --> 00:03:50.185
I wanna put out house fires faster.

75
00:03:50.185 --> 00:03:50.790
>> Yeah.
[LAUGH]

76
00:03:50.790 --> 00:03:51.966
>> I live in the mountains and

77
00:03:51.966 --> 00:03:54.540
we're always worried about fires and
things like that.

78
00:03:54.540 --> 00:04:00.740
So on fire department my major thing
I want to put out fires faster.

79
00:04:00.740 --> 00:04:03.890
So what are some of the core
x's I'd have to have?

80
00:04:03.890 --> 00:04:08.100
>> So your inputs here would need to
be well, personnel, the firemen or

81
00:04:08.100 --> 00:04:09.890
women who are working for you.

82
00:04:09.890 --> 00:04:14.740
You would need a vehicle to get to
the location of that fire some way.

83
00:04:14.740 --> 00:04:16.900
You would need equipment.

84
00:04:16.900 --> 00:04:19.110
Hoses, buckets, do they use buckets?

85
00:04:19.110 --> 00:04:22.060
To carry the water to put the fire out.

86
00:04:22.060 --> 00:04:23.270
>> And you need the water.

87
00:04:23.270 --> 00:04:23.890
>> Yeah.
And

88
00:04:23.890 --> 00:04:25.570
I don't think the dog is
really a requirement,

89
00:04:25.570 --> 00:04:26.770
that's just something fun to have.

90
00:04:26.770 --> 00:04:27.950
A little dalmatian.

91
00:04:27.950 --> 00:04:28.660
>> Exactly.

92
00:04:28.660 --> 00:04:29.980
So on my value stream map.

93
00:04:29.980 --> 00:04:31.470
Remember on my value stream map,

94
00:04:31.470 --> 00:04:35.790
I'm gonna record everything that's
necessary to put the fire out.

95
00:04:35.790 --> 00:04:39.090
Nice to have a dog but on my process map.

96
00:04:39.090 --> 00:04:39.870
>> Leave it out.

97
00:04:39.870 --> 00:04:42.345
>> Yeah.
In the process map I might have a step,

98
00:04:42.345 --> 00:04:44.150
put the dog on the fire truck.

99
00:04:44.150 --> 00:04:46.220
In my value stream map
that's not gonna be there.

100
00:04:46.220 --> 00:04:46.910
>> Okay.

101
00:04:46.910 --> 00:04:49.160
>> So that's a really good
point that you brought up.

102
00:04:49.160 --> 00:04:52.820
So now I'm looking at, I'm gonna
pick something easy such as water.

103
00:04:52.820 --> 00:04:55.070
To put out the fire I need water, right?

104
00:04:55.070 --> 00:04:58.350
So now I need to know,
how does that water need to function?

105
00:04:58.350 --> 00:05:00.700
Does it have to be a certain pressure?

106
00:05:00.700 --> 00:05:02.880
Does it have to be a certain temperature?

107
00:05:02.880 --> 00:05:05.390
Does it have to be a certain volume?

108
00:05:05.390 --> 00:05:07.530
Does it have to be a certain
level of cleanliness?

109
00:05:07.530 --> 00:05:08.160
Right?

110
00:05:08.160 --> 00:05:11.870
So sometimes that becomes
part of my capability study.

111
00:05:11.870 --> 00:05:17.280
Sometimes I don't use the Y = f(x)
relationship till I get to measure.

112
00:05:17.280 --> 00:05:21.170
In that case I'm using it
to help look at variation.

113
00:05:21.170 --> 00:05:25.300
In our measure phase which we'll be
covering next in our next session,

114
00:05:25.300 --> 00:05:29.140
what I'm trying to do is I'm trying
to establish a current picture,

115
00:05:29.140 --> 00:05:31.080
a snapshot if you will.

116
00:05:31.080 --> 00:05:35.990
And so I might use the Y = f(x)
formula to look at variations and

117
00:05:35.990 --> 00:05:38.210
things such as water, right?

118
00:05:38.210 --> 00:05:40.500
Because I wanna do a variation study.

119
00:05:40.500 --> 00:05:46.430
So, I might take the Y = f(x) and pull it
over in to analyze, because at that time,

120
00:05:46.430 --> 00:05:51.060
I'm trying to analyze my variation study,
and that's called the Variation Analysis.

121
00:05:51.060 --> 00:05:54.430
So, this is one of those formulas
that if you start using in Define,

122
00:05:54.430 --> 00:05:56.820
you really can carry through
all those different phases.

123
00:05:58.160 --> 00:06:01.060
And so, this is just that reminder
slide that we looked at about

124
00:06:01.060 --> 00:06:03.050
all the things we could do.

125
00:06:03.050 --> 00:06:07.820
When we're in Define we wanna
ask ourselves certain questions.

126
00:06:07.820 --> 00:06:09.440
What's the reason for the action?

127
00:06:09.440 --> 00:06:10.669
What's the target?

128
00:06:11.870 --> 00:06:13.660
What's within our control?

129
00:06:13.660 --> 00:06:18.190
Things that are within our control,
we call common cause variation.

130
00:06:18.190 --> 00:06:21.720
Things that are outside our control,
we call special cause variation.

131
00:06:21.720 --> 00:06:23.920
Now, there's lots of different
types of variation, and

132
00:06:23.920 --> 00:06:28.260
lots of different vernacular
around what we call this.

133
00:06:28.260 --> 00:06:32.670
So there's cyclical, there's seasonal.

134
00:06:32.670 --> 00:06:37.040
Some people call variation regular
variation verses non-regular, but

135
00:06:37.040 --> 00:06:41.250
in Lean Six Sigma we have a tendency
to say common verses special.

136
00:06:41.250 --> 00:06:45.400
The reason why that's important in
Define is that I have to figure

137
00:06:45.400 --> 00:06:49.130
out is that variation something
within my control or not?

138
00:06:49.130 --> 00:06:53.490
So an example would be I'm
a visitor at a company and

139
00:06:53.490 --> 00:06:57.720
I want a cup of coffee right,
but I'm not from that company.

140
00:06:57.720 --> 00:07:02.040
So If I go and
the coffee pot isn't filled I might really

141
00:07:02.040 --> 00:07:05.480
not get a cup of coffee because I
don't where the coffee is, right.

142
00:07:05.480 --> 00:07:06.070
>> Right.

143
00:07:06.070 --> 00:07:11.840
>> So another example of common variation
is just cost of doing business or

144
00:07:11.840 --> 00:07:15.260
what happens within the normal realm.

145
00:07:15.260 --> 00:07:18.530
So if I buy a new car,
at some point I'm gonna have to buy tires.

146
00:07:18.530 --> 00:07:22.530
I'm never get a new car, no matter how new
it is, no matter how great the tires are,

147
00:07:22.530 --> 00:07:24.270
where the tires last forever.

148
00:07:24.270 --> 00:07:28.450
So if you think of common cause variation,
things that are in my control.
