what I'm actually capable of doing.

372
00:19:41.520 --> 00:19:46.120
I'm looking at the relationship
like on a scale from one to five.

373
00:19:46.120 --> 00:19:47.530
How close am I?

374
00:19:47.530 --> 00:19:50.150
So let's say I bring my sandwich cart in.

375
00:19:50.150 --> 00:19:52.060
And there is a power source,

376
00:19:52.060 --> 00:19:55.120
but I'm not gonna be able to keep
my sandwich cart in that place.

377
00:19:55.120 --> 00:19:57.010
I'm gonna have to move it, right.

378
00:19:57.010 --> 00:19:59.930
So on a scale from one to five,
I have like maybe a three,

379
00:19:59.930 --> 00:20:03.440
because it's there, but I'm probably
gonna have to get permission and for

380
00:20:03.440 --> 00:20:06.580
years I've been having my sandwich
cart in a certain place, right.

381
00:20:06.580 --> 00:20:10.120
So, all I'm trying to do is say,
kind of on a scale from one to five, and

382
00:20:10.120 --> 00:20:14.210
some people use happy faces or
emoji con type things, or

383
00:20:14.210 --> 00:20:18.410
they use moons like a full moon means
I've got everything, a half moon.

384
00:20:18.410 --> 00:20:21.410
So people get very clever with these
Houses Of Quality because they

385
00:20:21.410 --> 00:20:25.550
are graphic, but
basically all I'm trying to say is how

386
00:20:25.550 --> 00:20:30.330
if I were doing a scale from one to five
and I had that, it would be a five, right?

387
00:20:30.330 --> 00:20:35.140
If I can get it, or if I'm never gonna get
it, it might be a one or a zero, right?

388
00:20:35.140 --> 00:20:38.350
Then I'm also looking at
how they interrelate.

389
00:20:38.350 --> 00:20:40.590
I'm looking at the competitive assessment.

390
00:20:40.590 --> 00:20:44.770
How well is my customer doing in
providing hot sandwiches, for example.

391
00:20:44.770 --> 00:20:47.710
I am looking at prioritizing.

392
00:20:47.710 --> 00:20:52.020
On a scale from one to five, you want
a hot sandwich, you want hot beverages,

393
00:20:52.020 --> 00:20:55.050
you want better napkins.

394
00:20:55.050 --> 00:20:57.850
So which one of those
are the most important to you?

395
00:20:57.850 --> 00:21:02.210
And then finally I am just prioritizing
some of my technical descriptors.

396
00:21:02.210 --> 00:21:04.719
Now somehow some House Of Quality,
all that stuff I just said,

397
00:21:05.750 --> 00:21:09.140
some House Of Quality are more
complicated than others and

398
00:21:09.140 --> 00:21:14.030
the new trend in House Of Quality
is kind of cute.

399
00:21:14.030 --> 00:21:18.400
The chimney means my waist and
the flowers mean my vision,

400
00:21:18.400 --> 00:21:22.610
no wait my flowers are my values,
the sun is my vision, right?

401
00:21:22.610 --> 00:21:25.330
So some people are really
taking a lot of liberty.

402
00:21:25.330 --> 00:21:29.587
What I want to caution you is on the Six
Sigma exam, there's a lot of questions

403
00:21:29.587 --> 00:21:34.194
about the math behind QFD, and that's why
you wanna look at your student handout.

404
00:21:36.553 --> 00:21:40.920
But the idea of it, and here you see
what the template would look like.

405
00:21:40.920 --> 00:21:42.360
I think this kinda helps.

406
00:21:42.360 --> 00:21:46.120
This is where you would record things,
but again there's different templates.

407
00:21:46.120 --> 00:21:48.520
This is the most popular one right now.

408
00:21:48.520 --> 00:21:49.610
But you get the idea.

409
00:21:49.610 --> 00:21:51.440
I'm putting all of the stuff now.

410
00:21:51.440 --> 00:21:52.740
In order to make this work,

411
00:21:52.740 --> 00:21:56.450
you have to have other people on your
team that get the whole concept of QFD.

412
00:21:56.450 --> 00:21:57.501
>> For sure.
>> Right, you know.

413
00:21:57.501 --> 00:21:59.901
>> [LAUGH]
>> If they don't get what you're doing

414
00:21:59.901 --> 00:22:00.561
that's like.

415
00:22:00.561 --> 00:22:01.161
>> What is this?

416
00:22:01.161 --> 00:22:02.130
>> [LAUGH]
>> Exactly.

417
00:22:02.130 --> 00:22:06.560
>> But again, it's quite,
what we want you to know or

418
00:22:06.560 --> 00:22:10.610
what we're shooting for is that.

419
00:22:10.610 --> 00:22:14.680
>> We want you to be able to take
the exams and be successful with them.

420
00:22:14.680 --> 00:22:16.150
>> That's right.

421
00:22:16.150 --> 00:22:20.930
So here's an example, now this is
a slightly different template, but

422
00:22:20.930 --> 00:22:23.500
here's an example of it filled in.

423
00:22:23.500 --> 00:22:27.130
And again like I said in your student
packet this will make a little bit

424
00:22:27.130 --> 00:22:27.789
more sense.

425
00:22:29.620 --> 00:22:34.630
And here's like kind of
the new kind of quality house.

426
00:22:34.630 --> 00:22:38.410
Where you'll see there's kind
of more simple type things.

427
00:22:38.410 --> 00:22:43.702
And like we were saying some of
them get really, really cutesy.

428
00:22:43.702 --> 00:22:46.065
So, the House Of Quality.

429
00:22:46.065 --> 00:22:49.575
What you want to know for
the Lean Six Sigma exam,

430
00:22:49.575 --> 00:22:55.345
is that the House Of Quality is a way to
show a picture of all the different facets

431
00:22:55.345 --> 00:23:00.620
of what's going on in your department,
as related to your process improvement.

432
00:23:00.620 --> 00:23:05.650
It's not used a lot in Lean Six Sigma, but
it's heavily hit on the Six Sigma site.

433
00:23:05.650 --> 00:23:10.700
So on Lean Six Sigma, we just want you to
know what it is, in case you ran across

434
00:23:10.700 --> 00:23:14.450
it in a work environment, because it
is popular in Six Sigma environments.

435
00:23:14.450 --> 00:23:16.630
So kind of keep that mind
that that's why you need to

436
00:23:16.630 --> 00:23:18.920
know what a House Of Quality is.

437
00:23:18.920 --> 00:23:22.650
On the Six Sigma side again, you're gonna
wanna understand some of the math and

438
00:23:22.650 --> 00:23:23.930
some of the relationships, and

439
00:23:23.930 --> 00:23:27.010
that will be explained a little
bit more in your student package.

440
00:23:27.010 --> 00:23:29.390
So the second thing, and
that's on the Six Sigma side.

441
00:23:29.390 --> 00:23:34.020
So back again on the Lean side,
you're taking the Lean only test.

442
00:23:34.020 --> 00:23:35.170
On Lean Six Sigma,

443
00:23:35.170 --> 00:23:40.990
what we want you to know is that the Kano
model is a way to categorize your CTQs.

444
00:23:40.990 --> 00:23:43.700
It's a way to look at your different CTQs.

445
00:23:43.700 --> 00:23:47.180
And you're looking at things
like performance and delighters.

446
00:23:47.180 --> 00:23:51.015
And you're trying to categorize your CTQs,
even back to that Likert Scale,

447
00:23:51.015 --> 00:23:52.372
on a scale from one to five.

448
00:23:52.372 --> 00:23:56.579
On the Lean side, Dr.
Kano is actually still alive and

449
00:23:56.579 --> 00:24:00.248
spoke at the last ASQ
conference in Milwaukee.

450
00:24:00.248 --> 00:24:03.047
Which is just kind of amazing,
he's in his 90s.

451
00:24:03.047 --> 00:24:10.540
On the Lean side,
the Kano model is a very well loved model.

452
00:24:10.540 --> 00:24:14.250
And so you wanna know a little
bit more about the Kano model

453
00:24:14.250 --> 00:24:17.590
if you're taking the lean only test,
if that makes sense.

454
00:24:17.590 --> 00:24:18.320
>> Okay.

455
00:24:18.320 --> 00:24:20.530
>> So
we're gonna talk a little bit about it.

456
00:24:20.530 --> 00:24:24.610
This is what you typically
will see is this, thank you.

457
00:24:24.610 --> 00:24:26.480
This is my full screen and

458
00:24:26.480 --> 00:24:30.430
what I'm doing is I'm taking my CTQs and
I'm putting them in one of those boxes.

459
00:24:30.430 --> 00:24:35.600
So kind of think of there's things that
are gonna satisfy your client, and

460
00:24:35.600 --> 00:24:37.620
they're kind of expected, right?

461
00:24:37.620 --> 00:24:40.510
And there's gonna be things that
are gonna delight your client,

462
00:24:40.510 --> 00:24:42.460
that little bit extra that
you might wanna give.

463
00:24:42.460 --> 00:24:45.499
And so you're gonna put them
somewhere on this model.

464
00:24:48.340 --> 00:24:51.190
The Kano model process is very,

465
00:24:51.190 --> 00:24:56.100
is a lot more serious about defining
CTQs as well, like when we talked

466
00:24:56.100 --> 00:25:00.860
about CTQs we say, okay customer
requirement for sure is a CTQ and

467
00:25:00.860 --> 00:25:06.260
then anything that is gonna make your
project successful or bring satisfaction.

468
00:25:06.260 --> 00:25:12.180
In Lean Six Sigma we kind of have a little
bit less formal idea of developing CTQs.

469
00:25:12.180 --> 00:25:15.150
The Kano model on the other hand,
and those again for

470
00:25:15.150 --> 00:25:19.550
the people that are taking the Lean test,
has kind of a methodology

471
00:25:19.550 --> 00:25:22.090
even to develop and
that's what you're looking at right now.

472
00:25:22.090 --> 00:25:27.044
So there are steps to developing the CTQs.

473
00:25:27.044 --> 00:25:32.940
So again on the Lean exam you wanna
really know the process of developing

474
00:25:32.940 --> 00:25:36.650
those CTQs and that is outlined in it and
it's a handout in your student pack.

475
00:25:38.420 --> 00:25:43.000
So I'd like to just kind of closeup and
I know you have some ideas as well.

476
00:25:43.000 --> 00:25:48.044
But the thing is is that on
the Lean Six Sigma exam, you want to

477
00:25:48.044 --> 00:25:54.240
understand about projects and why it's
important to name your project correctly.

478
00:25:54.240 --> 00:25:58.960
And you want to make sure that there's
a project charter, there's a process map.

479
00:25:58.960 --> 00:26:03.380
You want to be able to understand
the components of team building.

480
00:26:03.380 --> 00:26:07.120
You're looking at, Defining your CTQs,

481
00:26:07.120 --> 00:26:11.150
keeping in mind on the Lean side that
there's actually a process to do that.

482
00:26:11.150 --> 00:26:14.690
You want to align your goals
with your business initiative,

483
00:26:14.690 --> 00:26:18.050
and you want to determine your
projected return on investment.

484
00:26:18.050 --> 00:26:20.970
And there's lots of different
paths to do that, so.

485
00:26:20.970 --> 00:26:24.670
>> You've had so much information during
this segment and the previous one.

486
00:26:24.670 --> 00:26:27.020
It really opens a lot of doors for us.

487
00:26:27.020 --> 00:26:31.650
I mean, even in previous sections,
sessions we've spoke about different tools

488
00:26:31.650 --> 00:26:35.350
that we can bring in here, like our SIPOC,
our TIM WOODS, our voices.

489
00:26:35.350 --> 00:26:40.310
We also were introduced to our why
statement and in this segment we looked at

490
00:26:40.310 --> 00:26:46.260
things like our house of quality,
the Kano, so we see a lot of flexibility.

491
00:26:46.260 --> 00:26:49.070
A place where we can insert
a lot of creativity.

492
00:26:49.070 --> 00:26:51.180
But we have to remember those two rules.

493
00:26:51.180 --> 00:26:54.040
And those two rules to
have our process map and

494
00:26:54.040 --> 00:26:57.120
our project charter before
we exit the define phase.

495
00:26:57.120 --> 00:26:59.510
So I think we got a ton of information.

496
00:26:59.510 --> 00:27:03.540
I appreciate that so much and
I appreciate you guys for staying here and

497
00:27:03.540 --> 00:27:07.180
understanding all the different
processes we have.

498
00:27:07.180 --> 00:27:09.510
And I think that about wraps it up for
this episode.

499
00:27:09.510 --> 00:27:12.630
So we'll go ahead and sign off for
this particular show.

500
00:27:12.630 --> 00:27:14.950
As your host I'm Cherokee Boose.

501
00:27:14.950 --> 00:27:19.060
>> And I'm Dr Terra Vanzant-Stern
with SSD Global Solutions.

502
00:27:19.060 --> 00:27:22.112
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

503
00:27:22.112 --> 00:27:27.929
[MUSIC]

504
00:27:27.929 --> 00:27:31.002
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: The second phase of the DMAIC model  is Measure. In this show you will see how Measure ties into the model. Dr. Terra Vanzant Stern and Cherokee Boose explain why it is so important to obtain an “as is” picture of the current process. You also look at what to measure, how to measure, and how to articulate the measurement with tools such as Fishbone, Balanced Scorecard, benchmarking and observation.
episodes.title: DMAIC Model - Measure Phase
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.230 --> 00:00:02.706
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.706 --> 00:00:06.508
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.508 --> 00:00:08.308
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.308 --> 00:00:11.925
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.925 --> 00:00:17.200
>> Welcome to your Lean Six Sigma: Green
Belt Certification Preparation series.

6
00:00:17.200 --> 00:00:19.660
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:19.660 --> 00:00:23.610
In the last episode we were
looking at the define phase and

8
00:00:23.610 --> 00:00:25.270
really where to get started.

9
00:00:25.270 --> 00:00:30.350
Now in this phase we're moving along and
we're gonna be looking at measure.

10
00:00:30.350 --> 00:00:35.617
So in studios today we have Dr Terra
Vanzant Stern to help us with this topic.

11
00:00:35.617 --> 00:00:37.140
Thank you for being here today.

12
00:00:37.140 --> 00:00:39.040
>> Thank you, Cherokee.

13
00:00:39.040 --> 00:00:41.630
>> So now that we've moved
out of our define phase,

14
00:00:41.630 --> 00:00:44.320
what are the next steps
that we need to take?

15
00:00:44.320 --> 00:00:47.740
>> Well, the very first thing that
we're gonna do now is going to measure.

16
00:00:47.740 --> 00:00:51.990
I think what's very important
is that sometimes someone has

17
00:00:51.990 --> 00:00:55.690
already defined the process
improvement that they want us to make.

18
00:00:55.690 --> 00:00:57.060
They're telling us.

19
00:00:57.060 --> 00:00:59.790
Now in a perfect world,
I got to be part of define and

20
00:00:59.790 --> 00:01:02.350
come up with what I needed to work on.

21
00:01:02.350 --> 00:01:06.360
But in reality, a lot of times our boss is
gonna come to us and they're gonna say,

22
00:01:06.360 --> 00:01:10.380
can you make x better,
faster, more cost-effective.

23
00:01:10.380 --> 00:01:14.729
But we know x is called y
because y is a positive outcome.

24
00:01:14.729 --> 00:01:18.549
So in measure, the very first thing we
have to do is we have to make sure we

25
00:01:18.549 --> 00:01:21.010
understand the why statement, right?

26
00:01:21.010 --> 00:01:24.340
Now if we got to be part of define,
we created that why statement, so

27
00:01:24.340 --> 00:01:25.690
it's gonna be easy.

28
00:01:25.690 --> 00:01:30.030
But if we weren't a part of define, we may
need to take a little step backwards and

29
00:01:30.030 --> 00:01:31.890
kind of look at some of
those define tools so

30
00:01:31.890 --> 00:01:35.290
that we understand what it
is that we're measuring.

31
00:01:35.290 --> 00:01:40.200
Now if I could go to my slide deck,
we're going to look at measure.

32
00:01:41.680 --> 00:01:44.610
And in this session we're
gonna look at what to measure,

33
00:01:44.610 --> 00:01:46.910
and there are tools for that.

34
00:01:46.910 --> 00:01:49.680
And how to measure, and
there's tools for that.

35
00:01:49.680 --> 00:01:52.640
And how to articulate that measurement,
right?

36
00:01:52.640 --> 00:01:56.470
Now we're using the term measurement,
and to me that's not as intuitive.

37
00:01:56.470 --> 00:02:00.120
In define, we're defining the problem,
we're defining what we wanna work on.

38
00:02:00.120 --> 00:02:02.970
So define feels really comfortable for me.

39
00:02:02.970 --> 00:02:05.280
Measure actually means,

40
00:02:05.280 --> 00:02:09.190
I wanna get a clear,
accurate picture of where we are today.

41
00:02:09.190 --> 00:02:12.780
Now if I could just go take a snapshot,
that's what I would do and

42
00:02:12.780 --> 00:02:16.610
in some some cases you just
completely luck out, right?

43
00:02:16.610 --> 00:02:20.550
>> Now if you were a part of the define
process, if you were lucky enough to be

44
00:02:20.550 --> 00:02:25.260
defining the process that you wanted
to measure, when you get to measure,

45
00:02:25.260 --> 00:02:29.240
you may already have a list of
things that you wanna check into.

46
00:02:29.240 --> 00:02:33.340
But sometimes you don't get
the project until after or

47
00:02:33.340 --> 00:02:35.310
you've got a lot of other
things on your mind.

48
00:02:35.310 --> 00:02:37.880
So when you get to measure,
you don't really even know where to start.

49
00:02:37.880 --> 00:02:40.060
So that's what we're gonna talk about.

50
00:02:40.060 --> 00:02:45.298
Now keep in mind, I think a clear
as-is picture of where you are today

51
00:02:45.298 --> 00:02:50.288
is imperative and just think,
if I could take a snapshot, do it.

52
00:02:50.288 --> 00:02:55.113
If I could take a photo on my phone and
show you this is we are right now,

53
00:02:55.113 --> 00:02:59.090
that's okay,
that satisfies that requirement.

54
00:02:59.090 --> 00:03:03.023
But typically, when you're working in
a service or a transaction environment,

55
00:03:03.023 --> 00:03:04.341
you can't take a picture.

56
00:03:04.341 --> 00:03:08.550
You're gonna have to explain
the picture using words and models.

57
00:03:08.550 --> 00:03:13.260
Sometimes at the end of measure,
you could actually be done in real life

58
00:03:13.260 --> 00:03:17.650
because sometimes people just need to
know, hey, what is our current state?

59
00:03:17.650 --> 00:03:19.300
What's going on right now?

60
00:03:19.300 --> 00:03:21.240
>> Exactly and from an IT perspective,

61
00:03:21.240 --> 00:03:25.600
we talk about this all the time,
how important baselines really are.

62
00:03:25.600 --> 00:03:30.160
And like you mentioned, let's say my end
users can't connect to a particular server

63
00:03:30.160 --> 00:03:33.531
and they're getting error messages,
connectivity issues.

64
00:03:33.531 --> 00:03:35.686
And then I use tools to
measure my bandwidth and

65
00:03:35.686 --> 00:03:39.166
I see that I've exceeded the number of
people that wanna connect to my, and

66
00:03:39.166 --> 00:03:41.820
then I find my problem is
that we need more bandwidth.

67
00:03:41.820 --> 00:03:42.418
There you go.

68
00:03:42.418 --> 00:03:43.480
[LAUGH]
>> Exactly and

69
00:03:43.480 --> 00:03:46.150
that's something that I think I really,
really love and

70
00:03:46.150 --> 00:03:51.400
appreciate about the DMAIC model is at
the end of define, you may have a project.

71
00:03:51.400 --> 00:03:54.160
And remember, if it's a project
you just go to project plan and

72
00:03:54.160 --> 00:03:55.650
you just go do it, right?

73
00:03:55.650 --> 00:03:59.303
At the end of measure,
you may not have to go to analyze.

74
00:03:59.303 --> 00:04:02.180
Once you really know
what's happening today,

75
00:04:02.180 --> 00:04:04.270
you might have solved the problem, right?

76
00:04:04.270 --> 00:04:11.150
So when we are in measure,
what we wanna do is we wanna look out.

77
00:04:11.150 --> 00:04:14.561
Probably more importantly than
anything else is what to measure.

78
00:04:14.561 --> 00:04:15.584
>> Okay.

79
00:04:15.584 --> 00:04:17.290
>> What do I wanna measure?

80
00:04:17.290 --> 00:04:19.410
And then I wanna identify,
how am I gonna do it?

81
00:04:19.410 --> 00:04:21.475
How am I going to make that measurement so

82
00:04:21.475 --> 00:04:24.103
that people understand
what it is I'm measuring?

83
00:04:24.103 --> 00:04:29.850
And then sometimes I might have to work
on developing a measurement strategy.

84
00:04:29.850 --> 00:04:33.030
And that's because maybe some of
the things that I need to find out

85
00:04:33.030 --> 00:04:34.570
aren't in my department.

86
00:04:34.570 --> 00:04:40.410
Maybe I need to go get special permission
to look at certain records or files.

87
00:04:40.410 --> 00:04:45.660
Or even, in some cases, if you are working
in an environment with security,

88
00:04:45.660 --> 00:04:47.500
clearance requirements-
>> Sure.

89

316
00:16:53.360 --> 00:16:56.010
But I might have only started
the process and measure or

317
00:16:56.010 --> 00:16:58.420
I could still get to measure and
go, I know where to start.

318
00:17:00.040 --> 00:17:02.660
So that's just such another strategy.

319
00:17:02.660 --> 00:17:06.300
Now, another strategy, if I'm trying to
gather measurements, is to go back and

320
00:17:06.300 --> 00:17:08.080
look at my CTQs.

321
00:17:08.080 --> 00:17:12.090
If I develop those CTQs, those customer
requirements and those things that

322
00:17:12.090 --> 00:17:15.950
are required to make me successful,
if I took the time to develop those and

323
00:17:15.950 --> 00:17:20.410
define, then I could say, hey, on a scale
from one to five, how am I doing on that?

324
00:17:20.410 --> 00:17:21.290
That could be my measurement.

325
00:17:22.465 --> 00:17:24.980
Cuz remember,
I'm just trying to get a clear picture.

326
00:17:24.980 --> 00:17:28.820
Same thing, on a scale from one to five,
if I took time to

327
00:17:28.820 --> 00:17:33.280
think my voice of the customer, voice
of the employee, voice of the process,

328
00:17:33.280 --> 00:17:37.240
voice of the business,
how am I doing with those things?

329
00:17:37.240 --> 00:17:39.790
Now, it doesn't mean you had
to develop them in define.

330
00:17:39.790 --> 00:17:43.700
CTQ's or the voices, because you might not
have picked up the process until measure.

331
00:17:43.700 --> 00:17:46.590
So you can always step back and
develop those things.

332
00:17:46.590 --> 00:17:50.950
But if you already have them placed and
defined, the beauty of going to measure,

333
00:17:50.950 --> 00:17:53.290
is that you can now go back and
use those things I developed.

334
00:17:53.290 --> 00:17:55.644
And I'm kind of killing
two birds with one stone.

335
00:17:57.641 --> 00:18:01.892
So another place, and this is similar
to the three Ps, when we talked about

336
00:18:01.892 --> 00:18:06.590
it earlier, we were talking about it
in context of the fish bone diagram.

337
00:18:06.590 --> 00:18:09.680
However, if I'm trying to get an idea,
what should I be measuring?

338
00:18:09.680 --> 00:18:13.510
I wanna give my boss a clear,
as-is picture of where we are today.

339
00:18:13.510 --> 00:18:14.940
I don't know where to start.

340
00:18:14.940 --> 00:18:16.640
Well, I can do that 3P thing.

341
00:18:16.640 --> 00:18:17.790
Maybe I do that.

342
00:18:17.790 --> 00:18:19.200
Or I can sit down and I can say,

343
00:18:19.200 --> 00:18:22.710
okay, are there any kind of machines or
equipment that I should be measuring?

344
00:18:22.710 --> 00:18:24.010
Is there any kind of methods?

345
00:18:24.010 --> 00:18:25.670
Is there any materials?

346
00:18:25.670 --> 00:18:28.110
Are there measurements,
mother nature, manpower?

347
00:18:28.110 --> 00:18:30.160
It's just a way to get my brain thinking.

348
00:18:33.570 --> 00:18:38.930
Now, when you're using the fishbone, you
could also just use the four Ms, right?

349
00:18:38.930 --> 00:18:43.410
And in this case,
the fishbone wouldn't be used.

350
00:18:43.410 --> 00:18:47.440
I might use the fishbone in analyze
to figure out my root cause.

351
00:18:47.440 --> 00:18:51.660
I might use it in define, to just figure
out what the heck I should be working on.

352
00:18:51.660 --> 00:18:54.920
But I could also just use that
structure when I'm in measure,

353
00:18:54.920 --> 00:18:57.220
trying to figure out what
should I measure, right?

354
00:18:57.220 --> 00:19:00.440
So in that case I'm kind of using
the fishbone in a different way.

355
00:19:00.440 --> 00:19:02.880
And I might just use 4
Ms instead of 6 Ms and

356
00:19:02.880 --> 00:19:06.400
this says machines, man, method, material.

357
00:19:06.400 --> 00:19:08.740
So I might draw it out in a fishbone.

358
00:19:08.740 --> 00:19:11.860
And where it says effect,
just what should I measure.?

359
00:19:12.970 --> 00:19:16.270
And then in each one of these categories,
just start writing up some ideas.

360
00:19:16.270 --> 00:19:19.430
So I have one piece of paper that
I could be doing in a meeting.

361
00:19:19.430 --> 00:19:23.770
I might be doing this in an actual
meeting and just kind of drawing it out,

362
00:19:23.770 --> 00:19:25.282
like what should I be looking at?

363
00:19:25.282 --> 00:19:30.440
So just keep in mind that
you could use that as well.

364
00:19:30.440 --> 00:19:34.660
And then we come to what we call
the balanced score card approach.

365
00:19:34.660 --> 00:19:38.853
And the balance scorecard typically
has four different components,

366
00:19:38.853 --> 00:19:41.985
it has finance, it has customer,
it has process.

367
00:19:41.985 --> 00:19:46.635
And then it has, in the case of our
graphic organizational capacity, but

368
00:19:46.635 --> 00:19:50.155
a lot of times that's referred
to as training or education.

369
00:19:50.155 --> 00:19:51.085
>> Okay.
>> Right?

370
00:19:51.085 --> 00:19:54.675
And so what I'm doing is I'm
pretending like I get to measure, and

371
00:19:54.675 --> 00:19:55.995
I don't where to start.

372
00:19:55.995 --> 00:19:56.625
So I say, well,

373
00:19:56.625 --> 00:20:00.435
if I were looking through a financial lens
what kinds of things would I measure?

374
00:20:00.435 --> 00:20:04.445
If I were looking through a customer
service lens, or operations lens, or

375
00:20:04.445 --> 00:20:07.630
a training and development lens,
what would I measure?

376
00:20:07.630 --> 00:20:08.650
And I would write this down.

377
00:20:08.650 --> 00:20:10.700
Now obviously I still have to go out and
measure them.

378
00:20:10.700 --> 00:20:15.320
But I still maintain what to measure
is a little bit more important than

379
00:20:15.320 --> 00:20:18.030
how to measure it because you can go and
ask for help.

380
00:20:18.030 --> 00:20:19.600
>> Someone might have a better idea,
exactly.

381
00:20:19.600 --> 00:20:23.460
>> Yeah, exactly, and you could go to
the net and say how do I measure x, right?

382
00:20:23.460 --> 00:20:24.910
Because I don't really know.

383
00:20:24.910 --> 00:20:26.790
But knowing what to measure.

384
00:20:26.790 --> 00:20:29.300
Now, the beauty of the balance scorecard

385
00:20:29.300 --> 00:20:34.000
is that over half of the Fortune
500 companies use balance scorecard

386
00:20:34.000 --> 00:20:38.620
as their as their enterprise-wide
measurement system.

387
00:20:38.620 --> 00:20:42.760
So, if you're working with a company that
the company is using balanced scorecard,

388
00:20:42.760 --> 00:20:45.380
when you go explain your current state,

389
00:20:45.380 --> 00:20:49.770
they're gonna be familiar with this
is how we're doing financially.

390
00:20:49.770 --> 00:20:53.090
This is how we're doing
customer service-wise etc.

391
00:20:53.090 --> 00:20:54.100
etc., right?

392
00:20:54.100 --> 00:20:57.560
Now, there are scorecards
cards out there as well

393
00:20:57.560 --> 00:20:59.460
that you can get from search engines.

394
00:20:59.460 --> 00:21:01.970
So let's say you never
worked in supply chain,

395
00:21:01.970 --> 00:21:05.890
you could say supply chain scorecard and
it's gonna come up with all kinds of

396
00:21:05.890 --> 00:21:08.310
ideas of things you should
measure in the supply chain.

397
00:21:08.310 --> 00:21:09.980
So kind of keep that in mind.

398
00:21:09.980 --> 00:21:13.375
They're usually Excel spreadsheets and

399
00:21:13.375 --> 00:21:18.400
there's usually either no cost or
a minor cost to them.

400
00:21:18.400 --> 00:21:21.840
So if you get into a situation where you
don't know where to start you could type

401
00:21:21.840 --> 00:21:23.850
that, HR scorecard, and

402
00:21:23.850 --> 00:21:26.040
it's gonna give you some ideas
of what you should be measuring.

403
00:21:27.140 --> 00:21:31.110
Another place that you can look, and
this is kind of cool, is benchmarking,

404
00:21:31.110 --> 00:21:35.460
because benchmarking can provide you with
some ideas and some measurement tools.

405
00:21:35.460 --> 00:21:38.920
So let's say I'm just trying to figure out
what I should be measuring in the customer

406
00:21:38.920 --> 00:21:40.990
service department or IT.

407
00:21:40.990 --> 00:21:44.520
I could go to a benchmarking study and
say, well what is everyone else measuring?

408
00:21:44.520 --> 00:21:48.530
Now, if I wanna go back and say,
okay their benchmark is here and

409
00:21:48.530 --> 00:21:51.880
my benchmark is there,
that could also be interesting.

410
00:21:51.880 --> 00:21:55.620
But maybe IT or HR or customer service or

411
00:21:55.620 --> 00:21:58.420
operations is measuring something
you've never even measured before.

412
00:21:58.420 --> 00:22:00.400
You never even thought about measuring it.

413
00:22:00.400 --> 00:22:03.240
So there's another place you
could look for measurement.

414
00:22:03.240 --> 00:22:05.790
So another thing I want
you to keep in mind about

415
00:22:05.790 --> 00:22:08.920
measure is some of those
seven tools of quality.

416
00:22:08.920 --> 00:22:13.640
Now, if you're using the seven tools
of quality to figure out something,

417
00:22:13.640 --> 00:22:15.980
you're gonna wait until analyze.

418
00:22:15.980 --> 00:22:19.870
But if you're using those seven tools
of quality just to gather information,

419
00:22:19.870 --> 00:22:23.100
just to give us a picture
of where we are today,

420
00:22:23.100 --> 00:22:26.312
some of the tools that could be
helpful would be your check sheet,

421
00:22:26.312 --> 00:22:30.460
your histograms, your Pareto charts, your
scatter diagrams, your control charts.

422
00:22:30.460 --> 00:22:37.100
So those seven tools of quality can be use
to form a really great before picture.

423
00:22:37.100 --> 00:22:38.030
So for example,

424
00:22:38.030 --> 00:22:42.960
if I were showing my control chart as
a before picture and I let everyone know

425
00:22:42.960 --> 00:22:46.750
that the idea is the data points
needed to come close to the middle.

426
00:22:46.750 --> 00:22:49.430
At the end of my story I
could show that same control

427
00:22:49.430 --> 00:22:51.350
chart to show you how I improved.

428
00:22:51.350 --> 00:22:53.520
Same thing with the Pareto chart for
example.

429
00:22:53.520 --> 00:22:56.320
If I had a Pareto chart, and
I had one thing, remember,

430
00:22:56.320 --> 00:22:58.650
that was completely out of whack.

431
00:22:58.650 --> 00:23:00.580
After I rolled out my process improvement,

432
00:23:00.580 --> 00:23:02.780
because I'm trying to
do that before picture.

433
00:23:02.780 --> 00:23:05.420
After I rolled out my process
improvement I could show you another

434
00:23:05.420 --> 00:23:08.510
Pareto chart where that
thing is minimized, right?

435
00:23:08.510 --> 00:23:09.840
So don't forget your charts and

436
00:23:09.840 --> 00:23:13.830
graphs as a good way to show
your clear as-is picture.

437
00:23:13.830 --> 00:23:19.500
Where it gets confusing is you don't want
to think of those graphs as analyzed yet.

438
00:23:19.500 --> 00:23:22.360
You'll send those over to
the analyze section, but

439
00:23:22.360 --> 00:23:23.760
you don't wanna be analyzing them.

440
00:23:23.760 --> 00:23:26.851
Right now you're just collecting
information to form that as-is

441
00:23:26.851 --> 00:23:28.180
picture, right?

442
00:23:28.180 --> 00:23:30.140
Now, sometimes you're
gonna get to analyze,

443
00:23:30.140 --> 00:23:32.870
and all you have is a bunch
of spreadsheets from measure.

444
00:23:32.870 --> 00:23:33.920
That's very possible.

445
00:23:33.920 --> 00:23:36.550
And that's where you would
develop your charts and crafts.

446
00:23:36.550 --> 00:23:40.010
But if you're in measure, and you go wow,
this would make a great Pareto chart.

447
00:23:40.010 --> 00:23:41.070
Then you would just go ahead and

448
00:23:41.070 --> 00:23:43.770
do the Pareto chart there to
form your before picture, right?

449
00:23:43.770 --> 00:23:50.210
And so finally, a tool that people forget
about all the time is observation.

450
00:23:50.210 --> 00:23:53.090
And that's just go out and
look at the process.

451
00:23:53.090 --> 00:23:56.240
I have a number of consulting
clients where they really haven't

452
00:23:56.240 --> 00:23:58.410
been to the manufacturing floor.

453
00:23:58.410 --> 00:23:59.230
So seriously-
>> Well, sure.

454
00:23:59.230 --> 00:24:00.630
I mean-
>> They just haven't been there.

455
00:24:00.630 --> 00:24:04.140
>> Corporate doesn't always have their
hands in the day to day functions so

456
00:24:04.140 --> 00:24:07.000
that's why it really is important
to speak to those people

457
00:24:07.000 --> 00:24:10.290
who are familiar with the process and
who are working it every day.

458
00:24:10.290 --> 00:24:11.300
>> Exactly.

459
00:24:11.300 --> 00:24:14.610
And the thing is that we want to remember
is that if we're using observation for

460
00:24:14.610 --> 00:24:15.660
the tool.

461
00:24:15.660 --> 00:24:20.190
Because that's a great tool to get a good
clear as-is picture of where we are today,

462
00:24:20.190 --> 00:24:24.190
is that we just have to make sure
that we watch for any kind of bias.

463
00:24:24.190 --> 00:24:26.700
And in order to do that,
we might take someone with us.

464
00:24:26.700 --> 00:24:29.335
We might make sure,
we might stay cognizant of the day.

465
00:24:29.335 --> 00:24:32.240
Like, is it the day after a holiday
that we're watching a process?

466
00:24:32.240 --> 00:24:33.430
That type of thing.

467
00:24:33.430 --> 00:24:36.480
So, observation, absolutely a great tool.

468
00:24:36.480 --> 00:24:38.470
We just have to be a little
careful with that tool.

469
00:24:38.470 --> 00:24:41.430
And sometimes, unlike a chart, or graph,

470
00:24:41.430 --> 00:24:46.500
or a statistic, we might have to back up
that observation with more information.

471
00:24:46.500 --> 00:24:50.890
And I really do love these methodologies
because you see the flexibility, and

472
00:24:50.890 --> 00:24:54.550
even just building upon our tools as
we go along we have some options.

473
00:24:54.550 --> 00:24:58.040
We can bring it in during this phase,
or the analyze phase, or

474
00:24:58.040 --> 00:25:01.670
we can take tools that we've already
worked on in the define phase.

475
00:25:01.670 --> 00:25:03.530
So, it's pretty cool in that way.

476
00:25:03.530 --> 00:25:06.720
But that does about wrap it up for
our measure phase.

477
00:25:06.720 --> 00:25:07.720
But don't go anywhere.

478
00:25:07.720 --> 00:25:09.560
We still have some more phases to cover.

479
00:25:09.560 --> 00:25:13.150
I think we're gonna go ahead and
sign off for this particular episode.

480
00:25:13.150 --> 00:25:16.320
So I'm gonna sign out as your host,
Cherokee Boose.

481
00:25:16.320 --> 00:25:20.120
And this is Dr Tara Van Zanstern
with SSD Global Solutions.

482
00:25:20.120 --> 00:25:22.720
See you next time here at ITProTV.

483
00:25:22.720 --> 00:25:29.470
[MUSIC]

484
00:25:29.470 --> 00:25:34.910
>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV

episodes.description: The third phase of the DMAIC model is Analyze. In this show you will see how Analyze ties into the model. Dr. Terra Vanzant Stern and Cherokee Boose explain how tools from previous shows tie into this phase. You will also see additional tools such as the 6 hats, critical thinking wheel, critical thinking levels, critical thinking chart and 6 critical questions.
episodes.title: DMAIC Model - Analyze Phase
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.230 --> 00:00:03.415
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.415 --> 00:00:06.004
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.004 --> 00:00:08.232
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.232 --> 00:00:12.167
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.167 --> 00:00:17.390
>> Welcome to your Lean Six Sigma: Green
Belt Certification Preparation series.

6
00:00:17.390 --> 00:00:18.950
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:20.210 --> 00:00:23.580
In the past few episodes we've
been looking at the DMAIC model.

8
00:00:23.580 --> 00:00:26.190
We're currently up to the analyze phase.

9
00:00:26.190 --> 00:00:29.542
So with us to explain the analyze
phase in the studios today,

10
00:00:29.542 --> 00:00:31.470
we have Doctor Terra Vanzant Stern.

11
00:00:31.470 --> 00:00:33.060
Thank you for being here today Terra.

12
00:00:33.060 --> 00:00:34.120
>> And thank you Cherokee.

13
00:00:35.210 --> 00:00:39.150
>> So we've already taken a look at
the define phase and the measure phase.

14
00:00:39.150 --> 00:00:41.940
But where do we begin
in the analyze phase?

15
00:00:41.940 --> 00:00:42.500
>> That's correct.

16
00:00:44.390 --> 00:00:48.730
And so we're gonna be pulling together
some of the tools that we've used in

17
00:00:48.730 --> 00:00:52.560
former sessions and even some of the tools
that we used in define and measure.

18
00:00:52.560 --> 00:00:54.900
But now the focus is gonna
be totally different.

19
00:00:54.900 --> 00:00:55.400
>> All right.

20
00:00:57.370 --> 00:00:59.109
>> So I think I'll bring up my slide deck.

21
00:01:00.630 --> 00:01:03.130
And in this session, obviously,

22
00:01:03.130 --> 00:01:06.520
we're gonna look at the role
analyze plays in the DMAIC model.

23
00:01:06.520 --> 00:01:09.810
We're going to look at the important
tools that we have already covered,

24
00:01:09.810 --> 00:01:11.950
the seven tools of quality and the voices.

25
00:01:11.950 --> 00:01:15.570
And then we're gonna look at some
additional tools to help us with our

26
00:01:15.570 --> 00:01:16.494
critical thinking.

27
00:01:16.494 --> 00:01:20.380
The Hats, Critical Thinking Wheel,
Critical Thinking Levels,

28
00:01:20.380 --> 00:01:23.180
Critical Thinking Chart so
you're kinda getting the idea there.

29
00:01:23.180 --> 00:01:25.070
Six critical questions.

30
00:01:25.070 --> 00:01:26.410
>> They want us to think.

31
00:01:26.410 --> 00:01:32.860
>> That's true, and in this session
continued in your student package is going

32
00:01:32.860 --> 00:01:39.020
to be Issues Identification, Hypothesis
Testing and Tips for Brainstorming.

33
00:01:39.020 --> 00:01:41.214
The Issues Identification and

34
00:01:41.214 --> 00:01:46.360
Hypothesis Testing which is normally
covered in analyze on the six sigma

35
00:01:46.360 --> 00:01:52.195
side are some things that you might need
if you're taking the six sigma only exam.

36
00:01:52.195 --> 00:01:56.446
And then Tips for Brainstorming
is a section that's covered sort

37
00:01:56.446 --> 00:02:00.498
of on the lean side of you're
just doing a lean only exam.

38
00:02:00.498 --> 00:02:04.170
These things aren't typically
covered in lean six sigma exams, but

39
00:02:04.170 --> 00:02:06.750
they're gonna be there a new student
package just in case you need them.

40
00:02:08.070 --> 00:02:09.990
So when we're in analyze,

41
00:02:09.990 --> 00:02:15.080
analytical thinking follows the scientific
approach to problem solving.

42
00:02:15.080 --> 00:02:19.740
What we wanna keep in mind is that
now we have two pieces of the puzzle.

43
00:02:19.740 --> 00:02:22.550
Define what it is we're working on and

44
00:02:22.550 --> 00:02:27.220
now we have measure which
tells us what's happening now.

45
00:02:27.220 --> 00:02:32.440
Our goal in analyze is to come up
with two to three solutions and then

46
00:02:32.440 --> 00:02:36.680
when we get into improve we're gonna ask
whoever we're working for to choose one.

47
00:02:36.680 --> 00:02:38.650
This is gonna help us with our buy in.

48
00:02:38.650 --> 00:02:41.320
But once we have those
two pieces of the puzzle,

49
00:02:41.320 --> 00:02:44.170
what the problem really
is that we wanna solve,

50
00:02:44.170 --> 00:02:48.270
what is the activity that we wanna make
better, faster, more cost effective?

51
00:02:48.270 --> 00:02:52.370
And what's going on that's
related to that environment?

52
00:02:52.370 --> 00:02:55.190
We can kind of just start doing
some regular problem solving.

53
00:02:55.190 --> 00:02:57.010
That's one of our options.

54
00:02:57.010 --> 00:03:01.630
In scientific problem solving, what
happens is, we start with the problem and

55
00:03:01.630 --> 00:03:03.330
then we look at the hypothesis.

56
00:03:03.330 --> 00:03:04.130
Could it be this?

57
00:03:04.130 --> 00:03:05.210
Could it be that?

58
00:03:05.210 --> 00:03:09.030
Now if we have more than two conditions,
we have to look at a different tool,

59
00:03:09.030 --> 00:03:11.510

00:03:41.430 --> 00:03:47.670

00:03:47.670 --> 00:03:51.090

00:04:12.610 --> 00:04:15.470

So in six sigma we're pretty

In lean six sigma we're saying

There is a possibility for the small

00:05:25.548 --> 00:05:30.232
But impact is also looking at

00:05:47.592 --> 00:05:52.830

that what I put on that list,

00:28:21.240 --> 00:28:23.110
everything is going to be pretty good.

512
00:28:23.110 --> 00:28:29.810
Now, I am going to be responsible in the
final phase of the model to sustain it.

513
00:28:29.810 --> 00:28:33.947
So if I start thinking about
sustainability now when I'm in analyze,

514
00:28:33.947 --> 00:28:37.160
that's a good place to start thinking.

515
00:28:37.160 --> 00:28:40.250
It's a great idea, but
will I be able to keep it going?

516
00:28:40.250 --> 00:28:42.810
So, that might be another test
that I'm running it through.

517
00:28:42.810 --> 00:28:43.310
>> Okay.

518
00:28:45.920 --> 00:28:49.695
>> Now, when we typically make a decision
these are the things that happen,

519
00:28:49.695 --> 00:28:53.769
self-doubt, sometimes
we're over confident,

520
00:28:54.990 --> 00:28:59.930
Sometimes we procrastinate, and
sometimes we have false starts, right?

521
00:28:59.930 --> 00:29:01.880
>> True.
>> So we just need to kinda keep that

522
00:29:01.880 --> 00:29:02.420
in mind.

523
00:29:02.420 --> 00:29:05.990
You might have a good decision and
then you might just kinda panic, or

524
00:29:05.990 --> 00:29:07.160
you might be over confident.

525
00:29:07.160 --> 00:29:10.440
So these are things that you just
want to think about and analyze.

526
00:29:10.440 --> 00:29:14.682
And then you wanna think of when you're
looking at problem solving models.

527
00:29:17.044 --> 00:29:20.800
One that's really kind of a fun
one to look at is P O A C T.

528
00:29:20.800 --> 00:29:22.800
And I just pulled everything up at once.

529
00:29:22.800 --> 00:29:24.980
But the problem, the objectives,
the alternatives,

530
00:29:24.980 --> 00:29:26.490
the consequences, the tradeoffs.

531
00:29:26.490 --> 00:29:30.440
Again, just other model,
and you would progressively

532
00:29:30.440 --> 00:29:35.120
use these models until you hit something
and go this works for that problem right.

533
00:29:35.120 --> 00:29:37.340
And a lot of times,
I can't stress that enough.

534
00:29:37.340 --> 00:29:40.340
A lot of times just those charts and
graphs are gonna do it.

535
00:29:40.340 --> 00:29:42.360
Just looking at a chart or graph,

536
00:29:42.360 --> 00:29:46.380
once you've got all this information from
measure, that might be all you need.

537
00:29:46.380 --> 00:29:49.690
But, if it doesn't work,
then you've got the thinking hats and

538
00:29:49.690 --> 00:29:54.590
the skills and all these other schematics
that you can run your problems through.

539
00:29:54.590 --> 00:29:58.230
So Cherokee, I think I'd like
to end with this for analyze.

540
00:29:58.230 --> 00:30:00.260
What's the best solution?

541
00:30:00.260 --> 00:30:03.530
And again, I'm not really sure who
said this, but I read it all the time.

542
00:30:03.530 --> 00:30:08.340
A good solution to a well-posed problem,
is almost always a smarter

543
00:30:08.340 --> 00:30:13.970
choice than an excellent solution
to a poorly posed problem.

544
00:30:13.970 --> 00:30:15.600
>> I like it, I really do.

545
00:30:15.600 --> 00:30:21.380
So, we were able to go through our define,
our measure, and now we're analyzing.

546
00:30:21.380 --> 00:30:24.610
And if we haven't already found
the problem at this point, well,

547
00:30:24.610 --> 00:30:29.030
we might want to continue into our next
phase which would be the improve phase.

548
00:30:29.030 --> 00:30:32.290
So, we have a lot more
information headed your way.

549
00:30:32.290 --> 00:30:34.370
Don't go anywhere, get comfortable.

550
00:30:34.370 --> 00:30:37.940
I think that's about it for this episode,
so we'll go ahead and wrap up.

551
00:30:37.940 --> 00:30:41.620
And I'll sign off as your show host,
Cherokee Boose.

552
00:30:41.620 --> 00:30:45.600
>> And this is Dr Terra Vanzant Stern
with SSD Global Solutions.

553
00:30:45.600 --> 00:30:48.022
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

554
00:30:49.721 --> 00:30:55.597
[MUSIC]

555
00:30:55.597 --> 00:31:00.660
Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: The fourth phase of the DMAIC model is Improve. In this show you will see how Improve ties into the model. Dr. Terra Vanzant Stern and Cherokee Boose describe the steps one should take in this phase such as listing three to five Solutions from analyze, gaining Consensus on which one to try, trying it out first (Pilot, Focus Group, Simulation), creating your Project Plan and rolling it out.
episodes.title: DMAIC Model - Improve Phase
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.230 --> 00:00:03.596
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm you host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.596 --> 00:00:04.537
[CROSSTALK].

3
00:00:04.537 --> 00:00:12.487
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

4
00:00:12.487 --> 00:00:16.316
>> Welcome to your Lean Six Sigma: Green
Belt Certification Preparation series.

5
00:00:16.316 --> 00:00:20.230
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:20.230 --> 00:00:24.030
If you've been following along,
we've already traveled through the define,

7
00:00:24.030 --> 00:00:27.630
the measure,
the analyze phases of the DMAIC model.

8
00:00:27.630 --> 00:00:29.930
And now we've landed on improve.

9
00:00:29.930 --> 00:00:33.590
With us today, we have Dr.
Tara van Zagstern In studios.

10
00:00:33.590 --> 00:00:35.190
Thank you for joining us today, Doctor.

11
00:00:35.190 --> 00:00:36.470
>> Thank you, Cherokee.

12
00:00:36.470 --> 00:00:38.940
>> So, we started talking
about all these different

13
00:00:38.940 --> 00:00:40.470
phases that we have available to us.

14
00:00:40.470 --> 00:00:44.210
But, now we've gone through all the work,
we've come up with some pretty good ideas,

15
00:00:44.210 --> 00:00:45.990
and now how are we going
to implement them?

16
00:00:47.090 --> 00:00:51.350
>> Well, what we're gonna do is we're
gonna start in the improve phase, right?

17
00:00:51.350 --> 00:00:52.855
And, if we could go to my slide deck.

18
00:00:55.070 --> 00:00:58.380
Improve is a little bit different.

19
00:00:58.380 --> 00:01:02.880
And when I say that it's because define,
measure,

20
00:01:02.880 --> 00:01:05.650
and analyze are pretty creative, Cherokee.

21
00:01:05.650 --> 00:01:07.920
I mean they're creative phases.

22
00:01:07.920 --> 00:01:12.300
When you get to Improve,
it's almost like the hammer falls.

23
00:01:12.300 --> 00:01:13.860
It's a roadmap.

24
00:01:13.860 --> 00:01:17.460
We have to do things in
a particular order, okay?

25
00:01:17.460 --> 00:01:20.630
So, what we're gonna talk about in
this session is the role that Improve

26
00:01:20.630 --> 00:01:23.760
plays in the DMAIC, and
the tools that are used in Improve.

27
00:01:23.760 --> 00:01:24.630
>> Great.

28
00:01:24.630 --> 00:01:28.070
>> Now the first thing is that I had

29
00:01:28.070 --> 00:01:31.150
figured out my three to five solutions and
analyze.

30
00:01:31.150 --> 00:01:35.960
So, i wouldn't have really left analyze
unless I have three to five solutions.

31
00:01:35.960 --> 00:01:40.703
Now, sometimes I may have more, but when
I get ready to present those solutions,

32
00:01:40.703 --> 00:01:42.442
I just want the three to five.

33
00:01:42.442 --> 00:01:46.270
And then sometimes my boss is gonna
ask me, which one would you choose?

34
00:01:46.270 --> 00:01:51.930
I still want my boss to pick one,
because that helps with the buy in,

35
00:01:51.930 --> 00:01:55.610
but I need to be prepared to
say which one I think is best.

36
00:01:55.610 --> 00:01:59.820
So what I'm about to tell you could
happen at the bottom of analyze.

37
00:01:59.820 --> 00:02:02.370
Or it could happen at the top of Improve,

38
00:02:02.370 --> 00:02:04.840
before you list your
three to five solutions.

39
00:02:04.840 --> 00:02:07.660
But your first official goal in Improve,

40
00:02:07.660 --> 00:02:12.300
is to have three to five solutions
that you can present, okay?

41
00:02:12.300 --> 00:02:14.660
So that's your first official step.

42
00:02:14.660 --> 00:02:18.990
So between that first official step and
when you leave, analyze, or

43
00:02:18.990 --> 00:02:23.640
the bottom part of analyze, these are some
things that you wanna think about.

44
00:02:25.050 --> 00:02:26.560
What are the consequences?

45
00:02:26.560 --> 00:02:29.099
Now I'm just gonna ahead and
pull up these bullet points.

46
00:02:30.420 --> 00:02:35.370
And what would be the consequences
of each alternative?

47
00:02:35.370 --> 00:02:38.270
So what you are trying to do is
you're trying to either narrow that

48
00:02:38.270 --> 00:02:42.560
down to three to five, or
you're trying to pick which one,

49
00:02:42.560 --> 00:02:45.270
if they ask you,
that you would choose over the others.

50
00:02:45.270 --> 00:02:46.863
Now, sometimes you're just
gonna naturally know.

51
00:02:46.863 --> 00:02:47.719
You're gonna say,

52
00:02:47.719 --> 00:02:51.360
well I picked this one because I think
it's the greenest solution, right?

53
00:02:51.360 --> 00:02:53.034
But sometimes you won't.
So kinda of think of,

54
00:02:53.034 --> 00:02:57.403
this is a way to narrow down that list,
and/or help you choose the one that,

55
00:02:57.403 --> 00:03:00.203
if they where to ask you
which one would you pick,

56
00:03:00.203 --> 00:03:02.880
that you would have something to say.

57
00:03:02.880 --> 00:03:05.420
So I'm gonna list the consequences for
each alternative,

58
00:03:05.420 --> 00:03:07.630
like what are all the things
that could go wrong.

59
00:03:07.630 --> 00:03:10.740
I'm gonna access future consequences.

60
00:03:10.740 --> 00:03:11.570
Sorry.

61
00:03:11.570 --> 00:03:13.745
I'm gonna think about
the future consequences,

62
00:03:13.745 --> 00:03:15.408
like down the road what could happen?

63
00:03:15.408 --> 00:03:19.830
I'm gonna look at the descriptions
of the consequences.

64
00:03:19.830 --> 00:03:23.690
I'm gonna eliminate any
clearly inferior alternatives,

65
00:03:23.690 --> 00:03:27.312
just because maybe there's
just too much risk involved.

66
00:03:27.312 --> 00:03:30.310
And then I'm gonna organized
the description of what I have left.

67
00:03:30.310 --> 00:03:34.260
So this is just another thinking model

68
00:03:34.260 --> 00:03:37.970
to help me determine
what's the best solution.

69
00:03:39.570 --> 00:03:43.890
Another way, another strategy I could
use is I could look at tradeoffs.

70
00:03:43.890 --> 00:03:45.470
So I'm gonna pull these up again.

71
00:03:46.890 --> 00:03:47.390
Oops.

72
00:03:49.090 --> 00:03:53.340
I wanna eliminate any alternatives
that clearly are dominated by others.

73
00:03:53.340 --> 00:03:58.840
Like this solution is so much better
than this other solution for example.

74
00:03:58.840 --> 00:04:00.790
I wanna do swaps,

75
00:04:00.790 --> 00:04:05.780
I wanna look at incremental improvements,
because sometimes those

76
00:04:05.780 --> 00:04:09.760
aren't quite as scary to people if
we just do a little bit at a time.

77
00:04:09.760 --> 00:04:12.050
And I wanna make consistent tradeoffs.

78
00:04:12.050 --> 00:04:14.400
So if I do this, maybe we could do that.

79
00:04:14.400 --> 00:04:17.970
I wanna kind of think of all of those
things before I present my three to five

80
00:04:17.970 --> 00:04:22.110
solutions because, mostly, I want to be
prepared for questions people might ask.

81
00:04:23.230 --> 00:04:27.920
And then, I also wanna be prepared for
the uncertainties.

82
00:04:27.920 --> 00:04:28.945
So I'm gonna pull those up.

83
00:04:28.945 --> 00:04:31.170
Whoops.

84
00:04:31.170 --> 00:04:34.430
What are the key uncertainties
of each alternative?

85
00:04:34.430 --> 00:04:36.900
Now, I'm not saying that
you would introduce this.

86
00:04:36.900 --> 00:04:41.070
When you do your presentation, your first
official task, remember, your first

87
00:04:41.070 --> 00:04:46.300
official task in Improve, is to present
those three to five solutions, right?

88
00:04:46.300 --> 00:04:50.160
I'm not saying that you even need to
talk about the Key Uncertainties.

89
00:04:50.160 --> 00:04:55.000
But you want to know what those are, so
if you get asked, well what if we do this?

90
00:04:55.000 --> 00:04:58.130
What would happen, right?

91
00:04:58.130 --> 00:05:01.030
So kind of think about it
from their standpoint,

92
00:05:01.030 --> 00:05:04.950
when you present these solutions, what
kinds of questions are they gonna ask you.

93
00:05:04.950 --> 00:05:08.010
So you can look at consequences,
you can look at tradeoffs.

94
00:05:08.010 --> 00:05:10.810
And what we're looking at
right now is Uncertainties.

95
00:05:10.810 --> 00:05:13.280
So the questions under uncertainty.

96
00:05:13.280 --> 00:05:15.780
What are the possible outcomes?

97
00:05:15.780 --> 00:05:18.430
What are the changes of the outcomes?

98
00:05:18.430 --> 00:05:21.370
What are the consequences for
each of the outcomes?

99
00:05:21.370 --> 00:05:23.860
So again, just some things to think about.

100
00:05:23.860 --> 00:05:28.560
Now if you're pretty solid when you leave
Analyze, and you say, you know what?

101
00:05:28.560 --> 00:05:31.940
I've got three to five solutions,
I feel really good about these.

102
00:05:31.940 --> 00:05:34.380
I feel like I can defend these.

103
00:05:34.380 --> 00:05:37.680
I think I can answer all the questions,
well then you don't need this help.

104
00:05:37.680 --> 00:05:41.960
This help is there in case you're really
busy, you're working on my goodness,

105
00:05:41.960 --> 00:05:45.420
more than one project, and you're
trying to prepare your presentation.

106
00:05:45.420 --> 00:05:48.990
And these aren't bad to just
when you're presenting an idea,

107
00:05:48.990 --> 00:05:51.480
these aren't bad ideas to have
in the back if your mind.

108
00:05:51.480 --> 00:05:54.730
>> Well sure, you wanna look thorough, and
you don't wanna look this kind of rushed

109
00:05:54.730 --> 00:05:57.610
and put together right before a meeting or
something like that.

110
00:05:57.610 --> 00:06:00.000
>> Exactly, so these are kinda
good questions to go through.

111
00:06:00.000 --> 00:06:03.400
And then finally in this
list is Risk Tolerance.

112
00:06:03.400 --> 00:06:05.620
How much risk do you wanna handle?

113
00:06:05.620 --> 00:06:10.180
And you wanna kinda think from their
standpoint, what do they want to handle?

114
00:06:10.180 --> 00:06:13.310
And how much are others
affected by your decision?

115
00:06:13.310 --> 00:06:16.082
A lot of times what happens
is we make a decision and

116
00:06:16.082 --> 00:06:19.186
we're not even thinking about
the other people right?

117
00:06:19.186 --> 00:06:24.320
I wanna quantify the risk,
I wanna seek to lessen the risk.

118
00:06:24.320 --> 00:06:27.520
And I want to avoid
making risky decisions.

119
00:06:27.520 --> 00:06:31.560
So again, just another little test
I can run things through, and

120
00:06:31.560 --> 00:06:34.450
or think from their side
things that they might ask me.

121
00:06:35.560 --> 00:06:37.960
So, I get to the Improve Phase.

122
00:06:37.960 --> 00:06:40.910
And my very first thing which
I've said a number of times.

123
00:06:40.910 --> 00:06:44.720
My very, very, first thing is I want
to list three to five solutions.

124
00:06:44.720 --> 00:06:46.300
Now you may notice on the slide,

125
00:06:46.300 --> 00:06:48.980
that there's a lot of whitespace
in between these things.

126
00:06:48.980 --> 00:06:53.070
And that's because there's
some unpredictability there.

127
00:06:53.070 --> 00:06:57.750
So if I list my 3 to 5 solutions and
I'm only working with 1 person,

128
00:06:57.750 --> 00:07:01.500
my boss, It might go really fast, right?

129
00:07:01.500 --> 00:07:06.430
However, I could be doing
a full blown presentation,

130
00:07:06.430 --> 00:07:10.160
in which case I want to go back and
look at those things we just talked about.

131
00:07:10.160 --> 00:07:11.890
Like, what is my risk?

132
00:07:11.890 --> 00:07:13.440
What's the uncertainty?

133
00:07:13.440 --> 00:07:14.510
What are the trade offs?

134
00:07:14.510 --> 00:07:15.670
What are the consequences?

135
00:07:15.670 --> 00:07:17.620
If I'm going to do a presentation
in front of people,

136
00:07:17.620 --> 00:07:21.510
I want to be prepared, cuz there's going
to be people asking me these questions.

137
00:07:21.510 --> 00:07:25.100
That could be a much longer process right?

138
00:07:25.100 --> 00:07:28.580
So, if I'm working for one person
they may say, go with solution two-

139
00:07:28.580 --> 00:07:29.580
>> I trust your judgement.

140
00:07:29.580 --> 00:07:30.162
>> I trust your judgement.

141
00:07:30.162 --> 00:07:30.880
>> Exactly.

142
00:07:30.880 --> 00:07:33.050
>> Right, just do what you wanna do.

143
00:07:33.050 --> 00:07:35.090
But it could be a really big deal.

144
00:07:35.090 --> 00:07:38.210
I might have to get consensus, right?

145
00:07:38.210 --> 00:07:42.880
But no matter what, I have to figure out,
I mean from a logical stand point,

146
00:07:42.880 --> 00:07:44.100
what am I going to do?

147
00:07:44.100 --> 00:07:46.190
Which solution am I going to try out?

148
00:07:46.190 --> 00:07:48.886
Now, this is where it starts
getting a little tricky.

149
00:07:48.886 --> 00:07:52.326
Because sometimes the problem is so
urgent,

150
00:07:52.326 --> 00:07:57.340
that no one's going to be buying
into that you want to do a pilot.

151
00:07:57.340 --> 00:07:58.709
They may not want to fund it.

152
00:07:58.709 --> 00:08:00.325
They might not want the time.

153
00:08:00.325 --> 00:08:04.153
But when it says do a pilot,
basically what Lean Six Sigma is

154
00:08:04.153 --> 00:08:08.610
saying is that you need to figure
out a way to try it out, right?

155
00:08:08.610 --> 00:08:12.938
So if you can't try it out in a small
format, maybe a focus group or

156
00:08:12.938 --> 00:08:17.997
a simulation, maybe you can read case
studies of where other people did it.

157
00:08:17.997 --> 00:08:21.026
You can do a kind of a mock,
being like a simulation.

158
00:08:21.026 --> 00:08:23.689
>> [CROSSTALK]
>> Exactly, so the thing is,

159
00:08:23.689 --> 00:08:27.611
this actually makes a lot of sense,
if we skip this step,

160
00:08:27.611 --> 00:08:30.910
we really wanna try it out
before we roll it out.

161
00:08:30.910 --> 00:08:31.520
>> Always.

162
00:08:31.520 --> 00:08:32.160
>> Yeah-
>> [LAUGH]

163
00:08:32.160 --> 00:08:34.740
>> And so let's say we try it out and

164
00:08:34.740 --> 00:08:35.950
it doesn't work?

165
00:08:35.950 --> 00:08:39.360
The beauty of the DMAIC model is
that's when I go back up to one of my

166
00:08:39.360 --> 00:08:41.570
other three to five solutions and
I try that.

167
00:08:41.570 --> 00:08:43.880
I'm not going all the back to Define.

168
00:08:43.880 --> 00:08:46.010
I don't think anyone, including ourselves,

169
00:08:46.010 --> 00:08:49.990
wants to be in a situation where it's
back to the drawing board, right?

170
00:08:49.990 --> 00:08:54.230
>> Right, well, that's the whole idea of
having a plan A, a plan B, and a plan C.

171
00:08:54.230 --> 00:08:56.962
>> Exactly, exactly, and so,

172
00:08:56.962 --> 00:09:02.880
then let's say it did work because
we're gonna be optimistic.

173
00:09:02.880 --> 00:09:03.501
>> Sure.
>> When we say it.

174
00:09:03.501 --> 00:09:04.750
>> [LAUGH]
>> It did work.

175
00:09:04.750 --> 00:09:07.960
Now what we're gonna do is we're
gonna create our project plan,

176
00:09:07.960 --> 00:09:12.880
and we're gonna stay in our project
plan until an improvement is made.

177
00:09:12.880 --> 00:09:17.840
Now the way we know an improvement is
made, is we take our picture again.

178
00:09:17.840 --> 00:09:19.170
We look at where we're at and

179
00:09:19.170 --> 00:09:22.900
we compare it against the before
picture that we created in measure.

180
00:09:22.900 --> 00:09:28.455
So measure has our before picture, then we
analyzed it, then we came up with a plan.

181
00:09:28.455 --> 00:09:31.640
Then we rolled out the plan, and now
we're gonna go look at that same picture.

182
00:09:31.640 --> 00:09:35.750
So if I use return on
investment in measure,

indirect costs that you might.

636
00:34:16.530 --> 00:34:18.775
>> Would you recommend leaving
a bit of a buffer there?

637
00:34:18.775 --> 00:34:19.785
So that's
>> Absolutely.

638
00:34:19.785 --> 00:34:21.075
>> All right.

00:34:21.075 --> 00:34:23.985
Yeah, and I'm just thinking maybe

00:34:25.795 --> 00:34:27.165
So you had to go to another company.

00:34:27.165 --> 00:34:28.205
That cost was higher.

Just random things like that.

644
00:34:29.595 --> 00:34:30.465
>> Right.

645
00:34:30.465 --> 00:34:33.635
And then a lot of times we just

There's just ongoing costs that we might
not have packaged into our project.

647

In some cases the employer isn't

But it's something that

649
00:34:44.020 --> 00:34:45.320
>> All right.

650
00:34:45.320 --> 00:34:45.920

651
00:34:47.590 --> 00:34:53.451
So just to kind of give you an idea,

652
00:34:53.451 --> 00:34:57.666
software, contractor fees,
training fanfare.

653
00:34:57.666 --> 00:34:58.531
Other.

00:34:58.531 --> 00:35:03.857
[LAUGH] And this is just showing

Where it says year 1, year 2,

00:35:15.274 --> 00:35:16.660
Now Indirect costs.

People's time and effort,

659

other time opportunity costs you know, so

660
00:35:23.910 --> 00:35:24.770
>> Okay.
>> So

Because I'll tell you from personal

00:35:33.743 --> 00:35:37.840
>> [LAUGH]
>> So, when you're managing the project,

there are some things that

00:35:40.120 --> 00:35:45.630
Now, if you're in the Lean Six Sigma

these are really super important.

When you're managing the project, these

Five stages, project manager role,

So if you are taking

Now, the triple constraints, and

And so now, even though it's

00:37:07.970 --> 00:37:12.100
But you're gonna see scope and

And especially if you're doing

694
00:37:16.670 --> 00:37:18.300
Scope and quality play a role.

00:37:18.300 --> 00:37:20.925
Even though we say triple,

696
00:37:20.925 --> 00:37:23.010
>> [LAUGH]
>> In Lean Six Sigma we make it easy.

We say the triple constraints, the things

the bottom part of improve,

And risk is another one [LAUGH] of

It was called the triple constraints, and

But I think if you think time, money,

Now as a project manager,

So even though you're not

But there is also something

So, if were trying to come up with

I might have used this in Define.

The way I'm thinking of it right

all the things that absolutely have

Thinking tool to make sure I've got my

But in order to do that,

in the FMEA Thinking,

Now if I'm in define and

I make sure I built that

>> So, maybe it would be a good idea

00:40:48.430 --> 00:40:50.510
Things like that,

Now, if I were using the same thing in

I mean I think everyone is gonna say yes

I might see well how well

This is something,

We were able to look at things like

I did all this work I spend all this time

00:24:04.814 --> 00:24:08.162

00:24:08.162 --> 00:24:11.150

00:24:11.150 --> 00:24:15.140

00:24:22.250 --> 00:24:24.100
But they almost always have,

00:24:24.100 --> 00:24:28.000
