that part that we did with FMEA thinking.

441
00:24:28.000 --> 00:24:32.420
What's the function, what would happen if
it went wrong, what are the ramifications?

442
00:24:32.420 --> 00:24:35.980
What controls do we have in place
to keep that from happening?

443
00:24:35.980 --> 00:24:40.090
The difference with an FMEA form, and
the reason why it's a good form to

444
00:24:40.090 --> 00:24:45.190
use in control, that you can either
make up, you can use our template,

445
00:24:45.190 --> 00:24:50.040
you can use an industry standard template,
is that it keeps everything on track.

446
00:24:50.040 --> 00:24:54.630
Because one of the things that
the FMEA form does that FMEA thinking

447
00:24:54.630 --> 00:24:59.130
doesn't do is it has sign-offs, like,
who's in charge of this process control.

448
00:24:59.130 --> 00:25:00.750
And it doesn't just have sign-offs.

449
00:25:00.750 --> 00:25:03.814
It says, okay, I'm gonna take
responsibility for this area,

450
00:25:03.814 --> 00:25:06.870
and then after I complete it,
I have to sign off again.

451
00:25:06.870 --> 00:25:10.130
I'm sure a lot of you have been in
a situation where someone said they were

452
00:25:10.130 --> 00:25:11.848
gonna do something and they didn't.

453
00:25:11.848 --> 00:25:12.880
>> [LAUGH] Never.

454
00:25:12.880 --> 00:25:15.870
>> So
it's that extra later of accountability.

455
00:25:15.870 --> 00:25:19.270
Another thing that's really
popular with FMEA forms

456
00:25:19.270 --> 00:25:23.730
is they give us some information
about our risk priority number.

457
00:25:23.730 --> 00:25:26.480
And our risk priority number
is just what it says.

458
00:25:26.480 --> 00:25:29.200
How bad is it if this doesn't happen,
right?

459
00:25:29.200 --> 00:25:33.320
Now, generally speaking, we look at
severity, we look at occurrence,

460
00:25:33.320 --> 00:25:36.390
which just means how often
is it happening now.

461
00:25:36.390 --> 00:25:42.150
And we look at detection, how likely
are we to know that that's gonna happen.

462
00:25:42.150 --> 00:25:46.329
So if I look at a risk, I could be looking
at a risk on a scale from one to five.

463
00:25:46.329 --> 00:25:47.448
>> Sure.

464
00:25:47.448 --> 00:25:49.046
>> Or one to ten, right?

465
00:25:49.046 --> 00:25:52.950
And I could say number
one is the worst thing.

466
00:25:52.950 --> 00:25:58.681
The EPAs old schedule used to say that you
had to die before you got a number one.

467
00:25:58.681 --> 00:25:59.240
>> [LAUGH].

468
00:25:59.240 --> 00:26:03.452
>> Now the EPA says that any risk
to a worker, any physical risk,

469
00:26:03.452 --> 00:26:05.720
is the number one, right?

470
00:26:05.720 --> 00:26:08.550
So even those schedules kind of change.

471
00:26:08.550 --> 00:26:11.310
Occurrence, that would be a metric.

472
00:26:11.310 --> 00:26:14.950
I would actually go and
count how often is it happening now.

473
00:26:14.950 --> 00:26:17.670
And then detection,
on a scale back to one to five,

474
00:26:17.670 --> 00:26:21.470
how likely are we to know
that that risk might occur?

475
00:26:21.470 --> 00:26:23.425
>> Sure.
>> And so I multiply those together,

476
00:26:23.425 --> 00:26:27.041
and it doesn't really, it technically
wouldn't really matter if we added them.

477
00:26:27.041 --> 00:26:32.310
But the formula is, we multiply
those together and we get a number.

478
00:26:32.310 --> 00:26:37.110
Now, in sigma,
we're trying to make that number higher.

479
00:26:37.110 --> 00:26:43.420
If I'm in measure, and I get a sigma of 3,
I wanna start making it 3.1 or 3.2.

480
00:26:43.420 --> 00:26:45.560
If I get a risk priority number,

481
00:26:45.560 --> 00:26:49.810
on the other hand, in measure,
I'm trying to lower that number, right?

482
00:26:49.810 --> 00:26:52.330
So, this FMEA does a bunch of things.

483
00:26:52.330 --> 00:26:55.441
The other thing is that, in FMEA thinking,

484
00:26:55.441 --> 00:26:58.816
we're just looking at
one condition at a time.

485
00:26:58.816 --> 00:27:02.757
On an FMEA form, I'm looking at all
the functions of that process, and

486
00:27:02.757 --> 00:27:05.170
I'm capturing it all in one place.

487
00:27:05.170 --> 00:27:07.893
So the form is really
just a clever form to-

488
00:27:07.893 --> 00:27:09.581
>> Yeah, we actually use that in

489
00:27:09.581 --> 00:27:10.260
IT as well.

490
00:27:10.260 --> 00:27:13.060
We have our SLE times our ARO.

491
00:27:13.060 --> 00:27:17.850
So your SLE is your single loss expectancy
times your annual rate occurrence,

492
00:27:17.850 --> 00:27:21.060
which will give you your ALE,
which is your annual loss expectancy.

493
00:27:21.060 --> 00:27:22.708
>> There you go.
>> So pretty easy in that sense.

494
00:27:22.708 --> 00:27:24.868
>> Yeah, and so you would want,
in that case too,

495
00:27:24.868 --> 00:27:28.000
you would wanna lower the number,
right, after you got the number?

496
00:27:28.000 --> 00:27:30.760
Or would you be trying to
make the number better or?

497
00:27:30.760 --> 00:27:33.025
>> Well there are different models, and

498
00:27:33.025 --> 00:27:37.213
we would normally look at different
types of risk analysis matrices.

499
00:27:37.213 --> 00:27:41.960
You do wanna obviously lower the number
of your annual rate of occurrence.

500
00:27:41.960 --> 00:27:43.452
>> Perfect.
>> As well as your annual, or

501
00:27:43.452 --> 00:27:47.350
your single loss, any kind of security
control that you can implement.

502
00:27:47.350 --> 00:27:51.380
But you also have to make sure
that the controls are actually,

503
00:27:51.380 --> 00:27:54.320
its worth the money and the effort
that you're putting in to go ahead and

504
00:27:54.320 --> 00:27:56.160
prevent that incident from occurring.

505
00:27:56.160 --> 00:28:00.940
>> And see, that's another perfect
example of a tool I could use in measure.

506
00:28:00.940 --> 00:28:01.875
I could look at it and

507
00:28:01.875 --> 00:28:05.350
improve, and when I get to control,
I could give you the results, right?

508
00:28:05.350 --> 00:28:06.870
>> Yeah, yeah.

509
00:28:06.870 --> 00:28:09.929
>> Okay, so I think,
even though there are some reading and

510
00:28:09.929 --> 00:28:13.905
things that you're gonna wanna do if
you're taking that Six Sigma test.

511
00:28:13.905 --> 00:28:16.544
I think I pretty much covered control.

512
00:28:16.544 --> 00:28:18.016
There's those three parts.

513
00:28:18.016 --> 00:28:20.348
if you're a Lean Six Sigma person or

514
00:28:20.348 --> 00:28:23.480
you're trying to take
the Lean Six Sigma exam.

515
00:28:23.480 --> 00:28:26.440
Part one,
you wanna tell them what you did for them.

516
00:28:26.440 --> 00:28:29.030
Part two,
you wanna write a sustainability plan.

517
00:28:29.030 --> 00:28:32.850
And part three, you wanna make sure
everyone knows the project's over.

518
00:28:32.850 --> 00:28:35.600
>> Yeah, and looking at everything
that you've given us in this

519
00:28:35.600 --> 00:28:39.980
episode to go ahead and support those
three really important phases of, well,

520
00:28:39.980 --> 00:28:42.850
our DMAIC phase, the control phase.

521
00:28:42.850 --> 00:28:44.650
It has, it has been a lot of information.

522
00:28:44.650 --> 00:28:48.810
So, I think what we're gonna go ahead and
do is have a wrap up of it and

523
00:28:48.810 --> 00:28:52.860
just a brief overview of everything that
we've covered in the last series here.

524
00:28:52.860 --> 00:28:56.280
So, we're gonna go ahead and
sign off for this particular episode.

525
00:28:56.280 --> 00:28:57.262
But, stay tuned.

526
00:28:57.262 --> 00:28:59.540
We're gonna have a brief overview and

527
00:28:59.540 --> 00:29:04.970
some more great Lean Six Sigma Green Belt
Certification information headed your way.

528
00:29:04.970 --> 00:29:08.794
I'm gonna go ahead and sign off as
your show host, Cherokee Boose.

529
00:29:08.794 --> 00:29:13.180
>> And this is Dr. Terra Vanzant-Stern
with SSD Global Solutions.

530
00:29:13.180 --> 00:29:16.597
>> See you next time, here at ITPRO.TV.

531
00:29:16.597 --> 00:29:22.595
[MUSIC]

532
00:29:22.595 --> 00:29:25.315
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: This episode reviews all the phases and how they work together and depend on each other. You also see a review of tolls available at each phase.
episodes.title: DMAIC Model - Review
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:01.350
Welcome to ITPro.TV.

2
00:00:01.350 --> 00:00:07.115
I'm your host [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:07.115 --> 00:00:08.440
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.440 --> 00:00:10.587
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

5
00:00:10.587 --> 00:00:15.007
>> Welcome to your
Lean Six Sigma Green Belt Certification,

6
00:00:15.007 --> 00:00:17.540
preparation episode overview.

7
00:00:17.540 --> 00:00:21.230
We've gone through the entire series,
and now we're gonna go ahead and

8
00:00:21.230 --> 00:00:24.636
just remind you what it is you've
learned throughout the series.

9
00:00:24.636 --> 00:00:26.890
Now, in studios today, we have Dr.

10
00:00:26.890 --> 00:00:31.570
Terra Vanzant Stern, as you already know,
to go ahead and wrap it up for us.

11
00:00:31.570 --> 00:00:33.590
So where we gonna look at first here?

12
00:00:33.590 --> 00:00:35.450
What topics will we look at first?

13
00:00:35.450 --> 00:00:39.560
>> Well, I think what I'd like to start
with Cherokee is the DMAIC overview,

14
00:00:39.560 --> 00:00:43.260
because that's what we left off
with We looked at, in the episodes,

15
00:00:43.260 --> 00:00:45.290
we looked at each phase of the DMAIC.

16
00:00:45.290 --> 00:00:47.780
So I wanna just kind of summarize that.

17
00:00:47.780 --> 00:00:51.680
Okay, so if we could go to my slide deck,

18
00:00:51.680 --> 00:00:57.330
the DMAIC Model has five phases,
and the first phase is Define.

19
00:00:57.330 --> 00:01:01.010
And in Define, the most important
thing is that we leave with

20
00:01:01.010 --> 00:01:04.100
everyone understand what
it is we're working on.

21
00:01:04.100 --> 00:01:06.620
And then, we move to Measure and

22
00:01:06.620 --> 00:01:11.890
to Analyze, in measure and analyze there's
a whole lot of tools that are the same.

23
00:01:11.890 --> 00:01:15.470
In measure we're trying to get a current
as is picture of where we are today.

24
00:01:15.470 --> 00:01:18.330
Analyze, we're trying to
analyze that picture, but

25
00:01:18.330 --> 00:01:23.210
there's a whole lot of tools that can
be used jointly in both of those.

26
00:01:23.210 --> 00:01:25.780
>> Sure.
>> And then,

27
00:01:25.780 --> 00:01:29.760
sorry, we move on to Improve and Control.

28
00:01:29.760 --> 00:01:33.580
And Improve is where we actually
do the project and analyze,

29
00:01:33.580 --> 00:01:38.650
we leave analyze with three to five
solutions and improve, we actually

30
00:01:38.650 --> 00:01:43.290
roll out the projects, we stay there until
we can make sure that improvements been

31
00:01:43.290 --> 00:01:47.840
made in a way we know that is that we
compare it to our measure pitcher.

32
00:01:47.840 --> 00:01:50.877
And then if everything's okay,
we move on to Control, and

33
00:01:50.877 --> 00:01:53.511
we tell people how to keep
that process into place.

34
00:01:53.511 --> 00:01:57.748
So I'm gonna kind of just
quickly go through the model,

35
00:01:57.748 --> 00:02:04.090
the key points of each phase, and remember
the DMAIC model and Lean Six Sigma.

36
00:02:04.090 --> 00:02:05.730
Is a circular model.

37
00:02:05.730 --> 00:02:07.980
If you're taking the Six Sigma exam,

38
00:02:07.980 --> 00:02:13.390
well, through any vendor, they're looking
at the DMAIC more as a waterfall.

39
00:02:13.390 --> 00:02:15.680
Circular means that I'm gonna
move through the model,

40
00:02:15.680 --> 00:02:17.700
I'm probably gonna manage
the whole process.

41
00:02:17.700 --> 00:02:20.250
If I have to move back through the model,
it's okay.

42
00:02:21.290 --> 00:02:26.310
We said that there's a lot of different
things depicting the model, and

43
00:02:26.310 --> 00:02:28.420
this is one of the more complicated ones.

44
00:02:30.370 --> 00:02:33.780
We actually have some,
I think we have that simple one.

45
00:02:33.780 --> 00:02:38.700
See if I can get it to come up, my
slideshow is acting a little crazy guys.

46
00:02:38.700 --> 00:02:39.980
Okay, so here's a simple model,

47
00:02:39.980 --> 00:02:44.160
you don't necessarily have to have a
complicated one, but of the things we said

48
00:02:44.160 --> 00:02:48.010
is having the basics of the model in
front of us, is really quite helpfu,

49
00:02:48.010 --> 00:02:52.460
because there's different dynamics
in each one of those phases.

50
00:02:52.460 --> 00:02:55.570
So, if I have more than one project going,
it's kind of helpful to know,

51
00:02:55.570 --> 00:02:59.420
in this project I'm in Measure,
in this other project, I'm in Improve.

52
00:02:59.420 --> 00:03:02.513
Because just the way people
are reacting to me and

53
00:03:02.513 --> 00:03:05.162
my project could be slightly different.

54
00:03:05.162 --> 00:03:08.904
Okay, so the first one we're gonna
look at is the Define Phase and

55
00:03:08.904 --> 00:03:13.180
we said that in Define we're identifying,
we're prioritizing.

56
00:03:13.180 --> 00:03:17.660
We're selecting our teams,
we're looking at building effective teams.

57
00:03:17.660 --> 00:03:19.720
We're identifying
the customer segments and

58
00:03:19.720 --> 00:03:21.850
determining the process to be improved.

59
00:03:21.850 --> 00:03:26.470
Again, there's only two rules in Define,
we have to start with a high level

60
00:03:26.470 --> 00:03:29.470
process map,
we have to end with a project charter.

61
00:03:29.470 --> 00:03:33.557
And remember, the basic idea of Define is
we wanna make sure everyone understands

62
00:03:33.557 --> 00:03:34.810
what we're working on.

63
00:03:34.810 --> 00:03:39.148
And the reason for that is, the number
one people don't buy into our ideas and

64
00:03:39.148 --> 00:03:42.016
our and the things that we wanna do,
our projects,

65
00:03:42.016 --> 00:03:44.100
is because they don't understand.

66
00:03:44.100 --> 00:03:47.380
So Define gives you a lot of tools
that help people understand what

67
00:03:47.380 --> 00:03:48.840
you're working on.

68
00:03:48.840 --> 00:03:53.180
So then when we move to Measure,
we're looking at forming a picture, and

69
00:03:53.180 --> 00:03:55.355
if I can take a picture, hey, do that.

70
00:03:55.355 --> 00:03:59.460
Because if you've got
a really messy supply room,

71
00:03:59.460 --> 00:04:04.000
or a manufacturing floor, you literally
could just take a picture of that, right?

72
00:04:04.000 --> 00:04:07.090
And that's,
you have a clear as-is picture.

73
00:04:07.090 --> 00:04:10.390
But what happens is a lot of times
we're looking at a service or

74
00:04:10.390 --> 00:04:13.280
a transaction that we
can't take a picture of.

75
00:04:13.280 --> 00:04:16.330
And so we have to come up
with more creative ideas.

76
00:04:16.330 --> 00:04:18.120
But when I leave Measure,

77
00:04:18.120 --> 00:04:23.270
I want you to believe my picture
because that forms the before picture.

78
00:04:23.270 --> 00:04:27.738
So I wanna make sure that
you believe that picture.

79
00:04:27.738 --> 00:04:32.160
Some of the bullet points that you're seen
on the screen are gonna help you do that.

80
00:04:32.160 --> 00:04:34.240
Determine the parameters to be measured,

81
00:04:34.240 --> 00:04:37.160
I still maintain what I'm
suppose to be measuring.

82
00:04:37.160 --> 00:04:41.584
Is a little bit more important than
how to measure it cuz you can always

83
00:04:41.584 --> 00:04:43.805
look up how to measure something.

84
00:04:43.805 --> 00:04:47.838
I wanna be thinking about variation
because there's a thought in just

85
00:04:47.838 --> 00:04:52.006
a Six Sigma side that if I reduce
variation I may have an automatic process

86
00:04:52.006 --> 00:04:53.230
improvement.

87
00:04:53.230 --> 00:04:57.942
So I might wanna do a variation study.

88
00:04:57.942 --> 00:05:02.480
I want to think about my final solutions,
what is it that I'm trying to record for

89
00:05:02.480 --> 00:05:03.565
my improve phase.

90
00:05:07.073 --> 00:05:08.620
We skipped a phase you guys.

91
00:05:08.620 --> 00:05:13.460
Okay, so in analyze I've got a clear as
this picture of where we are today, so

92
00:05:13.460 --> 00:05:17.120
in Analyze what I wanna do is
I'm trying to figure out why.

93
00:05:17.120 --> 00:05:19.270
And even though you're looking
at those bullet points,

94
00:05:19.270 --> 00:05:24.160
remember those four conditions that
the things I'm looking through the lenses

95
00:05:24.160 --> 00:05:26.860
are looking through a root conslines.

96
00:05:26.860 --> 00:05:31.180
I'm looking through a trigger's lens, like
if this happens, does that other thing

97
00:05:31.180 --> 00:05:36.930
happen, and a lot of times that's I'm
looking at, like, correlation analysis.

98
00:05:36.930 --> 00:05:40.000
I'm looking at impact,
how much does it matter really?

99
00:05:40.000 --> 00:05:43.770
And this is where I might
do a variation analysis.

100
00:05:43.770 --> 00:05:46.450
In measure, I did a variation study, but

101
00:05:46.450 --> 00:05:49.290
in analyze I might do
a variation analysis.

102
00:05:49.290 --> 00:05:53.340
I don't leave Analyze until I
have three to five solutions, and

103
00:05:53.340 --> 00:05:56.800
that's the very first step
when I get to improve.

104
00:05:56.800 --> 00:06:01.760
My very first step when I get to Improve,
is that I'm gonna list those three to

105
00:06:01.760 --> 00:06:05.580
five solutions, and then,
I'm gonna look at which one I'm gonna do.

106
00:06:05.580 --> 00:06:09.680
If I can, I'm gonna pilot it, then,
I'm gonna roll out my project plan and

107
00:06:09.680 --> 00:06:13.230
the moment,
I can show an improvement's been made.

108
00:06:13.230 --> 00:06:16.210
And the way I do that is,
I go back to my measure picture and

109
00:06:16.210 --> 00:06:19.190
I say, that's before this is after.

110
00:06:19.190 --> 00:06:22.342
As soon as I can show
an improvement's been made,

111
00:06:22.342 --> 00:06:24.755
then I can move on to my control phase.

112
00:06:29.075 --> 00:06:31.082
In Control Phase, they have three,

113
00:06:31.082 --> 00:06:33.980
my little phases are kind
of out of order there.

114
00:06:33.980 --> 00:06:37.312
In the Control Phase,
I have three responsibilities.

115
00:06:37.312 --> 00:06:40.822
I wanna tell you what your
benefit was in dollars and cents.

116
00:06:40.822 --> 00:06:43.410
I wanna say what I did, why I did it, and

117
00:06:43.410 --> 00:06:46.710
this is what you made,
saved, or avoided spending.

118
00:06:46.710 --> 00:06:53.875
If I use money metrics and measure and
improve, that's gonna be easy, right?

119
00:06:53.875 --> 00:06:55.790
I'm just gonna translate it over.

120
00:06:55.790 --> 00:07:00.030
But, it might be a little more complicated
if I used a different way to show you that

121
00:07:00.030 --> 00:07:00.850
current picture.

122
00:07:00.850 --> 00:07:04.530
So, if I showed you a picture of
the warehouse being messed up, and

123
00:07:04.530 --> 00:07:07.980
then I showed you a picture of
the warehouse just being beautiful.

124
00:07:07.980 --> 00:07:09.610
I might have to break it down for you.

125
00:07:09.610 --> 00:07:13.560
Why you care, what did that save
make you or avoid you spending?

126
00:07:13.560 --> 00:07:16.420
So, if I used anything other than money,

127
00:07:16.420 --> 00:07:19.270
then I might have to break
that down a little bit more.

128
00:07:19.270 --> 00:07:22.370
The main thing in Control
is what I'm trying to do

129
00:07:22.370 --> 00:07:25.370
is I'm trying to build
a sustainability plan.

130
00:07:26.770 --> 00:07:29.680
And so that that process
improvement stays in place and

131
00:07:29.680 --> 00:07:35.310
then I wrap up all those DMAIC
phases by closing out the project.

132
00:07:38.420 --> 00:07:43.040
So, the thing is that,
what I'd like you to kind of keep in

133
00:07:43.040 --> 00:07:46.960
mind is all the tools and different
things that we studied, Cherokee,

134
00:07:46.960 --> 00:07:52.180
in all those other sessions, somehow
play in somewhere to that DMAIC model.

135
00:07:52.180 --> 00:07:54.830
And, what are some of the things
that we talked about in all of

136
00:07:54.830 --> 00:07:58.500
those earlier sessions, before we
did all those sessions on the DMAIC?

137
00:07:58.500 --> 00:08:03.710
>> So now if we look at the complete
process, the DMAIC model,

138
00:08:03.710 --> 00:08:07.780
we do understand that that's not
the only model available to us.

139
00:08:07.780 --> 00:08:10.766
There are other methodologies available,
but

140
00:08:10.766 --> 00:08:15.256
now understanding all those tools
that we've covered in this series.

141
00:08:15.256 --> 00:08:19.706
How we can significantly apply those tools
directly to the models that we've learned

142
00:08:19.706 --> 00:08:20.850
about as well.

143
00:08:20.850 --> 00:08:24.000
And we look at things like
our seven quality tools.

144
00:08:24.000 --> 00:08:26.200
We can look at things like metrics.

145
00:08:26.200 --> 00:08:30.030
We can look at ideas of
understanding waste and

146
00:08:30.030 --> 00:08:33.700
looking at our different voices
are different perspectives.

147
00:08:33.700 --> 00:08:37.980
Are different CTQs, we can look at
things like implementing graphs and

148
00:08:37.980 --> 00:08:41.935
charts to provide those visual
aids to convey our messages.

149
00:08:41.935 --> 00:08:44.810
We've also understood
the core concepts and terms.

150
00:08:44.810 --> 00:08:47.785
You should really have a good
understanding of that at this point.

151
00:08:47.785 --> 00:08:50.980
You should also be really
familiar with the basic.

152
00:08:50.980 --> 00:08:56.460
The basics of process improvement, and
now we can see the full picture and

153
00:08:56.460 --> 00:08:59.530
how it all relates and
can be plugged into these models.

154
00:08:59.530 --> 00:09:01.604
So, I appreciate that, Dr Stern.

155
00:09:01.604 --> 00:09:03.120
>> Thank you.
>> And now that we understand all these

156
00:09:03.120 --> 00:09:04.820
concepts, what do we do next?

157
00:09:05.980 --> 00:09:07.804
>> Okay, well thank you for
asking, Cherokee.

158
00:09:07.804 --> 00:09:11.949
The next steps that we would be taking,
well, first let me say that

SSD Global Solutions teaches
a product called Linear Six Sigma but

00:09:16.099 --> 00:09:21.110
your certifications still say
Lin Six Sigma Green Belter Black Belt.

So we specialized in
a Lin Six Sigma Black Belt Workshop.

00:09:26.210 --> 00:09:29.460
There is a bit of a financial committment.

One of the prerequisites for

are a Lean Six Sigma Green Belt.

00:09:35.244 --> 00:09:38.130
Now, you can take your
Lean Six Sigma Green Belt.

166
00:09:38.130 --> 00:09:41.750
Remember, you can take that

167
00:09:41.750 --> 00:09:46.390
If you take it through our company,

168
00:09:46.390 --> 00:09:47.630
One of the pre-requisites,

have facilitated through ITProTV?

But we, in order for you to sit for

We have those templates available for

>> Cool.
>> But

174
